description: How archaeologists invent their own version of the past, illustrated with compelling Old and New World discoveries from early prehistory to the present. How archaeological sites are discovered, excavated and analyzed; how facts are tested and fictions unmasked.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Completion of GE Area A2 with a grade of C- or better.
satisfies: Satisfies A3: Critical Thinking and Writing.

name: Human Lifecourse in Context
description: Human development and its physiological, psychological and sociocultural contexts. Cross-cultural perspectives on infancy, childhood, adolescence, adulthood and old age. The role of university education in the life span.
satisfies: Satisfies E: Human Understanding & Development.

name: International Program Studies
description: Study Abroad and Away transfer credit course. Study Abroad and Away provides students the opportunity to study abroad on long term programs (Exchange Programs, CSU International Programs, and International Student Exchange Programs) and short-term programs (Faculty-Led Programs and Summer School Abroad Programs) for academic credit, offering Alternative Break Programs for cultural immersion, and designing other globally focused opportunities. This course is designated as a placeholder course for Study Abroad and Away programs.

name: Writing Workshop
description: Practice in improvement of writing skills appropriate to the fields of anthropology and behavioral science. Includes essays, reports and scholarly communication.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): A3 or equivalent second semester composition course (with a grade of C- or better); completion of core GE; and upper division standing. Or Graduate or Postbaccalaureate level.
satisfies: Satisfies Writing in the Disciplines (WID).
notes: Note(s): Must be passed with C or better to satisfy the CSU Graduation Writing Assessment Requirement (GWAR).

name: Silicon Valley Connections
description: Examines issues of cultural diversity, work and family. technology in daily life, attachment to organizations, and community building in Silicon Valley through an anthropological perspective.Connections to other global regions are explored; public policy implications are developed and analyzed.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Upper Division Standing
sustainability: Sustainability Focused - SDG 11: Sustainable Cities and Communities

name: Applied Anthropology
description: Use of anthropological knowledge in problem solving and policy making. Survey of applied anthropology, models of applying anthropology and affecting policy making, and the use of anthropology by non-professionals in diverse careers.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): ANTH 11 or instructor consent.

name: Eating Culture: The Anthropology of Food
description: This course will explore the many ways in which humans seek, collect, grow, transform and consume foods. We will examine elements of human evolutionary history that mold our current consumption choices. Changes in subsistence strategies, human migration, and colonial expansions remade our landscapes, kitchens, cuisines and our bodies. We will identify and analyze the material processes of food production, preparation and consumption; the cognitive models that define our food choices and the ways in which power and inequality drive global feast and famine. The course will draw on archaeological, biological and cultural anthropologies, as well as examining the potential applications by anthropologists of food.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): ANTH 11, Upper Division Standing.

name: Medical Anthropology
description: A comprehensive examination of culture, sickness and healing in a cross-cultural perspective, emphasizing ecological/evolutionary bases of disease and healing and cultural dimensions of health in modern world.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): ANTH 11 or instructor consent.

name: Legacy of Asia
description: Interdisciplinary focus on continuity and change in China and India as these ancient civilizations responded to challenges throughout their history.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Completion of Core General Education, and upper-division standing are prerequisites to all SJSU studies courses. Completion of, or co-registration in, 100W is strongly recommended.
satisfies: Satisfies SJSU Studies V: Cultures and Global Understanding.
crosslist: Cross-listed with ASIA 114 / HUM 114 / RELS 114. Humanities is responsible for scheduling.

name: The Emerging Global Culture
description: Introduction to systems concepts and approach as a way to investigate the global impacts of industrial technology on political, economic, social and moral/psychological structures of humankind.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Completion of Core General Education and upper division standing are prerequisites to all SJSU studies courses. Completion of, or co-registration in, 100W is strongly recommended.
satisfies: Satisfies SJSU Studies V: Cultures and Global Understanding.
crosslist: Cross-listed with ASIA 115. Anthropology is responsible for scheduling.
sustainability: Sustainability Focused - SDG 16: Peace, Justice and Strong Institutions

name: Magic, Science and Religion
description: Exploring the ways in which people have attempted to gain mastery over the natural and supernatural worlds beginning with prehistoric times and concluding with modern day society and the contemporary world.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Completion of Core General Education, and upper-division standing are prerequisites to all SJSU studies courses. Completion of, or co-registration in, 100W is strongly recommended.
satisfies: Satisfies SJSU Studies V: Cultures and Global Understanding.
crosslist: Cross-listed with RELS 122. Humanities is responsible for scheduling.
sustainability: Sustainability Related - SDG 16: Peace, Justice and Strong Institutions

name: Urban Anthropology
description: Anthropological theories and methods in analyzing the global effects of urban growth. Relevance of anthropological approach in understanding our local multiethnic metropolitan area.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): ANTH 11 or instructor consent.
crosslist: Cross-listed with URBP 125. Anthropology is responsible for scheduling.
sustainability: Sustainability Focused - SDG 11: Sustainable Cities and Communities

name: Environmental Anthropology
description: Anthropological examination of humans’ relationship to their biological environment. Course topics include population growth, resource consumption, human induced climate change, biodiversity, solid and hazardous waste, economic and cultural patterns affecting the environment, environmental risk, water resources, hazards, disasters, sustainable initiatives.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): ANTH 11
sustainability: Sustainability Focused - SDG 13: Climate Action SDG 15: Life on Land

name: Kin, Kith, and Community: The Anthropology of Social Organization
description: Overview of social organization focused on local forms of human relationships: kinship, non-kin relations such as friendship and networking, and community. Explores the principles of kinship and community-building. Examples will be drawn from small-scale, complex and international societies.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing.

name: Theories of Culture
description: Seminar on evolutionary, functional and structural theories of culture. Analysis of contemporary theory and development of the discipline of anthropology.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing; ANTH 11; ANTH 12 or ANTH 13 or declared Anthropology major or instructor consent.

name: Creating Built Worlds
description: Cross-cultural exploration of material expressions of culture. Analysis of production and consumption of places, shelters, and goods. Implications for design and policy.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing.
sustainability: Sustainability Focused - SDG 11: Sustainable Cities and Communities

name: Organizational Cultures
description: Complex organizations as dynamic sociocultural systems. Topics include organizational culture, cross-cultural study of organizations, organizational ethnography, cultural diversity, organizational learning and relevance of a cultural approach to enhance organizational effectiveness in a rapidly-changing world.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): ANTH 11 or instructor consent.

name: Systemic Leadership
description: Examination of systemic leadership thought and practice, especially its application to helping resolve complex problematic issues more effectively and responsibly. Focus is on leading collaborative change efforts with diverse sets of stakeholders in group, organizational, community, cultural, and global settings.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing.

name: Thought Control in Contemporary Society
description: Anthropological analysis of sociocultural controls influencing and regulating human thought and behavior in the contemporary period. Topics include propaganda, censorship, undue influence, coercive persuasion and “brainwashing,” groupthink, messianic cults, totalitarianism, technologies of control, ritualized rebellion, resistance movements, and democratic alternatives.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing.

name: Human Sexuality
description: Biological and sociocultural facets of human sexuality. Evolution and physiology of sex, reproductive biology/ethics and cross-cultural expression of sexual behavior.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Completion of Core General Education and upper division standing are prerequisites to all SJSU studies courses. Completion of, or co-registration in, 100W is strongly recommended.
satisfies: Satisfies SJSU Studies S: Self, Society & Equality in U.S.
crosslist: Cross-listed with BIOL 140 / PH 140. Anthropology is responsible for scheduling.
notes: Note(s): Not acceptable as an elective in the Biology major.

name: Culture in Mind
description: Exploration of self, identity and behavior in cultural context. Cognition, socialization, cross-cultural mental health issues and comparison of intercultural communication modes.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): ANTH 11, ANTH 25 or instructor consent.

name: Culture and Adaptation
description: Explores the relationship between adaptive human behavior and the environment. Theories of interaction between biology, environment and culture are illustrated by examples of mobile foraging peoples, village sedentary farmers, complex chiefdoms and state-level societies.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing.
sustainability: Sustainability Focused - SDG 12: Responsible Consumption and Production

name: Gifts, Markets, and Power
description: Cross-cultural analysis of economic systems. Topics include reciprocity, redistribution, and market exchange; the history of money and virtual currencies; the cultural construction of debt and credit; corporate capitalism and cyclical crises; global economic integration; and contemporary “alternative” economic systems.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): ANTH 11 or Instructor Consent

name: Middle Eastern Traditions
description: Introduction to the peoples and cultures of the Middle East through exploration of the cooperation, competition, conflict and dialogues between the ethnic, national, and religious communities of contemporary Middle Eastern countries.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Completion of Core General Education, and upper-division standing are prerequisites to all SJSU studies courses. Completion of, or co-registration in, 100W is strongly recommended.
satisfies: Satisfies SJSU Studies V: Cultures and Global Understanding.
crosslist: Cross-listed with MDES 145 / RELS 145. Humanities is responsible for scheduling.

name: Culture and Conflict
description: Problems of change, especially in multiethnic societies of both established and emerging nations. Technological development, modernization, social changes and value conflicts.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Completion of Core General Education and upper division standing are prerequisites to all SJSU studies courses. Completion of, or co-registration in, 100W is strongly recommended.
satisfies: Satisfies SJSU Studies V: Cultures and Global Understanding.
sustainability: Sustainability Related - SDG 16: Peace, Justice and Strong Institutions

name: Religion and Anthropology
description: Comparative anthropological study of religious systems and world views; Anthropological theories concerning origin and evolution of religion; structure and function of ritual and myth; types of religious specialists.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): ANTH 11, ANTH 25 or instructor consent.
crosslist: Cross-listed with RELS 148. Anthropology is responsible for scheduling.

name: Ethnographic Methods
description: Qualitative methods: research design, participant observation, collection of life histories, ethical responsibilities, interviewing, analysis and ethnographic writing.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): ANTH 11 or instructor consent.
sustainability: Sustainability Related - SDG 16: Peace, Justice and Strong Institutions

name: Modernity and Disease
description: Modernity and Disease explores the effects of the modern world on human biology, with specific emphasis on adaptations to the last several decades of environmental changes. Topics include reproduction, diet, and infectious, geriatric and environmental diseases.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): ANTH 12 or instructor consent.
sustainability: Sustainability Focused - SDG 3: Good Health and Well-Being

name: Becoming Human
description: This course reviews the fossil evidence for human evolution. It emphasizes areas of scientific controversy in paleoanthropology by assessing recent fossil discoveries and molecular data. Lectures are supplemented with lab demonstration of modern skeletal materials and reproductions of fossil hominids.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): ANTH 12 or instructor consent.

name: Monkeys, Apes and Humans
description: Behavior, ecology and evolution of our closest animal relatives, the nonhuman primates. Interpretive emphasis toward broader understanding of human evolution and behavior.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Any lower division anthropology or psychology course or instructor consent.

name: Forensic Osteology
description: The human skeletal system for forensic identification. Lab experience in identification of osteological material to answer questions regarding sex, age, ethnicity and cause of death.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): ANTH 12 or Instructor Consent.

name: Bioarchaeology
description: Study of human skeletal remains from archaeological setting to aid in reconstructing the biological and cultural past. Current theoretical and methodological issues in bioarchaeology. Emphasis on potential of skeletal analysis for uncovering disease and trauma, subsistence patterns, biological relatedness, physical activity and diverse reactions to stressors.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing.

name: Forensic Anthropology
description: An overview of forensic anthropological methods and applications emphasizing the recovery and interpretation of human remains within the context of multidisciplinary scientific death investigation. Topics include the history of the discipline and a concentrated hands-on overview of basic human osteological identification.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): ANTH 12, BIOL 10, BIOL 21, or BIOL 65.

name: Mummies
description: Explore mummies from around the world. Examine the archaeological and biological evidence of how and why mummification was practiced in these cultures, plus what the examination of mummies can tell us about past peoples cultures, diseases, and lifestyles.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing or instructor consent.

name: Reconstructing Lost Civilizations
description: Explores scientific archaeology and the reconstruction of civilizations. Topics include framing hypotheses, site selection, excavation, analysis of artifacts and ecofacts, and reconstructing social systems.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Completion of Core General Education and upper division standing are prerequisites to all SJSU studies courses. Completion of, or co-registration in, 100W is strongly recommended.
satisfies: Satisfies SJSU Studies R: Earth, Environment, and Sustainability.

name: Old World Civilizations
description: Prehistoric cultural development in Europe, Asia, and Africa from the Paleolithic to the development of civilizations. Discussions of early states include social organization, economic systems, art, architecture and intellectual achievements.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing.

name: Inca, Aztec and Maya Civilization
description: Ancient high civilizations of Mexico, Central America and Andean South America, their predecessors and contemporaries. Explores sociocultural systems with emphasis on art, architecture and intellectual achievements.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing.

name: North America before 1492
description: Archaeology and history of North American peoples before 1492. Precolumbian culture areas and relationships between them; development of state societies; relationships with and resistance to European colonizers.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing or instructor approval

name: Historical Archaeology
description: Course centers on the archaeology of the recent past. Students explore how to employ archaeological material analysis and archival research to develop a fuller understanding of the development of the modern industrialized world.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing.

name: Archaeological Methodology
description: Central methods of archaeological practice. Methods of archaeological inquiry, research design, and the cultural resource management presented through case studies in historic and prehistoric archaeology.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): ANTH 13.

name: Archaeological Site Excavation
description: Artifact recovery and analysis during archaeological field project. All phases of professional archaeological practice leading to publication of findings. Sites may be local or distant.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): ANTH 13 or instructor consent.

name: Multimedia Anthropology
description: Planning, production, and presentation of ethnographic materials using various media. Theoretical and applied aspects of multimedia anthropology. Use of multiple media in data collection, analysis, evaluation, and representation of culture including photographs, documentary video, websites, social networking platforms, and infographics.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): ANTH 11 or instructor consent.

name: Anthropology of Native America
description: Anthropological survey of North American indigenous peoples and issues from historical and contemporary perspectives. Topics include cultural variation and diversity, decolonizing narratives of indigenous histories, resistance, social and environmental justice, law, and politics.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Any lower division Anthropology course or Instructor Consent.
sustainability: Sustainability Focused - SDG 16: Peace, Justice and Strong Institutions

name: Native California: Past and Present
description: Native Californian cultures before and after white contact, emphasizing ecological, sociopolitical and religious interrelationships, colonialism, resistance, and struggles for tribal sovereignty. Ethnographic, archaeological and documentary sources.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): ANTH 11 or Instructor Consent.
sustainability: Sustainability Focused - SDG 16: Peace, Justice and Strong Institutions

name: Anthropology of Asia
description: Sociocultural themes of selected Asia cultures. Covers cultural pluralism, intercultural contact, social organization, worldview and economic adaptations. Explores connections within the Pacific Rim, especially to the local region. Course is repeatable once for credit when different cultures are emphasized.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing.
crosslist: Cross-listed with ASIA 177. Anthropology is responsible for scheduling.

name: Individual Studies
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Instructor consent.

name: Directed Reading
description: Directed reading in cultural anthropology, physical anthropology or archaeology to gain a broader understanding of a particular topic, culture or theoretical issue.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing and instructor consent.

name: Special Topics
description: Contemporary issues in anthropological theory including cultural anthropology, archaeology and physical anthropology. Course is repeatable once for credit on different issue.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing.

name: Designing Research
description: Describes research conception, development and implementation for academic research and applied careers alike. Emphasizes writing grant proposals, academic theses, and professional contracts. Topics include research question identification, methodological and technical approaches, broader significance and impact of research, and ethical considerations.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Declared major in Anthropology or Behavioral Sciences; Completion of Area Z (100W); Two of the following courses: ANTH 11, ANTH 12, ANTH 13 or Instructor consent.

name: Frontiers of Anthropology
description: Critical contemporary social issues that cut across archaeology and cultural and physical anthropology. Anthropology as a holistic social science. Seminar format uses reading, simulations and class discussions. Professionalism in the discipline stressed.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): ANTH 131 and senior standing or instructor consent.

name: International Program Studies
description: Study Abroad and Away transfer credit course. Study Abroad and Away provides students the opportunity to study abroad on long term programs (Exchange Programs, CSU International Programs, and International Student Exchange Programs) and short-term programs (Faculty-Led Programs and Summer School Abroad Programs) for academic credit, offering Alternative Break Programs for cultural immersion, and designing other globally focused opportunities. This course is designated as a placeholder course for Study Abroad and Away programs.

name: Behavioral Science in Practice
description: Capstone workshop for behavioral science majors. Students assess methods and knowledge of anthropology, psychology and sociology, and synthesize them by reflecting upon case studies of individual, organizational, community, and global issues. Emphasis is on cooperative learning, reflection and synthesis of skills and knowledge.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Senior standing. Allowed Declared Major: Behavioral Science or Behavioral Science double major.
crosslist: Cross-listed with PSYC 193 / SOCI 193. Anthropology is responsible for scheduling.
sustainability: Sustainability Related - SDG 16: Peace, Justice and Strong Institutions

name: Anthropology Practicum
description: Advanced practicum in archaeology, ethnography, physical anthropology or linguistics.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Instructor consent.

name: Special Projects
description: Independent research in cultural anthropology, physical anthropology or archaeology.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing and instructor consent.

name: Theory in Practice
description: In-depth analysis of anthropological and related theory and accompanying methodology, emphasizing the use of theory in practice.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): ANTH 131 or instructor consent.
satisfies: Satisfies GWAR: Graduation Writing Assessment Requirement.
notes: Note(s): This course satisfies graduate-level GWAR in this master’s program.

name: Applications Core
description: Methods for the analysis of sociocultural systems, ethnographic evaluation, and program/design development. Emphasis on professionalism, project management, budgeting, ethics, and contracts.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): ANTH 232, ANTH 105 or instructor consent.

name: Applications Core
description: Methods for the analysis sociocultural systems, ethnographic evaluation, and program/design development. Emphasis on professionalism, project management, budgeting, ethics, and contracts
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): ANTH 231 or instructor consent.

name: Fields of Application
description: Survey of domains in which anthropological skills and knowledge are applied. Topics include health, business and industry, sustainable regions, and immigration. Emphasis is on opportunities for anthropological contributions.

name: Advanced Research Methods
description: Advanced research methods including individual and group interviewing, structured observation, and formal analytical methods. Emphasis on data management, ethnographic writing, and presentation of data through different media.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): ANTH 149 or equivalent.

name: Quantitative Methods
description: Advanced quantitative methods to gain comprehension of statistical analyses, especially in regards to predictive value for regional issues. Emphasis will be on understanding statistics, creating databases, using statistical software packages, and employing proper statistics.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): STAT 95 or equivalent.

name: Individual Studies
description: Advanced individual research and projects.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Instructor consent and department chair approval.

name: Special Topics
description: Contemporary issues in applied and practicing anthropology not covered in other courses. Course is repeatable once for credit on different topic with advisor consent. Repeatable for credit when topic changes.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing or instructor consent.
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 6 units.

name: International Program Studies
description: Study Abroad and Away transfer credit course. Study Abroad and Away provides students the opportunity to study abroad on long term programs (Exchange Programs, CSU International Programs, and International Student Exchange Programs) and short-term programs (Faculty-Led Programs and Summer School Abroad Programs) for academic credit, offering Alternative Break Programs for cultural immersion, and designing other globally focused opportunities. This course is designated as a placeholder course for Study Abroad and Away programs.

name: Anthropology Project
description: Course consists of supervised units applying anthropology in a project, the documentation of that project and the evaluation of the project in a written report. Course is repeatable for credit in the same semester.

name: Master’s Thesis
description: Independent anthropological research conducted under supervision of faculty advisor.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing.

name: Culminating Experience Supervision
description: Continued work on project or thesis.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Outstanding RP grade in a preceding semester in a project or thesis class
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 16 units.
notes: Note(s): No Degree Credit.

name: Field Experience in the Arts
description: Provides opportunities for those considering teaching, K-12 levels, to interact with outstanding teachers of the arts in the region through structured field experiences in classrooms,reflective writing, community service, and weekly discussion in a seminar setting.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): ART 138 or ART 139, upper division standing, or instructor consent.
crosslist: Cross-listed with CA 150. Art and Art History is responsible for scheduling.

name: Student Teaching II - Classroom Teaching
description: Minimum 80-120 class periods of classroom, teaching laboratory or field teaching in appropriate single subjects, grades K-12 and related teaching activities and seminar.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Major and Education Department joint approval.

name: Student Teaching III - Classroom Teaching
description: See ARED 184Y for course description.
notes: Note(s): May be in different subject/school and will be at a different grade level.

name: Principles of Art Education
description: This course is designed to equip prospective art educators with the knowledge, skills, and strategies to effectively organize and implement sequential art instruction at the secondary level with an emphasis on Art Teaching Methods and Art Curriculum Development.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing or instructor consent.

name: Field Experience Seminar in Art Education
description: This companion to the Phase II/III student teaching experience in the Single Subject Credential Program provides a forum for discussing field experiences and prepared candidates for the program’s capstone assessment: The performance Assessment for California Teachers (PACT).
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): EDSC 184X

name: Professional Preparation in Art
description: Introduction to skills and documents needed in preparation for professional careers in the arts; orientation to SJSU. Intended for BA/BFA ART majors and minors.

name: The Artist in Contemporary Culture
description: Introduces art beginners to roles that artists play in contemporary culture. Critical readings and problem-solving: principles of form and theory and research applied to real-world situations confronted by contemporary artists. Orientation to SJSU.

name: Medium and Message
description: This undergraduate seminar introduces intermediate-level artists to a research and project-based approach to artmaking with a focus on contemporary, idea-appropriate mediums and methods. Orientation to SJSU.

name: Two-Dimensional Design and Color Concepts
description: Theories and applications of two-dimensional design and color in visual art and design. Studio practice.
notes: Note(s): ART 12 is treated as a repeat for students who have taken ANI 12.

name: Three-Dimensional Design Concepts
description: Theories and applications of three-dimensional form in visual art and design. Studio practice.

name: Color
description: Attributes of color. Studio practice exploring theories and creative use of color in visual art and design.
notes: Note(s): ART 14 is treated as a repeat for students who have taken ANI 14.

name: Drawing I
description: Elements and principles of drawing. Studio practice emphasizing line, shape and light-dark used in visual art and design.
notes: Note(s): ART 24 is treated as a repeat for students who have taken ANI 24.

name: Expressive Drawing
description: Drawing concepts emphasizing creative expression. Studio practice with a variety of methods and materials.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): ART 24.

name: Drawing II
description: Observation and depiction of volume and perspective.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): ART 24.

name: Multicultural Arts for Children
description: Focus on teaching arts of many cultures, places and times to young people (preschool through high school).

name: Introduction to Ceramics
description: Studio work in ceramics; a survey of methods used by contemporary artists. Includes use of the potter’s wheel, handbuilding techniques, clay preparation, glazing and firing for utilitarian and sculptural work.

name: Introduction to Metalsmithing
description: Introduction to tools, materials and techniques for small scale metal work. Primer course for metalsmithing and jewelry.

name: Beginning Painting
description: Studio practice in selected media. Specific content, materials and subject matter may vary with instructors.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): ART 12 and ART 24

name: Beginning Sculpture: Object & Concept
description: Introduction to core sculptural media: woodworking, welding, mold-making, metal-casting and working with found objects. Emphasis on concept development and critical thinking.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): ART 13 or instructor consent.
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 6 units.

name: Introduction to Digital Media
description: Fundamental concepts and methods of Digital Media production. Introduction to visualization software applications and web presentation techniques.

name: Introduction to Digital Video Art
description: Introduction of the fundamental skills, software and techniques involved in the production of Digital Video. Critical discourse and contemporary art theories will be explored.

name: International Program Studies
description: Study Abroad and Away transfer credit course. Study Abroad and Away provides students the opportunity to study abroad on long term programs (Exchange Programs, CSU International Programs, and International Student Exchange Programs) and short-term programs (Faculty-Led Programs and Summer School Abroad Programs) for academic credit, offering Alternative Break Programs for cultural immersion, and designing other globally focused opportunities. This course is designated as a placeholder course for Study Abroad and Away programs.

name: Writing Workshop: Fine Arts
description: Advanced writing course for fine art majors, based upon philosophical issues and current professional practice in art. Clear analytical and critical writing in examination of these topics.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): A3 or equivalent second semester composition course (with a grade of C- or better); completion of core GE; and upper division standing. Or Graduate or Postbaccalaureate level. Allowed Declared Majors: Art, Art History, Interior Design, Industrial Design, Graphic Design, Fine Arts.
satisfies: Satisfies Writing in the Disciplines (WID).
notes: Note(s): Must be passed with C or better to satisfy the CSU Graduation Writing Assessment Requirement (GWAR).

name: Digital Media Art
description: Experimental applications in creative coding as an art practice. Focus includes programming interactivity, generative graphics, intro to data visualization and user interface and user experience strategies.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): ART 74, ART 75 or instructor consent

name: 3D Modeling and Printing
description: Introduces experimental 3D methods with a focus on conceptual and creative processes using 3D modeling software and 3D printing technology while addressing contemporary uses for artistic production.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): ART 75 or instructor consent.

name: Art as System
description: Experimental applications in the use of systems-based approach for art making. Focus on various CNC 3D printing/cutting methods, parametric art, CAD/CAM techniques, physical computing integration and collaborative art models.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): ART 75 and ART 101

name: Interdisciplinary Seminar in Digital Media Art
description: Investigation of theoretical topics in digital media art and analysis of contemporary technology research issues.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing or instructor consent.

name: Advanced Digital Video
description: Advanced exploration of digital video within the context of conceptual art practice. Focus on issues and applications of digital technology and critical thinking in art with specific focus on video, the Internet and alternative media applications.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): ART 75 or permission of instructor.
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 6 units.

name: Topics in Human Machine Interface
description: Experimental applications in physical computing in art. Topics include computer-controlled sensors and actuators, the nature of the cyborg and interactive electronic interfaces for sculpture, environments and performance. Course is repeatable up to 6 units, when course topic changes.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): ART 75 and ART 101 or permission of instructor.
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 6 units.

name: Advanced Projects in Digital Media Art
description: Advanced issues and applications of digital technology in art. Application of interactive technology in installation and performance. Emphasis on collaborative projects, user interaction, and experience. Course is repeatable up to 6 units.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): ART 75 or permission of instructor.
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 6 units.

name: Introduction to Game Studies
description: Introduction to the systems, design, history, and cultural analysis of games with emphasis on critical studies, development, technological literacy, markets and impact on society.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing or instructor consent.
crosslist: Cross-listed with CS 108. Art and Art History is responsible for scheduling.

name: Web Development in HTML, CSS and JavaScript
description: Tracing the emergence of networked, online, and screen-based contexts for the exhibition of new media art, course explores programming, tools and methodologies for the creation of websites, web applications and net-based digital media artworks. Students develop website architectures, user interfaces, style sheets, animation and web-optimized content using industry-standard tools and techniques. Development of a collaborative networked installation environment and/ or online gallery for the exhibition of culminating work.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): ART 75 and ART 101.

name: History and Theory of New Media
description: The history of art and technology introducing contemporary critical theory and practice. Course will address digital visualization, simulation, interactive network technologies in the arts and speculate on the artistic implications of advances in engineering and science.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): ARTH 70B or ARTH 72 or instructor consent.
crosslist: Cross-listed with ARTH 110. Art and Art History is responsible for scheduling.

name: Topics in Intermediate Ceramics
description: Investigation of ceramic form and surface design with emphasis on the vessel. Development of skills on the potter’s wheel and in glazing, kiln loading and firing. Included are raku, salt, earthenware, stoneware and porcelain. Repeatable for up to 9 units of credit when course topic changes.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): ART 46 or instructor consent
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 9 units.

name: Topics in Ceramic Sculpture
description: Focus on handbuilding and nontraditional techniques in clay and related media. Includes gallery and studio visits. Repeatable for Credit when topic changes, up to 3 times.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): ART 13, ART 46 or instructor consent.
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 9 units.

name: Topics in Advanced Ceramics
description: Focus on personal stylistic development, individual critiques and portfolio preparation. Includes gallery and studio visits. Repeatable for Credit when topic changes, up to 3 times.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): ART 132 or ART 133.
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 9 units.

name: Topics in Moldmaking for Artists
description: Introduction to moldmaking for upper division/graduate students. Course will include techniques for rubber molds for wax or plastic, molds for pressed clay, slip casting and waste molds. Course is repeatable for a total of 6 units.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): ART 13 or instructor consent.
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 9 units.
notes: Note(s): Offered only occasionally.

name: Figure Modeling
description: Representation of the human figure in three dimensions. Sculpting in clay from a live model. Course is repeatable for a total of 6 units.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): ART 13 and ART 55 or instructor consent.
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 6 units.

name: Elementary Art Methods
description: Equips prospective pre-K through high school educators with the basic knowledge, skills, and strategies to effectively organize and provide sequential art education. Emphasis on art teaching methods, art curriculum development, and art experiences.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing.

name: Teaching Diversity through Art
description: Strategies for teaching ideas of diversity through art in the preschool through high school classroom. Students deepen their understanding of culture and context and of why the arts matter.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): upper-division standing or instructor consent
crosslist: Cross-listed with CA 139. Art and Art History is responsible for scheduling.
sustainability: Sustainability Related - SDG 4: Quality Education

name: Topics in Glass
description: Introduction to glass working techniques, chemistry, history and concept. Basic glass blowing, sand casting, slumping, fusing, cold working, stained glass and gluing techniques. Taught through a series of hands-on projects. Repeatable for up to 9 units when topic changes.
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 9 units.

name: Topics in Advanced Glass
description: Technical and esthetic aspects of glass for sculpture and design. Advanced blowing, kiln casting, mold making, lamp working, lathe techniques and surface treatments. Repeatable for up to 9 units of credit, when topic changes.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): ART 140, ART 13 or instructor consent.
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 9 units.

name: Topics in Metalsmithing and Jewelry
description: Technical and esthetic aspects of metalsmithing and jewelry design. Fabricating, surfacing, soldering, raising, forming and forging. Repeatable for 12 units of credit when topic changes.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): ART 47.
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 12 units.

name: Topics in Jewelry and Small Sculpture
description: Technical and esthetic aspects of metalcasting for small-scale sculpture and jewelry. Pattern materials, gating techniques, burnout procedure, vacuum casting, centrifugal casting and finishing. Repeatable for 12 units of credit when topic changes.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing or permission of instructor.
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 12 units.

name: Topics in Printmaking and Letterpress
description: Introduction to relief printing, letterpress and related processes. Studio practice.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): ART 12 and ART 24
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 6 units.

name: Topics in Screen-Printing
description: Screen printing and related photographic processes. Studio practice. Repeatable for Credit when topic changes.
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 9 units.

name: Topics in Lithography
description: Studio practice. A comprehensive study of the practice of stone and metal plate lithography. Course is repeatable for a total of 9 units when topic changes.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): ART 61 (or equivalent).
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 9 units.

name: Topics in Intaglio Processes
description: Studio practice towards an understanding of the methods, techniques and procedures necessary to make intaglio prints. Course is repeatable for a total of 9 units when course topic changes.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): ART 61 (or equivalent)
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 9 units.

name: Topics in Monotype
description: Studio practice. An investigation of the methods, techniques and syntax of the monotype and monoprint. Course is repeatable for total of 9 units when course topic changes.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): ART 61 (or equivalent).
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 9 units.

name: Topics in Drawing III
description: Form and expression in drawing. Selected media. Course Repeatable for up to 9 units of credit when topic changes.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): ART 25 or ART 26
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 9 units.

name: Watercolor
description: Painting with various water base media.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): ART 12 and ART 24.

name: Intermediate Painting
description: Emphasis may vary with instructor. Course is repeatable for a total of 6 units.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): ART 61 (or equivalent).

name: Intermediate Painting II
description: Intermediate Painting II expands and builds on the concepts and skills introduced in ART 164A-Intermediate Painting I; with the goal of developing more complex content and process in preparation for Advanced Painting.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): ART 61 and ART 164A or instructor consent

name: Topics in Figure Painting
description: Figure and portrait painting from the model. Repeatable for up to 9 units of credit when course topic changes.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): ART 26 and ART 61.
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 9 units.

name: Topics in Advanced Painting
description: Emphasis may vary with instructor. Repeatable for 9 units of credit when topic changes.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): ART 61, ART 164A, ART 164B and ART 165 or equivalent, or instructor consent
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 9 units.

name: Topics in Woodworking
description: Introduction to the physical structure of wood and to the design and construction of furniture and sculptural objects in wood. Also, an introduction to the historical use of wood joinery in man-made objects. Course is repeatable for 6 units of credit.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): ART 13 or instructor consent.
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 6 units.

name: Topics in Metal Sculpture
description: Conception and creation of three-dimensional aesthetic form using metal techniques including casting, welding, fabrication and other forming processes. Repeatable for up to 9 units when topic changes.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): ART 13.
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 9 units.

name: Topics in Fabricated Sculpture
description: Fabricated Sculpture includes welding training, a concise history of fabricated metal sculpture since 1945, and studio time wherein the student practices skills and executes three steel sculptures. Repeatable for up to 9 units of credit when course topic changes.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): ART 13.
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 9 units.

name: Advanced Sculpture
description: Self expression and advanced techniques in sculpture. Emphasis will be placed on individual development, current directions and goals.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): 6 units of sculpture.

name: Intermediate Sculpture: System/Structure
description: This is an intermediate-level sculpture class with a focus on contemporary materials and processes. Students will make sculptural responses to timely issues raised in course readings and lectures.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): ART 68 or instructor consent.
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 6 units.

name: Topics in Installation Art
description: Exploration of cross-disciplinary artmaking, with an emphasis on conceptual development and critical dialogue. Students make installation art and site-specific artworks using a variety of techniques and processes, including time-based media. Course can be repeated for up to 6 units when course topic changes.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): ART 13 or instructor consent.
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 6 units.

name: Museum and Gallery Operations
description: Theoretical and technical problems of gallery and museum work including administration, security and curatorship.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing.
crosslist: Cross-listed with ARTH 174A. Art and Art History is responsible for scheduling.

name: Internship: Museum and Gallery Operations
description: Supervised internship in museum or gallery. Experience including installation, curating and administration. Course is repeatable for a total of 6 units.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): ART 174A.
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 6 units.
crosslist: Cross-listed with ARTH 174B. Art and Art History is responsible for scheduling.

name: Special Topics in Studio Art
description: Varying concepts, media or techniques. Emphasizing individual expression, professional ability and recent movements and directions in art.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing in art.

name: Professional & Business Practices
description: An introduction to the ways and means necessary to build a career in the arts while successfully negotiating its challenges, this course will provide information on portfolio development and professional and business practices essential for the practicing artist.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Upper division or graduate standing.

name: Art Field Work
description: Professional practice in a selected field.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Application for assignment made preceding semester. Supervisor and department approval.

name: Special Problems in Art
description: Individual study on a tutorial basis.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Qualified seniors or graduates.

name: Individual Studies
description: Special topics or projects by arrangement with instructor. Course is repeatable up to 4 units of credit toward graduation.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Majors or minors with Department of Art & Art History consent.
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 4 units.

name: International Program Studies
description: Study Abroad and Away transfer credit course. Study Abroad and Away provides students the opportunity to study abroad on long term programs (Exchange Programs, CSU International Programs, and International Student Exchange Programs) and short-term programs (Faculty-Led Programs and Summer School Abroad Programs) for academic credit, offering Alternative Break Programs for cultural immersion, and designing other globally focused opportunities. This course is designated as a placeholder course for Study Abroad and Away programs.

name: Digital Materials
description: Technical skills to facilitate the realization of projects conceptually rooted in an analysis of computational media and its relationship to the physical world. Introduction to video and computational outputs integrated with tangible presentation methods. Material survey, exhibition strategies, and introductory fabrication techniques that facilitate projects bridging computation, architecture, objects, and the body.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): ART 74 and ART 75.
crosslist: Cross-listed with DSGN 193. Art is responsible for scheduling.

name: BFA Group Exhibition
description: Student develop individual approaches, methodologies, and practices in the creation of art and participate in a final group show demonstrating professional competence in the students area of concentration. Participation in the final exhibition with the approval of the student’s advisory committee is required.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): 30 units of upper division art, admission to the BFA program and ART 198, or ART 210 with advisor’s approval.

name: BA Senior Project
description: Creation of a studio art or design capstone project consisting of new work in media selected by student to be documented and presented to studio or design faculty.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): 15 units of upper division work in the major.

name: BFA Seminar
description: Preparation for BFA project and postgraduate career planning, this course includes field trips, class discussions and studio visits with art professionals.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Prior acceptance in the B.F.A. program.

name: BFA Project
description: A project demonstrating professional competence in area of concentration. A gallery exhibition with the approval of the student’s advisory committee is required.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): 30 units of upper division art, admission to the BFA program and ART 198, or ART 178 with advisor’s approval.

name: Professional Writing in Contemporary Art
description: Graduate seminar focusing on issues and practices of writing about contemporary art, including artist statements, exhibition catalogs and art criticism.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Graduate Standing in Department of Art & Art History.
satisfies: Satisfies GWAR: Graduation Writing Assessment Requirement.
notes: Note(s): This course satisfies graduate-level GWAR in this master’s program.

name: Graduate Photography Critique
description: Professional practice in the discipline of fine art photography is multi faceted and complex. To embrace this diversity, Art 208 Graduate Photography Critique offers rotating topics that influence portfolio development, emphasize an ongoing critique of work, and build a healthy professional practice. Repeatably for up to 18 units of credit when course topic changes.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Classified status in art or instructor consent.
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 18 units.

name: Seminar in Digital Media Art
description: Theoretical discourse involving art and information culture. Review and analysis of contemporary theory and critical literature. Emphasis on collaborative activities and art practice.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Classified status in art or instructor consent.

name: Tutorials in Pictorial Arts
description: Individual projects in painting, drawing and printmaking supervised by an instructor.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Classified or conditionally classified status in art and instructor consent.

name: Tutorials in Spatial Art
description: Individual projects in sculpture, installation, performance and other 3-D media supervised by an instructor.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Classified or conditionally classified status in art and instructor consent.

name: Tutorials in Digital Media Art
description: Individual problems in selected area of research or practice.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Classified status in art and instructor consent.

name: Tutorials in Photography
description: Individual projects employing photographic media supervised by an instructor.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Classified or conditionally classified status in art and instructor consent.

name: Special Tutorials in Art
description: Individual problems in a selected art area supervised by an instructor.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Classified or conditionally classified status in art and instructor consent.

name: Artists Teaching Art
description: Seminar will examine theoretical and practical issues of art education which relate to traditional institutions of higher learning as well as to other teaching opportunities in the community.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Classified graduate status or instructor consent.

name: Interdisciplinary Critique Seminar
description: Interdisciplinary peer group critiques and discussion of individual student work. Repeatable for up to 9 units when topic changes.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the MFA in Art program.
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 9 units.

name: Seminar in the Theory and Criticism of Contemporary Art
description: A historical approach to the thought of major critics and theoreticians of contemporary art.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): ARTH 191A and admission to classified MFA status in art or instructor consent.

name: Seminar in Contemporary Art
description: An examination of a particular theme in contemporary art theory. Repeatable for credit.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): ARTH 191A and admission to classified MFA status in art or instructor consent.
satisfies: Satisfies GWAR: Graduation Writing Assessment Requirement.
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 6 units.
notes: Note(s): This course satisfies graduate-level GWAR in this master’s program.

name: Master’s Special Study
description: Advanced individual research in an area closely related to the master’s thesis, research or project. Course may be repeated for a total of 6 units.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Acceptance of qualifications for candidacy by Art Graduate Committee and permission of Thesis, Research or Project Committee chair.
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 6 units.

name: Master’s Project
description: Advanced projects in Creative Expression.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Advancement to candidacy for the master’s degree in art.

name: MFA Special Study
description: Advanced individual research in an area closely related to the MFA in Art project.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Advancement to candidacy for the MFA in Art degree.

name: MFA Project
description: A creative project of professional caliber.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Advancement to candidacy for the MFA in Art degree.

name: Culminating Experience Supervision
description: This course satisfies the requirement that all graduate students must remain enrolled during semesters in which they are working solely on their theses or projects, for which they have previously received but not cleared an RP grade.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Existing RP grade in a graduate-level thesis or project course
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 20 units.
notes: Note(s): No Degree Credit.

name: Modern Art History
description: Introductory survey of 20th and 21st century art, its history, and its contexts. Related developments in illustration, design, other forms of art production, and cultural institutions such as museums, galleries, publications also considered.
prereqs: Pre/Corequisite(s): ART 12 or ART 13 or PHOT 40 or instructor consent.

name: Intro to Visual Culture
description: Key ideas and debates pertaining to visual culture considered through interdisciplinary study of art and media as significant social forces.
satisfies: Satisfies C1: Arts.

name: Art History, Prehistoric to Medieval
description: Western painting, sculpture and architecture from Prehistoric times through the Middle Ages. Important art works of Egypt, Greece, Rome and Medieval Europe.
satisfies: Satisfies C1: Arts.

name: Art History, Renaissance to Modern
description: Western painting, sculpture and architecture from the Renaissance to the present. Masters of the Renaissance, Baroque, Rococo, Neo-Classic, Romantic and Modern periods, including Da Vinci, Michelangelo, Durer, Rembrandt, Vermeer, David, Delacroix and Monet.
satisfies: Satisfies C1: Arts.

name: Arts of Asia
description: Major trends in the art of China, India and Japan, as well as Southeast and Central Asia and Korea, from the Neolithic period to the twentieth century.
satisfies: Satisfies C1: Arts.
crosslist: Cross-listed with ASIA 70C. Art and Art History is responsible for scheduling.

name: Design in Society
description: Considers the cultural role of design in addressing human needs in shaping the environment, in providing shelter, clothing, utilitarian objects, and transportation, in visual communication for political and entertainment purposes.
satisfies: Satisfies C1: Arts.
sustainability: Sustainability Focused - SDG 12: Responsible Consumption and Production

name: International Program Studies
description: Study Abroad and Away transfer credit course. Study Abroad and Away provides students the opportunity to study abroad on long term programs (Exchange Programs, CSU International Programs, and International Student Exchange Programs) and short-term programs (Faculty-Led Programs and Summer School Abroad Programs) for academic credit, offering Alternative Break Programs for cultural immersion, and designing other globally focused opportunities. This course is designated as a placeholder course for Study Abroad and Away programs.

name: Introduction to Practice of Art History
description: Introduction to practice of art history including visual analysis, research tools, and examination of professional options.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Art History and Visual Culture major or instructor consent.

name: History and Theory of New Media
description: The history of art and technology introducing contemporary critical theory and practice. Course will address digital visualization, simulation, interactive network technologies in the arts and speculate on the artistic implications of advances in engineering and science.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): ARTH 70B or ARTH 72 or instructor consent.
crosslist: Cross-listed with ART 110. Art and Art History is responsible for scheduling.

name: History of Photography
description: Technical developments and aesthetic trends in photography traced from its invention in the nineteenth century to the present day. Slide presentations, discussions, field trips.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): ARTH 70B or instructor consent.
crosslist: Cross-listed with PHOT 126. Art and Art History is responsible for scheduling.

name: Photography, Film, and Architecture
description: This course presents a closely contextualized examination of major photographers, architects and film-makers through their work and their interpretations of modern culture and its spaces. Lectures will cover developments in photography, film and architecture, as well as the changing relationship among these media and other domains visual culture.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): ARTH 70B or Instructor Consent

name: Modern Architecture
description: Development of modern architecture from the late 19th century to the present, including Richardson, Sullivan, Wright, Le Corbusier, the Bauhaus, Mies van der Rohe, Meier and Gehry.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): ARTH 70B, ARTH 72 or instructor consent.

name: Contemporary Architecture
description: History of contemporary architecture since 1945, covering major trends and issues in a global context; includes Louis Kahn, Frank Gehry and Zaha Hadid.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): ARTH 70B or instructor consent.

name: California Architecture
description: History of architecture in California since 1700, covering major architectural developments in a national and transnational context; includes Bernard Maybeck, Richard Neutra and Morphosis.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): ARTH 70B or instructor consent.

name: Twentieth Century Urban Design
description: History of urban design since 1900, covering theories and practices of urban design in the industrialized world; includes Camillo Sitte, Le Corbusier and Frank Lloyd Wright.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): ARTH 70B or URBP 151 or instructor consent.
crosslist: Cross-listed with URBP 163. Art and Art History is responsible for scheduling.
sustainability: Sustainability Focused - SDG 11: Sustainable Cities and Communities

name: Museum and Gallery Operations
description: Theoretical and technical problems of gallery and museum work including administration, security and curatorship.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing.
crosslist: Cross-listed with ART 174A. Art and Art History is responsible for scheduling.

name: Internship: Museum and Gallery Operations
description: Supervised internship in museum or gallery. Experience including installation, curating and administration. Course is repeatable for a total of 6 units.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): ART 174A.
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 6 units.
crosslist: Cross-listed with ART 174B. Art and Art History is responsible for scheduling.

name: Theories of Art History and Art Criticism
description: The study of approaches used by professional art historians and critics. The focus will be on 20th century writers who helped shape the development of contemporary art history and criticism.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing, 6 units of ARTH 70A, ARTH 70B, and/or ARTH 70C or instructor consent.

name: Graphic Design History and Theory
description: The history of graphic design and typography with an emphasis on the 20th century. Define technological, historical and theoretical concerns and influences on individuals and movements in graphic design.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): ARTH 72, completion of Area Z, or instructor consent.
crosslist: Cross-listed with DSGD 176A. Art and Art History is responsible for scheduling.

name: Art History Field Work
description: Professional practice in a selected field of Art History.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Application for assignment made preceding semester. Supervisor and department approval.

name: Individual Studies in Art History
description: Special topics or projects by arrangement with instructor. Course is repeatable up to 4 units of credit toward graduation.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Majors or minors with Department of Art & Art History consent.
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 4 units.

name: Special Topics in Art History
description: In-depth analysis of a selected art historical topic.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): ARTH 70A and ARTH 70B or instructor consent.

name: Art of the Americas
description: A survey of architecture, ceramics, metalwork, sculpture, painting and textiles of North, South, and Meso American cultures.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): ARTH 70A or instructor consent.

name: American Art
description: From the Colonial Period to 1940. Social context of America.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing.

name: Art of Egypt and Mesopotamia
description: The Arts of Egypt, Sumer, Akkad, Babylonia, Assyria, Anatolia, Hittites, and Persia (Elamite to Sassanian).
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): ARTH 70A or instructor consent.
crosslist: Cross-listed with MDES 183A. Art and Art History is responsible for scheduling.

name: Art of the Classical World
description: Focus on the ancient arts of Greece, Roman and Etruria from the 8th century BC through the 4th century AD. Major monuments: Parthenon, Altar of Zeus at Pergamon, Ara Pacis and Forum of Trajan.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): ARTH 70A or instructor consent.

name: Medieval Art
description: Introductory survey of art and architecture from from the end of the Western Roman Empire, circa 500 AD to the beginning of the Italian Renaissance, circa 1400 AD. Focuses on the meanings and uses of art and architecture within their specific historical and cultural contexts.

name: Art of the Italian Renaissance, Fifteenth Century
description: Early Renaissance art and architecture. Masaccio, Botticelli, Brunelleschi and Donatello.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): ARTH 70B or instructor consent.

name: Art of the Italian Renaissance, Sixteenth Century
description: High Renaissance and Mannerism in Italy. Leonardo, Michelangelo, Raphael and Titian.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): ARTH 70B or instructor consent.

name: The Art of Renaissance Venice
description: A study of Venetian art and its urban ideology, 11th through 18th century, emphasizing the great painters and architects of the Renaissance (Carpaccio, Bellini, Titian, Tintoretto and Veronese, Mauro Codussi, Sansovino and Palladio).
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): ARTH 70B or instructor consent.

name: Northern Renaissance Fourteenth and Fifteenth Centuries
description: Survey of art of Netherlands, France and Bohemia from mid-fourteenth through fifteenth century. Principal artists covered include the Limbourg Brothers, Van Eyck, Van der Weyden, Memling and Fouquet. Emphasis on northern painting, manuscripts, tapestry traditions, iconography and social history of northern European art.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): ARTH 70B or instructor consent.

name: Northern Renaissance, Sixteenth Century
description: Survey of fifteenth and sixteenth century art of Netherlands, France and Germany. Principal artists covered include Bosch, Durer, Grunewald, Holbein and Bruegel. Emphasis on northern painting, printmaking traditions, iconography, social history of northern European art.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): ARTH 70B or instructor consent.

name: Baroque Art and Architecture in Europe
description: The art and architecture of Europe in the late 16th and 17th centuries. Broad trends and issues; artists such as Caravaggio, Bernini, Borromini, Vermeer, Rembrandt, Poussin, Mansart, Velazquez.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): ARTH 70B or instructor consent.

name: Global Baroque Art and Architecture
description: Art and architecture in the empires of Spain, Portugal and the Netherlands with a focus on painting, sculpture, and architecture, including the ways in which these artworks and artists circulated globally.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): ARTH 70B or instructor consent.

name: Art of the Nineteenth Century
description: Western Europe from Neoclassicism through Post-Impressionism including David, Delacroix, Goya, Manet, Monet, Cassatt, Cezanne, Van Gogh and Gauguin.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): ARTH 70B or instructor consent.

name: Early Modernist Art
description: Critical investigation of modern art from the 1880’s (Post Impressionism) to World War I with an emphasis on painting and sculpture with some attention paid to architecture, photography, printmaking and design.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): ARTH 70B or instructor consent.

name: 20th Century Art: from Dada to Pop
description: Critical investigation of modernist art from World War I to the 1960s (from Dada to Pop art) with an emphasis on painting and sculpture but some attention paid to architecture, photography, printmaking and design.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): ARTH 70B or instructor consent.

name: German Art, 1800-2000
description: This course is an upper-division survey of historical figures, movements and developments in German art, architecture, aesthetics and design from the late Enlightenment to the present era.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): ARTH 70B or completion of Area Z or instructor consent

name: Issues in Contemporary Art
description: A critical investigation of a theme which bears on the arts from mid-century to the present, looking closely at major artists and trends in order to understand their philosophies, objectives, styles, and contexts. Course is repeatable for a total of 6 units.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): ARTH 70B.
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 6 units.

name: Women in Art
description: Contributions made to Western culture by women involved in the arts from the Middle Ages to the present and the influence on art of attitudes held about women.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): ARTH 70B or instructor consent.

name: Contemporary Art in Mexico, the U.S., and Latin America
description: Contemporary Art in Mexico, the U.S., and Latin America. Includes Mexican modernism, social movements of post-revolutionary Mexico (1910-1940), and works influenced by the Chicano Civil Rights Movement (El Movimiento) in the United States (1960s-1990s) up to the present day.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): ARTH 70B or completion of Area Z or instructor consent

name: International Program Studies
description: Study Abroad and Away transfer credit course. Study Abroad and Away provides students the opportunity to study abroad on long term programs (Exchange Programs, CSU International Programs, and International Student Exchange Programs) and short-term programs (Faculty-Led Programs and Summer School Abroad Programs) for academic credit, offering Alternative Break Programs for cultural immersion, and designing other globally focused opportunities. This course is designated as a placeholder course for Study Abroad and Away programs.

name: Modern Design
description: History of design philosophy and practice from the Industrial Revolution to the present including Art Nouveau and Art Deco, the Bauhaus, International Style, Functionalism vs. Formalism, Post-Modern and Deconstructivism.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): ARTH 72, completion of Writing in the Disciplines (WID) course, or instructor consent.

name: History of Interior Design
description: Survey of interior design through historical, political, social, economic, technological, and aesthetic factors that shape the built environment. Design will be analyzed formally and through parallel developments in the arts.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): ARTH 70B or ARTH 72, completion of Writing in the Disciplines (WID) course, or instructor consent.
crosslist: Cross-listed with DSIT 192C. Art and Art History is responsible for scheduling.
sustainability: Sustainability Related - SDG 12: Responsible Consumption and Production

name: Worlds of Art and Culture
description: Focuses on the use of art images as primary sources for the study of cultural development in a globalized context and ways in which past cultures and their interactions influence the modern world.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Completion of Core General Education and upper division standing are prerequisites to all SJSU studies courses. Completion of, or co-registration in, 100W is strongly recommended.
satisfies: Satisfies SJSU Studies V: Cultures and Global Understanding.

name: East Meets West in Art
description: Comparative study of Eastern and Western art. Emphasis on cross-fertilization. Historical and cultural backgrounds. Includes lectures, discussions and presentations. Research or art project and paper required.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Completion of Core General Education and upper division standing are prerequisites to all SJSU studies courses. Completion of, or co-registration in, 100W is strongly recommended.
satisfies: Satisfies SJSU Studies V: Cultures and Global Understanding.
crosslist: Cross-listed with ASIA 193B. Art and Art History is responsible for scheduling.

name: Art of China
description: Architecture, sculpture and painting in China from prehistoric times to the Republic.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing or instructor consent.
crosslist: Cross-listed with ASIA 194A. Art and Art History is responsible for scheduling.

name: Art of Japan
description: Architecture, sculpture and painting in Japan from prehistoric times to Edo era.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing or instructor consent.
crosslist: Cross-listed with ASIA 195. Art and Art History is responsible for scheduling.

name: Art History Capstone Seminar
description: This seminar explores art history as an academic discipline. Topics include: discovering subfields within art history; constructing art historical arguments; and the methods and practices of art history.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): ARTH 70A or ARTH 70C; ARTH 70B; ART 100W.

name: Seminar in Renaissance Art
description: Directed group research in area of European art history of Renaissance period on topic designated by instructor. Research project required. Course is repeatable for up to 9 units of credit when course topic changes.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): At least two upper division art history courses or instructor consent.
satisfies: Satisfies GWAR: Graduation Writing Assessment Requirement.
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 9 units.
notes: Note(s): This course satisfies graduate-level GWAR in this master’s program.

name: Seminar in Baroque Art
description: Directed group research in area of European or Latin American art history of Baroque period on topic designated by instructor. Research projects required. Course is repeatable for up to 9 units of credit when course topic changes.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): At least two upper division art history courses or instructor consent.
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 9 units.

name: Seminar in Nineteenth Century Art
description: Directed group research in area of European or American art of nineteenth century on topic designated by instructor. Research projects required. Course is repeatable for up to 9 units of credit when course topic changes.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): At least two upper division art history courses or instructor consent.
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 9 units.

name: Seminar in Twentieth Century Art
description: Directed group research in area of European or American art of twentieth century on topic designated by instructor. Research projects required. Course is repeatable for up to 9 units of credit when course topic changes.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): At least two upper division art history courses or instructor consent.
satisfies: Satisfies GWAR: Graduation Writing Assessment Requirement.
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 9 units.
notes: Note(s): This course satisfies graduate-level GWAR in this master’s program.
