description: Directed group research in theories and methodologies of art history. Research projects required. Course is repeatable for up to 9 units of credit when course topic changes.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): At least two upper division art history courses or instructor consent.
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 9 units.

name: Seminar in Myth and Symbol
description: Directed group research in sources and meanings of myths and symbols. Research projects required. Repeatable for up to 9 units of credit when course topic changes.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): At least two upper division art history courses or instructor consent.
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 9 units.

name: Graduate Problems in Art History
description: Independent studies on a focused research project.

name: Master’s Project
description: Advanced problems in research.  Course may be repeated for a total of 6 units.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Advancement to candidacy for the Master’s degree in Art.

name: Master’s Thesis
description: Advanced problems in research. Course may be repeated for a total of 6 units.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Advancement to candidacy for the master’s degree in art.
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 6 units.

name: Culminating Experience Supervision
description: This course satisfies the requirement that all graduate students must remain enrolled during semesters in which they are working solely on their theses or projects, for which they have previously received but not cleared an RP grade.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Existing RP grade in a graduate-level thesis or project course
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 20 units.
notes: Note(s): No Degree Credit.

name: Heritage and Values
description: Introduces students to the Department of the Air Force (DAF) and provides an overview of the basic characteristics, missions, communications and organization of the Air and Space Forces.
notes: Note(s): Year course. Enrollment in leadership lab required.

name: Heritage and Values
description: Introduces students to the Department of the Air Force (DAF) and provides an overview of the basic characteristics, missions, communications and organization of the Air and Space Forces.
notes: Note(s): Year course. Enrollment in leadership lab required.

name: Team Leadership Fundamentals
description: Provides a fundamental understanding of both leadership and team building, including aspects such as listening, understanding themselves, being a good follower and problem solving efficiently. Students apply these leadership perspectives when completing team building activities and discussing issues like conflict management. Students should demonstrate basic verbal and written communication skills. Cadets apply these lessons at Field Training.

name: Team Leadership Fundamentals
description: Provides a fundamental understanding of both leadership and team building, including aspects such as listening, understanding themselves, being a good follower and problem solving efficiently. Students apply these leadership perspectives when completing team building activities and discussing issues like conflict management. Students should demonstrate basic verbal and written communication skills. Cadets apply these lessons at Field Training.

name: Leading People and Effective Communication
description: Utilizes student’s field training experience to take a more in-depth look at leadership. Special emphasis is placed on enhancing communication skills and why that is important as a leader. Students practice these leadership and management techniques in a supervised environment.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): AS 1A and AS 1B, AS 2A and AS 2B, or as determined by department chair.
notes: Note(s): Year course. Enrollment in Leadership lab required.

name: Leading People and Effective Communication
description: Utilizes student’s field training experience to take a more in-depth look at leadership. Special emphasis is placed on enhancing communication skills and why that is important as a leader. Students practice these leadership and management techniques in a supervised environment.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): AS 1A and AS 1B, AS 2A and AS 2B, or as determined by department chair.
notes: Note(s): Year course. Enrollment in Leadership lab required.

name: National Security, Leadership & Commissioning Prep
description: Provides students with the foundation to understand their role as military officers and how they are directly tied to our National Security Strategy. Provides an overview of the complex social and political issues facing the military profession and requires a measure of sophistication commensurate with the senior college level.
prereqs: Pre/Corequisite(s): AS 131A.
notes: Note(s): Enrollment in leadership lab required.

name: National Security, Leadership & Commissioning Prep
description: Provides students with the foundation to understand their role as military officers and how they are directly tied to our National Security Strategy. Provides an overview of the complex social and political issues facing the military profession and requires a measure of sophistication commensurate with the senior college level.
prereqs: Pre/Corequisite(s): AS 131B.
notes: Note(s): Enrollment in leadership lab required.

name: Music in World Cultures
description: Introduction to music in various cultural contexts outside European classical tradition. Live performances, film, video tapes and slides. Projects involving related arts encouraged.
satisfies: Satisfies C1: Arts.
crosslist: Cross-listed with MUSC 19.  Music is responsible for scheduling.

name: Arts of Asia
description: Major trends in the art of China, India and Japan, as well as Southeast and Central Asia and Korea, from the Neolithic period to the twentieth century.
satisfies: Satisfies C1: Arts.
crosslist: Cross-listed with ARTH 70C. Art and Art History is responsible for scheduling.

name: International Program Studies
description: Study Abroad and Away transfer credit course. Study Abroad and Away provides students the opportunity to study abroad on long term programs (Exchange Programs, CSU International Programs, and International Student Exchange Programs) and short-term programs (Faculty-Led Programs and Summer School Abroad Programs) for academic credit, offering Alternative Break Programs for cultural immersion, and designing other globally focused opportunities. This course is designated as a placeholder course for Study Abroad and Away programs.

name: Chinese Culture
description: Traditional Chinese culture in light of contemporary values. Ideographs, folk tales, festivals, creeds and customs, myths and superstitions, opera and the arts, women, the art of living.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing.
crosslist: Cross-listed with CHIN 102. World Languages and Literatures is responsible for scheduling.
notes: Note(s): Taught in English.

name: Asian Philosophy
description: Philosophical examination of Confucianism, Daoism, Buddhism and some other significant movements of thought originated in Asia. Comparison with Western philosophy.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Completion of Core General Education and upper division standing are prerequisites to all SJSU studies courses. Completion of, or co-registration in, 100W is strongly recommended.
satisfies: Satisfies SJSU Studies V: Cultures and Global Understanding.
crosslist: Cross-listed with PHIL 104 / RELS 104. Philosophy is responsible for scheduling.

name: History of China
description: Traditional society from earliest times to 1800.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Upper Division Standing
crosslist: Cross-listed with HIST 109A. History is responsible for scheduling.

name: History of China
description: China’s revolutions and ongoing modernization.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing or instructor consent.
crosslist: Cross-listed with HIST 109B. History is responsible for scheduling.

name: History of Japan
description: Development of state and society from prehistoric times to 1750. Major topics include the controversy over the origins of the Japanese people; the adaptation of Chinese cultural, religious, and political models; the role of the emperor in state formation; the classical era of Japanese culture during the Heian period; the rise of the samurai elites; and the development of military rule under the shoguns.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing or consent of instructor.
crosslist: Cross-listed with HIST 110A. History is responsible for scheduling.

name: History of Japan
description: Since 1750 emphasizing the process of modernization.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing or instructor consent.
crosslist: Cross-listed with HIST 110B. History is responsible for scheduling.

name: Legacy of Asia
description: Interdisciplinary focus on continuity and change in China and India as these ancient civilizations responded to challenges throughout their history.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Completion of Core General Education, and upper-division standing are prerequisites to all SJSU studies courses. Completion of, or co-registration in, 100W is strongly recommended.
satisfies: Satisfies SJSU Studies V: Cultures and Global Understanding.
crosslist: Cross-listed with ANTH 114 / HUM 114 / RELS 114. Humanities is responsible for scheduling.

name: The Emerging Global Culture
description: Introduction to systems concepts and approach as a way to investigate the global impacts of industrial technology on political, economic, social and moral/psychological structures of humankind.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Completion of Core General Education and upper division standing are prerequisites to all SJSU studies courses. Completion of, or co-registration in, 100W is strongly recommended.
satisfies: Satisfies SJSU Studies V: Cultures and Global Understanding.
crosslist: Cross-listed with ANTH 115. Anthropology is responsible for scheduling.
sustainability: Sustainability Related - SDG 9: Industry, Innovation and Infrastructure

name: English as a World Language
description: A survey of the ways and the purposes which English is used in diverse societies and cultures around the world, including the United States; implications for international and cross-cultural communication.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Completion of Core General Education and upper division standing are prerequisites to all SJSU studies courses. Completion of, or co-registration in, 100W is strongly recommended.
satisfies: Satisfies SJSU Studies V: Cultures and Global Understanding.
crosslist: Cross-listed with LING 122. Linguistics and Language Development is responsible for scheduling.

name: Relationship Marketing: Pacific Rim
description: Why not use PacRim marketing methods in PacRim markets? Americans tend to be short-term, sales-oriented. Asians tend to be relationship oriented. Why not master both marketing methods? Focus: Launching a “start-up”. Topics: PacRim forms of product-launch, sales presentation, negotiation, promotion, PacRim risks.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): BUS2 130.
crosslist: Cross-listed with BUS2 133B. Marketing is responsible for scheduling.

name: Chinese Culture and Politics Through Literature
description: Exploration of the interaction between culture, politics and literature as reflected in the contemporary (post-1949) narrative, poetry and drama of China, Taiwan and Hong Kong.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Completion of Core General Education and upper division standing are prerequisites to all SJSU studies courses. Completion of, or co-registration in, 100W is strongly recommended.
satisfies: Satisfies SJSU Studies V: Cultures and Global Understanding.
crosslist: Cross-listed with CHIN 140. World Languages and Literatures is responsible for scheduling.
notes: Note(s): Taught in English.

name: Contemporary Buddhism and its Roots
description: Teachings of Gautama, the Buddha and ways in which those teachings were modified in forms of Buddhism that followed: Therevada in southeast Asia and Mahayana in East Asia.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Upper-division standing or instructor consent.
crosslist: Cross-listed with HUM 142 / RELS 142. Humanities is responsible for scheduling.

name: Chinese Traditions
description: Religious thought and practice of China’s three Great Traditions (Buddhism, Taoism and Confucianism) as well as China’s Little Tradition (Chinese folk religion). The role of these traditions within traditional Chinese culture and their relevance to the modern world, including China.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Upper-division standing or instructor consent.
crosslist: Cross-listed with HUM 144 / RELS 144. Humanities is responsible for scheduling.

name: Asian Politics
description: Study of unfolding events in Asia. Themes include: the Asian economic ‘miracle,’ the implications of China’s rise for international security, nuclear proliferation and terrorism, and sustainability; specifically, energy, environment and human rights.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing.
crosslist: Cross-listed with POLS 145. Political Science is responsible for scheduling.
sustainability: Sustainability Related - SDG 7: Affordable and Clean Energy

name: East and South Asia
description: Geography of Eastern, Southeastern, and Southern Asia. Themes include environmental, historical, political, and economic geographies at the scales of the region, its countries, and selected cities. Particular emphasis is given to comparing and analyzing the variable rates of economic progress across the region.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing or instructor consent.
crosslist: Cross-listed with GEOG 160. Geology is responsible for scheduling.
sustainability: Sustainability Related - SDG 15: Life on Land

name: Anthropology of Asia
description: Sociocultural themes of selected Asia cultures. Covers cultural pluralism, intercultural contact, social organization, worldview and economic adaptations. Explores connections within the Pacific Rim, especially to the local region. Course is repeatable once for credit when different cultures are emphasized.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing.
crosslist: Cross-listed with ANTH 177. Anthropology is responsible for scheduling.

name: Astrophysics I
description: Physical and observational foundations of astronomy and astrophysics. Celestial coordinates, telescopes, astronomical observations, orbital motion, physics and chemistry of planetary systems; introduction to stellar physics. Computer models and simulations may be used.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): PHYS 52 and MATH 32 or MATH 32X with a “C-” or better.

name: Astrophysics II
description: Physics of stellar structure and evolution; observed properties of stars; physics and chemistry of the interstellar medium; galaxies and cosmology.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): PHYS 52 and MATH 31 or MATH 31X with a “C-” or better. College of Science or Engineering Majors only.

description: Activities include mental and physical skill development for successful participation in NCAA intercollegiate women’s soccer including drills, assignments, film study, scrimmages and competitions not to exceed 20 hours per week.
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 8 units.

name: Women’s Skills Development, Soccer
description: Activities include sport specific fitness training and conditioning for successful participation in NCAA intercollegiate women’s soccer. Approximately 8 hours per week.
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 8 units.

repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 8 units.

description: Activities include sport specific fitness training and conditioning for successful participation in NCAA intercollegiate women’s water polo. Approximately 8 hours per week.
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 8 units.

name: Men’s Cross Country
description: Activities include mental and physical skill development for successful participation in NCAA intercollegiate men’s cross country including drills, assignments, film study, scrimmages and competitions not to exceed 20 hours per week.
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 8 units.

name: Men’s Skills Development, Cross Country
description: Activities include sport specific fitness training and conditioning for successful participation in NCAA intercollegiate men’s cross country. Approximately 8 hours per week.

repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 8 units.

name: Women’ Skills Development, Track & Field
description: Activities include sport specific fitness training and conditioning for successful participation in NCAA intercollegiate women’s track & field. Approximately 8 hours per week.

repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 8 units.

name: Men’s Skills Development, Water Polo
description: Activities include sport specific fitness training and conditioning for successful participation in NCAA intercollegiate men’s water polo. Approximately 8 hours per week.
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 8 units.

name: Men’s Track & Field
description: Activities include mental and physical skill development for successful participation in NCAA intercollegiate men’s track & field including drills, assignments, film study, scrimmages and competitions not to exceed 20 hours per week.
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 8 units.

name: Men’ Skills Development, Track & Field

name: Acoustics and Instrumentation
description: Fundamentals of the physics of sound and techniques for measuring and analyzing sound and sound environments related to audiological practice.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Matriculation into Doctor of Audiology Program.

name: Anatomy and Physiology
description: Anatomy and physiology of the auditory and vestibular systems, including outer ear, middle ear, and inner ear; embryologic origins and development of structures related to body systems.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Matriculation into Doctor of Audiology Program.

name: Psychoacoustics
description: Psychoacoustic theory and methods; auditory perception in normal hearing and hearing-impaired listeners. Includes lab demonstrations and projects.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Matriculation into Doctor of Audiology Program.

name: Audiological Assessment I
description: Evaluation of hearing using the standard audiological test battery (pure tone audiometrics, speech audiometry, acoustic immittance, and OAEs); differential diagnosis of hearing loss.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Matriculation into Doctor of Audiology Program.

name: Professional Issues I
description: Topics related to the professional practice of audiology, including: the role of professional associations; scope of practice; code of ethics; HIPPA regulations; introduction to interprofessional practice; introduction to evidence-based practice. Clinical observations and experiences that underscore concepts will be included.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Matriculation into the Doctor of Audiology Program.

name: Professional Issues II
description: Topics related to the professional practice of audiology, including patient and family counseling; report writing; role of audiologist in the IEF/IFSP process.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): AUD 505A.

name: Professional Issues III
description: Interprofessional identification, diagnosis, and treatment of adults and children with hearing loss and other disabilities including seminar discussion and clinical practicum experience.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Third year standing.

name: Professional Issues IV
description: Business practices in audiology, including billing and coding; practice management; interview strategies and processes for obtaining fourth year externships.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Third year standing.

name: Professional Issues V
description: Cultural competency, multicultural issues.

name: Anatomy and Physiology of the Central Auditory Nervous System (CANS)
description: The organization and function of the central auditory nervous system (CANS), including the effects of hearing loss on brain organization. The relationship between visual/proprioceptive systems and hearing and balance also will be examined.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): AUD 502 and AUD 503.

name: Hearing Aids I
description: Electroacoustical characteristics of hearing aids and group amplification systems. Topics include signal processing strategies and software used by audiologists to provide audible, intelligible, and comfortable amplification. Devices used in specialized hearing aid fittings also will be examined.

name: Audiological Assessment II
description: Advanced concepts in tympanometry and otoacoustic emissions, and their role in the evaluation and differential diagnosis of hearing loss.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): AUD 504.

name: Practicum in Audiology
description: Placement in SJSU on-campus audiology clinic for supervised training in providing audiological services to the local community. May be repeated for credit.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): AUD 504 and AUD 505A.

name: Clinical Rotation in Audiology I
description: Supervised clinical practice in audiology at an on-campus or off-site location. Doctoral students are expected to become increasingly independent and knowledgeable about patient care with each subsequent placement.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Successful completion of Fall and Spring year 1.

name: Clinical Rotation in Audiology II
description: Supervised clinical practice in audiology at an off-site location. Doctoral students are expected to become increasingly independent and knowledgeable about patient care with each subsequent placement.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Second year standing.

name: Clinical Rotation in Audiology III
description: Supervised clinical practice in audiology at an off-site location. Doctoral students are expected to become increasingly independent and knowledgeable about patient care with each subsequent placement.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Second year standing.

name: Clinical Rotation in Audiology IV
description: Supervised clinical practice in audiology at an off-site location. Doctoral students are expected to become increasingly independent and knowledgeable about patient care with each subsequent placement.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Second year standing.

name: Clinical Rotation in Audiology V
description: Supervised clinical practice in audiology at an off-site location. Doctoral students are expected to become increasingly independent and knowledgeable about patient care with each subsequent placement.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Third year standing.

name: Clinical Rotation in Audiology VI
description: Supervised clinical practice in audiology at an off-site location. Doctoral students are expected to become increasingly independent and knowledgeable about patient care with each subsequent placement.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Third year standing.

name: Clinical Rotation in Audiology VII
description: Supervised clinical practice in audiology at an off-site location. Doctoral students are expected to become increasingly independent and knowledgeable about patient care with each subsequent placement.

name: Pediatric Audiology
description: Topics related to hearing loss in children, including common etiologies and syndromes; newborn hearing screening procedures; and behavioral and electrophysiological diagnostic tests.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): AUD 504.

name: Pediatric Auditory Habilitation
description: Topics related to the management of children diagnosed with hearing loss, including: interprofessional practices; early intervention; communication modalities; hearing aid selection, provision, orientation, and follow up; FM systems; introduction to cochlear implants; Deaf community.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): AUD 505B and AUD 507.

name: Research Methods
description: Design and analysis of research experiments, including the role of evidence-based practice in patient care.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Second year standing.
satisfies: Satisfies GWAR: Graduation Writing Assessment Requirement.
notes: Note(s): This course satisfies graduate-level GWAR in this doctoral program.

name: Audiological Assessment III
description: Theoretical and applied aspects of electrophysiological testing, including: brainstem responses; middle-latency responses; and cognitive potentials.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Second year standing.

name: Hearing Aids II
description: Selection, fitting, and verification methods for optimizing hearing aid use, satisfaction, and benefits.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Second year standing.

name: Adult Auditory Rehabilitation
description: Topics related to the management of adults with hearing loss, including the impact of hearing loss on adults of all ages; diagnosis of handicap; communicative strategies; speechreading; individual and group therapy techniques.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Second year standing.

name: Audiological Assessment IV
description: Theoretical and applied aspects of vestibular assessment, including the administration and interpretation of electronystagmography (ENG), rotation, and posturography.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Second year standing.

name: Hearing Conservation
description: The effects of noise on hearing. Topics include definitions and measurement of occupational and recreational noise; changes in auditory physiology as a result of noise exposure; psychological effects of noise on function and productivity; federal and state regulations regarding workplace safety; and elements of hearing conservation programs (measurement; counseling; provision of ear protection).
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Second year standing.

name: Hearing Aids III
description: Advanced concepts in selecting, fitting, and verification of specialized hearing devices, including cochlear implants; middle-ear implants; assistive communication technologies for individuals with hearing loss.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Second year standing.

name: Medical Audiology
description: Pathologies of the ear and medical diagnosis and treatment; interprofessional practice in the audiological and medical community.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Second year standing.

name: Tinnitus
description: Etiology, diagnosis, and evidence-based treatments for patients with tinnitus.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Second year standing.

name: Pharmacology
description: Principles and applications of pharmacology for audiologists.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Second year standing.

name: Speech Perception and Language Development
description: Topics include normal speech and language development; effects of hearing loss on speech and language development; specialized tests of speech recognition in quiet and noise; and central auditory processing evaluation and treatment.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Third year standing.

name: Genetics
description: Applications of genetics for audiologists, including syndromes involving the auditory and vestibular systems.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Third year standing.

name: Clinical Externship in Audiology I
description: Full time clinical placement in an off-site facility. Placements coordinated by department chair.

name: Clinical Externship in Audiology II
description: Full time clinical placement in an off-site facility. Placements coordinated by department chair.

name: Clinical Externship in Audiology III
description: Full time clinical placement in an off-site facility.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s):  Fourth year standing; Successful completion of AUD 510E, AUD 526A, and AUD 526B.

name: Research Project
description: Readings and discussion of topics in preparation for doctoral student research. A research question and it’s justification, as well as an outline of the intended experimental process, will be finalized.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Second year standing.

name: Research Project II
description: Methodology for student research projects will be finalized and IRB approval obtained, if needed.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): AUD 598A.

name: Research Project III
description: Data collection and analysis for doctoral student research projects.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): AUD 598A and AUD 598B.

name: Research Project IV
description: Completion of student research projects; oral presentations.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): AUD 598A, AUD 598B, and AUD 598C.

name: Introduction to the Aviation Industry
description: Career planning, paths, and opportunities within the aviation industry. Concepts and knowledge building blocks for any aviation professional, including: history of aviation; qualifications and privileges of aviation professionals; basics of aeronautics.

name: Private Pilot Ground
description: Foundational concepts of aviation studies for professional pilots. Ground course for private pilot FAA certification. Aeronautics basics, weather, visual navigation, regulations, and operational environment for conducting flights under visual flight rules.
prereqs: Pre/Corequisite(s): AVIA 1

name: Introduction to Private Pilot Part 141 Flight
description: This course covers the FAA requirements leading up to the award of the FAA Private Pilot Certificate. The course consists of flight training segments in an FAA-approved FAR part 141 flight training program.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): AVIA 2

name: Aircraft Theory and Design
description: Aerodynamics and aeroelastics force. Load analysis of flight vehicles. Aircraft design optimization, material selection along with, safe-life, fail-safe and damage tolerance in design.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): AVIA 2, PHYS 2A,MATH 71 or MATH 71X.

name: Aircraft Systems
description: Operational and analytical aspects of key aircraft systems such as propulsion, flight control, electrical, and hydraulic. Reliability and maintainability concepts related to the design of aircraft systems. Emphasis is placed on general aviation aircraft.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): AVIA 1 or AVIA 2 , PHYS 2A.

name: Propulsion Theory
description: Propulsion theory of piston engines. Aircraft fuel systems and components. Fundamental systems, maintainability, and reliability methods. Aviation regulations related to engines. Maintenance cycles for engines and components.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): AVIA 1 or AVIA 2 , PHYS 2A.

name: Instrument Pilot Ground
description: Flight procedures, radio navigation, air traffic control, use of instrument charts. Flight simulator exercises on instrument flight maneuvers, departure and approach procedures.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): AVIA 2.

name: Instrument Rating Part 141 Flight
description: This course covers the FAA requirements leading up to the award of the FAA Instrument Rating Certificate. The course consists of 29 instrument flight training segments in an FAA approved FAR part 141 instrument flight training program.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): AVIA 3 or FAA Private Pilot Certificate, AVIA 73

name: Avionics and Airborne Communication
description: Communications and navigation systems installed on a typical general aviation aircraft. History of avionics. Laboratory exercises will include field-testing and airworthiness evaluation.
prereqs: Pre/Corequisite(s): AVIA 42.

name: Air Traffic Control
description: Air Traffic Control System Structure and Communications. Current configuration and future design of the National Airspace System. Oceanic and International Air Traffic Control. Automation issues and Emerging Technologies.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): AVIA 1 or AVIA 2.

name: Introduction to Aviation Management
description: History and fundamentals of aviation management. Pilot relations to Fixed Base Operators (FBOs). Overview of aviation human resources; basics of aviation maintenance and risk management. Basic financial management analysis.

name: Aircraft Turbine Engines
description: A study of gas turbine fundamentals, including various gas turbine cycles, components and component efficiency, thrust, specific fuel consumption, duct flow and inlet diffuser, centrifugal and axial compressors, combustion chambers and jet nozzles for aircraft propulsion.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): AVIA 43.

name: Aviation Weather
description: Introduction to meteorology with emphasis on aviation applications. Causes of weather, characteristics of common weather phenomena, and climatology. Aviation weather resources and reporting, and weather briefings in relation to visual and instrument meteorological conditions for flying.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): AVIA 73, AVIA 78

name: Commercial Pilot Ground
description: Material necessary for the FAA requirements leading up to the award of the FAA Commercial Pilot Certificate. Formatted as a ground school and covers the aeronautical knowledge requirements for the Commercial Pilot Knowledge Test.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): AVIA 31, AVIA 42, and AVIA 91.

name: Commercial Professional Pilot Part 141 Flight
description: This course covers the FAA requirements leading up to the award of the FAA Commercial Pilot Certificate. The course consists of 58 flight training segments in an FAA approved FAR part 141 flight training program.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): FAA Private Pilot Certificate

name: Certified Flight Instructor Preparation
description: A comprehensive ground school training course to prepare students to teach those seeking Recreational, Private, Commercial pilot certification, and to satisfactorily meet the requirements to pass the FAA Knowledge Exam FAR 61.185(a)(1) - Fundamentals of Instructing and FAR 61.185(a)(2) Flight/Ground Instructor.
prereqs: Pre/Corequisite(s): AVIA 112

name: Aircraft Multi-Engine Land Rating
description: Introduction to the Private and Commercial Aircraft Multi/Engine Land Airman Certification Standard (ACS) to evaluate performance. Designed to provide and prepare aviation students for an aircraft Multi-Engine Land Rating to a Private/Commercial Certificate.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): AVIA 2, AVIA 62.

name: Aviation Safety and Security
description: Safety in aviation design, operation, and maintenance; hazardous materials; airport environment issues; security regulations for aviation.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): AVIA 1 or AVIA 2.
sustainability: Sustainability Related - SDG 9: Industry, Innovation and Infrastructure

name: Aviation Cybersecurity
description: Fundamentals of cybersecurity and cyber risk management in aviation industry related to communication of information between aircraft and air traffic control and ground services. Impact of cyber attacks on flight data and safety. Implementation of cyber security in aviation.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): AVIA 78, AVIA 128.

name: Human Factors in Aviation
description: Effects of time zone changes, sleep disruption, drugs on pilot performance. Role of FAA inspectors, physicians, cabin attendants, unions. Cockpit crew coordination; pilot psychology; aviation safety and accident investigation. Experimental avionics.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): AVIA 73, AVIA 78

name: Unmanned Aerial Systems
description: Introduction to Unmanned Aerial Systems (UAS). Overview of UAS classes and typical UAS missions. Application of sensors/payload analysis, basic design concepts, current regulations in the U.S., and mishaps examination.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): AVIA 31 or Instructor Consent

name: Aviation Law
description: Law and legal issues in aviation from both a national and international perspective. Rights and responsibilities of individuals, organizations, and the aviation community. Regulations and liability pertaining to the design, manufacture, operation and maintenance of aircraft.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): AVIA 78.

name: Airline Operations and Management
description: Aspects of managing air transportation companies. Integration of technical, environmental, market and regulatory considerations in the decision-making process in airline management. Future planning techniques.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): AVIA 78
sustainability: Sustainability Related - SDG 9: Industry, Innovation and Infrastructure

name: General Aviation Operations and Management
description: Aspects of managing general aviation companies, such as the structure of the general aviation industry, supply and demand of products, and technical and regulatory constraints.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): AVIA 1 or AVIA 2.

name: Airport Planning and Management
description: Design, planning, and management of airports in the US including airport development and airport design. Legal responsibilities as an airport manager. Issues and regulations applicable to airport planning and management.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): AVIA 78.

name: Advanced Airport Planning and Management
description: Noise generation and abatement. Leasing and property management including the impact of federal regulations. Concession planning. Use of technology to increase efficiency and security in airports.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): AVIA 178.

name: Individual Studies
description: Special topics by arrangement. Course is repeatable for a maximum of 3 units.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Aviation majors or minors after advisor consultation and department chair approval.
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 3 units.

name: Individual Studies
description: Individual honors studies by arrangement. Course is repeatable for maximum of 2 units.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Acceptance into Aviation Honors Program.
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 2 units.

name: Senior Capstone Seminar
description: Current industry analysis and career development; leadership skills for an aviation professional. Aviation standard procedures. Ethical principles for Aviation. Student projects related to Aviation major.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Graduating senior, major form completed.

name: International Program Studies
description: Study Abroad and Away transfer credit course. Study Abroad and Away provides students the opportunity to study abroad on long term programs (Exchange Programs, CSU International Programs, and International Student Exchange Programs) and short-term programs (Faculty-Led Programs and Summer School Abroad Programs) for academic credit, offering Alternative Break Programs for cultural immersion, and designing other globally focused opportunities. This course is designated as a placeholder course for Study Abroad and Away programs.

name: Aerodynamics
description: Aerodynamic forces involved in an airplane in flight. Fundamental flowing gas, incompressible and compressible flow, Bernoulli’s Principles, circulation forces, boundary layer, airfoils, measurement methods, laminar and turbulent flow, force and vortex interactions.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): PHYS 2A, MATH 71 or MATH 71X, AVIA 31.

name: Pilot Avionics and General Aviation Systems
description: Operations of avionics as found on modern general aviation aircraft and turboprop/turbofan aircraft. Major systems used on general aviation aircraft including GPS, FMS, navigation systems, fuel systems, hydraulic systems, environmental systems, landing gear.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): AVIA 42, AVIA 43.

name: Internship with the Aviation Industry
description: Practical experience with aviation industry under direct supervision of aviation professionals. Experience will relate to air carrier or general aviation aircraft operation/management/maintenance, fixed-based operation management and/or airport operation/management. Course is repeatable for a maximum of 12 units.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Junior standing and instructor consent.
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 12 units.

name: Aviation and Human Civilization
description: Critical analysis of the role of aviation in human civilization focusing on cultures outside the US and how their development impacted US practices. Topics include: aviation early history; impact of aviation on global economy; gender disparity in the field.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Completion of Core General Education and upper division standing are prerequisites to all SJSU Studies courses. Completion of, or co-registration in, 100W is strongly recommended.
satisfies: Satisfies SJSU Studies V: Cultures and Global Understanding.

name: Special Topics in Aviation Management
description: Special topics in Aviation Management. Content varies from semester to semester. Course is repeatable for a total of 6 units.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Instructor consent.
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 6 units.

name: Special Topics in Aviation Operations
description: Special topics in Aviation Operations. Content varies from semester to semester. Course is repeatable for a total of 6 units.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Instructor consent.
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 6 units.

name: The Living World
description: Provides students with an understanding of the most fundamental concepts of modern biology including ecology (the interaction between organisms and their environment), human inheritance, the structure and function of living organisms, evolution, strategies for survival and reproduction, and biotechnology.
satisfies: Satisfies B2: Life Science.
sustainability: Sustainability Related - SDG 15: Life on Land
notes: Note(s): Not an elective in the department majors.

name: Ecological Biology
description: Introduction to diversity, ecology, evolution and behavior. In conjunction with BIOL 21 a more complete survey of biology.
satisfies: Satisfies B2 + B3: Life Science & Lab.
notes: Note(s): Not an elective in the department majors.

name: Human Biology
description: Introduction to physiology, reproduction, development, heredity and aging. With BIOL 20 a more complete survey of biology.
satisfies: Satisfies B2 + B3: Life Science & Lab.
notes: Note(s): Not an elective in the department majors.

name: Principles of Biology I
description: Cellular and physiological aspects of biological diversity. Concepts include: biomolecules, cellular structures/function, cell-cell communication, cellular energetics, molecular evolution, gene expression, enzymes, and animal physiological systems.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Writing Enrollment Group W-I or W-II, or ENGL 1AF with a grade of CR, or ENGL 1A with a grade of C- or better; Math Enrollment Group M-I or M-II, or completion of a GE Area B4 course. Must be majoring in Biology (all), Biomedical Eng, Biochemistry, ENVS (all), Forensic Science (all), Nutritional Science, Meterology-CS, Kinesiology, Computer Science, and Communicative Disorders.
satisfies: Satisfies B2 + B3: Life Science & Lab.

name: Principles of Biology II
description: The diversity of life and the mechanisms by which that diversity has arisen. Concepts include: scientific method, origins of life, adaptation of organisms to different environments, ecology, and evolution.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): BIOL 30 (with a grade of “C-” or better for all Biology majors). Must be majoring in Biology (all), Biomedical Eng, Biochemistry, Forensic Science (all), Environmental Studies (all), Nutritional Science, Meteorology - Climate Science Concentration, Kinesiology, Computer Science, and Communicative Disorders.
satisfies: Satisfies B1 + B3: Physical + Lab Science

name: Human Understanding
description: Major issues in health and disease, learning and memory, maturation and aging (such as diet, exercise, mind-body medicine, and addictions). Emphasis on learning how to understand and apply physiologic information for personal growth and lifelong learning.
satisfies: Satisfies E: Human Understanding & Development.

name: Biostatistics
description: Introductory experimental design and statistical analysis of biological data from manipulated experiments. Experience in designing and analyzing experiments utilizing both univariate and multivariate tests.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): BIOL 30 or BIOL 31 with a grade of C- or better, or instructor consent. Must be a declared Biology Major (all) or Environmental Studies Major (all).

name: Human Anatomy
description: Introductory study of gross and microscopic human anatomy including corresponding pathology. For majors in nursing and kinesiology.
satisfies: Satisfies B2 + B3: Life Science & Lab.
notes: Note(s): Not an elective in the department majors.

name: Human Anatomy
description: Introductory study of gross and microscopic human anatomy including corresponding pathology. For majors in nursing and kinesiology. This online anatomy course is not intended for students pursuing degrees in kinesiology, recreation (therapeutic recreation) or to meet the anatomy prerequisite for occupational therapy at SJSU. Students who intend to transfer the human anatomy course to another institution which requires an “in class” lab should enroll in BIOL 65.
satisfies: Satisfies B2 + B3: Life Science & Lab.
notes: Note(s): Not an elective in the department majors.

name: Human Physiology
description: Explanation of physiological principles from the molecular and cellular-levels to organ systems. Neural and endocrine controls and integration among systems. Health care orientation.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): High school algebra. Recommended: Human Anatomy, CHEM 30A.
satisfies: Satisfies B2 + B3: Life Science & Lab.
notes: Note(s): Not an elective in the major departments. A grade of “C” or better is required to receive B2 and B3 GE credit.

name: Scientific Communication Workshop
description: Analysis and communication of scientific research to both scientific and general audiences. Satisfies upper division writing requirement.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): BIOL 30 and BIOL 31 (with grades of “C-” or better); A3 or equivalent second semester composition course (with a grade of C- or better); completion of core GE; and upper division standing. Or Graduate or Postbaccalaureate level. Allowed Declared Majors: Biology (all).
satisfies: Satisfies SJSU Studies R: Earth, Environment, and Sustainability + Writing in the Disciplines (WID).
notes: Note(s): Must be passed with C or better to satisfy the CSU Graduation Writing Assessment Requirement (GWAR).

name: Origins of Life
description: Process of evolution, fossil evidence for life origins, and the place of humans in nature.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Completion of Core General Education and upper division standing are prerequisites to all SJSU studies courses. Completion of, or co-registration in, 100W is strongly recommended.
satisfies: Satisfies SJSU Studies R: Earth, Environment, and Sustainability.
notes: Note(s): Not an elective in the Biological Sciences Department majors.

name: Principles of Developmental Biology
description: Emphasis on human development. Other animal systems (fly, frog, chick, mouse) will also be studied to aid in understanding anatomical, physiological, genetic and molecular mechanisms operating during gametogenesis, fertilization, cleavage, gastrulation and organogenesis.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): BIOL 30 and BIOL 31  (with a grade of “C-” or better in each), or instructor consent; BIOL 115 (with a grade of “C” or better). Must be a declared Biology Major (all).

name: Physiological Ecology
description: Study of the interaction of an organism with its environment. Looking at both plants and animals, students examine how both structure and function interact to enable an organism to survive under particular environmental conditions.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): BIOL 113 or (with a grade of “C” or better); BIOL 100W; CHEM 8 or CHEM 112A and CHEM 112B (with a grade of “C-” or better), upper division standing, or instructor consent. Must be a declared major in Biological Sciences.
sustainability: Sustainability Related - SDG 15: Life on Land

name: Physiological Ecology Lab
description: Experimental labs that illustrate/demonstrate key physiological concepts of plant and animal adaptations to their environment, as discussed in the lecture section, BIOL 106 - Physiological Ecology.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): BIOL 113 (with a grade of “C” or better); BIOL 100W; CHEM 8 or CHEM 112A and CHEM 112B (with a grade of “C-” or better), upper division standing, or instructor consent. Must be a declared major in Biological Sciences.

name: Immunology
description: Provides information about all areas of immunology with emphasis on the basic concepts of immune mechanisms of the acquired and innate immune systems. Uses the basic information to study immune disorders and the immune response to infectious agents.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): MICR 101 (with a grade of “C” or better), or instructor consent. Must be a declared Biology Major (all).

name: Immunology Laboratory
description: The experiments in this beginning immunology laboratory are designed to study both the innate and acquired immune systems. Experimentation into the formation, function and detection of antibodies provides students with skills in basic immunologic techniques. Flow cytometry is used in identification of immune cells as well as functional assays of complement mediated phagocytosis.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Must be a declared Biology Major (all).

name: Human Neuroanatomy and Physiology
description: Gross and microscopic structure and function of the human nervous system. Introduction to experimental and clinical techniques.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): BIOL 65 or instructor consent
notes: Note(s): Not an elective in the department majors.

name: Biodiversity and Biopolitics
description: Application of ecological principles to the conservation of biodiversity and the management of ecosystems. Analysis of biological, economic, social and political interrelationships involved in conservation.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Completion of Core General Education and upper division standing are prerequisites to all SJSU studies courses. Completion of, or co-registration in, 100W is strongly recommended.
satisfies: Satisfies SJSU Studies R: Earth, Environment, and Sustainability.
sustainability: Sustainability Focused - SDG 15: Life on Land
notes: Note(s): Not an elective in the Biological Sciences Department majors.

name: Fire Ecology
description: Fire is a fundamental ecological process in many terrestrial ecosystems. Examination of fire ecology and ecologically-based management of a variety of ecosystems.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Any GE Area B1 or B2 class. Biology major (all) or Wildfire Science minor. Other majors considered with instructor consent.

name: Principles of Systematics
description: Students gain the understanding and skills needed to taxonomically study biodiversity, including the use of morphological and DNA sequence characters to examine phylogeny, and use of a range of biodiversity research techniques and tools.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): BIOL 115 or BIOL 118 (with a grade of “C” or better), or instructor consent. Must be a declared Biology Major (all).
crosslist: Cross-listed with BOT 113 / ENT 113 / ZOOL 113. Biological Sciences is responsible for scheduling.

name: Functional Morphology
description: Develops understanding and skills needed to taxonomically study biodiversity, including the use of morphological and DNA sequence characters to examine phylogeny, and use of a range of biodiversity research techniques and tools.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): BIOL 115 or BIOL 118 (with a grade of “C” or better), or instructor consent. Must be a declared Biology Major (all).
crosslist: Cross-listed with BOT 114 / ENT 114 / ZOOL 114. Biological Sciences is responsible for scheduling.

name: General Genetics
description: Principles and methods of microbial, plant and animal genetics. Mendelism, cytogenetics, molecular genetics, mutation, quantitative genetics and genetic aspects of evolution.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): BIOL 30 and BIOL 31 (with a grade of “C-” or better in each), or instructor consent; CHEM 1A and CHEM 1B  (with a grade of “C” or better in each). Must be a declared Biology (all) or Chemistry (all) or Forensic Science (Biology concentration only) major.

name: Molecular Genetics
description: Molecular genetics of eukaryotes. Replication, repair, mutation, regulation of gene expression, gene organization and methods of recombinant DNA research.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): BIOL 115 or MICR 166, and CHEM 135 (all with a grade of “C” or better). Must be a declared Biological Sciences BS, Molecular Biology concentration major. Other Biological Sciences majors must get instructor consent.

name: Molecular Genetics Laboratory
description: Lab experience in modern molecular biology techniques used in research and industry settings. Techniques may include nucleic acid purification, enzymatic modification of nucleic acids, recombinant DNA cloning, PCR, Quantitative PCR, bacterial transformation and culture, agarose gel electrophoresis. The techniques chosen depend upon the course instructor.

name: Human Genetics
description: Mendelian traits, classical and molecular cytogenetics, DNA variation, sex determination, gene mapping, mutation, population genetics, multifactorial inheritance, genetic counseling and prenatal diagnosis.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): BIOL 115 (with a grade of “C” or better). Must be a declared Biology Major (all).

name: Evolution
description: An analysis of the patterns and processes of biological evolution. Topics include: history and philosophy of evolutionary thought; macroevolution and biogeography; selection, adaptation, and other forces; sexual selection and behavior; genetics, genomics, and the molecular basis of evolution.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): BIOL 30 and BIOL 31  (with a grade of “C-” or better in each for Biology Majors). Must be a declared Biology or Chemistry Major (all).
sustainability: Sustainability Related - SDG 15: Life on Land

name: Neurogenetics
description: Cellular and molecular neuroscience at the neuron, synapse and circuit level, including electrical and chemical signaling. Neurophysiology of development, maintenance and modification of neural circuits. Molecular genetics of neurological disorders such as autism, schizophrenia, Alzheimer’s disease, and mood disorders.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): BIOL 115 (with a grade of “C” or better). Must be a declared Biology Major (all).

name: Bacterial Diversity
description: Study of the characteristics and microecology of unusual prokaryotes. Molecular and traditional approaches will be discussed.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): MICR 101 (with a grade of “C” or better), or instructor consent. Must be a declared Biology Major (all).
crosslist: Cross-listed with MICR 122. Biological Sciences is responsible for scheduling.
sustainability: Sustainability Related - SDG 15: Life on Land

name: Bacterial Diversity Laboratory
description: Laboratory techniques in bacterial diversity.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): MICR 101 (with grade of “C” or better) or Instructor Consent. Must be a declared Biology Major (all).
crosslist: Cross-listed with MICR 122L. Biological Sciences is responsible for scheduling.

name: Bioinformatics I
description: Introduction to algorithms, tools, and databases of Bioinformatics. Biological foundations: central dogma; sequence databases; pairwise alignment algorithms and tools; Blast; phylogenetics. Possible additional topics: protein structure, multiple sequence alignment, next-gen sequencing, epigenetics, CRISPR. Project applying these approaches to real-world problems.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): CS 46B or BIOL 31, or instructor consent; Allowed Majors: Computer Science, Data Science, Software Engineering, Biology, Chemistry or MS Bioinformatics.
crosslist: Cross-listed with CS 123A / SE 123A. Computer Science is responsible for scheduling.

name: Bioinformatics II
description: Advanced Bioinformatics algorithms, tools, databases. Biological background; protein structure/function; sequencing technology; sequence identification; transcriptomics; metagenomics; CRISPR. Possible additional topics: functional genomics; protein networks; drug discovery; pathway analysis; immunoinformatics; analysis pipelines; machine learning applications. Project applying advanced approaches to real-world problems.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): CS 123A / BIOL 123A / SE 123A; Allowed Majors: Computer Science, Data Science, Software Engineering, Biology, Chemistry or MS Bioinformatics.
crosslist: Cross-listed with CS 123B / SE 123B. Computer Science is responsible for scheduling.

name: Systems Physiology
description: Physiology of organ systems with emphasis on the human. Neural & hormonal communication, muscle, cardiovascular, respiratory, urinary, digestive, endocrine, and reproductive physiology.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): BIOL 115; PHYS 2A, PHYS 2B ; CHEM 112A, CHEM 112B ; All courses with a “C or better”. Must be a declared Biology Major (all).

name: Systems Physiology Laboratory
description: Selected lab units to demonstrate complex physiological mechanisms and the physiology of organ systems. Methods include animal experiments and physiological recording and stimulation.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Must be a declared Biology Major (all).

name: Neuroscience
description: Principles of brain organization and function underlying behavior. Topics include neuroanatomy and physiology of language, vision, sexual behavior, memory and abnormal behavior.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Either PSYC 30 and 3 units of biology, or 9 units of biology.
crosslist: Cross-listed with PSYC 129. Psychology is responsible for scheduling.
notes: Note(s): Not acceptable as an elective in the Biology major.

name: Endocrine Physiology
description: Emphasis on mammalian systems. Mechanisms of hormone action, secretion and physiological effects; hormone assay techniques.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): BIOL 124 (with grade of “C-” or better), or instructor consent. Must be a declared Biology Major (all).

name: Vertebrate Histology
description: Light and electron microscopic structure of vertebrate tissues with consideration of related functions. Emphasis on the examination of human tissues including corresponding pathology.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): BIOL 124 (with grade of “C-” or better), or instructor consent. Must be a declared Biology Major (all).

name: Eukaryotic Cell and Molecular Biology I
description: First semester of a year-long cell and molecular biology course. Topics include membrane structure, signal transduction, cytoskeletal structure, cell migration, and gene expression.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): BIOL 115, CHEM 112A, CHEM 112B, and CHEM 135 (with a grade of “C” or better in each). Must be a declared Biology major.

name: Eukaryotic Cell and Molecular Biology II
description: BIOL 135B is the second semester of a year-long cell and molecular biology course. Topics covered include chromosome structure and maintenance, stem cell biology, cell death, and cancer biology.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): BIOL 115; BIOL 135A; BIOL 100W (with a grade of “C” or better in each). Must be a declared Biology Major (all).
satisfies: Satisfies SJSU Studies R: Earth, Environment, and Sustainability.

name: Molecular Cell Biology Lab
description: Lab experience in nucleic acid and protein purification, enzyme assay, bacterial and mammalian cell culture, immunofluorescence, column chromatography, agarose and polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis, spectrophotometry, light microscopy, etc.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): BIOL 135A (with grade of “C” or better), or instructor consent. Must be a declared Biology Major (all).

name: Vertebrate Neurophysiology
description: Review of topics from the molecular to the organismal level. Chemical and electrotonic phenomena of membranes, neurochemistry, sensory transduction, information coding, neural control, and additional rotating topics.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): BIOL 124 (with a grade of “C-” or better), or instructor consent. Must be a declared Biology Major (all).

name: Vertebrate Neurophysiology Laboratory
description: Course-based undergraduate research experience using electrophysiological techniques to study nervous system function. Topics include chemical and electrotonic phenomena of membranes, information coding, and additional rotating topics.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): BIOL 124 with a C- or better.

name: Introduction to Principles of Toxicology
description: Emphasis on basic principles of toxicology. Toxicity of several classes of compounds covered in depth. Focus on basic chemical principles and appropriate applications.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): BIOL 124; CHEM 112B (all with a grade of “C-” or better). Must be a declared Biology Major (all).
sustainability: Sustainability Related - SDG 3: Good Health and Well-Being

name: Stem Cell Biology
description: Topics in the growing field of stem cell biology. Topics include: properties of embryonic and adult stem cells, use of stem cells in scientific research, regulation of stem cells, and invertebrate and vertebrate models of stem cell research.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): BIOL 115 with a C or better. Must be a declared Biology Major (all).

name: Cancer Biology
description: Basic principles of cancer biology needed to gain an overall understanding of cellular and molecular events that lead to the formation and progression of cancer. Topics include normal and abnormal cell behaviors, the steps leading to the development of malignancy, in-depth discussions of specific cancers, such as breast, colon, and myeoloid leukemias, and the development of diagnostic tools and therapies.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): BIOL 115 with a C or better, or instructor consent. Must be a declared Biology Major (all).

name: Human Sexuality
description: Biological and sociocultural facets of human sexuality. Evolution and physiology of sex, reproductive biology/ethics and cross-cultural expression of sexual behavior.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Completion of Core General Education and upper division standing are prerequisites to all SJSU studies courses. Completion of, or co-registration in, 100W is strongly recommended.
satisfies: Satisfies SJSU Studies S: Self, Society & Equality in U.S.
crosslist: Cross-listed with ANTH 140 / PH 140. Anthropology is responsible for scheduling.
notes: Note(s): Not acceptable as an elective in the Biology major.

name: Paleontology
description: Study of the major groups of invertebrate and vertebrate fossils and their use in the study of geology, paleoecology, and macroevolution.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): GEOL 1 and GEOL 7, or instructor consent.
crosslist: Cross-listed with GEOL 142. Geology is responsible for scheduling.

name: Biogeography
description: Examination of the patterns of biodiversity over space and through time. Using data and models from a variety of sources including botany, zoology, ecology, evolutionary biology, paleontology, and geology, effects of isolation, elevation, and latitude are examined to understand spatial patterns of biodiversity.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): BIOL 31 or equivalent (with a grade of “C-” or better), or instructor consent. Must be a declared Biology Major (all).
crosslist: Cross-listed with BOT 143 / ENT 143 / ZOOL 143. Biological Sciences is responsible for scheduling.
sustainability: Sustainability Related

name: Advanced Undergraduate Biology Seminar
description: Undergraduate Seminar in Biology. May be taken concurrently with BIOL 145L.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Completion of 9 units of upper division major coursework, or instructor consent. Must be a declared Biology Major.

name: Advanced Undergraduate Biology Lab
description: Advanced undergraduate laboratory or field experience. May be taken concurrently with BIOL 145. Course is repeatable for credit when content changes.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Completion of nine (9) units of upper division majors’ coursework. Instructor Consent. Must be a declared Biology Major (all).

name: Molecular Ecology
description: Applying molecular genetics approaches to ecological questions. Topics include: population genetics/genomics, landscape genetics/genomics, conservation genetics/genomics, non-invasive sampling, eDNA, etc. Lab section includes experience in modern molecular biology techniques.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): BIOL 118 or BIOL 115 with a grade of C or better is required. Must be a declared Biology Major (all).

name: Field Studies in Natural History
description: Field courses given on site, typically covering general ecology, botany, geology, zoology and specialized natural areas such as Baja California, Death Valley, seacoasts and mountains. Repeatable for up to a total of 3 units of credit when location or content changes.
satisfies: Satisfies B3: Laboratory Science.
crosslist: Cross-listed with GEOL 150. Biological Sciences is responsible for scheduling.
sustainability: Sustainability Related - SDG 15: Life on Land
notes: Note(s): Not an elective in the department majors.

name: Hypothesis Testing
description: Experimental design and statistical analysis of biological data from manipulative experiments. Experience in designing and analyzing experiments using t-tests, 1- and 2-way ANOVA, Randomized Block ANOVA, Nested ANOVA, Linear Regression and Tests of Independence.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): BIOL 30 and BIOL 31  (with grade of “C-” or better), or instructor consent. Must be a declared Biology or Environmental Studies Major (all).

name: Ecological Sampling Design and Analyses
description: Sampling design and statistical analysis of biological patterns. In this course, students design and execute a field experiment (one required weekend field trip) that incorporates multivariate measurements. Students analyze the data with Log Linear analysis, Logistic Regression, Principal Components Analysis, Canonical Correlation and various Regression techniques.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): BIOL 113 or (with a grade of “C” or better), or instructor consent. Must be a declared Biology or Environmental Studies or Business Majors.

name: Integrative Biology
description: Capstone course in the BA Biological Science degree. Critical reading of scientific literature, experimental design and scientific communication skills will be emphasized. Topics covered may vary for a given semester.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Senior standing, completion of A3, ENGL 1B, HUM 2B, or equivalent with a C- or better; BIOL 115 or BIOL 118; BIOL 55 or BIOL 155, (all with grade of “C” or better). Allowed Declared Majors: BIOL majors only.
satisfies: Satisfies SJSU Studies R: Earth, Environment, and Sustainability.

name: Ecology
description: Factors that influence the distribution and abundance of organisms; some aspects of applied ecology.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): BIOL 113 (with a grade of “C or better”); Allowed Declared Majors (Biology, Natural Science); Completion of Core General Education and upper division standing are prerequisites to all SJSU studies courses. Completion of, or co-registration in, 100W is strongly recommended.
satisfies: Satisfies SJSU Studies R: Earth, Environment, and Sustainability for Biology Majors only.
crosslist: Cross-listed with BOT 160. Biological Sciences is responsible for scheduling.
sustainability: Sustainability Focused
notes: Note(s): All of SJSU Studies courses require completion of the WST and upper division standing.

name: Marine Ecology and Biology
description: Introduction to the major ecological processes that determine the structure and diversity of species assemblages in marine and estuarine environments through field-oriented activities.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): BIOL 55/BIOL 155 or BIOL 156, BIOL 115 or BIOL 118; must be a declared Biology Major (all); or instructor consent.

name: Introduction to Biological Oceanography
description: Introduction to the major physical, chemical, ecological, and biological processes, including human influences, that govern life in marine environments.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): BIOL 55/BIOL 155 or BIOL 156, and BIOL 115 or BIOL 118; all with a grade of ”C” or better. Must be a Biology Major (all).

name: Conservation Biology
description: Principles of conservation biology, including management for the preservation of biodiversity and maintenance of viable populations. Examples from plants and animals
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): BIOL 113 (with grade of “C” or better), or instructor consent. Must be a declared major in Biological Sciences.
sustainability: Sustainability Focused - SDG 15: Life on Land

name: Ecological Field Methods
description: Techniques for evaluating and managing the abundance and diversity of plants and animals.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): BIOL 113 or (with a grade of “C” or better), or instructor consent. Must be a declared major in Biological Sciences.
sustainability: Sustainability Focused - SDG 15: Life on Land

name: Advanced Human Anatomy
description: Study of human anatomy, including clinical correlations, for pre-professional students. Not open to student who have completed BIOL 065.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): BIOL 30 and BIOL 31  (with a grade of “C-” or better in each), BIOL 115 (with a grade of “C” or better), or instructor consent. Must be a declared Biology Major (all).

name: Cardiorespiratory Physiology
description: Covers the normal anatomy and physiology of the cardiovascular and respiratory systems, as well as how they function following perturbations in homeostasis. Focuses on the mammalian system with some discussion of comparative physiology.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): BIOL 124 (with a grade of “C-” or better), or instructor consent. Must be a declared Biology Major (all).

name: Reproductive Physiology
description: Reproductive Physiology covers the anatomy and physiology of the reproductive system, as well as how deviations from the norm affect reproduction. Course focuses on the mammalian system with discussion of comparative physiology.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): BIOL 124 (with a grade of “C-” or better), or instructor consent. Must be a declared Biology Major (all).

name: Cellular and Molecular Physiology
description: Introduction to the structure and physiological function of cells.  Topics include synthesis of cellular macromolecules such as DNA, RNA and proteins; internal cellular organization; biochemical reactions necessary for cell growth, death and cellular communication.  Relevant pathophysiology examples of cellular dysfunction are presented.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): BIOL 124 (with a grade of “C-” or better), or instructor consent. Must be a declared Biology Major (all).

name: Physiology for Engineers
description: Structure and function of physiological systems and discussion of topics of particular importance to the design, development, construction and clinical application of biomedical devices. Practical laboratory application of technologies to monitor, repair, replace or augment physiological systems.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): BIOL 30, CHEM 1B, PHYS 50
crosslist: Cross-listed with BME 177. Biomedical Engineering is responsible for scheduling.

name: Integrative Physiology
description: Integrative Physiology is the capstone course in the Systems Physiology concentration. The specific physiology topics covered may vary depending on the semester. Critical reading of scientific literature, experimental design and scientific communication skills will be emphasized.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): BIOL 100W and BIOL 115 (with a grade of “C” or better); BIOL 124 (with a grade of “C-” or better); at least one upper division systems physiology elective; completion of Core General Education and upper division standing are prerequisites to all SJSU studies courses. Must be a declared Biology Major (all).
satisfies: Satisfies SJSU Studies R: Earth, Environment, and Sustainability for Biology Majors only.

name: Individual Studies
description: Undergraduate advanced lab or field work in special fields.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Instructor consent. Must be a declared Biology Major (all). Not available to Open University Students.

name: Introduction to Health Care
description: Participation and observation with a medical doctor, dentist, optometrist, pharmacist, or veterinarian in private practice, hospital or retail setting.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Instructor consent. Must be a declared Biology Major (all). Not available to Open University Students.
notes: Note(s): Hepatitis B or other vaccinations may be required in some settings.

name: Tutor Assistant in Biology
description: Supervised classroom or field experience as a tutor-assistant in experiments, demonstrations and discussion. Course may be repeated for credit.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Sophomore or Upper division standing, instructor consent and appropriate academic background. Not available to Open University Students. Must be a declared Biology Major (all).

name: Directed Reading
description: Assigned readings of selected books, journals and papers chosen to fill gaps in training or for contact with new fields. Evaluation through weekly reports and conferences.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Instructor consent. Not available to Open University Students. Must be a declared Biology Major (all).

name: Senior Thesis
description: Advanced library, laboratory or field research under the supervision of a faculty member, culminating in a senior thesis.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Instructor consent. Not available to Open University Students. Must be a declared Biology Major (all).

name: Field Studies in Biology
description: Field program involving planning and execution of a project. Course is repeatable for a maximum of 12 units.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Instructor consent. Not available to Open University Students. Must be a declared Biology Major (all).
sustainability: Sustainability Related - SDG 15: Life on Land

name: Undergraduate Research
description: Field or laboratory biological research under the direction of a faculty member.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Instructor consent. Must be a declared Biology Major (all).

name: Graduate Seminar in Biological Sciences
description: Seminar designed to introduce principles and topics in biological research. Mandatory during first semester of enrollment.
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 4 units.

name: Graduate Studies in Biology
description: A seminar on current research and theory in the life sciences, emphasizing scientific writing and formal oral presentations.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Instructor consent.
satisfies: Satisfies GWAR: Graduation Writing Assessment Requirement.
notes: Note(s): This course satisfies graduate-level GWAR in this master’s program.

name: Biotech Seminar: Biotech Products
description: Seminar course in which students develop professional skills in writing, speaking, literature review, and critical thinking. Assignments are targeted at developing expertise and knowledge useful in the biotechnology industry. Focuses on biotechnology products.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Enrollment in the Master of Biotechnology Program.
satisfies: Satisfies GWAR: Graduation Writing Assessment Requirement.
notes: Note(s): This course satisfies graduate-level GWAR in this master’s program.

name: Biotech Seminar: Drug Development Process
description: Seminar course in which students develop their professional skills. Assignments are targeted at developing expertise and knowledge useful in the biotechnology industry. Focuses on the development of drugs and other biotechnology products.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Enrollment in the Master of Biotechnology Program.
satisfies: Satisfies GWAR: Graduation Writing Assessment Requirement.
notes: Note(s): This course satisfies graduate-level GWAR in this master’s program.

name: Biotech Seminar: Biotech Business I
description: BIOL 202TC is a seminar course in which students develop their professional skills. Assignments are targeted at developing expertise and knowledge useful in the biotechnology and pharmaceutical industries. BIOL 202TC focuses on the financial aspects of business development in biotechnology.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Enrollment in the Master of Biotechnology Program.

name: Biotech Seminar: Biotech Business II
description: Seminar course in which students develop their professional skills. Assignments target developing expertise and knowledge useful in the biotechnology and pharmaceutical industries. Focuses on business development in biotechnology and a team project in which students develop a business plan.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): BIOL 202TC or instructor consent

name: Biology Teaching Forum
description: Introduction to effective methods for teaching undergraduate biology laboratories, activities, seminars and/or lectures. Emphasis on pedagogy and application of best practices and strategies for teaching biology to a diverse audience. Course administration, student conduct and expectations, and assessment will also be covered.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): graduate standing or instructor consent

name: Advanced Molecular Techniques
description: Emphasizes the laboratory techniques of modern molecular biology. Depending on instructor, focus will be on animal, plant, yeast, bacterial or viral systems. Course is repeatable for credit if content changes.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): BIOL 135L or instructor consent.

name: Advanced Molecular Techniques for Biotechnology
description: Emphasizes the laboratory techniques of modern molecular biology especially: report writing and communication of research results. Depending on instructor, focus will be on animal, plant, yeast, bacterial, or viral systems.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): BIOL 135L and admission into the Master of Biotechnology program.

name: Seminar in Advanced Genetics
description: Selected topics of current interest in advanced genetics. Each semester will emphasize a particular field of genetics; e.g., molecular genetics, human genetics, developmental genetics, population genetics, etc.

name: Advanced Evolution
description: Integrated use of modern molecular techniques and classical evolutionary theory to address a broad array of questions in evolutionary biology.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): BIOL 115 and instructor consent.

name: Science Communication
description: This course will focus on learning to effectively present ongoing scientific research to a wide audience, with an emphasis on developing science communication skills, learning to place data within the context of a field, and developing critical thinking skills.
prereqs: Pre/Corequisite(s): BIOL 202

name: Advanced Bioinformatics for Biotechnology
description: Bioinformatics/computer applications to solve advanced problems in molecular and cell biology by manipulation and analysis of DNA, RNA, and protein sequences.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): BIOL 116 or either CHEM 130A, CHEM 135, or Chem 136 and admission into the Master of Biotechnology program.

name: Advanced Physiology
description: Integrated discussion of modern physiological techniques to address a broad array of questions in physiology. Each semester will emphasize a particular field of physiology.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing and completion of an upper division physiology course or instructor consent.

name: Principles of Pharmacology
description: Principles of pharmacology, especially as related to the pharmaceutical industry and clinical applications.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): BIOL 30 or equivalent; Physiology recommended

name: Biotechnology Instrumentation
description: Introduction to the principles of operation of common instruments used in the biotechnology and pharmaceutical industries. Includes understanding and experience with calibration, detection mechanisms, data output, trouble-shooting and decision making process.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Enrollment in the Master of Biotechnology program.

name: Comparative Animal Physiology
description: A seminar in the functional relationships of invertebrates and vertebrates. Evolutionary patterns and environmental adaptations are considered.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): An upper division course in physiology or instructor consent.

name: Immunological Techniques
