prereqs: Prerequisite(s): BIOL 123B and MATH 162 or CS 156 or CS 171, or instructor consent. Graduate standing. Allowed Declared Major: MS Computer Science, MS Bioinformatics, MS Data Science.

name: User Interface Design
description: Human-computer interaction principles. Direct manipulation, focus plus context, interaction history; interfaces for websites and website collections; usability testing; role of metaphors; case studies; advanced topics include information visualization, interfaces for collaboration, intelligent interfaces, and software agents.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): CS 130 or CS 116A, and Graduate standing. Allowed Declared Major: Computer Science, Bioinformatics, Data Science. Or instructor consent.

name: Advanced Computer Architecture
description: Advanced topics in vector architectures, including: pipelined architectures, dataflow computers, VLSI architectures, butterfly connections; bus and memory architectures; cache structures; hardware implementations of algorithms.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): CS 147, CS 149, and Graduate standing. Allowed Declared Major: Computer Science, Bioinformatics, Data Science. Or instructor consent.

name: Distributed Computing
description: Current issues in operating systems, including multiprocessor systems and distributed computing, networks, security and performance. Case studies of current operating systems.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): CS 149 and Graduate standing. Allowed Declared Major: Computer Science, Bioinformatics, Data Science. Or instructor consent.

name: Obj Oriented Anlys
description: Introduction to important concepts, activities, and artifacts of the analysis and design phases of object-oriented software development. Use of CASE tools, UML, and pattern catalogs to build requirements models, domain models, design models, and reusable frameworks for a variety of software systems.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): CS 160 and Graduate standing. Allowed Declared Major: Computer Science, Bioinformatics, Data Science. Or instructor consent.

name: Advanced Programming Language Principles
description: Language design and paradigms, including concepts underlying functional, logic, object-oriented and parallel paradigms. Theoretical foundations, including lambda calculus, denotational and axiomatic semantics. Proofs of program correctness. Programming projects emphasizing different aspects of language design.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): CS 152 and Graduate standing. Allowed Declared Major: Computer Science, Bioinformatics, Data Science. Or instructor consent.

name: Advanced Compiler Design
description: Review of attribute analysis and static semantic evaluation. Runtime environments and code generation. Basic blocks and flow graphs. Register allocation and storage classes. Common subexpression elimination and constant propagation. Loop optimizations. Global data flow analysis. Completion of a code optimization project.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): CS 153 and Graduate standing. Allowed Declared Major: Computer Science, Bioinformatics, Data Science. Or instructor consent.

name: Theory of Computation
description: Models of computation; decidability; complexity measures; hierarchies; P, NP and other complexity classes; intractable problems.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): CS 154 and Graduate standing. Allowed Declared Major: Computer Science, Bioinformatics, Data Science. Or instructor consent.

name: Design and Analysis of Algorithms
description: Randomized algorithms. Parallel algorithms. Distributed algorithms. NP-completeness of particular problems. Approximation algorithms.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): CS 155 and Graduate standing. Allowed Declared Major: Computer Science, Bioinformatics, Data Science. Or instructor consent.

name: Topics in Artificial Intelligence
description: Introduction to topics in artificial intelligence such as problem solving methods, game playing, understanding natural languages, pattern recognition, computer vision and the general problem of representing knowledge. Students will be expected to use LISP.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): CS 156 and Graduate standing. Allowed Declared Major: Computer Science, Bioinformatics, Data Science. Or instructor consent.

name: Database System Principles
description: Design management and performance issues on: file organization and access methods, buffer management and storage management. Query processing and query optimization, transaction management, recovery, and concurrency control techniques. Reliability, protection and integrity techniques. Extensive programming project.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): CS 157B and Graduate standing. Allowed Declared Major: Computer Science, Bioinformatics, Data Science. Or instructor consent.

name: Computer Communication Systems
description: Design, analysis and survey of the latest advancements in network and Internet technologies, such as supporting TCP/IP over various network media, software-defined networks, networks supporting cloud computing, network security, peer-to-peer and overlay networks, and quality of services.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): CS 158A and Graduate standing. Allowed Declared Major: Computer Science, Bioinformatics, Data Science. Or instructor consent.

name: Advanced Parallel Processing
description: An advanced hardware architecture and software development class focused on multi-threaded, parallel processing algorithms and techniques. A study of high-performance parallel hardware architectures and parallel programming languages. Applications of parallel and GPU processing, including computer gaming.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing. Allowed Declared Major: Computer Science, Bioinformatics, Data Science. Or instructor consent.

name: Randomized Algorithms and Applications
description: Design and analysis of algorithms which incorporate randomness in their design. Applications will be given in several of the following areas: data structures, pattern matching, cryptography, parallel computing, distributed computing, and interactive proof systems.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): CS 154 or CS 155, and Graduate standing. Allowed Declared Major: Computer Science, Bioinformatics, Data Science. Or instructor consent.

name: Cryptography and Computer Security
description: Security mechanisms for protecting information in computer systems and networks. Includes cryptography and its applications to security services in distributed systems, mathematics of cryptography, access control, protection models, security policies, design of secure systems, firewalls, and intrusion detection.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): CS 149 andCS 166, or instructor consent. Graduate standing. Allowed Declared Major: Computer Science MS, Bioinformatics MS, and Data Science MS.

name: Topics in Information Security
description: Advanced topics in the area of information security. Content differs with each offering. Possible topics include, but are not restricted to: Network Security, Software Reverse Engineering and Cryptanalysis.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): CS 166 and Graduate standing. Allowed Declared Major: Computer Science, Bioinformatics, Data Science. Or instructor consent.

name: Topics in Database Systems
description: Advanced topics in the area of database and information systems. Content differs in each offering. Possible topics include though not restricted to: Data Mining, Distributed Databases and Transaction Processing.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): CS 157B and Graduate standing. Allowed Declared Major: Computer Science, Bioinformatics, Data Science. Or instructor consent.

name: Topics in Wireless Mobile Networking
description: Advanced topics in the area of wireless mobile networking. Content may differ in each offering. Possible topics include though not restricted to: wireless local and metropolitan area networks, mobile Internet, sensor networks, mobile computing, wireless network security. Repeatable when topic changes.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): CS 158A and Graduate standing. Allowed Declared Major: Computer Science, Bioinformatics, Data Science. Or instructor consent.

name: Topics in Machine Learning
description: Variable topics in machine learning. Content may include hidden Markov models, principal component analysis, support vector machines, clustering, boosting, random forests, neural networks, and deep learning. Relevant applications will be covered.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): CS 157A. Graduate standing. Allowed Declared Major: MS in Computer Science, Bioinformatics, Data Science. Or instructor consent.

name: Reinforcement Learning and Sequential Decision Making
description: Introduction to reinforcement learning, deep reinforcement learning, other online learning algorithms, and their applications.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): CS 157A. Allowed Declared Major: MS in Computer Science, Bioinformatics, Data Science.

name: Topics in Natural Language Processing
description: Variable topics in Natural Language Processing. Content may include regression/classification model evaluation, text processing, spell correction, language models, sentiment classification, keyword search, and other NLP-based systems.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing. CS 156 or CS 171 or instructor consent.

name: Topics in Web Intelligence
description: Topics in web intelligence including finding similar items, mining data streams, link analysis, frequent itemsets, advertising on the web, recommender systems, and mining social-network graphs.  Relevant applications will be covered. Significant programming project is required.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): CS 157A and Graduate standing. Allowed Declared Major: Computer Science, Bioinformatics, Data Science. Or instructor consent.

name: Machine Learning on Graphs
description: Graphs are a powerful way to model networks. Networks contain a plethora of valuable information about the underlying data of various scientific fields. Introduction to various network analysis and machine learning techniques to extract, analyze and visualize networks.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): CS 146

name: Graduate Individual Studies
description: Individual study in specific field.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Department chair consent. Not available to Open University Students

name: Advanced Topics in Computer Science
description: Selected topics in computer science. Topics vary each semester and may be repeated for a maximum of 6 units.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Suitable upper division background in mathematics and computer science as set by instructor. Graduate standing. Allowed Declared Major: Computer Science, Bioinformatics, Data Science. Or instructor consent.
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 6 units.

name: Preparation for Writing Project or Thesis
description: Supervised individual research and project work to prepare for a master’s writing project or thesis.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Fully classified standing in the MS Computer Science, MS Bioinformatics, or MS Data Science program, department chair consent. Not available to Open University Students.

name: Master’s Writing Project
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): CS 297 or CS 240, and department chair consent and advancement to candidacy for the MS degree. Not available to Open University Students.

name: Bioinformatics Master’s Project
description: Supervised individual research of an advanced character for the completion of the masters project.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Fully classified standing in the MS in Bioinformatics program and department chair consent. Not available to Open University Students.
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 3 units.

name: Master’s Thesis
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): CS 297 and Department Chair consent and advancement to candidacy for the MS degree. Not available to Open University Students.

name: Support Course for CS 22A
description: Review of relevant background material prior to the corresponding content for CS 22A.
notes: Note(s): No Degree Credit.

name: Culminating Experience Supervision
description: Continued work on thesis or project beyond minimum required units, for cases in which final deliverables are still in progress.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): RP grade in a preceding thesis or project semester. Graduate standing. Allowed Declared Major: Computer Science, Bioinformatics, Data Science. Or instructor consent.
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 16 units.
notes: Note(s): No Degree Credit.

name: Dance Appreciation
description: A survey of dance as art in the Western world. The course examines the diversity of people, cultures and events that led to the development of Ballet, Modern, Jazz, Tap and Musical Theatre Dance.
satisfies: Satisfies C1: Arts.

name: Ensemble Dance Rehearsal and Performance
description: ENS: Training and performance experience in the field of dance. Fully-staged productions of original professional choreographic works.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Audition and Instructor Consent
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 4 units.

name: Topics in Modern Dance I
description: Training experience in the field of beginning modern dance with varied topics. Can be repeated when topic changes.
satisfies: Satisfies PE: Physical Education.
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 8 units.
crosslist: Cross-listed with KIN 40A. Film and Theatre is responsible for scheduling.

name: Topics in Ballet I
description: Training experience in the field of beginning ballet dance with varied topics. Can be repeated when topic changes.
satisfies: Satisfies PE: Physical Education.
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 8 units.
crosslist: Cross-listed with KIN 41A. Film and Theatre is responsible for scheduling.

name: Topics in Jazz Dance I
description: Training experience in the field of beginning Jazz dance with varied topics. Can be repeated when topic changes.
satisfies: Satisfies PE: Physical Education.
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 8 units.
crosslist: Cross-listed with KIN 42A. Film and Theatre is responsible for scheduling.

name: Dance Improvisation
description: Introduction to dance improvisation, developing skills in creativity in preparation for DANC 145A.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Intermediate technique standing and permission of instructor.

name: Beginning Lindy Hop and Night Club Swing
description: This course is focused on the development of fundamental Swing dance skills and knowledge. Steps, technique, and styling will be drawn from Lindy Hop, Jitterbug, Street Swing, Jive and Triple-Time Swing dances.
satisfies: Satisfies PE: Physical Education.
crosslist: Cross-listed with KIN 45A. Kinesiology is responsible for scheduling.

name: Beginning Social Dance
description: This course is focused on the development of fundamental social dance skills and knowledge. Dances will be selected from the American Smooth (e.g. Waltz, Tango), American Rhythm (e.g. Rumba, Cha Cha) and night club (e.g. Hustle, West Coast Swing) dance categories.
satisfies: Satisfies PE: Physical Education.
crosslist: Cross-listed with KIN 46A. Kinesiology is responsible for scheduling.

name: Beginning Latin Dance
description: This course is focused on the development of fundamental Latin dance skills and knowledge. Dances will be selected from the International Latin, American Rhythm (e.g. Rumba, Cha Cha) and night club (e.g. Salsa) dance categories.
satisfies: Satisfies PE: Physical Education.
crosslist: Cross-listed with KIN 48A. Kinesiology is responsible for scheduling.

name: Topics in Tap Dance I
description: Training and experience in the field of beginning tap dance with varied topics. Can be repeated when topic changes.
satisfies: Satisfies D: Social Sciences (formerly GE Area D2).
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 2 units.
crosslist: Cross-listed with KIN 49A. Film and Theatre is responsible for scheduling.

name: Dance Production
description: Practical experience in technical aspects of producing a dance concert.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Instructor consent.

name: Topics in Dance Crewing
description: The purpose of this course is to apply practical application of skills in dance production.
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 1 units.

name: Topics in Dance Technique II
description: Beginning/Intermediate Dance with varied topics.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Audition or Instructor Consent
satisfies: Satisfies PE: Physical Education
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 12 units.

name: Rhythm and Dynamics in Dance
description: Basic music theory and the relationship of dance and music.

name: International Program Studies
description: Study Abroad and Away transfer credit course. Study Abroad and Away provides students the opportunity to study abroad on long term programs (Exchange Programs, CSU International Programs, and International Student Exchange Programs) and short-term programs (Faculty-Led Programs and Summer School Abroad Programs) for academic credit, offering Alternative Break Programs for cultural immersion, and designing other globally focused opportunities. This course is designated as a placeholder course for Study Abroad and Away programs.
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 6 units.

name: Dance in World Cultures
description: Survey of dance in selected world cultures; the role of dance in society; consideration of style, historical background and religious/cultural influences. Included are: Caribbean, West African, Mexican, Balkan, European, Asian and American cultures.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Completion of Core General Education and upper division standing are prerequisites to all SJSU studies courses. Completion of, or co-registration in, 100W is strongly recommended.
satisfies: Satisfies SJSU Studies V: Cultures and Global Understanding.

name: ENS: Dance Rehearsal and Performance
description: ENS: Training and performance experience in the field of dance. Fully-staged productions of original professional choreographic works of varying styles.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Audition and instructor consent
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 12 units.

name: Dance History and Repertory
description: History of dance and dances from ancient time to the court of King Louis XIV. Selected repertory works.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing.

name: Choreography I
description: Presentation and criticism of solo choreography; introduction to improvisational techniques.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): DANC 43 and Audition.

name: Choreography II
description: Styles; forms; use of improvisation; presentation and criticism of small group dance.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): DANC 145A and Audition.

name: Choreography III
description: Practical application of external style in relationship with art from tribal to contemporary times. Concepts, styles and forms of modern dance in the twentieth century.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): DANC 145B and Audition.

name: Dance Seminar
description: Course geared toward the understanding of a broader perspective of the Art of Dance with emphasis on current trends, development of personal artistic statement and introductory teaching techniques.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Senior standing and completion or concurrent enrollment in DANC 144A and/or DANC 144B.

name: Children’s Dance
description: Study of dance for children as personal expression through movement. Use of creative dance as a tool for the enrichment of learning. Experiencing dance in a variety of cultures.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing.
crosslist: Cross-listed with HUM 148. Film and Theatre is responsible for scheduling.

name: Kinesiology I
description: This course is designed to help provide the dancer with essential information about structure and function of the human body and the achievement of optimal performance through the science of human motion.

name: Kinesiology II
description: This course is designed to help provide the dancer with essential information about injury prevention and introduce active somatic techniques to increase muscular efficiency, balance and overall awareness of the body.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): DANC 150A.

name: Introduction to Dance Pedagogy
description: Examines methods and modes of teaching dance as an art form, and embodied practice for producing and constructing knowledge and as movement research. Course investigates both theory and practice with concentrated focus on experiential, relational and holistic learning modes.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): DANC 54 and instructor approval

name: Topics in Dance Technique III
description: Intermediate/advanced dance with varied topics.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Two semesters of DANC 54 or by Audition.
satisfies: Satisfies PE: Physical Education
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 12 units.

name: Topics in Dance Technique IV
description: Advanced Dance with varied topics.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Two semesters of DANC 154A or by Audition.
satisfies: Satisfies PE: Physical Education
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 12 units.

name: International Program Studies
description: Study Abroad and Away transfer credit course. Study Abroad and Away provides students the opportunity to study abroad on long term programs (Exchange Programs, CSU International Programs, and International Student Exchange Programs) and short-term programs (Faculty-Led Programs and Summer School Abroad Programs) for academic credit, offering Alternative Break Programs for cultural immersion, and designing other globally focused opportunities. This course is designated as a placeholder course for Study Abroad and Away programs.

name: Dance Repertory Activity
description: Training and performance experience in the field of dance. Fully-staged productions of original student choreographic works. Can be repeated up to 12 times when repertory changes.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): DANC 51A or instructor consent.
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 12 units.

name: Internship in Dance
description: Supervised internship with approved dance organization. Written evaluation submitted by organizations and student after field work.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Instructor consent.
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 9 units.

name: Computational Programming for Data Analytics
description: Computational thinking and problem solving; data structures, algorithms, iterations, functions, and other core concepts; standard libraries; functional programming and object-oriented programming; applications to data processing, data analytics, data visualization, and database manipulation.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Admission into MS in Data Analytics and instructor consent.

name: Mathematical Methods for Data Analytics
description: Mathematical and Statistical methods for Data Analytics. Selected topics from probability, statistics, linear algebra, and mathematical optimization. Programming for numerical implementation of mathematical and statistical algorithms.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Instructor Consent.

name: Database Systems for Analytics
description: Design operational and analytical databases with relational, dimensional, and NoSQL data models; deploy data analytics applications with SQL programming and data access APIs; perform data cleansing, extract, transform, and load (ETL) operations for data warehouses and online analytical processing (OLAP).
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Classified standing or instructor consent.

name: Big Data Technologies and Applications
description: Leverage emerging big data systems, technologies, and applications to transform data into knowledge through capturing, managing, analyzing, and understanding large data at volumes and rates; design analytical solutions in data warehouse, big data databases, data streaming, security and governance.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): DATA 200 (or equivalent) and DATA 225, or instructor consent

name: Data Visualization
description: Study data visualization as an analytical tool, a medium of communication, and the basis for interactive dashboards; apply cognitive theories and design principles in the development of presentations and visualizations; create digital data visualizations using emerging software packages and environments.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Classified standing or instructor consent.

name: Data Mining and Analytics
description: Learn data mining technologies for Knowledge Discovery in Databases (KDD) process including system architectures, functionalities, methodology, query language, user interaction, and performance; extract patterns and identify knowledge for diverse applications in data analytics, decision support, text mining, and stream mining.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): DATA 220 and DATA 225, or instructor consent.

name: Machine Learning Technologies
description: Learn concepts, techniques and algorithms in machine learning for the development of real-world applications; build, evaluate and refine machine learning models to predict patterns from trained data sets; apply supervised and unsupervised learning methodologies in solving classification and regression problems.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): DATA 220 and DATA 225, or instructor consent.

name: Large Scale Data Analytics
description: Learn and apply data analytics technologies and processes to large amount of data in various application domains; technologies include big data analytics algorithms, process and solutions, technology platforms, and data repositories; processes include validation, cleaning, preprocessing, and visualization.

name: Deep Learning Technologies
description: Study deep learning theory, techniques and technologies; implement neural networks using deep learning frameworks to solve problems in various application domains; build convolutional networks for image recognition, recurrent networks for sequence generation, and generative adversarial networks for image generation.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): DATA 245 or instructor consent.

name: Applied Intelligent Systems
units: Apply modern computational intelligent techniques, methodologies, tools and environments to develop integrated systems for solving practical problems; incorporate development processes, architectures, smart components, models and algorithms in building intelligent systems; perform integration, operations, management and evaluation tasks of intelligent systems.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): DATA 240 and DATA 245, or instructor consent.

name: Data Analytics Processes
description: Data analytics processes to complete project lifecycle; project scope, requirements and management; data planning and exploration; model selection, development and presentation; results evaluation and visualization; planning and analyzing processes of data analytics projects through case studies of various domains.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): DATA 225 or instructor consent.
satisfies: Satisfies GWAR: Graduation Writing Assessment Requirement.
notes: Note(s): This course satisfies graduate-level GWAR in this master’s program.

name: Data Analytics Seminar
description: Advanced and domain specific topics in the area of data analytics; content is updated in each offering; possible topics include though not restricted to research design and data analytics for the applications of business, engineering, natural science, social science, etc.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing and instructor consent.

name: Special Problems in Data Analytics
description: Advanced individual work in data analytics. Repeatable with graduate advisor approval.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Instructor and graduate advisor consents.

name: Special Topics in Data Analytics
description: Special topics in Data Analytics.  Content varies from semester to semester. Repeatable in different topic areas.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Instructor Consent.

name: Data Analytics Internship
description: Fieldwork for MS in Data Analytics students. A report is required at the end of the semester addressing the goals set at the start of the assignment.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Completed 12 units degree required courses, classified status, in good standing, and graduate advisor consent

name: MSDA Project I
description: Comprehensive plan and preliminary design of data analytics project; integration of knowledge in technologies, processes and management to support program outcomes.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Classified status, good standing, DATA 270, completed 12 units of MSDA courses, and graduate advisor consent.

name: MSDA Project II
description: Completion of an in-depth project to achieve the program outcomes and satisfy the culminating experience; write a detailed project report; make a comprehensive presentation and demonstration.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Advancement to candidacy, DATA 298A, and graduate advisor consent.

name: MSDA Thesis I
description: First of a two-course sequence for the Plan A (Thesis) culminating experience.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Classified status, good standing, DATA 270, completed 12 units of MSDA courses, and graduate advisor consent.

name: MSDA Thesis II
description: Second of the two-course sequence for the Plan A (Thesis) culminating experience.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Advancement to candidacy, DATA 299A, and graduate advisor consent.

name: Fundamental Graphic Visualization
description: Critical examination and theories on how to work with two-dimensional compositional space and the interrelated basic principles, attributes, and elements of graphic design, includes the relationships between some production methods and materials.

name: Digital Applications: Basics
description: The fundamental use of features and functions inherent within graphic software programs for graphic design.

name: International Program Studies
description: Study Abroad and Away transfer credit course. Study Abroad and Away provides students the opportunity to study abroad on long term programs (Exchange Programs, CSU International Programs, and International Student Exchange Programs) and short-term programs (Faculty-Led Programs and Summer School Abroad Programs) for academic credit, offering Alternative Break Programs for cultural immersion, and designing other globally focused opportunities. This course is designated as a placeholder course for Study Abroad and Away programs.

name: Introduction to Typography
description: Study and demonstration of letterforms and fundamental typographic principles. Emphasis on the vocabulary of typographic form and its relationship to message/purpose.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s):  GD majors: ANI 11 or ART 24, DSGD 83; ANI majors: ANI 11, ANI 71; IT majors: DSIT 33, DSIT 10, DSIT 83; ID majors: completion of DSID 22 or completion of DSGD 83 and concurrently enrolled in DSID 22

name: Visual Communication & Process
description: Problems explore methods of visual organization used in graphic communication. Course promotes the critical examination and development of ideas, two-dimensional spaces, and three-dimensional structures, including the relationship between some production methods and materials.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): ANI 11 (or ART 24 or DSID 21 or DSIT 10), DSGD 63 (or ART 12 or ANI 10 or DSID 22 or DSIT 5), DSGD 83 (or ANI 71 or DSID 32 or DSIT 83), and DSGD 99. Allowed Declared Majors: BA Design Studies, BS Industrial Design, BFA Animation/Illustration, BFA Interior Design. Allowed Declared Minor: Graphic Design Minor.

name: Intermediate Typography
description: Application of typographic principles to a diverse series of graphic design problems utilizing text and display letterforms, organizational systems, fundamental design theories and conceptual innovation.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Pass BFA portfolio review, DSGD 104

name: Advanced Typography I
description: Advanced conceptual investigations, verbal and visual problem solving utilizing typography and image.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Pass BFA Portfolio Review, DSGD 104. Allowed Declared Major: Graphic Design.
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 6 units.

name: Advanced Typography II
description: Capstone conceptual investigations, verbal and visual problem solving utilizing typography and image.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Pass BFA Portfolio Review, DSGD 102, DSGD 103A,  DSGD 186, and DSGD 110.

name: Introduction to Graphic Design
description: Familiarization to form and message development. Emphasis on visual concepts and fundamental design theory.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): DSGD 100 and DSGD 99. Allowed Declared Majors: BA Design Studies, BS Industrial Design, BFA Animation/Illustration, BFA Interior Design.  Allowed Declared Minor: Graphic Design Minor.
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 6 units.

name: Intermediate Graphic Design
description: Development of concepts combining image/form, message, typography and function with fundamental design theory.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Pass BFA Portfolio Review, DSGD 104. Allowed Declared Major: Graphic Design.

name: Advanced Graphic Design
description: Advanced and diverse series of topics confronting a wide variety of situations and needs emphasizing conceptual innovation, organization, planning and analysis.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Pass BFA Portfolio Review, DSGD 102, DSGD 186 and DSGD 110. Allowed Declared Majors: Graphic Design.

name: Special Topics in Graphic Design
description: Comprehensive design problems utilizing design theories, analysis, experimentation, innovation and conceptual development as systematic approaches to structuring various degrees of graphic design issues; database scientific visualization, graphic information system, publication design, and promotion & media graphics.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Pass BFA Portfolio Review

name: Special Topics in Experience Design
description: Capstone design problems utilizing design methodologies, theories, and analysis in the area of time-base multimedia design; narrative filming, kinetic typography in motion, interaction design, and event design as related to visual information design.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Pass BFA Portfolio Review

name: Graphic Design Portfolio
description: Portfolio preparation using various media and methods for effective professional presentation.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Pass BFA Portfolio Review, DSGD 105, and DSGD 186. Allowed Declared Majors: Graphic Design.

name: Digital Apps: Motion & Interaction Design
description: Introduction to fundamental motion and interaction design. Promotes the critical examination and development of basic time-based media design, motion graphics design, and motions in web media based on design theory and design practices by using interdisciplinary approaches and the latest techniques.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): DSGD 63, DSGD 83, and DSGD 99. Allowed Declared Majors: BA Design Studies, BFA Graphic Design.

name: Visual Literacy: Image Making
description: A course that defines the ability to assess and utilizes communications composed of various visual images (hybridization of manual, analog, and digital processes) for goal oriented projects. Students will develop tools needed to critically examine the visual world and strategies for creating unique visual forms and process of visual encoding and visual decoding for incorporating into graphic design projects.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Pass BFA portfolio review; DSGD 104.

name: Design Values and Professional Practices
description: Defines and investigates design practices, processes, materials, and vocation and their effects on society, environment, business, and intellectual property. Lectures, discussions, and group and individual projects explore applications of design thinking for positive local to global outcomes.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): ANI majors: ANI 50; GD majors: DSGD 63, DSGD 83; IT majors: DSIT 33, DSIT 83; ID majors: DSID 22 or DSGD 83.
sustainability: Sustainability Related - SDG 12: Responsible Consumption and Production

name: Exhibition Design & Info Graphics
description: Introducing principles, processes, and vocabularies of exhibition design. A substantial amount of student activity in the classroom will address acquiring and refining the two- and three-dimensional visualization of objects and spaces.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Pass BFA Portfolio Review, DSGD 110, DSGD 186

name: Design Practicum
description: Building a successful design career requires an understanding of best practices and the standards governing the ever-evolving business of graphic design. This course aims to explore the creative business processes, marketing, negotiation and pricing, ethical standards of design business, and professional relationships in design.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Pass BFA Portfolio Review, DSGD 110, DSGD 186

name: Motion Graphics
description: A capstone design problems course that exposes students to the principles, methodologies, and elements of motion graphics and narrative design. Students develop techniques and skills for synthesizing the language of motion simultaneously with an emphasis on narrative structure, and text and image in relation to time-based media. The project is examined in terms of its historical, cultural and conceptual implications.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Pass BFA Portfolio Review, DSGD 102, DSGD 110 and DSGD 186.

name: User Interface & Interaction Design
description: An advanced course focusing on the fundamental theory and practice of computer user interface and interactive design with emphasis on: the 2D graphic digital user interfaces, the current interaction development technology, theory, process and methods, and its overall impact on culture and society.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Pass BFA Portfolio Review, DSGD 102, DSGD 110 and DSGD 186.

name: 3D Branding & Promotion Design
description: Experimental problems and themes exploring theories, strategies, and methodologies in 3D branding and Promotion Design such as marketing communication tools, packaging and P.O.P design, emphasizing innovative expression. Projects also examine contextual and conceptual prototyping for point of purchase display.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Pass BFA Portfolio Review, DSGD 102, DSGD 110 and DSGD 186.

name: Degree Project: Senior Studio
description: In-depth studies course focused on research concerning current issues in visual communication/information/graphic design fields. The student develops an individual design approach, process, and methodology for the application of graphic design solutions as the thesis project that fulfills the criteria for the BFA Graphic Design.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Pass BFA Portfolio Review, DSGD 105, and DSGD 186.

name: Graphic Design History and Theory
description: The history of graphic design and typography with an emphasis on the 20th century. Define technological, historical and theoretical concerns and influences on individuals and movements in graphic design.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): ARTH 72, completion of Area Z, or instructor consent.
crosslist: Cross-listed with ARTH 176A. Art and Art History is responsible for scheduling.

name: Digital Applications: Methodology
description: Exposes students to the tools, skill sets, and languages that are essential to understanding the fundamentals for web based information and interaction design principles and discovery of its practice in the profession. Activity 6 hours.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): BFA Graphic Design Major, or Interaction Design Minors must complete DSID 126.

name: International Program Studies
description: Study Abroad and Away transfer credit course. Study Abroad and Away provides students the opportunity to study abroad on long term programs (Exchange Programs, CSU International Programs, and International Student Exchange Programs) and short-term programs (Faculty-Led Programs and Summer School Abroad Programs) for academic credit, offering Alternative Break Programs for cultural immersion, and designing other globally focused opportunities. This course is designated as a placeholder course for Study Abroad and Away programs.

name: International Program Studies
description: Study Abroad and Away transfer credit course. Study Abroad and Away provides students the opportunity to study abroad on long term programs (Exchange Programs, CSU International Programs, and International Student Exchange Programs) and short-term programs (Faculty-Led Programs and Summer School Abroad Programs) for academic credit, offering Alternative Break Programs for cultural immersion, and designing other globally focused opportunities. This course is designated as a placeholder course for Study Abroad and Away programs.
satisfies: Satisfies D: Social Sciences (formerly GE Area D2).

name: Writing Workshop: Design
description: Advanced writing course for design majors, based upon philosophical issues and current professional practices in design. Clear analytical and critical writing in examination of these topics.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): A3 or equivalent second semester composition course (with a grade of C- or better); Completion of core GE; and upper division standing. Or Graduate or Postbaccalaureate level.
satisfies: Satisfies Writing in the Disciplines (WID).
notes: Note(s): Must be passed with C or better to satisfy the CSU Graduation Writing Assessment Requirement (GWAR).

name: Internship
description: Experience in the methods and procedures employed by professional designers in consulting offices and corporate design departments. Professional responsibilities in local design offices on a weekly basis. Course is repeatable for a total of 6 units.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Completion of 3 units of DSIT 104, DSGD 186, or DSID 123, with GPA in major of at least 3.0, or instructor consent.
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 6 units.

name: Introduction to Spatial Visualization Technology in Urban Planning
description: Lab-based course in digital visualization for urban spatial representation using industry standard software such as Adobe Photoshop, Adobe Illustrator and Trimble Sketch-Up.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing or instructor consent.
crosslist: Cross-listed with URBP 148. Urban and Regional Planning is responsible for scheduling.

name: Individual Studies
description: Special topics or projects by arrangement with faculty.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Art and design majors with upper division standing.

name: Special Topics in Design
description: In-depth study of cultural and/or contemporary topics in the interdisciplnary design. Content changes each semester. Course repeatable when content changes.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing.
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 6 units.

name: International Program Studies
description: Study Abroad and Away transfer credit course. Study Abroad and Away provides students the opportunity to study abroad on long term programs (Exchange Programs, CSU International Programs, and International Student Exchange Programs) and short-term programs (Faculty-Led Programs and Summer School Abroad Programs) for academic credit, offering Alternative Break Programs for cultural immersion, and designing other globally focused opportunities. This course is designated as a placeholder course for Study Abroad and Away programs.

name: BA Senior Project
description: In-depth study of current issues in the design fields. Utilizes interdisciplinary approaches and concepts to provide a capstone experience for the design studies student.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): DSGD 99 and DSGD 100. Allowed Declared Majors: BA Design Studies, Concentration in Graphic Design.

name: Professional Writing in Design
description: Introduction to a variety of advanced writing formats based in professional and academic practices.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Master of Design (M.Des) students only.
satisfies: Satisfies Graduation Writing Assessment Requirement (GWAR).
notes: Note(s): This course satisfies graduate-level GWAR in this master’s program.

name: Graduate Seminar in Design
description: Examination of critical theories and their relation to design practice in experience design and animation. Also explores a variety of broad themes and approaches within the field of experience design and animation.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Master of Design (M.Des) students only.

name: Contextual Studies
description: Students will gain a broad understanding of design and animation, past and present, to inspire and inform projects of their own.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Master of Design (M.Des) students only.

name: Graduate Studio: Experience Design
description: Students will engage in various design methodologies and approaches related to experience design as they develop a design project.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Master of Design (M.Des) students only.

name: Design Research Methodologies
description: Introduces students to the advanced concepts and skills of design research methodologies, with an emphasis placed on how these can be applied to address real-world problems.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Master of Design (M.Des) students only.

name: Human Dimensions in Experience Design
description: Study and application of human factors and participatory, or co-design, theory, including the development of an advanced design project that involves user, or stakeholder, participation and addresses a complex problem within the studio setting.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Master of Design (M.Des) students only.

name: Designing with Data & Emergent Technology
description: Introduction to a variety of approaches to the application of data and emerging technologies within the design process.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Master of Design (M.Des) students only.

name: Spatial Visualization Tech in Urb Plan
description: Lab-based course in digital visualization for urban spatial representation using industry standard software such as Adobe Photoshop, Adobe Illustrator and Trimble Sketch-Up.
crosslist: Cross-listed with URBP 248. Urban and Regional Planning is responsible for scheduling.

name: Professional Practices
description: Students will engage in one of the following types of pre-approved professional practice and/or mentorship activities: (1) an advanced student-mentor creative project; (2) a professional internship; or (3) a teaching assistantship.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Master of Design (M.Des) students only.

name: Pre-Proposal
description: Graduate students will develop a proposal for their master’s project.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Master of Design (M.Des) students only.

name: Proposal
description: Graduate students will develop a final proposal for their project, including a thoughtful project description, a question/problem that the project aims to address, a research itinerary, initial schedule, list of collaborators or consultants, initial bibliography, and a formal presentation.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): DSGN 201, DSGN 291. Master of Design (M.Des) students only.

name: Special Study
description: Advanced individual research in areas related to the graduate student’s Master-level creative project.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): DSGN 291. Master of Design (M.Des) students only.

name: Master’s Project
description: Students work with an approved faculty chair and committee to execute, publicly exhibit, and defend the merits of their Master’s project.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): DSGN 292. Master of Design (M.Des) students only.

name: Visualization I
description: Presenting design concepts in both preliminary and finished states. Appraisal and application of media used in industry. Includes elements of color theory.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Declared BA Design Studies or BS Industrial Design Major

name: Visualization II
description: Sketching techniques commonly used by designers for communicating their concepts.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): DSID 21, BA Design Studies or BS Industrial Design majors only.

name: Industrial Design Foundation I
description: Practical exploration of the basics of industrial design aesthetics. Introduction to the design process with special emphasis on 3D form development and presentation.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Declared BS Industrial Design or BA Design Studies Major

name: Industrial Design Foundation II
description: Development and application of basic industrial design skills, methodology and aesthetics to elementary product design. Project assignments leading from abstract exercises to actual product design.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): DSID 31; BA Design Studies or BS Industrial Design Majors Only

name: ID Portfolio Project I
description: ID portfolio project class combines 2D and 3D skills from previous ID classes, in the first complete product design application. Complete presentation for ID faculty review required.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): DSID 21, DSID 31; BA Design Studies and BS Industrial Design Majors only.
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 2 units.

name: Materials and Processes I
description: Introduction to materials and manufacturing processes as they relate to product development and the Industrial Design profession.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): DSID 22, DSID 32; BS Industrial Design majors only; BA Design Studies majors with department consent.

name: International Program Studies
description: Study Abroad and Away transfer credit course. Study Abroad and Away provides students the opportunity to study abroad on long term programs (Exchange Programs, CSU International Programs, and International Student Exchange Programs) and short-term programs (Faculty-Led Programs and Summer School Abroad Programs) for academic credit, offering Alternative Break Programs for cultural immersion, and designing other globally focused opportunities. This course is designated as a placeholder course for Study Abroad and Away programs.
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 6 units.

name: Industrial Design Process
description: Explores how a conscious and rational approach can enhance creativity. Techniques used include goal setting, brainstorming, time-management, evaluation matrices and journal keeping.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): DSID 125A, BS Industrial Design or HFS Graduate Majors Only, or Instructor consent

name: Cont. & Crit. Studies: Industrial Design
description: This course thematically offers readings in Industrial Design theory, considers specific applications intended to highlight problems in contemporary practice, and is divided into five modules. Course content and examples will be selected to complement the studio projects in the program.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): DSGN 100W; BA Design Studies or BS Industrial Design Majors Only.

name: Intermediate Industrial Design
description: Design theories, methods and presentation techniques used by product designers in small scale product design. Stress application of knowledge of ergonomics, industrial materials and manufacturing processes.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): DSID 32A. BS Industrial Design Majors only
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 6 units.

name: ID Portfolio Project 2
description: Professional practice expectations within the field of industrial design and creation of a professional level design portfolio.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): DSID 32A, BS Industrial Design majors only.

name: Design for All
description: Designing for as broad a percentage of the population as possible. Course focuses on accessible design despite physical, cognitive and/or socioeconomic obstacles. Course is repeatable for a total of 6 units.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): DSID 32A (Credit), BS Industrial Design Majors Only or Instructor Consent.
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 12 units.
sustainability: Sustainability Focused - SDG 10: Reduced Inequalities

name: Advanced Industrial Design
description: Advanced exploration of industrial design theory and practice with projects involving high levels of complexity of technological, functional and aesthetic constraints.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): DSID 123A. BS Industrial Design Majors only
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 6 units.

name: ID Portfolio Project 3
description: Development of design competition entry and cohesive portfolio using work created in prior and concurrent DSID courses by integrating advanced computer graphics and technology knowledge. Comprehensive presentation to ID faculty and invited professionals required.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): DSID 123A. BS Industrial Design Majors only

name: Ergonomics for Design
description: Aspects of products affecting human performance, comfort and safety. Emphasis on design of computer interfaces, automobiles and furniture. Topics include visual displays, anthropometry, seating design and safety design.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): BS Industrial Design Majors must complete DSID 22 and DSID 32. Interaction Design Minors must complete ANI 11 or DSID 22 or DSIT 10, and DSID 32 or DSGD 83.

name: Advanced Projects in Industrial Design
description: Comprehensive, in-depth analysis and design of faculty-assigned projects as well as a student-proposed project. Student-proposed projects must meet with the approval of the Industrial Design faculty.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): DSID 125A, BS Industrial Design majors only.

name: ID Portfolio Project 4
description: Integration of business and advanced technologies into the special graduating project. Final show and presentation for ID faculty and invited professionals required.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): DSID 125A, DSID 128, DSGN 127; BS Industrial Design Majors Only.
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 2 units.

name: Visualization III
description: Principles of computer graphics, computer-aided technology and applications in industrial design. Emphasis on the transition from 2D applications to 3D applications.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): DSID 22, DSID 32; BS Industrial Design Majors only; BA Design Studies with Department consent.

name: Sustainable Design
description: Design products with a focus on minimizing their impact on the environment. The entire lifespan of designed and manufactured products will be explored. Course is repeatable for credit for a total of 6 units.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): DSID 32A (Credit); BS Industrial Design Majors only, or Instructor Consent
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 6 units.
sustainability: Sustainability Focused - SDG 12: Responsible Consumption and Production
notes: Note(s): Offered only occasionally.

name: Interaction Design
description: Advanced practical applications of interaction design theory, with an emphasis on strategies for software products including aspects of both UX (user-experience) and UI (user-interface) design.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): DSID 126.

name: Softgoods
description: Design of products that incorporate soft materials and textiles in their construction. Products include furniture, clothing, shoes, and other products that contribute to current lifestyles.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): DSID 123A; BS Industrial Design majors only.
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 6 units.

name: Design Projects: Making It
description: Students gain experience using experimental or exploratory design and fabrication techniques or technologies to develop a design project.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): DSID 123A; BS Industrial Design majors only.
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 12 units.

name: Design and Meaning
description: This course will focus on the formal properties of products to better understand how design addresses and projects meaning as it relates to designed and manufactured objects. Coursework will explore this via experiments in specification and fabrication.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): DSID 32A; BS Industrial Design Majors Only

name: Design, Entrepreneurship, Intellectual Property and Professional Practice
description: Strategies for entering the profession as a business owner or design entrepreneur. Course includes the exploration of past and future business models as well as issues of intellectual property protection.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): DSID 123A or Instructor Permission.
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 12 units.

name: Advanced Digital Workshop
description: Advanced Digital modeling and prototyping tools for Industrial Design.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): DSID 129; BA Design Studies or BS Industrial Design Majors only, or Instructor Consent
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 12 units.

name: Advanced Physical Prototyping
description: Advanced prototyping techniques for Industrial Design, including patternmaking, sewing, and casting.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): DSID 32, BA Design Studies or BS Industrial Design majors only.
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 12 units.

name: Advanced Materials,Process & Technology
description: Advanced Materials, Processes and Technology will enhance themes covered in Materials and Processes coursework with the addition of study of the relevance and implications of advanced materials and technologies on designed artifacts.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): DSID 32, DSID 41; BA Design Studies or BS Industrial Design Majors only, or instructor consent.
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 12 units.

name: Design for Healthcare
description: Introduction to unique theories and challenges associated with the design of objects, experiences and services related to healthcare. Focuses on the application of patient-centered design theories for the betterment of patient experiences and patient-provider relationships.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): DSID 123 or instructor consent

name: International Program Studies
description: Study Abroad and Away transfer credit course. Study Abroad and Away provides students the opportunity to study abroad on long term programs (Exchange Programs, CSU International Programs, and International Student Exchange Programs) and short-term programs (Faculty-Led Programs and Summer School Abroad Programs) for academic credit, offering Alternative Break Programs for cultural immersion, and designing other globally focused opportunities. This course is designated as a placeholder course for Study Abroad and Away programs.

name: Ergonomics for Design
description: Aspects of products affecting human performance, comfort and safety. Emphasis on design of computer interfaces, automobiles and furniture. Topics include visual displays, anthropometry, seating design, and safety design.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s):  Graduate status in Human Factors/Ergonomics (HFE) or instructor consent.

name: Introduction of Interior Design and Architecture
description: A comprehensive introduction to the field of Interior Architecture. Focuses on social, psychological, economic and aesthetic challenges facing designers in the 21st century. Integration of design principles, creative expression and consumer information pertaining to living environments and public spaces.

name: Sketching, Drawing + Modeling
description: Explore the processes of conceptual sketching and drawing. Utilize and teach architectural documentation techniques such as interior: floor plans, reflected ceiling plans, elevations, sections, details, perspectives and axonometric drawings. Demonstrate techniques in pencil, contemporary pens, markers, and artistic visualization techniques.

name: Design Process
description: Development of skills to work with point, line and plane to create volumes with spatial relationships.

name: Architectural Presentation
description: Further study, exploration, and comprehensive development of the technical and conceptual aspects of architectural drawing and modelmaking used to visualize innovative and functional interior spaces.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): DSIT 29

name: Interior Architecture Foundation Studio
description: In-depth study exploration and comprehensive development of innovative and functional interior spaces using the technical and conceptual aspects of architectural drawing and architectural model making and the theoretical and conceptual methodologies used to formulate interior architectural space. Course emphasizes design theory, process, programming and human factors. Focus on residential and small-scale commercial building types.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): DSIT 29

name: Visual Communication I
description: Principles of digital drawing and presentation tools essential to 2D architectural representation. Principle skills and disciplines of making 3D forms through the use of digital technology.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): DSIT 5, DSIT 10.

name: Building Codes
description: Introduction to building codes and legal regulations related to interior architecture design. Egress, occupancy levels, regulations for the handicapped, general accessibility requirements, finishes and material specifications and fire ratings are highlighted in the class.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): DSIT 34. Allowed Declared Majors: Design Studies BA and Interior Design BFA majors only.

name: Architectural Systems and Materials + Adv Modeling
description: This course covers the functional, aesthetic and environmental aspects of building materials and systems focusing on the documentation of design through BIM software.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): DSIT 33 and DSIT 34. Allowed Declared Majors: Design Studies BA and Interior Design BFA majors only.

name: Computer Graphics for Interior Architecture
description: Examination of programs related to the development of state of the art presentation methods and portfolios.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): DSIT 34.

name: Interior Architecture Conceptual Design Studio
description: Organize programmatic adjacencies and allocate planned spaces based on a singular design concept or objective. Conceptualize and execute a design through the use of 3D modeling software, digital animation and analogue methods of fabrication. Site analysis, formal, thermal and material issues problem-solving, iterative and rigorous production, experimentation, and research. Presentation of work to a jury.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): DSIT 33 and DSIT 34. Allowed Declared Majors: Interior Design and Art.

name: Interior Architecture Space Planning Studio
description: Further project-oriented study, examination and analysis of planning and designing innovative and functional interior spaces. Emphasis on the space planning of state of the art commercial environments. Additional emphasis on implementation and interpretation of laws, codes and regulations. Course is repeatable for a total of 6 units.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): DSIT 103 and pass portfolio review .
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 6 units.

name: Interior Architecture Advanced Design Studio
description: In-depth project oriented study, examination and analysis of planning and designing innovative and functional interior spaces. Emphasis on the advanced design of state of art commercial environments. Additional emphasis on implementation and interpretation of laws, codes and regulations.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): DSIT 103, and pass portfolio review.

name: Architectural Project Materials
description: Discussion and analysis of materials for interior architecture lectures and field trips emphasizing aesthetic sensibilities, human factors, manufacturing processes and specifications.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): DSIT 34. Allowed Declared Majors: Interior Design and Art.

name: Furniture Design
description: Design and production of original furniture, including drawing, prototypes and materials selection.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): DSIT 34 or instructor consent.

name: Architectural Lighting Design
description: Theory and practice of architectural lighting emphasizing aesthetics, drawing, specifications, terminology, calculations and advances in technology. Course is repeatable for a total of 6 units.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): DSIT 103, DSIT 104 or upper division standing and instructor consent.
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 6 units.

name: Object Design for Interiors
description: Advanced exploration of object design theory and practice with projects involving high levels of aesthetic and functional complexity.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): DSIT 105, DSIT 106 and DSIT 108.

name: Capstone Thesis Studio
description: Students will select an appropriate project type, determine the site, prepare existing drawings, write a project statement and program, and develop a design solution. Work must be presented to a jury of professionals, and exhibited in a thesis exhibition.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): DSIT 104, DSIT 105.

name: Interior Architecture Seminar
description: A capstone course for discussion of design work and professional values as a basis for portfolio and resume preparation.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): DSIT 105 and enrollment in graduation semester. Allowed Declared Majors: Interior Design.

name: Professional Practice of Interior Archit
description: Examination of the business, legal, financial, and managerial considerations of interior design practice as well as the role and responsibilities of a design assistant, with emphasis on ethical considerations and the legal issues of the profession and licensing.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): DSIT 100.

name: Solar Energy Analysis
description: Provides a comprehensive overview of sustainable solar energy resources, economics, and policy. Includes a review of basic solar energy physics and interdisciplinary analysis of economic, social justice and environmental strategies for a solar powered civilization.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): ENVS 119, PHYS 2A, and PHYS 2B or instructor consent
crosslist: Cross-listed with ENVS 116. Environmental Studies is responsible for scheduling.
sustainability: Sustainability Focused - SDG 7: Affordable and Clean Energy

name: Solar Home Design
description: Techniques for designing environmentally-sensitive, healthy, passive solar homes via site selection, energy conservation, lighting, non-hazardous natural building materials. Residential passive solar heating and cooling approaches for retrofits and new construction. For homeowners, teachers, professional designers and architects.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): ENVS 1 or instructor consent.
crosslist: Cross-listed with ENVS 132. Environmental Studies is responsible for scheduling.
sustainability: Sustainability Focused - SDG 7: Affordable and Clean Energy

name: Introduction to Urban Design
description: Principles, goals and methods of the urban design process. Urban design as the comprehensive treatment of the human-made environment.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing or instructor consent.
crosslist: Cross-listed with URBP 151. Urban and Regional Planning is responsible for scheduling.
sustainability: Sustainability Related - SDG 11: Sustainable Cities and Communities

name: Introduction to Urban Design Studio
description: Introduction to the analysis of alternative urban design policies to direct urban form development. Course may be repeated for credit when topic changes.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): URBP 151 or instructor consent.
crosslist: Cross-listed with URBP 152. Urban and Regional Planning is responsible for scheduling.
sustainability: Sustainability Related - SDG 11: Sustainable Cities and Communities

name: International Program Studies
description: Study Abroad and Away transfer credit course. Study Abroad and Away provides students the opportunity to study abroad on long term programs (Exchange Programs, CSU International Programs, and International Student Exchange Programs) and short-term programs (Faculty-Led Programs and Summer School Abroad Programs) for academic credit, offering Alternative Break Programs for cultural immersion, and designing other globally focused opportunities. This course is designated as a placeholder course for Study Abroad and Away programs.

name: History of Interior Design
description: Survey of interior design through historical, political, social, economic, technological, and aesthetic factors that shape the built environment. Design will be analyzed formally and through parallel developments in the arts.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): ARTH 70B or ARTH 72, completion of Area Z, or instructor consent.
crosslist: Cross-listed with ARTH 192C. Art and Art History is responsible for scheduling.
sustainability: Sustainability Related

name: Principles of Economics: Macroeconomics
description: Determination of economic aggregates such as total output, total employment, the price level and the rate of economic growth.
notes: Note(s): May be taken concurrently or prior to ECON 1B. Offered in Fall 2021 as 4 units and Spring 2022 as 3 units.

name: Principles of Economics: Microeconomics
description: Allocation of resources and distribution of income as affected by the workings of the price system and by government policies.
satisfies: Satisfies D: Social Sciences (formerly GE Area D1).
notes: Note(s): May be taken concurrently or prior to ECON 1A. Offered in Fall 2021 as 4 units and Spring 2022 as 3 units.

name: Principles of Macroeconomics Online Lab
description: Self-paced, online lab guides students through practice and [“Graded”] problem sets of key macroeconomics tools and concepts.

name: Principles of Microeconomics Online Lab
description: Self-paced on line lab guides students through practice and [“Graded”] problem sets of key microeconomics tools and concepts.

name: Statistics Lab
description: This 1 unit, credit/no credit statistics lab is designed for transfer students who have taken a 3 semester-unit elementary statistics course. (SJSU Economics Department requires 4 semester units of introductory statistics. Transfer students who are economics majors and minors must make-up the missing unit.)  The lab also is useful for those who have taken an elementary statistics course and are in need of a refresher. Basic statistical concepts and methods that emphasize understanding the principles of data collection and analysis rather than theory. Discussions of how statistics is commonly used in the real world.

name: Economic Statistics
description: Elementary statistical analysis of economic data, probability theory, probability distributions, sampling, sampling distributions, estimation, hypothesis testing, simple linear regression, correlation and index numbers.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): ECON 1A, and ECON 1B

name: International Program Studies
description: Study Abroad and Away transfer credit course. Study Abroad and Away provides students the opportunity to study abroad on long term programs (Exchange Programs, CSU International Programs, and International Student Exchange Programs) and short-term programs (Faculty-Led Programs and Summer School Abroad Programs) for academic credit, offering Alternative Break Programs for cultural immersion, and designing other globally focused opportunities. This course is designated as a placeholder course for Study Abroad and Away programs.

name: Writing Workshop: Economic Reports
description: Writing skills appropriate to majors in economics of lucid expression in essays, reports and other types of communication.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): ECON 1A and ECON 1B; A3 or equivalent second semester composition course (with a grade of C- or better); completion of core GE; and upper division standing. Or Graduate or Postbaccalaureate level.
satisfies: Satisfies Writing in the Disciplines (WID).
notes: Note(s): Must be passed with C or better to satisfy the CSU Graduation Writing Assessment Requirement (GWAR).

name: Microeconomic Analysis
description: Consumer behavior determining demands for goods and services. Theory of the firm including theories of production and cost. Theory of distribution to production factors.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): ECON 1B and Calculus (MATH 30 or MATH 30X or MATH 71 or MATH 71X).

name: Macroeconomic Analysis
description: Theory of aggregate demand and related topics: national income accounting, employment and inflation, monetary and fiscal policies, economic stability, growth and balance of payments equilibrium.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): ECON 1A.

name: Intro to Econometrics
description: Use of econometric methods in analyzing economic data. Simple and multiple regression. Problems of autocorrelation multicollinearity and heteroskedasticity.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): ECON 3 or equivalent.

name: Introduction to Econometrics and Research Methods
description: Research methods and core econometric techniques for analysis of causal effects, from difference-in-means tests of experimental data through multiple regression analysis of observational data. Topics include selecting an appropriate research question, reviewing the relevant literature, and obtaining data. Core econometric techniques used to analyze data in an original term paper.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Introductory statistics (SOCI 15, STAT 95, UNVS 15, or equivalent).

name: Econometric Methods
description: Continuation of the econometric techniques and research methods introduced in ECON 103A. Econometric techniques for panel data, instrumental variables, regression discontinuity and difference-in-difference designs, and an introduction to time series topics. Term paper building on research projects completed in ECON 103A required.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): ECON 100W and ECON 103A.

name: Mathematical Methods for Economics
description: Applications of linear algebra and differential calculus to economic analysis. Topics include market equilibrium, properties of production functions, multipliers, optimization methods, comparative statics analysis.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): ECON 1A, ECON 1B, and a grade of “C” or better in MATH 30 or MATH 30X or MATH 71 or MATH 71X.

name: Managerial Economics
description: Applications of economic analysis to practical problems in the private and public sector. Demand and cost analysis, market structure, statistical estimation and forecasting; case studies.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): ECON 1B.

name: Introduction to Environmental Economics and Policy
description: Analysis of basic economic and political factors related to the environmental crisis. Surveys policy approaches to the problem: regulation, taxes, subsidies, cost benefit analysis.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): ECON 1B or instructor consent.
crosslist: Cross-listed with ENVS 107. Environmental Studies is responsible for scheduling.
sustainability: Sustainability Focused - SDG 17: Partnerships for the Goals

name: Cost-Benefit Analysis
description: Theory and practice of cost-benefit analysis applied to various topics including public projects and environment. Welfare foundations of CBA, valuation of goods (such as clean air, wilderness, and sports arenas), discounting future values and cost.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): ECON 1B and ECON 3 or STAT 95, or instructor consent
crosslist: Cross-listed with ENVS 108. Economics is responsible for scheduling.
sustainability: Sustainability Focused - SDG 12: Responsible Consumption and Production

name: Analysis of Economic Issues for Teachers
description: Economic analysis of such topics as unemployment, inflation, poverty, pollution, education and international trade will be covered within the context of K-12 education.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing.
notes: Note(s): Not acceptable for Economics majors, except double majors; acceptable for Economics minors.

name: Economic Development
description: Theories of development and underdevelopment. Problems of initiating and sustaining growth. Relations between developed and underdeveloped regions. Economic reform and change in the underdeveloped world.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): ECON 1A and ECON 1B.
sustainability: Sustainability Related - SDG 17: Partnerships for the Goals

name: Economic History of the United States
description: Economic analysis of U.S. and Canadian history to the mid-20th century and its application to understanding the causes, patterns and consequences of economic development.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): ECON 1A and ECON 1B, or instructor consent.
crosslist: Cross-listed with HIST 113A. Economics is responsible for scheduling.

name: Economic History of Europe
description: Economic analysis of European history to the mid-20th century and its application to understanding the causes, patterns and consequences of economic development.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing or instructor consent.
crosslist: Cross-listed with HIST 113B. Economics is responsible for scheduling.

name: Industrial Organization
description: Microeconomic theory applied to pricing of products by seller having different market structures such as competition, imperfect competition, monopoly, public utility regulation or government pricing.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): ECON 1B.

name: Public Finance
description: Microeconomics of the public sector. Role of government in market systems. Cost-benefit analysis, public choice theory, taxation, fiscal federalism. State and local government sector.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): ECON 1B.

name: Public Choice
description: Economic analysis applied to non-market decision making. Topics may include: voting, special interests, rent-seeking, legislative decision-making, bureaucracy, collective action problems, judicial decision-making, political business cycles, and comparative political institutions.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): ECON 1B

name: Money and Banking
description: Monetary institutions and theory, central banking, Federal Reserve System, interest rates, foreign exchange, price level theory, flow of funds, policy relative to private, government and international finance.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): ECON 1A.

name: International Economics
description: International trade theory, customs union, tariffs, quota policies. International monetary system balance of payments problems, foreign exchange markets.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): ECON 1A and ECON 1B.

name: Fundamentals of Corporate Finance
description: Net present value criterion for investment and financial decisions, portfolio analysis, capital assets pricing model, information efficiency of security markets, influence of dividend policy on stock prices and optimality of financial structure of corporations.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): ECON 1B.

name: Topics in Corporate Finance
description: Analytical coverage of topics such as role of leverage, valuation of options (warrants, puts, calls and convertibles), valuation of risky debt, capital budgeting, mergers, financial planning and international aspects of corporate finance.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): ECON 137A or instructor consent.

name: Business and Economic Forecasting
description: Use of regression techniques to forecast movements in economic conditions having effects on business firms and governments.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): ECON 1A, ECON 1B, ECON 103A, and a semester of statistics.

name: Principles of Investments
description: Stocks, bonds, money market instruments, options, futures and real estate. Institutions, markets and theory. Speculation, present value theory, yields, term structure, taxes, portfolios and insurance.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): ECON 1A and ECON 1B.

name: Law and Economics
description: Examines the economic effects of legal institutions, existing and proposed, and application of economic analysis to the law. Evaluation of the interactions between legal and economic principles and introduction to standard topics such as property rights, contracts, liability, and torts.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): ECON 1A or ECON 1B.

name: Labor Economics
description: Development of labor institutions and markets, public regulation of unions, economics of collective bargaining. Theories of wages, employment and labor income.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): ECON 1A and ECON 1B.

name: Principles of Austrian Economics
