name: World History from 1500
description: Introduces students to the world’s regions and civilizations as interconnected entities. HIST 1A examines the growth and development of traditional civilizations to 1500. HIST 1B surveys the transformation of civilizations since 1500.
satisfies: Satisfies D: Social Sciences (formerly GE Area D2).

name: Western Civilization
description: History and culture of Europe; social and political structures; roles of individuals and groups; relationships among ideas, institutions, society and culture; to 1648.
satisfies: Satisfies D: Social Sciences (formerly GE Area D2).

name: Western Civilization
description: History and culture of Europe; social and political structures; roles of individuals and groups; relationships among ideas, institutions, society and culture; 1648 to present.
satisfies: Satisfies D: Social Sciences (formerly GE Area D2).

name: Essentials of U.S. History
description: Treatment of essentials of U.S. history. Satisfies the American Institutions (US1) and the GE Area D: Social Sciences requirements.
satisfies: Satisfies D: Social Sciences (formerly GE Area D2) + US1: US History.

name: History of the American People
description: Survey of continuity and change in society, culture, institutions and environment. Origins through slavery conflict.
satisfies: Satisfies American Institutions US1: US History.

name: History of the American People
description: Survey of continuity and change in society, culture, institutions and environment. Emergence of modern society and world power status.
satisfies: Satisfies American Institutions US1: US History.

name: Historical Process: Understanding Historical Reasoning
description: Modes and skills of practical logic and reasoning through study of historical method. Historical problems examined to that end.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Completion of GE Area A2 with a grade of C- or better.
satisfies: Satisfies A3: Critical Thinking and Writing.

name: International Program Studies
description: Study Abroad and Away transfer credit course. Study Abroad and Away provides students the opportunity to study abroad on long term programs (Exchange Programs, CSU International Programs, and International Student Exchange Programs) and short-term programs (Faculty-Led Programs and Summer School Abroad Programs) for academic credit, offering Alternative Break Programs for cultural immersion, and designing other globally focused opportunities. This course is designated as a placeholder course for Study Abroad and Away programs.

name: History Fundamentals
description: An introduction to the skills, technology and technique of history reading, writing and research. It is a prerequisite to HIST 100W. Sophomores and transferring juniors are required to take this course.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Open to History and Social Science Teacher Preparation majors only; lower or upper division standing.

name: History Writers’ Workshop
description: Development of skills required for the art and practice of historical research and writing. Library research, oral reports and written exercises dealing with a variety of historical problems.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): HIST 99 required or Department permission. A3 or equivalent second semester composition course (with a grade of C- or better); completion of core GE; and upper division standing. Or Graduate or Postbaccalaureate level. Allowed Declared Majors: History and Social Science.
satisfies: Satisfies Writing in the Disciplines (WID).
notes: Note(s): Must be passed with C or better to satisfy the CSU Graduation Writing Assessment Requirement (GWAR).

name: Historiography
description: Critical study of the writings of great historians.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): HIST 99 and HIST 100W.

name: History of the Modern Middle East
description: Survey from late 18th century to the present. Topics include imperialism and dissolution of the Ottoman Empire; World War I, the Mandate System, and the growth of nationalism; secularism versus fundamentalist Islam; formation of the state of Israel and the Israeli-Palestinian conflict; the Iranian Revolution; U.S.-Middle East relations and thee quest for oil; the changing status of women.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Upper Division Standing or Instructor Consent

name: Advanced Topics in Ancient History
description: An investigation in depth of selected periods or topics in Ancient history. Repeatable for credit when topic changes up to 8 units.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing or instructor consent
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 8 units.

name: History of China
description: Traditional society from earliest times to 1800.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Upper Division Standing.
crosslist: Cross-listed with ASIA 109A. History is responsible for scheduling.

name: History of China
description: China’s revolutions and ongoing modernization.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing or instructor consent.
crosslist: Cross-listed with ASIA 109B. History is responsible for scheduling.

name: History of Japan
description: Development of state and society from prehistoric times to 1750. Major topics include the controversy over the origins of the Japanese people; the adaptation of Chinese cultural, religious, and political models; the role of the emperor in state formation; the classical era of Japanese culture during the Heian period; the rise of the samurai elites; and the development of military rule under the shoguns.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing or consent of instructor.
crosslist: Cross-listed with ASIA 110A. History is responsible for scheduling.

name: History of Japan
description: Since 1750 emphasizing the process of modernization.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing or instructor consent.
crosslist: Cross-listed with ASIA 110B. History is responsible for scheduling.

name: Special Topics in Jewish Studies
description: Special Topics in Jewish Studies. Topics vary and will be announced each semester. Repeatable for credit under different subtitles.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing.
crosslist: Cross-listed with HUM 111 / JWSS 111 / RELS 111. History is responsible for scheduling.

name: Ancient West to 500 BCE
description: Political, social and cultural history of the Ancient West (Europe, the Middle East and North Africa, from ca. 15,000 BCE to 500 BCE.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing

name: Economic History of the United States
description: Economic analysis of U.S. and Canadian history to the mid-20th century and its application to understanding the causes, patterns and consequences of economic development.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): ECON 1A and ECON 1B, or instructor consent.
crosslist: Cross-listed with ECON 113A. Economics is responsible for scheduling.

name: Economic History of Europe
description: Economic analysis of European history to the mid-20th century and its application to understanding the causes, patterns and consequences of economic development.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing or instructor consent.
crosslist: Cross-listed with ECON 113B. Economics is responsible for scheduling.

name: The Ancient West, 500 BCE-400 CE
description: Political, social, and cultural history of the Ancient West (Europe, the Middle East, and North Africa), from ca. 500 BCE to 400 CE.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing or instructor consent

name: Medieval Worlds, 400-1000
description: This course surveys European Medieval History from the late fourth century through the first millennium. It examines the political, economic, social, cultural, and religious changes that constituted the transformation of the antique world into a unique “European” civilization.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing

name: Medieval Worlds, 1000-1500
description: From 1000 - 1500 emphasizing growth of papal power, commercial revolution and revival of urban life, twelfth century Renaissance, interactions between the European, Byzantine, and Islamic worlds, and late medieval transformations leading to modernity
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing

name: The Renaissance and Reformation
description: The European world in transition from 1400-1600.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Upper Division Standing

name: Early Modern Europe
description: The European world in transition from 1580 to 1750. A continuation of HIST 122, exploring the central place of the princely court in the transformation of politics, religion, art, culture, science, technology and philosophy. Introduction to the Enlightenment.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Upper Division Standing

name: Advanced Topics in Medieval History
description: An investigation in depth of selected periods or topics in Medieval history. Repeatable for credit when topic changes for up to 12 units.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Departmental consent required.
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 12 units.

name: Military History to 1500
description: The development of military force and warfare from its origins to 1500.

name: Military History from 1500
description: Traces the development of military force and warfare from 1500 to the present.  Various aspects of military conflict are considered including technology, organization, culture and leadership. The role of war and armies in culture and in the development of civilization are considered. Students learn about the sources for military history and how historians use them, and are challenged to think about the “why” of military history, its development and its impact.

name: Advanced Topics in World History
description: Aspects of world history under various topics. Repeatable for credit when topic changes for up to 12 units.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing or instructor consent
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 12 units.
sustainability: Sustainability Related - SDG 10: Reduced Inequalities

name: World Jewish History
description: History of the Jewish people and Judaism around the world, from their origins to the present. Covers Jewish development, both as an ethnic group and as a religion, with an emphasis on the diverse ways in which Jews responded to their circumstances. A major focus is the effect of Judaism and the Jews on other cultures and societies.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Completion of Core General Education and upper division standing are prerequisites to all SJSU studies courses. Completion of, or co-registration in, 100W is strongly recommended (HIST 100W preferred).
satisfies: Satisfies SJSU Studies Area V: Cultures and Global Understanding.

name: Europe, 1750-1900
description: Major political, economic, social and cultural themes of European history from the Enlightenment to 1900.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing

name: Europe, 1900-1945
description: A history of political, economic, social and cultural developments in Europe during the era of the two world wars.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing

name: Europe and the World Since 1945
description: Political, economic and social developments since World War II, with emphasis on Europe.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing

name: Advanced Topics in European History
description: An investigation in depth of selected periods or topics in European history.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing

name: History of Women in Europe
description: Changes in women’s private and public roles in diverse national, class, religious, ethnic and racial contexts from Ancient Greece to Modern Europe.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Completion of Core General Education and upper division standing are prerequisites to all SJSU studies courses. Completion of, or co-registration in, 100W is strongly recommended.
satisfies: Satisfies SJSU Studies V: Cultures and Global Understanding.
sustainability: Sustainability Related - SDG 5: Gender Equality

name: 20th Century World
description: Global perspectives on a century of scientific progress that also saw the violent deaths of millions, with emphasis on the decline of traditional imperialism and the ideological contention that led to World War II and the Cold War.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Completion of Core General Education and upper division standing are prerequisites to all SJSU studies courses. Completion of, or co-registration in, 100W is strongly recommended.
satisfies: Satisfies SJSU Studies V: Cultures and Global Understanding.

name: Colonial Latin America
description: The course covers the colonial administration and society of the Spanish and Portuguese colonies in the New World. I also look at social, economic, and political conditions of the Iberian Peninsula and of the Amerindian empires on the eve of the conquest. The course concludes with an overview of the independence movements in Hispanic America and Brazil.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing or instructor consent

name: Modern Latin America, 1800-Present
description: Latin America since 1800. Focus on major political changes, such as independence, wars, popular uprisings, and systems of government. Also economic and cultural affairs, especially when they disrupt existing societies, and outstanding leaders who charted their nations’ destinies.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing or instructor consent

name: Advanced Topics in Latin American History
description: An investigation in depth of selected periods or topics in Latin American history. Repeatable for credit when topic changes up to 12 units.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing or instructor consent
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 12 units.

name: Topics in American History
description: An investigation in depth of selected periods or problems. Repeatable for credit when topic changes.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing.
satisfies: Satisfies American Institutions US1: US History.
sustainability: Sustainability Related - SDG 10: Reduced Inequalities
notes: Note(s): No credit for history majors or minors.

name: Topics in American History: American Identities and Institutions
description: An investigation in depth of selected periods or problems. This topic focuses on historical relationships between social groups and the political, social, economic and cultural institutions they created.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Completion of Core General Education and upper division standing are prerequisites to all SJSU studies courses. Completion of, or co-registration in, 100W is strongly recommended.
satisfies: Satisfies SJSU Studies S+US1: Self, Society & Equality in the U.S. + American History.
sustainability: Sustainability Related - SDG 10: Reduced Inequalities

name: U.S. Constitutional & Legal History
description: Origins and evolution of the United States Constitution and federal system from the American Revolution to the present.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing or instructor consent.

name: New World Encounters, 1400-1750
description: Examines the first wave of European expansion, from 1400-1750, through the prism of cultural and religious interactions. Explores how Europeans, Africans, and Indians understood each other during European exploration, conquest, and colonization of the “New World”.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing or instructor consent.
sustainability: Sustainability Related - SDG 10: Reduced Inequalities
notes: Note(s): Offered only occasionally.

name: Colonial & Revolutionary America
description: Investigates the socio-political development of British North America from the 1600s to the era of the American Revolution. Examines how mentalities, voluntary and involuntary immigration, demographic catastrophes, rebellions, and religious revivals shaped the British Atlantic.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing

name: Inventing America, 1800-1860
description: The history of the United States from 1800-1860. Topics include the rise of democratic political culture, industrialization, the emergence of a market economy, pivotal changes in institutions such as the family and church and the redefinition of key American values.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing

name: The Civil War and Reconstruction
description: Course takes a topical approach, examining the political, social, economic, military, and ideological dimensions of the Civil War and Reconstruction. Focus will be on the war and its aftermath as a revolutionary experience rather than solely as a military struggle.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing or instructor consent.

name: Industrial America, 1877-1920
description: Economic, social, and political history from the end of Reconstruction to the achievement of women’s suffrage. Topics include the triumph of industrial capitalism, labor conflict, women’s suffrage, Populism/Progressivism, race/ethnicity, and World War I.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing or instructor consent

name: Crash, Depression and War, 1920-1950
description: The United States from the “Roaring Twenties” through the Great Crash, the Great Depression, the New Deal, World War II, the home front, the Atomic Age, and the beginning of the Cold War.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing or instructor consent

name: Cold War America, 1950-Present
description: Modern history of the United States since 1950 including the Cold War, the Korean and Vietnam wars, the Civil Rights Movement, postwar society, culture, economics and politics.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing or instructor consent

name: Individual Studies
description: Individual work on special topics by arrangement.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): History majors or minors.

name: Advanced Topics in American History
description: An investigation in depth of selected periods or topics in American history.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing or instructor consent.
sustainability: Sustainability Related - SDG 10: Reduced Inequalities

name: Directed Reading
description: Directed reading on a specific topic in history.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): History major/minor and instructor and department chair consent.

name: LGBTQ+ History in the United States
description: Students use an intersectional framework to examine LGBTQ+ history in the United States. The course emphasizes how the development of institutions and ideals, the formation of identities, and shifting contexts of equality and inequality have impacted LGBTQ+ people through time.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Completion of Core General Education and upper division standing are prerequisites to all SJSU studies courses. Completion of, or co-registration in, 100W is strongly recommended.
satisfies: Satisfies SJSU Studies S: Self, Society & Equality in U.S.

name: History of Women in the United States
description: A multi-faceted history of women in the United States from colonial times to the present.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Completion of Core General Education and upper division standing are prerequisites to all SJSU studies courses. Completion of, or co-registration in, 100W is strongly recommended.
satisfies: Satisfies SJSU Studies S: Self, Society & Equality in U.S.
sustainability: Sustainability Focused - SDG 5: Gender Equality

name: California History to 1900
description: Topics include Native American civilizations, Spanish discovery and missions, the Mexican era, the American conquest, the Gold Rush, Chinese immigration, the railroad, growth, development, politics and class conflict.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing or instructor consent.
satisfies: Satisfies American Institutions US3: California Government.
notes: Note(s): Satisfies American Institutions requirement in California government.

name: California History Since 1900
description: Topics include the Progressive movement, migration, immigration, growth, prosperity, depression, agriculture, industry, war, politics, protests, riots, environmentalism, nativism, and diversity.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing or instructor consent.
satisfies: Satisfies American Institutions US3: California Government.
notes: Note(s): Satisfies American Institutions requirement in California government.

name: International Program Studies
description: Study Abroad and Away transfer credit course. Study Abroad and Away provides students the opportunity to study abroad on long term programs (Exchange Programs, CSU International Programs, and International Student Exchange Programs) and short-term programs (Faculty-Led Programs and Summer School Abroad Programs) for academic credit, offering Alternative Break Programs for cultural immersion, and designing other globally focused opportunities. prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Instructor consent.
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 6 units.

name: Graduate Methodology, Research and Writing
description: An orientation to history graduate study focusing on the critical advanced writing, library, research and historiographical skills needed for success as a graduate student and professional historian. Includes an overview of current methodologies and trends in the field.

name: Colloquium in Ancient and Medieval Europe
description: Intensive readings, discussions and reports on Ancient and Medieval Europe. For areas and field of emphasis see the schedule of classes. May be repeated when content changes.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing or instructor consent.
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 8 units.

description: Intensive readings, discussions, and reports on American history in the seventeenth and eighteenth centuries. Repeatable for credit once with different instructor.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 8 units.

description: Intensive readings, discussions, and reports on American history in the nineteenth century. Repeatable for credit once with different instructor.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing.
satisfies: Satisfies GWAR: Graduation Writing Assessment Requirement.
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 8 units.

prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing or instructor consent
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 8 units.

prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing.
satisfies: Satisfies GWAR: Graduation Writing Assessment Requirement.

description: Study Abroad and Away transfer credit course. Study Abroad and Away provides students the opportunity to study abroad on long term programs (Exchange Programs, CSU International Programs, and International Student Exchange Programs) and short-term programs (Faculty-Led Programs and Summer School Abroad Programs) for academic credit, offering Alternative Break Programs for cultural immersion, and designing other globally focused opportunities. name: Special Study
description: Advanced individual research.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Instructor consent and approval by graduate advisor.
notes: Note(s): More than 3 units only in areas where graduate courses not normally offered.

name: Master’s Thesis
description: Open only to approved master’s candidates in history. Reserved for students under Plan A.

name: Culminating Experience Supervision
description: This course is offered in special sessions for 1 unit. It is required of, and limited to, graduate students who have completed all degree coursework and need only pass the Plan B exam to complete the program. Students who have completed all coursework, are preparing for the Plan B, and are not enrolled in any other classes must enroll in H1290R. The course is also required of graduate students who have an outstanding RP grade in a preceding semester in a thesis class. If one has an outstanding RP, this course must be taken unless the student is enrolled in any other course. By outstanding, it is meant that the RP grade has not been changed to any other grade, including a CR or NC. The RP grade in the thesis course remains on the official record until a culminating memo has been submitted by the graduate advisor to the Office of Graduate Admissions & Program Evaluations and the course instructor of the class in which an RP was received has petitioned for a grade change to CR.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): HIST 299 or compeltion or all coursework.
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 16 units.
notes: Note(s): This course receives no degree credit and therefore cannot be used on the candidacy form or to fulfill graduation requirements.

name: Multidisciplinary Health Promotion in Later Life
description: Multidisciplinary assessment and planning. Principles of promoting health and preventing disability in later life. Physical, psychological, social, cultural, spiritual, and environmental factors that affect length and quality of life.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): BIOL 66 or GERO 108 or instructor consent.
crosslist: Cross-listed with GERO 260 / NUFS 260. Nutrition, Food Science and Packaging is responsible for scheduling.
sustainability: Sustainability Related - SDG 3: Good Health and Well-Being

name: The Global Tourism & Hospitality Industry
description: Overview of the global tourism and hospitality industry focusing on its growth, development, social and cultural context, industry segments and their distinguishing characteristics, trends and current concerns. Students are introduced to career opportunities and the employability skills needed to succeed in specific tourism and hospitality fields.
sustainability: Sustainability Related - SDG 8: Decent Work and Economic Growth

name: Restaurant Management
description: Overview of food and beverage with emphasis on food quality.
prereqs: Pre/Corequisite(s): HSPM 1.

crosslist: Cross-listed with NUFS 12. Hospitality Management is responsible for scheduling.

name: Sanitation and Environmental Issues in the Hospitality Industry
description: Sanitation in food service, hotel and travel/tourism industries; study of pathogenic organisms and food handling procedures. Occupational health, safety and environmental control in the hospitality industry.
crosslist: Cross-listed with NUFS 20. Nutrition, Food Science and Packaging is responsible for scheduling.
sustainability: Sustainability Related - SDG 8: Decent Work and Economic Growth

name: Catering and Beverage Management
description: Planning and executing catering and buffet functions. Evaluation of alcoholic and non-alcoholic beverages regarding purchasing, storage, preparation, merchandising and regulations.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): NUFS 20 or instructor consent.
crosslist: Cross-listed with NUFS 22. Nutrition, Food Science and Packaging is responsible for scheduling.

name: Professional Seminar in Hospitality Mgmt (To Be Inactivated after Fall 2022)
description: Designed for students who have declared a major in the Hospitality, Tourism and Event Management degree. The topics selected will facilitate the student’s entry into the academic program and the profession of hospitality management.
notes: Note(s): This course is part of the teach out plan for the Hospitality, Tourism, and Event Management BS. It will be offered in Fall 2021 and Fall 2022. The course will subsequently be discontinued.

name: Special Events Management in Hospitality
description: Hands-on experience in the operation, coordination, and management of special events as they relate to hospitality and tourism. Students develop management skills and experience in planning and execution of a major event.
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 6 units.

sustainability: Sustainability Related - SDG 8: Decent Work and Economic Growth

name: Hotel & Lodging Operations
description: Principles of organization, management, and decision models applied to the tasks and challenges of hotel operations. Involves techniques of problem-solving (including planning, organizing, staffing, directing, and controlling operations) in areas of front office operations, housekeeping, food/beverage, and personnel.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing.

name: Hospitality Information Systems
description: Focuses on the application of various information systems to the management of facilities, programs, services, finances and accounting, products, marketing and sales, human resources and other major functions of hospitality, recreation, and tourism organizations/agencies.

name: Customs and Courtesies in Hospitality
description: An exploration of a variety of customs and courtesies that demonstrate the influences of history, traditions, social customs, religious beliefs, language, and other cultural elements on hospitality service etiquette and manners in different cultures and countries.

name: Special Event Planning
description: Planning and production of a special event related to tourism and hospitality. Topics include setting event goals, developing the event plan, site selection, event infrastructure, guest experience, event technology, marketing, event analytics, budget, risk management, on-site management, and career opportunities.

name: Corporate Event Management
description: Corporate event planning, production, and management through examinations of the corporate’s goals and the planner’s role. Topics include industry overview, types of corporate events, typical event components, technology, event branding and marketing, entertainment, guest experience, budgeting, evaluation, and career opportunities.

name: Resort and Club Management
description: Management and operation of resort and private club properties from their historical development to their economic and environmental impact; marketing and managing of services provided by these facilities within the leisure industry.
sustainability: Sustainability Related - SDG 12: Responsible Consumption and Production

name: Trade Show and Exhibition Management
description: Management and operations of trade shows and exhibitions from the perspectives of show organizers and exhibitors.Topics include strategic goals setting, economic impacts, registration, marketing, floor plan design, booth design, exhibition technologies, sponsorships, sustainability, budget, evaluation, and career opportunities.

name: Tourism Destination Marketing and Management
description: Principles of destination marketing and management in formulating strategies to promote tourism in a variety of locations. Appraising a destination’s potential and developing a destination’s products/services and marketing campaign to attract both business and leisure travelers.

name: Wine Appreciation
description: Introduces the student to the significance of wine in the dining experience. The class will study the wine-making process, wine grape varieties, health and legal issues of wine and include in-class evaluation of wine.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing.

name: Beer Appreciation
description: Examining the history, business and economic impact of beer from its international brewery markets to the small craft beer distributors. Explore beer styles, regions, brewing processes and food pairings through weekly tastings and sensory applications of the principles of beer making.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing.

name: Hotel Catering and Banquet Management
description: Overview of hotel group sales, convention services, catering sales and banquet operations. Learn tools and applications necessary to be successful in providing catering and banquet operations for hotel, restaurant, or corporate events.

name: Revenue Management
description: Formulating tactical pricing decisions to maximize revenues for hospitality organizations. Topics include: history of revenue management, reservation systems, forecasting demand, inventory control, cost analysis, pricing strategy, channel management, revenue management tactics, and applications.

name: Sustainable Hospitality and Tourism Management
description: Concepts and principles of sustainable operations in tourism, hospitality, and event management organizations. Topics include the UN’s 17 Sustainable Development Goals, socio-cultural, economic, and environmental dimensions of sustainable development, impacts of development, corporate social responsibility, and current trends/issues in sustainable operations.

name: Cruise Operations and Management
description: This course examines the major aspects of cruise operations and management including history, global cruise market, economic significance, geography of cruising, itinerary design, anatomy of a cruise ship, operations, sales and marketing procedures, passenger services, event planning and management, and career opportunities.

name: Gaming Management
description: Introduction to the casino’s external environments and the casino’s impact on the consumer and the local economy. Topics cover the history of gaming and gaming development, casino organization and operation, the mathematics of casino games, and casino management.

name: Hospitality Service Management
description: Develop skills in setting formal service standards and procedures to deliver customer experience and evaluate service quality for hospitality businesses. Topics include service experience design, psychological/social characteristics of customer satisfaction, service delivery processes, consumer/server encounters, service quality, and service recovery.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Senior standing.

name: Individual Studies
description: Investigation of special problems, including research projects and/or field experience.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Instructor or department consent. Not available to Open University Students.

name: Directed Reading
description: Directed reading in journals and books by authorities in Hospitality, Recreation, Tourism and related fields. Assessment by project(s) and/or paper(s).
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Instructor approval or department consent. Not available to Open University Students.
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 4 units.

name: Hospitality, Tourism and Event Management Internship
description: Supervised professional broad-based work experience in hospitality, tourism, or event management industry.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Instructor or department consent.

name: International Program Studies
description: Study Abroad and Away transfer credit course. Study Abroad and Away provides students the opportunity to study abroad on long term programs (Exchange Programs, CSU International Programs, and International Student Exchange Programs) and short-term programs (Faculty-Led Programs and Summer School Abroad Programs) for academic credit, offering Alternative Break Programs for cultural immersion, and designing other globally focused opportunities. This course is designated as a placeholder course for Study Abroad and Away programs.

name: Humanities Honors - Origins, Agriculture, Empire
description: Interdisciplinary study of human culture from its beginnings through the establishment of far-flung urban empires. Examination of creation stories, domestication of agriculture, and the development of cities in the ancient world, across Africa, Europe, Asia, North America and South America. Cohort-based, team-taught course eligible for credit for Honors commendation.
prereqs: Pre/Corequisite(s): Completion of GE Area A2.
satisfies: Satisfies C1: Arts + E: Human Understanding & Development.
notes: Note(s): This cohort-based, team-taught course is eligible for credit for Honors commendation. High Impact Practice: First Year Seminar/Experience

name: Humanities Honors - Silk Roads & Water Ways
description: Interdisciplinary study of human cultural interactions from the late ancient to the early modern world. Examination of developments in learning, science, visual arts, diffusion of knowledge, religious ideas, conflicts and resolutions in the medieval world writ large, across Africa, Europe, Asia, North America and South America. Cohort-based, team-taught course eligible for credit for Honors commendation.
satisfies: Satisfies A1: Oral Communication (C- or better) + A3: Critical Thinking and Writing (C- or better).
notes: Note(s): This cohort-based, team-taught course is eligible for credit for Honors commendation. High Impact Practice: First Year Seminar/Experience

name: Humanities Honors - Imperialism, Science & Resistance
description: Interdisciplinary study of imperialism, the influence of science, and resistance to colonial expansion and scientific influence. Examine how knowledge is produced, the influence of the arts, the rise of empires, and understandings of wealth and revolution across Africa, Europe, Asia, North America, and South America.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Completion of GE Area A2 with a grade of C- or better.
satisfies: Satisfies C1: Arts + C2: Humanities.
notes: Note(s): This cohort-based, team-taught course is eligible for credit for Honors commendation.

name: Humanities Honors - Global Revolutions, the US & the Future
description: Explores the legal history and influence of constitutional power at the federal and state levels. Structure, function, and polities of the Supreme Court, Congress, and Presidency through an examination of federalism, the U.S. Constitution, and the Bill of Rights; the role of public opinion, elections, political parties, foreign policy, the experience of race/ethnicity, gender, and class in the American experience. Examines the relationship and inspiration of the American revolution and democratic ideals on revolutions throughout the world.
satisfies: Satisfies D: Social Sciences (6 units) + US123: American Institutions.
notes: Note(s): This cohort-based, team-taught course is eligible for credit for Honors commendation.

name: Reading the World
description: By studying the history, philosophy, and science of reading, we build a transdisciplinary, critical approach to the value of reading comparative, historical, and cross-cultural texts. Activities and writing assignments enable students to understand the logical construction of arguments to become reflexive participants in reading.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Completion of GE Area A2 with a grade of C- or better.
satisfies: Satisfies A3: Critical Thinking and Writing.

name: Bible History and Literature
description: The Bible in context of its history, literary sources and as a reflection of Jewish and Christian traditions. Motifs and themes in light of their original audience, historic usage and contemporary development.
satisfies: Satisfies C2: Humanities.
crosslist: Cross-listed with JWSS 90 / MDES 90 / RELS 90. Humanities is responsible for scheduling.

name: International Program Studies
description: Study Abroad and Away transfer credit course. Study Abroad and Away provides students the opportunity to study abroad on long term programs (Exchange Programs, CSU International Programs, and International Student Exchange Programs) and short-term programs (Faculty-Led Programs and Summer School Abroad Programs) for academic credit, offering Alternative Break Programs for cultural immersion, and designing other globally focused opportunities. This course is designated as a placeholder course for Study Abroad and Away programs.

name: Introduction to Digital Humanities
description: Seminar course that explores how digital technologies create new possibilities for knowledge-making in the humanities. Students engage in digital humanities research using a variety of multi-modal methods to explore how technologies can be harnessed to tell stories, connect information, raise awareness, and visualize complex ideas in interactive ways.

name: Death, Dying and Religions
description: Is death the end or the beginning? Learn how people integrate the physical, emotional, psychological, and spiritual dimensions of living and dying. Examine religious teachings and practices for making death personally meaningful, socially significant, or even politically powerful.
satisfies: Satisfies E: Human Understanding & Development.
crosslist: Cross-listed with GERO 99 / RELS 99. Humanities is responsible for scheduling.

name: Writing in the Humanities & Interdisciplinary Arts
description: Advanced workshop in composition and reading for the critical and comparative study of the humanities and interdisciplinary arts. Students explore and practice the thinking and writing skills that help us communicate insight, critique, interpretation, description, and analysis of arts, literature, history, and culture, including expository writing and library research. Readings and objects of study include a range of topics and at least two different art forms.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): A3 or equivalent second-semester composition course (with a grade of C- or better); completion of core GE; and upper-division standing. Or Graduate or Postbaccalaureate level.
satisfies: Satisfies Writing in the Disciplines (WID).
crosslist: Cross-listed with AMS 100W / RELS 100W. Humanities is responsible for scheduling.
notes: Note(s): Must be passed with C or better to satisfy the CSU Graduation Writing Assessment Requirement (GWAR).

name: Human Life: Let’s Think About It
description: Introduction to interdisciplinary comparative and creative studies. A range of methodologies will be explored through two contrasting subjects. Students learn and synthesize approaches - geography, history, literature, arts, and social science - to achieve a holistic understanding of the topics.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Upper Division Standing.

name: Special Topics in Jewish Studies
description: Special Topics in Jewish Studies. Topics vary and will be announced each semester. Repeatable for credit under different subtitles. Repeatable for credit when topic changes.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing.
crosslist: Cross-listed with HIST 111 / JWSS 111 / RELS 111. History is responsible for scheduling.

name: Legacy of Asia
description: Interdisciplinary focus on continuity and change in China and India as these ancient civilizations responded to challenges throughout their history.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Completion of Core General Education, and upper-division standing are prerequisites to all SJSU studies courses. Completion of, or co-registration in, 100W is strongly recommended.
satisfies: Satisfies SJSU Studies V: Cultures and Global Understanding.
crosslist: Cross-listed with ANTH 114 / ASIA 114 / RELS 114. Humanities is responsible for scheduling.

name: Myths, Heroes, and Global Cultures
description: This course examines cultural developments in Europe, Asia and Africa during the ancient era and middle ages, roughly 700 B.C.E. to 1400 C.E, and the roles of pivotal figures, both mythic and historical, whose actions and ideas created our understanding of the early world.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing or permission of instructor

name: Introduction to Comparative Literature
description: Literature exploring themes, styles, or strategies, shared across national borders and languages.
crosslist: Cross-listed with COLT 121 / ENGL 121 / FORL 121. English and Comparative Literature is responsible for scheduling.

name: Topics in Comparative World Literature
description: An exemplary theme as treated in various literatures from different national sites, e.g., war, love, freedom, colonialism, environmental disaster.
crosslist: Cross-listed with COLT 122 / ENGL 122 / FORL 122. English and Comparative Literature is responsible for scheduling.

name: Holocaust Literature
description: Survey of literature written by survivors or witnesses of the Holocaust, the destruction of European Jewry during World War II, focusing upon diaries, memoirs, fiction, and occasionally poetry and drama. Writers may include Elie Wiesel, Primo Levi, Anne Frank, Charlotte Delbo.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Completion of Core General Education and upper division standing are prerequisites to all SJSU studies courses. Completion of, or co-registration in, 100W is strongly recommended.
satisfies: Satisfies SJSU Studies V: Cultures and Global Understanding.
crosslist: Cross-listed with ENGL 126 / FORL 126 / JWSS 126. English and Comparative Literature is responsible for scheduling.

name: Perspectives on the Twentieth Century: The West in a Global Context
description: Literature and the arts of selected world cultures contextualized in significant events and concepts of the twentieth century, such as two world wars, totalitarian systems, the revolt against colonial powers, modernity and postmodernity, and the global challenge to western hegemony.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Completion of Core General Education and upper division standing are prerequisites to all SJSU studies courses. Completion of, or co-registration in, 100W is strongly recommended.
satisfies: Satisfies SJSU Studies V: Cultures and Global Understanding.

name: Religion Film & Media
description: Depictions of religion, religions, religious behavior, and religious propaganda in film and media. Exploring these from several perspectives, (e.g. emic and etic, cross-national, aesthetic) and examining the murky problem of “the truth” in the depiction of religious and spiritual experience.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Upper-division standing or instructor consent.
crosslist: Cross-listed with CA 134 / RELS 134. Humanities is responsible for scheduling.

name: Medieval Literature
description: Middle English and continental literature, including such forms as the lyric, allegory, narrative, romance and biblically-based drama.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing.
crosslist: Cross-listed with ENGL 141. English and Comparative Literature is responsible for scheduling.

name: Contemporary Buddhism and its Roots
description: Teachings of Gautama, the Buddha and ways in which those teachings were modified in forms of Buddhism that followed: Therevada in southeast Asia and Mahayana in East Asia.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Upper-division standing or instructor consent.
crosslist: Cross-listed with ASIA 142 / RELS 142. Humanities is responsible for scheduling.

name: Chinese Traditions
description: Religious thought and practice of China’s three Great Traditions (Buddhism, Taoism and Confucianism) as well as China’s Little Tradition (Chinese folk religion). The role of these traditions within traditional Chinese culture and their relevance to the modern world, including China.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Upper-division standing or instructor consent.
crosslist: Cross-listed with ASIA 144 / RELS 144. Humanities is responsible for scheduling.

name: Children’s Dance
description: Study of dance for children as personal expression through movement. Use of creative dance as a tool for the enrichment of learning. Experiencing dance in a variety of cultures.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing.
crosslist: Cross-listed with DANC 148. Film and Theatre is responsible for scheduling.

name: Nature and World Cultures
description: The influence of industrialization and globalization on earth and the environment as seen through culture.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Completion of Core General Education, and upper-division standing are prerequisites to all SJSU studies courses. Completion of, or co-registration in, 100W is strongly recommended.
satisfies: Satisfies SJSU Studies V: Cultures and Global Understanding.
crosslist: Cross-listed with AMS 159 / ENVS 159. Humanities is responsible for scheduling.
sustainability: Sustainability Focused - SDG 15: Life on Land

name: Special Topics in Humanities
description: Comparative studies of vital issues and enduring ideas (ethical, political, social, cross-cultural, etc.). Content varies each semester and with each instructor. Repeatable for up to 9 units of credit when course topic changes.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Upper-division Standing.
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 9 units.
crosslist: Cross-listed with AMS 160. Humanities is responsible for scheduling.

name: The American Dream
description: The American search for identity and meaning, the struggle for equality and success, in relation to myths, illusions and realities reflected in history, literature and the arts.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Completion of Core General Education, and upper-division standing are prerequisites to all SJSU studies courses. Completion of, or co-registration in, 100W is strongly recommended.
satisfies: Satisfies SJSU Studies S: Self, Society & Equality in U.S.
crosslist: Cross-listed with AMS 169. Humanities is responsible for scheduling.

name: Advanced Honors in Integrated Science, Social Science, and Humanities
description: SJSU Studies Honors cultivates scientific study of the physical universe and life forms, explores individuals and groups in the USA regarding diversity, equality, and institutional inequalities and practices, and develops appreciation for human cultures and their diverse development globally over time.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): All-college GPA of 3.0 or higher. Completion of Core General Education and upper division standing are prerequisites to all SJSU studies courses.
satisfies: Satisfies SJSU Studies R+S+V: Earth, Environment, and Sustainability. + Self, Society & Equality in the U.S. + Cultures and Global Understanding with successful completion of HUM 177A/HUM 177B sequence.
sustainability: Sustainability Focused - SDG 16: Peace, Justice and Strong Institutions

name: Advanced Honors in Integrated Science, Social Science, and Humanities
description: SJSU Studies Honors cultivates scientific study of the physical universe and life form, explores individuals and groups in the USA regarding diversity, equality, and institutional inequalities and practices, and develops appreciation for human cultures and their diverse development globally over time.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): HUM 177A
satisfies: Satisfies SJSU Studies R+S+V: Earth, Environment, and Sustainability. + Self, Society & Equality in the U.S. + Cultures and Global Understanding with completion of HUM 177A/HUM 177B sequence.

name: Issues in US Popular Culture
description: Music, sports, fashion, popular literature, television and other arts and activities that are main forms of influence, entertainment and escape. Expressions of American attitudes and ideas as important influences upon evolving culture and consciousness.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Upper-division standing.
crosslist: Cross-listed with AMS 179. Humanities is responsible for scheduling.

name: Individual Studies
description: Directed reading and thesis by arrangement.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Department chair consent.

name: Senior Seminar in Humanities
description: Readings, discussions and individual research projects relating to an interdisciplinary theme selected by the instructor.
prereqs: Pre/Corequisite(s): Upper-division Standing, Passage of WST. Any 100W class.
crosslist: Cross-listed with AMS 190 / RELS 190. Humanities is responsible for scheduling.

name: Religion in America
description: History of social and intellectual influence of religious groups, stressing their African-, Asian-, European-, Latin- and Native-American roots. Highlights contact between groups, immigration, religious diversity and syncretism.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Completion of Core General Education, and upper-division standing are prerequisites to all SJSU studies courses. Completion of, or co-registration in, 100W is strongly recommended.
satisfies: Satisfies SJSU Studies S: Self, Society & Equality in U.S.
crosslist: Cross-listed with RELS 191. Humanities is responsible for scheduling.

name: International Program Studies
description: Study Abroad and Away transfer credit course. Study Abroad and Away provides students the opportunity to study abroad on long term programs (Exchange Programs, CSU International Programs, and International Student Exchange Programs) and short-term programs (Faculty-Led Programs and Summer School Abroad Programs) for academic credit, offering Alternative Break Programs for cultural immersion, and designing other globally focused opportunities. This course is designated as a placeholder course for Study Abroad and Away programs.

name: Informatics: Fundamentals
description: A broad perspective and understanding of informatics as a technical skill set that focuses on user-centered systems and balances legal and ethical considerations and measures. Examines informatics applications in specific and interprofessional contexts.
satisfies: Satisfies GWAR: Graduation Writing Assessment Requirement.
notes: Note(s): This course satisfies graduate-level GWAR in this master’s program.

name: Informatics: Technology Foundations
description: Introduction to computing fundamentals with an emphasis on understanding desktop and network computing, web framework architectures, and basic coding.

name: Informatics: Security Overview
description: Fundamentals of network security, compliance and operational security; threats and vulnerabilities; application, data, and host security; access control and identity management; and cryptography. Students are provided with an opportunity to gain hands-on experience using typical cybersecurity solutions.

name: Big Data Analytics and Management
description: Overview and use of important big data technologies, trends, infrastructure, and management issues that enable users to make informed and strategic decisions with the presence of large-scale data sets.

name: Human Centered Design
description: Designing and developing user-centered knowledge structures for the Web environment.  Core topics are: problems addressed by effective human-computer interaction; how to design for findability; design thinking concepts and tools; prototyping; and informing stakeholders about a content-rich product.

name: Informatics: Project Management
description: Introduces essential strategies and techniques for project management. Topics include: management styles, institutional constraints, project life cycles, stakeholder management, scope definition, risk assessment, project planning tools, and team management.

name: Electronic Records: Foundations
description: Principles and methods of managing records and information as operational, legal and historical evidence in electronic environments. Examines the ways in which new information technologies challenge organizations’ capacities to define, identify, control, manage, and preserve electronic records and information.

name: DAM: Digital Assets Management
description: Concepts, terminology, practice and application of DAM in the private and public sector. Addresses metadata, workflow, taxonomy, data security, governance, and preservation of digital assets.

name: Information Security: Info Assurance
description: Overview of Information Assurance and Risk Management theories, principles, and techniques. This course examines the information assurance frameworks and risk management planning structures used to ensure that an organization’s information resources and assets are protected.

name: Health Informatics
description: Health data and standards, electronic health records (EHR) and other healthcare information, data management concerns and technology governance in the health care environment.

name: Informatics Culminating Project
description: All Informatics students are required to complete a culminating project for the MS in Informatics degree program. The culminating project demonstrates mastery through the application of knowledge and skills developed in the Informatics program. Students select from two options: (1) an Organizational Consulting Project with a real-world partner to address a specific Informatics-related problem; or, (2) a personal e-Portfolio that presents a program-based assessment of all program learning outcomes (core competencies) learned during the MS in Informatics degree program.

name: Epidemiological Methods
description: Introduction to the principles and methods of epidemiologic research. Students are enabled to design, conduct, analyze, and interpret epidemiologic research.

name: Health Data and Analytics
description: Exploration of healthcare informatics and its relation to health information technology. Students will apply basic knowledge and skills from healthcare data mining, data science, data management and professional project management to address practical healthcare business and clinical intelligence issues.

name: Network Security
description: Technical and administrative aspects of information security and assurance. Includes compliance and operational security, Web application attacks, penetration testing, data loss prevention, cloud computing security, psychological and behavioral traits of users vulnerable to cyber and social engineering attacks, and application programming development security.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Graduate Standing or Instructor Consent

name: Computer Digital Forensics
description: Digital forensic investigation activities. Data acquisition, forensic imaging, use of Forensic Tool Kit (FTK) suite of applications (using Access Data virtual labs), locking mechanisms, search and seizure procedures, and report writing.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Graduate Standing or Instructor Consent

name: Tools Lab
description: Security tools used to detect network security threats and vulnerabilities at a microscopic level. Introduction to penetration testing, packet analyzers, standards and cryptography, reconnaissance and malware, hacking, and vulnerability scanning.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Graduate Standing or Instructor Consent

name: Sports Analytics
description: Analytical techniques and quantitative methods used to inform decisions in the sport industry. Theory, development, and application of analytics in sports to support player performance, in-game strategy, team management, sports operations, and fantasy competitions.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Graduate Standing or Instructor Consent

name: Seminar in Informatics
description: Special topics seminar on emerging trends in Informatics. Examples of topics: Artificial Intelligence, Data Aggregation/Analytics, eSports, Health Dashboards & Data Streams, Health Public Policy, Information Ethics, Machine Learning and Race/Gender for Informatics.

name: Information Communities
description: Examines information users and the social, cultural, economic, technological, and political forces that shape their information access and use.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Demonstrated computer literacy.
satisfies: Satisfies GWAR: Graduation Writing Assessment Requirement.
notes: Note(s): This course satisfies graduate-level GWAR in this master’s program.

name: Information Retrieval System Design
description: The systems and knowledge structures that information professionals create and use to connect users with information.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Demonstrated computer literacy.

name: Online Learning: Tools and Strategies
description: This course introduces students to new and emerging technologies used in today’s online learning environment. It covers learning management tools, various social networking platforms, web conferencing, as well as strategies and skills needed for success in online learning.

name: Information Professions
description: Examines the organizations and environments in which information professionals work.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Demonstrated computer literacy.

name: Big Data Technologies
description: Introduction to the technological ecosystem of Big Data and Hadoop as well as the goals and work of Data Science.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Graduate Standing or instructor consent

name: Reference and Information Services
description: Process-oriented examination of how information professionals answer reference questions. Stresses interpersonal skills required for effective question negotiation and sources with which questions are answered.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): INFO 202.
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 3 units.

name: Information Visualization
description: Applying perceptual and cognitive principles to the design and development of information visualization techniques, such as scatterplots, treemaps, parallel coordinates, and GIS visualizations; interactive visualization interface design and implementation; narrative visualization and storytelling; visual analytics for decision making.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Graduate Standing or Instructor Consent

name: Resources and Information Services in Professions and Disciplines
description: Examination of the nature of resources for, and services to, professions and disciplines. Possible disciplines for study may be law, business and economics, life and/or physical sciences, medical sciences, engineering and computer science, maps, and visual and performing arts.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s):
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 9 units when content changes.

name: Government Information Sources
description: Study in government publications and databases, their bibliographic organization, use in all types of libraries and information centers, methods of acquiring information from federal, state and local sources; problems of depository and non-depository collections.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): INFO 210.
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 6 units.

name: Issues in Academic Libraries
description: Investigate current issues that impact the functioning of the academic library. Topics include issues related to social and political environments, clientele, services, collections, physical settings, financing, staffing and future trends in the academic library sector.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): INFO 200, INFO 202 and INFO 204.

name: Issues in Special Libraries and Information Centers
description: This course will investigate current issues that impact the functioning of special libraries/information centers. Topics covered will include issues related to social and political environments, clientele, services, collections, physical settings, financing and staffing, and future trends in the special library/information center sector.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): INFO 200, INFO 202, INFO 204.

name: Issues in Public Libraries
description: This course will investigate current issues that impact the functioning of the public library. Topics covered will include issues related to social and political environments, clientele, services, collections, physical settings, financing and staffing, and future trends in the public library sector.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): INFO 200, INFO 202, INFO 204.

name: School Library Media Centers
description: The role of the school library media teacher and the school library media program in the educational community. Emphasis on creation of effective learning environments, involvement in the curriculum and teaching process as well as philosophies of service and management.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): INFO 204 and INFO 250.

name: Intellectual Freedom Seminar
description: Focuses on current intellectual freedom issues and the centrality of intellectual freedom to librarianship.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): INFO 200, INFO 204.

name: School Library Media Materials
description: Survey of materials in a variety of formats that meet the needs of K12 students. Materials will be examined that support state and national curriculum standards as well as material that support independent reading and learning.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): INFO 200, INFO 202, INFO 203, and INFO 204.

name: Information Technology Tools and Applications
description: Focuses on building practical skills in a variety of networked computer applications. Topics will vary, but will typically include web coding languages and designing web sites.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): INFO 202.

name: Automated Library Systems
description: Review of major systems for library automation. Problems associated with the planning, implementation and use of the systems, negotiation of systems acquisition and trends in the field.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): INFO 200, INFO 202 and INFO 204. Not available to Open University Students.
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 3 units.

name: Database Design and Management
description: Design and implementation of relational databases. Learn about database management systems (such as Oracle), database administration, and database querying with SQL.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): INFO 202. Not available to Open University Students.

name: Online Searching
description: Techniques and concepts for searching online, including strategies, database content, search options, and understanding the information environment. The course includes extensive hands-on experience with subscription search engines.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): INFO 202.

name: Information Technology Tools and Applications - Advanced
description: Designing advanced Web applications using technology such as dynamic HTML and XML and Web programming languages such as XSLT, JavaScript, JSP, Perl, PHP, MYSQL, and ASP. May be repeated for up to 12 units when content changes.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): INFO 202.
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 12 units.

name: Vocabulary Design
description: Survey of principles and practices used to index information-bearing objects such as documents or images. Includes term assignment, review of existing vocabularies, thesaurus design, metadate structures and automatic and natural language processes.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): INFO 202.

name: Beginning Cataloging and Classification
description: Theory and practice of bibliographic control including the study of descriptive cataloging standards (RDA with reference to AACR2), online cataloging using MARC format and other standards, and subject representation using Library of Congress Subject Headings (LCSH), Dewey Decimal Classification (DDC), and Library of Congress Classification (LCC).
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): INFO 202.

name: Design and Implementation of Instructional Strategies for Information Professionals
description: Examination of concepts of instruction in the use of information technologies, information services and sources. Includes investigation of learning theory and instructional design. Emphasis on application of theory through development of instruction and instructional resources in various media for use in a broad array of institutional environments.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): INFO 200. Not available to Open University Students.
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 6 units.

name: Web Usability
description: Through examination of theory, methodologies, and real-life cases, Info 251 offers a user experience (UX) framework for developing information systems. Students learn the principles of user-centric design and style for particular circumstances and populations.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): INFO 202.

name: Information Literacy and Learning
description: Provides theory and practice for teaching information literacy in an LIS setting. The course emphasizes learning theory as well as the practical aspects of teaching. Students learn methods and tools for teaching in both synchronous and asynchronous settings.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): INFO 200

name: Archives and Manuscripts
description: An introduction to the theory and practice of managing archival documents, such as personal papers, institutional records, photographs, electronic records and other unpublished material. Topics covered include manuscript and records acquisition and appraisal, arrangement and description, conservation and preservation, reference and access.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): INFO 200, INFO 202, INFO 204.

name: Preservation Management
description: An introduction to the philosophies and techniques used to preserve manuscript, printed and digital materials. Examination of the evolution of preservation practice, with emphasis on emerging theories, models and technologies in digital preservation.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): INFO 200, INFO 202, INFO 204.

name: Programming and Services for Children Ages 0-8
description: This course examines the importance of programming for children, including parent education programs, story hours, outreach techniques, services with schools, summer reading programs, and program series such as weekly or monthly programs on manga, knitting, book discussions, or homework help.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): INFO 200

name: Programming and Services for Young Adults Ages 9-18
description: Administration and delivery of professional library and information services with multi-cultural young adult populations: features critical youth studies cultural/historical research, resources, policy, threats, tools, methods, service philosophies and management skills necessary for a comprehensive profile of YA library services.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): INFO 200

name: Materials for Children
description: Survey of materials in a variety of formats including nonfiction, beginning chapter books, fictional genres, paperback series and electronic resources, and how they can help meet developmental needs. Collection development tools and techniques for this material will also be included.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): INFO 200, and either INFO 260A or INFO 261A

name: Materials for Young Adults Ages
description: This course will allow students to take an in depth look at materials in a variety of formats for teens, including fiction, popular nonfiction, graphic novels, movies, computer games, websites, other media, and determine how they can meet developmental needs.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): INFO 200, and either INFO 260A or INFO 261A

name: Collection Management
description: Study of collection management in all types of libraries and information centers. Includes analysis of information needs, criteria for selection, collection use evaluation and resources for collection development.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): INFO 202, INFO 204.

name: Services to Youth
description: Seminar in planning, developing and evaluating youth services in public libraries. Special needs of children and young adults in the public library, liaison with schools, reference services, and collection planning will be featured.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): INFO 200, and either INFO 260A or INFO 261A
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 9 units when content changes.
sustainability: Sustainability Focused - SDG 4: Quality Education

name: History of Youth Literature
description: The history of literature for children and teens from its earliest examples to today’s current trends, including how childhood has changed over the years, the influence of culture on those changes, and on the materials created for children and teens.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): INFO 200

name: Early Childhood Literacy
description: Covers a wide variety of topics important for an understanding of early childhood multi-literacies in library and non-library environments, including current research, best practices and practical examples that can be implemented in various work environments with children.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): INFO 200
sustainability: Sustainability Focused - SDG 4: Quality Education

name: Genres and Topics in Youth Literature
description: Various topics and genres in literature for children or teens will be examined in depth, such as graphic novels, poetry, fantasy, science fiction, publishing and writing trends, reading motivation techniques, literature in the classroom, and the art of picture books. Repeatable for up to 9 units.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): INFO 200, and either INFO 260A or INFO 261A
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 9 units.

name: Library Services for Racially and Ethnically Diverse Communities
description: This course focuses on developing skills for planning, implementing and evaluating programs for addressing the information needs of racially, ethnically and linguistically diverse communities. Reviews the major national, state and local studies.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): INFO 200 and INFO 204. Not available to Open University Students.

name: History of Books and Libraries
description: This class traces the development of the book through its many stages and explores how the creation, use, and storage of information are affected by social and technological change. The development of libraries and librarianship and how they have accommodated themselves to the changing form of the book will also be considered.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): INFO 200

name: Seminar in Contemporary Issues
description: Investigation of major contemporary issues within the information profession. Topics range from censorship to the need for a national information policy and change each time the course is offered.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): INFO 200, INFO 202, and INFO 204.
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 9 units when content changes.

name: Seminar in Library Management
description: Application of management theory to specific problems. Readings and discussions of the development of effective strategies for planning and implementing organizational change. Content changes each time offered.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): INFO 200 and INFO 204. Not available to Open University Students.
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 9 units when content changes.

name: Marketing of Information Products and Services
description: Applications of marketing concepts to library and information services. Market analysis, use surveys, market targeting and introduction of services.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): INFO 200 and INFO 204. Not available to Open University Students.

name: Seminar in Archives and Records Management
description: In-depth study of current issues and practices in archives and records management. The course addresses new areas of research and application such as oral history, sound and visual archives, digitization, archival automation, archival security, genealogy, and more.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): INFO 200, INFO 202, INFO 204
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 12 units.

name: Applied Research Methods
description: Selection, formulation and development of problems in library and information science research. Evaluation of published research and in the field.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): INFO 200, INFO 202, INFO 204
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 6 units.

name: Interpersonal Communication Skills for Librarians
description: The principles and practice of interpersonal communication; small group and peer relationships.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): INFO 200 and INFO 204. Not available to Open University Students.
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 3 units.

name: Seminar in Information Science
description: Current issues and problems in information retrieval as related to concepts and theories of information science.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): INFO 200. Not available to Open University Students.
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 12 units when content changes.

name: Advanced Topics in Library and Information Science
description: Advanced independent examination of selected issues and problems in library and information science with a focus on the integration of theory and practice. Issues and problems addressed will vary each semester.

name: Professional Experience: Projects
description: Gives students the opportunity to complete a professional project related to the theory and method of Library & Information Science in an information organization or institution, and to gain practical experience in one or more areas of LIS.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): INFO 200, INFO 202, INFO 204, plus six advanced courses.

name: Introduction to Data Networking
description: An introduction to computer networking in both Lan and Wan environments with an emphasis on hands-on projects.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): INFO 200, INFO 202, INFO 204. INFO 240 desirable.

name: Professional Experiences: Internships
description: Supervised professional experience in an approved public, academic, or special library or other information-based organization.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): INFO 200, INFO 202, INFO 204, and three advanced courses.
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 8 units.

name: School Library Field Work
description: A supervised professional experience of school librarianship at the levels of both elementary and secondary (middle or high) schools. Emphasis is on observation and guided practice with a credentialed school librarian (library media teacher).
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): INFO 200, INFO 202, INFO 204.

name: Special Studies
description: Advanced individual research and projects related to libraries and information systems. Available only to those students who have completed the major portion of the degree coursework.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): INFO 200, INFO 202, INFO 204, instructor consent.
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 6 units.

name: Thesis
description: Approved thesis proposal and consent of a faculty advisor required.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): INFO 200, INFO 202, INFO 204, INFO 285.
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 6 units.

name: Culminating Experience Supervision
description: Continued work on thesis.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Outstanding RP grade in a preceding semester in a thesis class
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 16 units.
notes: Note(s): No Degree Credit.

name: Query Languages
description: Introduction to the features and functionalities of structured query language (SQL) focusing on manipulating data in a database, creating tables and indexes, modifying stored records, creating database objects

name: Python Programming
description: Hands-on introduction to Python focusing on solving a problem by developing flowcharts and algorithms, building a Python application using Python I/O (input/output), variables and data types, conditionals, and loops, Python packages and integrated development environment (IDE).

name: Web Development
description: The structure and functionality of the world wide web and modular web design techniques. Covers HTML5, CSS, and JavaScript. Topics also include cultural issues in website designing, and accessible and responsive web design.

name: Computer Operating Systems
description: Overview of  the design and implementation of computer operating systems (OS) with emphasis on the three major subsystems: process management (processes, threads, CPU scheduling, synchronization, and deadlock), memory management (segmentation, paging, swapping), and file systems; and distributed systems.

name: Technical Writing for Information
description: Introduces students to the principles of effective communication for technical, scientific, and business environments. Students will create written work in a variety of standard formats and use appropriate style to address the needs of targeted audiences.

name: Online Learning: Tools and Strategies for Success
description: Introduces students to a variety of successful strategies in the use of new and emerging technologies found in today’s online learning environment. Covers learning management tools, web conferencing, social software, university resources, skills for success in an online environment.

name: Technology, Culture, and Society
description: Navigating the social, political, legal and ethical issues in data processing and use. Topics: social and political factors that interact with data mining, visualization and analytics, explainable AI and FATE (Fairness, Accountability, Transparency, and Ethics).

name: Information and Data Science
