description: This course examines various areas of norm violations and rule-breaking behaviors including, alcohol and drug use/abuse, criminal violence, corporate deviance, gang violence, and sexual deviance, child abuse, hate crime, mental illness, computer piracy and evaluates justice policies.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing.

name: Seminar: Penal Policies and Justice
description: A critical review of historical and contemporary theoretical models. Evaluation of current research on treatment, rehabilitation/punishment models and their use in adult and juvenile institutions and community settings.

name: Seminar: Comparative Criminology & Criminal Justice
description: This course provides a comparative perspective on crime, violence and punishment in contemporary global societies. The course analyzes transnational trends in crime, as well as organizational responses to criminality. Topics include international drug markets, sexual commerce, child soldiers, and terrorism.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Graduate Standing

name: Seminar in Reproductive Justice
description: Interdisciplinary exploration of the issues included in the umbrella of the Reproductive Justice framework, including an examination of institutions, laws and policies, historical accounts of these issues, and contemporary threats to reproductive justice.

name: Community Justice
description: Collaborative justice efforts as they relate to family violence in the American justice system. Emphasis on the role of the community and how citizens can be involved in collaborative justice.

name: Neurobiology Response to Family Violence
description: In this course, we explore current research, models, and theories introduced through the field of Interpersonal Neurobiology to better understand trauma, collaboration, and violence. Using IPNB concepts, students work to improve sustainable impact in reducing family violence and its effects.

name: Comparative Criminal Justice Systems
description: Theory-based comparative analysis of US criminal justice system with criminal justice systems around the world. Course focuses on legal traditions, policing, courts and corrections, with emphasis on the role of geographical, historical and cultural traditions in shaping criminal justice.
satisfies: Satisfies GWAR: Graduation Writing Assessment Requirement.
notes: Note(s): This course satisfies graduate-level GWAR in this master’s program.

name: Applied Research Methods and Statistics
description: This course introduces research concepts, methodology, design, qualitative and quantitative data analysis, interpretation, and SPSS use for understanding crime and evaluating criminal justice issues, policies, and agency practices.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): JS 114 or equivalent

name: Crime and Gender Around the World
description: This course is designed to examine the growing body of literature that deals with women’s experiences about crime and justice to understand the impact of gendered relations on criminal behavior and justice outcomes.
sustainability: Sustainability Focused - SDG 16: Peace, Justice and Strong Institutions

name: Immigration and International Law
description: This online course provides an overview of the United States legislation and policy relating to immigration and explores the opportunities and challenges facing policy-makers in the context of domestic law and policy, as well as global norms and regimes.

name: Cyber Forensics
description: This online course teaches procedures for identification, preservation and extraction of electronic evidence. Public and private sector responses to cyber security issues in national and international contexts are discussed.

name: Global Terrorism
description: This online course examines terrorism and the role it plays in today’s complex world as well as the theory and practice of international terrorism.

name: International Human Rights
description: This online course focuses on the politics and history of the conception, protection, and violation of human rights in global perspectives as well as the examination of the practical applications of the theory.

name: Policing in Global Contexts
description: This online course examines policing from a global perspective. The objective of this course is to orient students as to how police organizations operate in different parts of the world in terms organization, crime control, and crime prevention.

name: International Criminology and Juvenile Delinquency
description: This online course will examine: (1) issues fundamental to criminological and juvenile delinquency research and practical applications; (2) the current and emerging national/international crime and delinquency issues; and (3) criminal and juvenile justice policies adopted by different countries.

name: Applied Project
description: For this project, a substantial paper of a justice agency program, justice policy, and/or organizational issue is required. The contents will be determined by the student in consultation with the instructor, with whom the student meets regularly for supervision.

name: Justice Practicum
description: Supervised placement in a justice organization or agency in a position emphasizing analytical and research skills and/or managerial responsibilities. Culminating research or policy paper required.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing and graduate coordinator consent.

name: Seminar in Special Topics
description: In-depth exploration and analysis of selected justice-related topic. Course will consider relevant theories, issues, and research on the selected topic.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing or instructor consent.

name: Program Evaluation Project
description: A substantial paper/mock evaluation of a justice agency program, justice policy, or organizational issue.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): JS 201, JS 202, and JS 203. Not available to Open University students.

name: Special Study
description: Advanced individual research not covered in a regular course and not related to the project or the thesis topic.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Instructor and Grad Coordinator permission. Not available to Open University Students.
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 18 units.

name: Master’s Thesis
description: Six units are required to complete the thesis and oral defense of the thesis. Required for Plan A. Must be repeated for a total of 6 semester units.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Advancement to candidacy for the MS degree and thesis chair consent. Not available to Open University Students.
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 6 units.

name: Thesis/Project Supervision
description: Continued work on thesis or project.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Outstanding RP grade in a preceding semester in a project or thesis class
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 2 units.

name: Elementary Hebrew
description: Basic structure of the language in the context of culture.
crosslist: Cross-listed with HEBR 10A / RELS 10A. World Languages and Literatures is responsible for scheduling.

name: Elementary Hebrew
description: Basic structure of the language in the context of culture.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): HEBR 10A (or equivalent).
crosslist: Cross-listed with HEBR 10B / RELS 10B. World Languages and Literatures is responsible for scheduling.

name: Intermediate Hebrew
description: Developing speaking skills.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): HEBR 10A and HEBR 10B (or equivalent).
crosslist: Cross-listed with HEBR 15A / RELS 15A.  World Languages and Literatures is responsible for scheduling.

name: Intermediate Hebrew
description: Developing speaking skills.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): HEBR 10A and HEBR 10B (or equivalent).
crosslist: Cross-listed with HEBR 15B / RELS 15B. World Languages and Literatures is responsible for scheduling.

name: Bible History and Literature
description: The Bible in context of its history, literary sources and as a reflection of Jewish and Christian traditions. Motifs and themes in light of their original audience, historic usage and contemporary development.
satisfies: Satisfies C2: Humanities.
crosslist: Cross-listed with HUM 90 / MDES 90 / RELS 90. Humanities is responsible for scheduling.

name: Advanced Hebrew
description: Readings, grammar, discussion and composition.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Four semesters of college Hebrew (or equivalent).
crosslist: Cross-listed with HEBR 102A / RELS 102A. World Languages and Literatures is responsible for scheduling.

name: Advanced Hebrew
description: Readings, grammar, discussion and composition.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): 12 units of college Hebrew (or equivalent).
crosslist: Cross-listed with HEBR 102B / RELS 102B. World Languages and Literatures is responsible for scheduling.

name: Special Topics in Jewish Studies
description: Special Topics in Jewish Studies. Topics vary and will be announced each semester. Repeatable for credit when topic changes.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing.
crosslist: Cross-listed with HIST 111 / HUM 111 / RELS 111. History is responsible for scheduling.

name: Holocaust Literature
description: Survey of literature written by survivors or witnesses of the Holocaust, the destruction of European Jewry during World War II, focusing upon diaries, memoirs, fiction, and occasionally poetry and drama. Writers may include Elie Wiesel, Primo Levi, Anne Frank, Charlotte Delbo.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Completion of Core General Education and upper division standing are prerequisites to all SJSU studies courses. Completion of, or co-registration in, 100W is strongly recommended.
satisfies: Satisfies SJSU Studies V: Cultures and Global Understanding.
crosslist: Cross-listed with ENGL 126 / FORL 126 / HUM 126. English and Comparative Literature is responsible for scheduling.

name: Middle Eastern Politics
description: Study of unfolding events in the Middle East. Themes include: the failure of democratic movements, nuclear proliferation and terrorism, US foreign policy towards the region, the Israel-Palestine conflict, urbanization, gender and human rights.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing.
crosslist: Cross-listed with MDES 144 / POLS 144. Political Science is responsible for scheduling.

name: Individual Studies
description: Directed studies in relevant fields not covered by courses offered.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Instructor consent and program coordinator.
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 3 units.

name: Adapted Physical Activities
description: Structured individualized physical activities to enhance physical/motor fitness and develop an active, health-oriented lifestyle for students unable to participate in the general activity program.
satisfies: Satisfies PE: Physical Education.
notes: Note(s): Movement Area 2 Fitness

name: Beginning Swimming
description: This course is designed for the non-swimmer and beginning swimmer. It is assumed that all students enrolled in the class have had little or no experience in learning the basic skills of swimming. The course is designed to instruct the student in the basic skills necessary to enable him/her to swim safely in deep water. There are no prerequisites for the course.
satisfies: Satisfies PE: Physical Education.
notes: Note(s): Movement Area 4 Individual/Dual

name: Intermediate Swimming
description: This course is designed to meet the needs of students who have satisfactorily completed the skills involved in beginning swimming.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Beginning level or its equivalent.
satisfies: Satisfies PE: Physical Education.
notes: Note(s): Movement Area 4 Individual/Dual

name: Advanced Swimming
description: This course is designed to refine and extend the development of advanced skills in swimming.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Intermediate level or its equivalent.
satisfies: Satisfies PE: Physical Education.
notes: Note(s): Movement Area 4 Individual/Dual

name: Water Polo
description: Fundamental skills, techniques, strategies, rules, and knowledge necessary to safely and correctly play water polo.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Beginning level swimming proficiency.
notes: Note(s): Movement Area 5 Team

name: Mexican Folklorico Dance
description: Introduction to Mexican Folklorico Dance. Focus is on the development of fundamental Mexican Folk dance skills and knowledge.  Review of the interrelationship of dance culture to origins, holidays, people, and historical context.  Students learn danzas & Mestizo dances from various states and regions of Mexico (e.g. Veracruz Huasteca, Tamaulipas Norte) and indigenous community (e.g. Oaxaca Mixe) dance categories.
satisfies: Satisfies PE: Physical Education.
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 4 units.
crosslist: Cross-listed with CCS 7. Chicana Chicano Studies is responsible for scheduling.
notes: Note(s): Movement Area 3 Dance

name: Skin and SCUBA Diving
description: Both skin and SCUBA diving skills for enjoyment and to understand dangers connected with the sport. Only one unit can be applied for the physical education graduation requirement.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): KIN 2C (or equivalent).
satisfies: Satisfies PE: Physical Education.
notes: Note(s): Movement Area 6 Adventure

name: Beginning Sailing
description: Basic skills and safety knowledge in small boats for those with little or no sailing experience.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Student must be able to swim 100 yards without stopping, tread water for 5 minutes, and exit from an overturned dinghy. Students will be tested for this in the SPX pool.
satisfies: Satisfies PE: Physical Education.
notes: Note(s): Movement Area 6 Adventure

name: Beginning Kayaking
description: Beginning skills and knowledge for those with little or no experience of flat water kayaking. The emphasis will be on safe operation at all times.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Students must be able to swim 100 yards without stopping, tread water for 5 minutes, and exit from an overturned kayak. Students will be tested for this in the SPX pool.
satisfies: Satisfies PE: Physical Education.
notes: Note(s): Movement Area 6 Adventure

name: Beginning Rowing
description: Basic skills and knowledge for those with little or no experience of sweep rowing or sculling. Initial classes will be on indoor rowing machines, then eight-oared boats will be used. Students will learn both how to row and how to cox; improvement of strength / fitness is central.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Swim 100 yards without stopping; thread water for 5 minutes; don lifejacket in the water. Tested in pool.
satisfies: Satisfies PE: Physical Education.
notes: Note(s): Movement Area 5 Team

name: Beginning Rugby
description: This course is designed to familiarize the student with the rules, skills and basic concepts of modern Rugby Union Football. The class will equip the student to be an informed rugby spectator and/ or participant.
satisfies: Satisfies PE: Physical Education.
notes: Note(s): Movement Area 5 Team

name: Beginning Volleyball
description: This course provides the student with the opportunity to learn and develop the basic rules and skills of volleyball, the 6-6 offense and the defense against the 6-6 offense.
satisfies: Satisfies PE: Physical Education.
notes: Note(s): Movement Area 5 Team

name: Intermediate Volleyball
description: This course provides the intermediate student with the opportunity to refine and perfect the basic volleyball skills and to master individual positions when using the 6-2 offense and the defense against the offense.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Beginning level or its equivalent.
satisfies: Satisfies PE: Physical Education.
notes: Note(s): Movement Area 5 Team

name: Advanced Volleyball
description: This course is designed to teach advanced skills, principles and techniques necessary and fundamental to understanding and playing volleyball.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Intermediate level or its equivalent.
satisfies: Satisfies PE: Physical Education.
notes: Note(s): Movement Area 5 Team

name: Beginning Basketball
description: This course is designed to assist students in the development of fundamental skills necessary for effective involvement in playing the game of basketball.
satisfies: Satisfies PE: Physical Education.
notes: Note(s): Movement Area 5 Team

name: Intermediate Basketball
description: This course provides the intermediate student with the opportunity to refine and perfect basic basketball skills.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Beginning level or its equivalent.
satisfies: Satisfies PE: Physical Education.
notes: Note(s): Movement Area 5 Team

name: Beginning Team Handball
description: Development of beginning team handball skills. Knowledge and skills commensurate with playing beginning team handball. Improves the health-related components of fitness through a variety of drills and plays. Also provides an overall historical background of the sport of team handball.
satisfies: Satisfies PE: Physical Education
notes: Note(s): Movement Area 5 Team

name: Beginning Handball
description: This course is focused on the development of fundamental handball skills, basic tactics, simple strategies, etiquette and sportsmanship, rules, and their application in beginning games.
satisfies: Satisfies PE: Physical Education.
notes: Note(s): Movement Area 4 Individual/Dual

name: Intermediate Handball
description: Course focuses on improving the quality of fundamental handball skills, learning intermediate handball skills/drills and application, developing intermediate handball tactics and strategies, good sportsmanship, and playing more effective single and double games in different formats.
notes: Note(s): Movement Area 4 Individual/Dual

name: Beginning Soccer
description: This course is designed to introduce students to the game of soccer, and to provide students with the fundamental ability and knowledge needed to enjoy this game as players and as spectators.
satisfies: Satisfies PE: Physical Education.
notes: Note(s): Movement Area 5 Team

name: Intermediate Soccer
description: Designed for students with previous soccer experience to refine technical skills, enhance offensive and defensive tactical awareness, learn various strategy and game philosophies, and improve conditioning. Develop a greater understanding of the rules of the game with an emphasis on the application of skills and strategy in game play.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): KIN 19A (or equivalent) or Instructor Consent.
satisfies: Satisfies PE: Physical Education.
notes: Note(s): Movement Area 5 Team

name: Beginning Badminton
description: This course is focused on the development of fundamental badminton skills, basic tactics, simple strategies, etiquette, rules, and their application in single and double games.
satisfies: Satisfies PE: Physical Education.
notes: Note(s): Movement Area 4 Individual/Dual

name: Intermediate Badminton
description: This course is focused on improving the quality of fundamental badminton skills, learning intermediate badminton skills and their application, developing intermediate badminton tactics and strategies, good sportsmanship, and playing more effective single and double games in elimination, round robin, and team competitions.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Completed SJSU beginning badminton class or have equivalent skills/knowledge.
satisfies: Satisfies PE: Physical Education.
notes: Note(s): Movement Area 4 Individual/Dual

name: Advanced Badminton
description: This course is focused on improving the quality of fundamental and intermediate badminton skills, learning advanced skills and their application, developing advanced badminton tactics and strategies, good sportsmanship, and playing high level games.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Completed SJSU intermediate class or show equivalent skills/knowledge.
satisfies: Satisfies PE: Physical Education.
notes: Note(s): Movement Area 4 Individual/Dual

name: Beginning Tennis
description: This course is designed to give students a basic understanding of the game of tennis. Students will be given a chance to learn through lecture, demonstration, drilling and match play.
satisfies: Satisfies PE: Physical Education.
notes: Note(s): Movement Area 4 Individual/Dual

name: Intermediate Tennis
description: This course is focused on improving the quality of fundamental tennis skills, learning intermediate tennis skills and drills and application, developing intermediate tennis tactics and strategies, establishing proper manners, and playing more effective single and double games in elimination, round robin, and team competitions.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Completed SJSU beginning class or have equivalent skills/knowledge.
satisfies: Satisfies PE: Physical Education.
notes: Note(s): Movement Area 4 Individual/Dual

name: Beginning Racquetball
description: This course is focused on the development of fundamental racquetball skills, basic tactics, simple strategies, etiquette, rules, and their application in single and double games.
satisfies: Satisfies PE: Physical Education.
notes: Note(s): Movement Area 4 Individual/Dual

name: Intermediate Racquetball
description: This course is focused on improving the quality of fundamental racquetball skills, learning intermediate racquetball skills/drills and application, developing intermediate racquetball tactics and strategies, good sportsmanship, and playing more effective single and double games in different formats.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Completed SJSU beginning class or have equivalent skills/knowledge.
satisfies: Satisfies PE: Physical Education.
notes: Note(s): Movement Area 4 Individual/Dual

name: Beginning Archery
description: This course is designed to introduce the student to the basic skills and concepts, provides the opportunity to learn, practice and analyze correct shooting form and to participate in a variety of archery tournaments.
satisfies: Satisfies PE: Physical Education.
notes: Note(s): Movement Area 4 Individual/Dual

name: Intermediate Archery
description: This course builds upon beginning level skills and knowledge and provides the opportunity to shoot a variety of different archery rounds.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Beginning level or its equivalent.
satisfies: Satisfies PE: Physical Education.
notes: Note(s): Movement Area 4 Individual/Dual

name: Beginning Bowling
description: This course is designed to give students an understanding of the sport of bowling and develop fundamental bowling skills.
satisfies: Satisfies PE: Physical Education.
notes: Note(s): Movement Area 4 Individual/Dual

name: Intermediate Bowling
description: This course is designed to meet the needs of students who have satisfactorily completed the skills in beginning bowling. The course will add more advanced theory and techniques.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Beginning level or its equivalent.
satisfies: Satisfies PE: Physical Education.
notes: Note(s): Movement Area 4 Individual/Dual

name: Beginning Golf
description: Designed for those who have never played golf or who have played very little and have had no basic formal instruction. Provides the student with a sound set of fundamentals to prepare for further instruction, if desired.
satisfies: Satisfies PE: Physical Education.
notes: Note(s): Movement Area 4 Individual/Dual

name: Intermediate Golf
description: Development of intermediate golf skills and knowledge with a focus on technique that facilitates the acquisition of consistent intermediate level performance.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): KIN 25A or equivalent.
satisfies: Satisfies PE: Physical Education.
notes: Note(s): Movement Area 4 Individual/Dual

name: Beginning Table Tennis
description: This course is focused on the development of fundamental table tennis skills, basic tactics, simple strategies, etiquette, rules, and their application of in single and double games.
satisfies: Satisfies PE: Physical Education.
notes: Note(s): Movement Area 4 Individual/Dual

name: Intermediate Table Tennis
description: This course is focused on improving the quality of fundamental table tennis skills, learning intermediate table tennis skills and drills and their application, developing intermediate tactics and strategies, good sportsmanship, and playing more effective single and double games in elimination, round robin, and team competitions.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Completed SJSU beginning class or have equivalent skills/knowledge.
satisfies: Satisfies PE: Physical Education.
notes: Note(s): Movement Area 4 Individual/Dual

name: Beginning Gymnastics
description: This course is designed to develop the student’s awareness and performance of basic skills in gymnastics.
satisfies: Satisfies PE: Physical Education.
notes: Note(s): Movement Area 4 Individual/Dual

name: Cardio Kickboxing
description: Cardio Kickboxing is a non-contact aerobic conditioning activity combining punches, kicks, traditional aerobic skills, and fitness activities. The course is designed to enhance cardiovascular endurance, muscular strength, and muscular endurance.
satisfies: Satisfies PE: Physical Education.
notes: Note(s): Movement Area 2 Fitness

name: Pilates
description: Pilates employs an established exercise protocol designed to develop core strength, flexibility, posture, and range of motion. The course covers the fundamentals of a Pilates workout with an emphasis on breathing, alignment, neutral spine, and core stability.
satisfies: Satisfies PE: Physical Education.
notes: Note(s): Movement Area 2 Fitness

name: Body Sculpting
description: Body sculpting employs exercise augmented with moderate weights to enhance fitness. The course is designed to improve muscle tone and endurance, flexibility, balance, and core stability.
satisfies: Satisfies PE: Physical Education.
notes: Note(s): Movement Area 2 Fitness

name: Aerobics
description: Aerobics incorporates exercise and music, using large, continuous, rhythmic movements to elevate the heart rate and produce a training effect. The course is designed to improve muscle tone and enhance cardiorespiratory endurance.
satisfies: Satisfies PE: Physical Education.
notes: Note(s): Movement Area 2 Fitness

name: Advanced Aerobic Activities
description: Aerobic activities incorporating high intensity interval training, circuit training, cardio kickboxing, power step, and resistance training. This course is designed to enhance cardiorespiratory endurance, muscular strength and muscular endurance.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): KIN 32 or KIN 34 or instructor consent.
satisfies: Satisfies PE: Physical Education.
notes: Note(s): Movement Area 2 Fitness

name: Step Training
description: Step training is a low-impact aerobic conditioning activity designed to enhance cardiorespiratory endurance, muscular strength, and muscular endurance.
satisfies: Satisfies PE: Physical Education.
notes: Note(s): Movement Area 2 Fitness

name: Beginning Weight Training
description: This course is designed to teach the basic concepts of weight training for muscular strength and endurance. Its goal is to provide students with knowledge about the principles involved in weight training and the health-related components of fitness through a variety of exercises.
satisfies: Satisfies PE: Physical Education.
notes: Note(s): Movement Area 2 Fitness

name: Intermediate Weight Training
description: This course is designed for individuals with prior training experience and involves higher level exercises. Students will be exposed to a wide variety of machine as well as free weight exercises and will then design a program based on individual needs.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Beginning level or its equivalent.
satisfies: Satisfies PE: Physical Education.
notes: Note(s): Movement Area 2 Fitness

name: Conditioning through Cross Training
description: Designed to teach basic concepts of health and fitness by using a variety of exercise modalities to increase cardiovascular fitness and improve full-body strength and power. Students will acquire knowledge about the principles involved with cardiovascular fitness, physical conditioning, and the health and skill related components of physical fitness.
satisfies: Satisfies PE: Physical Education.
notes: Note(s): Movement Area 2 Fitness

name: Fitness Walking
description: Fitness walking is a low-impact conditioning activity designed to develop cardiovascular fitness.
satisfies: Satisfies PE: Physical Education.
notes: Note(s): Movement Area 2 Fitness

name: Beginning Jogging
description: Jogging is a moderate-impact activity designed to improve cardiovascular fitness.
satisfies: Satisfies PE: Physical Education.
notes: Note(s): Movement Area 2 Fitness

name: Topics in Modern Dance I
description: Training experience in the field of beginning modern dance with varied topics. Can be repeated when topic changes.
satisfies: Satisfies PE: Physical Education.
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 8 units.
crosslist: Cross-listed with DANC 40A. Film and Theatre is responsible for scheduling.
notes: Note(s): Movement Area 3 Dance

name: Topics in Ballet I
description: Training experience in the field of beginning ballet dance with varied topics. Can be repeated when topic changes.
satisfies: Satisfies PE: Physical Education.
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 8 units.
crosslist: Cross-listed with DANC 41A. Film and Theatre is responsible for scheduling.
notes: Note(s): Movement Area 3 Dance

name: Topics in Jazz Dance I
description: Training experience in the field of beginning Jazz dance with varied topics. Can be repeated when topic changes.
satisfies: Satisfies PE: Physical Education.
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 8 units.
crosslist: Cross-listed with DANC 42A. Film and Theatre is responsible for scheduling.
notes: Note(s): Movement Area 3 Dance

name: Beginning Lindy Hop and Night Club Swing
description: This course is focused on the development of fundamental Swing dance skills and knowledge. Steps, technique, and styling will be drawn from Lindy Hop, Jitterbug, Street Swing, Jive and Triple-Time Swing dances.
satisfies: Satisfies PE: Physical Education.
crosslist: Cross-listed with DANC 45A. Kinesiology is responsible for scheduling.
notes: Note(s): Movement Area 3 Dance

name: Beginning Social Dance
description: This course is focused on the development of fundamental social dance skills and knowledge. Dances will be selected from the American Smooth (e.g. Waltz, Tango), American Rhythm (e.g. Rumba, Cha Cha) and night club (e.g. Hustle, West Coast Swing) dance categories.
satisfies: Satisfies PE: Physical Education.
crosslist: Cross-listed with DANC 46A. Kinesiology is responsible for scheduling.
notes: Note(s): Movement Area 3 Dance

name: Beginning West Coast Swing
description: Designed to improve students’ understanding of West Coast Swing dancing and to improve fundamental dance skills common to the dance.
satisfies: Satisfies PE: Physical Education.
notes: Note(s): Movement Area 3 Dance

name: Beginning Latin Dance
description: This course is focused on the development of fundamental Latin dance skills and knowledge. Dances will be selected from the International Latin, American Rhythm (e.g. Rumba, Cha Cha) and night club (e.g. Salsa) dance categories.
satisfies: Satisfies PE: Physical Education.
crosslist: Cross-listed with DANC 48A. Kinesiology is responsible for scheduling.
notes: Note(s): Movement Area 3 Dance

name: Topics in Tap Dance I
description: Training and experience in the field of beginning tap dance with varied topics. Can be repeated when topic changes.
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 2 units.
crosslist: Cross-listed with DANC 49A. Film and Theatre is responsible for scheduling.
notes: Note(s): Movement Area 3 Dance

name: Tai Chi (Non-Combative)
description: Emphasis on knowledge and skill, development of the standard Simplified Tai Chi Form and applications of Tai Chi for life. It is assumed that students enrolled in the class have had little or no experience in Tai Chi.
satisfies: Satisfies PE: Physical Education.
notes: Note(s): Movement Area 2 Fitness

name: Beginning Aikido
description: This course is focused on the philosophy, history, and basic skills related to the Japanese-derived martial art of Aikido.
satisfies: Satisfies PE: Physical Education.
notes: Note(s): Movement Area 1 Combatives

name: Intermediate Aikido
description: This course is focused on the development of intermediate level skills and knowledge related to the Japanese-derived martial art of Aikido. It builds upon the basic movement patterns and falling skills introduced in the beginning class.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): KIN 51A or equivalent Aikido skills and experience.
satisfies: Satisfies PE: Physical Education.
notes: Note(s): Movement Area 1 Combatives

name: Beginning Judo
description: This course is focused on development the fundamental skills and knowledge related to Judo. Included are basic groundwork and throwing techniques.
satisfies: Satisfies PE: Physical Education.
notes: Note(s): Movement Area 1 Combatives

name: Intermediate Judo
description: This course is focused on development of intermediate level ground and throwing skills and learning in-depth strategies, philosophy, and culture related to Judo. It builds upon the basic ukemi, newaza, and tachiwaza techniques learned in the beginning class.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): KIN 52A or equivalent judo skills and experience.
satisfies: Satisfies PE: Physical Education.
notes: Note(s): Movement Area 1 Combatives

name: Competitive Judo
description: Prepares students to use Judo techniques in competitive tournaments. The course will offer intermediate and advanced skills (standing, mat and falling techniques) and strategies to improve competitiveness.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): KIN 52A or KIN 52B, and/or instructor consent.
satisfies: Satisfies PE: Physical Education.
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 12 units.
notes: Note(s): Movement Area 1 Combatives

name: Beginning Karate
description: This course is focused on development of fundamental skills and knowledge related to Karate. Included are basic kicking, punching, and blocking techniques.
satisfies: Satisfies PE: Physical Education.
notes: Note(s): Movement Area 1 Combatives

name: Intermediate Karate
description: This course is focused on development of intermediate level skills and knowledge related to Karate. It builds upon the fundamental skills and techniques developed in the beginning class.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): KIN 53A or equivalent karate skills and experience.
satisfies: Satisfies PE: Physical Education.
notes: Note(s): Movement Area 1 Combatives

name: Beginning Tae Kwon Do
description: This course is focused on development of fundamental skills and knowledge related to Tae Kwon Do. Included are basic patterns (poomse), kicking and one-step defenses.
satisfies: Satisfies PE: Physical Education.
notes: Note(s): Movement Area 1 Combatives

name: Intermediate Tae Kwon Do
description: This course is focused on development of intermediate level skills and knowledge related to Tae Kwon Do. It builds upon the fundamental skills and techniques developed in the beginning Tae Kwon Do class.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): KIN 54A or equivalent Tae Kwon Do skills and experience.
satisfies: Satisfies PE: Physical Education.
notes: Note(s): Movement Area 1 Combatives

name: Beginning Self-Defense
description: This course is focused on development of fundamental skills and knowledge related to self defense. Included are mental and physical self-defense skills and techniques applicable under a variety of conditions.
satisfies: Satisfies PE: Physical Education.
notes: Note(s): Movement Area 1 Combatives

name: Introductory Brazilian Jiu-Jitsu
description: Development of the essential skills and principles of Brazilian jiu-jitsu practice.  Included are the basic escapes, sweeps, and submissions from the most common positions.
notes: Note(s): Movement Area 1 Combatives

name: Beginning Hatha Yoga
description: In this course the student will learn the correct movements, postures, and sequence used in traditional Hatha Yoga.
satisfies: Satisfies PE: Physical Education.
notes: Note(s): Movement Area 2 Fitness

name: Intermediate Hatha Yoga
description: Further exploration of the theories and practices of Hatha Yoga encompassing the second level series of traditional intermediate Hatha Yoga postures, breathing exercises, and relaxation techniques.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Beginning level or its equivalent.
satisfies: Satisfies PE: Physical Education.
notes: Note(s): Movement Area 2 Fitness

name: Beginning Ice Skating
description: A beginning ice skating course that covers the skills identified by the International Ice Skating Association (IISA).
satisfies: Satisfies PE: Physical Education.
notes: Note(s): Movement Area 4 Individual/Dual

name: Beginning Hiking and Backpacking
description: An introductory course designed to impact skills such as topographical map reading, navigation and hiking. The emphases is on logistics and operations of adventure excursions and fitness in various wilderness environments.
satisfies: Satisfies PE: Physical Education.
notes: Note(s): Movement Area 6 Adventure

name: Beginning Ice Hockey
description: Basic skills, techniques, strategies and rules of ice hockey. No previous skating is required but the ability to skate is highly recommended.
satisfies: Satisfies PE: Physical Education.
notes: Note(s): Movement Area 5 Team

name: Visual Representations of Sport in Popular Culture
description: Critical examination of visual representations of sport in popular culture. Facilitate a deeper understanding and appreciation of the artistic qualities that exemplify works of human creativity as related to sport.
satisfies: Satisfies C1: Arts.

name: Stress Management: A Multidisciplinary Perspective
description: The stress process and its relation to health, disease, lifestyle, and the sociocultural environment. Physiological, psychological, sociological, and environmental parameters of stress across the lifespan, emphasizing university resources and stress management strategies to enhance academic, personal, and social development.
satisfies: Satisfies E: Human Understanding & Development.
sustainability: Sustainability Focused - SDG 3: Good Health and Well-Being

name: Introduction to Kinesiology
description: Explores the broad spectrum of kinesiology as an academic discipline, fundamental concepts and meaning of movement/physical activity, diversity of humans as moving beings, professional/career options, current issues, personal characteristics/professional responsibilities, Kinesiology at SJSU; initiates professional portfolio.
notes: Note(s): Required for KIN majors and minors only.

name: Individual Activity Program Studies
description: Through engagement in projects, assistance with teaching, and/or independent study related to a class in the Kinesiology physical activity program, further develops sport/fitness skills and knowledge.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Instructor consent and overall GPA of 2.0

name: International Program Studies
description: Study Abroad and Away transfer credit course. Study Abroad and Away provides students the opportunity to study abroad on long term programs (Exchange Programs, CSU International Programs, and International Student Exchange Programs) and short-term programs (Faculty-Led Programs and Summer School Abroad Programs) for academic credit, offering Alternative Break Programs for cultural immersion, and designing other globally focused opportunities. This course is designated as a placeholder course for Study Abroad and Away programs.
satisfies: Satisfies PE: Physical Education

name: Writing Workshop
description: Advanced skills in writing. Development of writing style and creation of organized, persuasive and analytical prose. Generalized and specialized forms of writing.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): KIN 70 for major/minors only or instructor consent. A3 or equivalent second semester composition course (with a grade of C- or better); Completion of core GE, and upper division standing. Allowed Declared Major/Minor: Kinesiology. Or Graduate or Postbaccalaureate level.
satisfies: Satisfies Writing in the Disciplines (WID).
notes: Note(s): Must be passed with C or better to satisfy the CSU Graduation Writing Assessment Requirement (GWAR).

name: Sport in America
description: The role of sport (recreational and professional) as a social, political and economic institution in American society. Critical examination of contemporary issues affecting sport and sport involvement by diverse cultural groups within American society.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Completion of Core General Education and upper division standing are prerequisites to all SJSU studies courses. Completion of, or co-registration in, 100W is strongly recommended.
satisfies: Satisfies SJSU Studies S: Self, Society & Equality in U.S.
notes: Note(s): Not open to Kinesiology majors for major/minor credit.

name: Water Safety Instructor’s Course
description: Designed to teach the basic concepts, skills and knowledge for successful teaching in the American Red Cross aquatics program. The content and requirements are in accordance with the American Red Cross and the criterion set forth by the organization.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Minimum age of 18.

name: Advanced SCUBA and Aquatic Technology
description: Underwater navigation, light salvage, searches, biological sampling, communications, weightless simulations, construction problem solving and lighting.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): NAUI SCUBA certification (or equivalent).
satisfies: Satisfies PE: Physical Education

name: Adapted Aquatics
description: Theories, techniques and practices in the instruction of persons with disabilities as they function in the aquatic environment.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): KIN 70 and KIN 156 for Kinesiology majors/minors only or instructor consent; passage of swim skills component required (must be able to swim 100 yards without stopping) or demonstrated by completing KIN 2A or KIN 105.

name: Adapted Physical Activity for Young Adults with Disabilities
description: Theories, techniques, and practices in the design of physical activity promotion for postsecondary transition students with disabilities.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): KIN 70 and KIN 156 for majors/minors only or instructor consent.

name: Sport & Movement in a Global Context
description: Human expression through sport, games, and movement in cultures outside the US, and how those expressions have changed over time. Exploration of how sporting traditions in cultures outside the US have influenced US culture and society.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Completion of Core General Education and upper division standing are prerequisites to all SJSU studies courses. Completion of, or co-registration in, 100W is strongly recommended.
satisfies: Satisfies SJSU Studies V: Cultures and Global Understanding.

name: Sport & Movement in a Global Context: International Experience
description: Human expression through sport, games, and movement in cultures outside the U.S. and how those expressions have changed over time. Exploration of how sporting traditions outside the U.S. have influenced US culture and society.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Completion of Core General Education and upper division standing are prerequisites to all SJSU studies courses. Completion of, or co-registration in, 100W is strongly recommended.
satisfies: Satisfies SJSU Studies V: Cultures and Global Understanding.

name: Physical Activity for Older Adults
description: Analyses of development and implementation processes of exercise programs for older adults.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): KIN 70 or instructor consent.

name: Introduction to Exercise Technology
description: Introduction to the topic of exercise technology and how technologies can be used to manage physical activity, monitor health and support pedagogical practices. Exploration of the potential benefits and risks associated with new technologies.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): KIN 70; Completion of KIN 100W is strongly recommended.

name: Biomechanical Assessment of Movement
description: This class is designed to assist the student in becoming familiar and proficient with the Biomechanical methods and equipment for assessing human movement performance characteristics with the following goals: improving movement effectiveness, preventing injuries, and assessing rehabilitation progress.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): KIN 158

name: Child Health and Activity
description: Explores concepts, frameworks, and national standards regarding children’s health and physical education using an interdisciplinary curriculum. Special attention is given to factors that influence children’s health and wellness, safety and prevention, motor skill development, and lifelong healthy practices.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): CHAD 60 or CHAD 70.
crosslist: Cross-listed with CHAD 149. Child and Adolescent Development is responsible for scheduling.

name: Sports and Fitness Marketing
description: Course is designed to apply marketing principles and processes to the sport and fitness industry. Content will focus on the sport and fitness product, consumer behavior, consumer satisfaction/dissatisfaction, and the customer experience in sport and fitness organizations.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): KIN 70

name: Theory of Sport and Fitness Management
description: Basic theory of sport management. Topics include sport management and organizational skills; sport marketing and sales; sport communication; sport finance, economics, law and governance.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): KIN 70 for majors/minors only or instructor consent.

name: Sport Facility and Event Management
description: Provide students with the skills necessary to effectively manage sport and fitness facilities and events.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): KIN 70; and KIN 152 for sports management specialization. Open only to declared Kinesiology majors/minors, or instructor consent.

name: ECG Interpretations and “Graded” Exercise Testing
description: Theoretical background and practical proficiency in the methods and instruments of electrocardiogram interpretations and “Graded” exercise testing.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): KIN 70 (or equivalent) for majors/minors only or instructor consent; KIN 70; KIN 155 with grades of ‘C-’ or better in each.

name: Exercise Physiology
description: Physiological responses and adaptations of the human organism to physical activity.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): KIN 70; BIOL 66 and CHEM 30A with a grade of ‘C-’ or better in each; approved GE Math Concept course. Open only to declared KIN majors/minors, or instructor consent.

name: Introduction to Adapted Physical Activity
description: Focus on attitude change as well as knowledge, comprehension and application of human movement principles related to individuals with disabling conditions.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): KIN 70 for majors/minors only or instructor consent.

name: Physiological Assessment
description: Use of exercise physiology instrumentation to assess physiological characteristics of human performance, interpret results, and implement corrective strategies, when appropriate.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): CHEM 30A, GE Area B4, BIOL 66, KIN 70 (C- or better grade), KIN 155 (C- or better grade)

name: Biomechanics
description: Relationship of structural and mechanical principles of the musculoskeletal system to the analysis of human performance.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): KIN 70; BIOL 65 with a grade of ‘C-’ or better; approved GE Math Concept Course. Open only to declared KIN majors/minors, or instructor consent.

name: Sport and Adapted Activities
description: Principles of kinesiology for adapting sport and activity for individuals with disabling conditions.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): KIN 70 for majors/minors only or instructor consent.

name: History of Sport and Physical Education
description: Historical survey of physical education and sport from primitive societies through classical and medieval periods to the nineteenth and twentieth centuries. Development of sport, physical education and recreation in the U.S. and factors affecting their growth.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): KIN 70 for majors/minors only or instructor consent.

name: Philosophical Perspectives of Sport
description: Emphasis on systems of philosophy, aesthetic and moral considerations, metaphysical fitness and contemporary issues. Review of leading human movement theorists.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): KIN 70 for majors/minors only or instructor consent.

name: Advanced Fitness Assessment and Exercise Prescription
description: In-depth study and analysis of the principles and techniques used in the assessment of physical fitness and health as well as the design of conditioning programs and physical activities.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): KIN 70 (or equivalent) for majors/minors only and KIN 155, or instructor consent. Grade of ‘C-’ or better in KIN 70 and KIN 155.

name: Physical Fitness and Nutrition
description: Use of scientific principles, scientific investigation, and current technological advances to assess the relationship between diet, physical fitness, and disease. Examine scientific literature to evaluate the effects of nutritional intervention on exercise performance.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Completion of Core General Education and upper division standing are prerequisites to all SJSU studies courses. Completion of, or co-registration in, 100W is strongly recommended.
satisfies: Satisfies SJSU Studies R: Earth, Environment, and Sustainability.
crosslist: Cross-listed with NUFS 163. Nutrition, Food Science and Packaging is responsible for scheduling.

name: Sociocultural Perspectives
description: Sociocultural processes of sport and play in contemporary society. The study of phenomena arising out of group relations within the realm of kinesiology.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): KIN 70 for Kinesiology majors/minors or Sports Journalism minors or instructor consent or lower division social science core GE.

name: Motor Development
description: Motor development of the individual from birth to maturity. Emphasis upon motor behavior, needs, capacities and interests.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): KIN 70 for majors/minors only or instructor consent. .

name: Motor Learning
description: Concepts, principles and theories of motor learning with application to physical activities.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): KIN 70 for majors/minors only or instructor consent; BIOL 66 with a grade of ‘C-’ or better.

name: Sports Psychology
description: Psychological aspects of sports, including the value of sports, psychological factors involved in competitive as well as non-competitive athletic activities and the role of sports psychologists.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): PSYC 1.
crosslist: Cross-listed with PSYC 167. Kinesiology is responsible for scheduling.

name: Psychology of Coaching
description: Social, clinical, child, measuring, industrial, personality and organizational psychology and the practical application of the material to coaching.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): KIN 70 for majors/minors only or instructor consent.

name: Diversity, Stress and Health
description: Impact of structured inequalities on stress and health of diverse populations. Analysis of physiological/psychosocial health factors related to diversity, as well as behavioral interventions and social actions that mediate stress and optimize health and social justice.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Completion of Core General Education and upper division standing are prerequisites to all SJSU studies courses. Completion of, or co-registration in, 100W is strongly recommended.
satisfies: Satisfies SJSU Studies S: Self, Society & Equality in U.S.
crosslist: Cross-listed with PH 169. Kinesiology is responsible for scheduling.
sustainability: Sustainability Focused - SDG 3: Good Health and Well-Being

name: Field Experience-Teaching
description: Practical experiences to satisfy certification requirement in off-campus or field-based programs. May be repeated for a maximum of 4 units.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): KIN 70 for majors/minors only or instructor consent. Concurrent enrollment in KIN 172, KIN 173, KIN 178, or KIN 179.
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 4 units.

name: Fieldwork in Sport Management
description: Practical experience in a professional work setting while working and observing 100 hours under direct supervision of qualified sport management professionals. Interns assigned a variety of duties and experiences.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): KIN 70, KIN 152, and upper division standing.
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 3 units.

name: Field Experience Coaching on Campus
description: Practical experience in on-campus programs for coaching minors. May be repeated once for credit.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): KIN 70 for majors/minors only or instructor consent.
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 4 units.

name: Elementary School Programs, K-6
description: Philosophy, principles and activities of physical education appropriate for children.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): KIN 70; KIN 165 or KIN 173. Open only to declared Kinesiology majors/minors or instructor consent.

name: Introduction to Teaching Physical Education and Non-Traditional Sports
description: This course will introduce future physical educators to the profession of teaching and will include philosophies, ethics, and standards for teaching, legal and current issues, learning-communities, inclusion of non-traditional and global games and sport activities, and observations of effective teaching.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): KIN 70 for majors/minors only or instructor consent.

name: Assessment of Psychomotor Function
description: Basic procedural elements of informal observation, formal performance testing and direct measures of psychomotor function of individuals with disabling conditions.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): KIN 70 and KIN 156; Open only to declared KIN majors/minors or instructor consent.

name: Measurement and Evaluation in Kinesiology
description: Designed to develop an understanding of measurement and evaluation concepts and application relevant to assessment in the psychomotor, cognitive and affective domains. Activities include collection and computer analysis of data.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): KIN 70 for majors/minors only or instructor consent; approved GE Math Concept Course.

name: Exercise Psychology
description: Examines the psychological determinants and consequences of exercise and physical activity.  Analysis and critique of research and theory relevant to exercise adherence, motivation, self-efficacy, and attributional style.  Practical applications of theoretical concepts.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): PSYC 1.

name: Movement Experiences for Children
description: Physical Education K-6 curricular philosophy and activities appropriate for elementary school personnel; emphasizes the social, emotional, physical and skill development of children in the elementary school setting.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): CHAD 60 or CHAD 067.

name: Management Practices for Physical Education Teachers
description: Examines current practices for managing student behaviors, instructional technology, legal regulations, and physical fitness needs as well as exploring adolescent development.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): KIN 70 for Kinesiology majors/minors only or instructor consent; KIN 172 and upper division standing.

name: Design and Assessment of Movement Experiences
description: Integrate concepts from kinesiology, motor learning, and motor development to address sequential movement experiences, including qualitative analysis and interactions with a performer.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): KIN 70 for Kinesiology majors/minors only or instructor consent; KIN 158, KIN 166 and KIN 178.

name: Independent Study
description: Independent study through projects or directed reading related to the field of Kinesiology. Repeatable for a total of 6 units.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): GPA overall of 2.0; KIN 70 or instructor consent
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 6 units.

name: Directed Reading
description: Assigned reading of selected books, journals and papers. Conferences with instructor, seminars, reports (oral and written). May be repeated for a total of 4 units.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): KIN 70 for majors/minors only for; instructor and department chair consent.
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 4 units.

name: Senior Seminar
description: Active learning capstone course designed to synthesize students’ undergraduate preparation, including internship experiences. Capstone course designed to integrate and synthesize students’ knowledge and skills gained in their undergraduate preparation through active participation in the class and reflection on the internship experience; requires completion of a professional portfolio and a movement project
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): KIN 70, Kin Majors ONLY, KIN Minors

name: Clinical Exercise Physiology
description: Physiological principles applied to the prevention, management, and treatment of chronic health conditions. Focus on the pathophysiology, acute response to exercise, chronic training effects, and development of appropriate conditioning and training programs for chronic conditions.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): KIN 70 (or equivalent) for majors/minors only or instructor consent; KIN 155; with grades of ‘C- ’ or better in each.

name: Prevention and Care of Athletic Injuries
description: Prevention through safe equipment, facilities and protective strapping. Methods used to aid recovery.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): KIN 70, BIOL 65 with a grade of ‘C-’ or better, or instructor consent.

name: Prevention and Care of Athletic Injuries Laboratory
description: The laboratory course is designed to provide hands-on experience in the prevention and care of athletic injuries, including preventive and supportive taping techniques, emergency management, and various hands-on experiences related to the prevention of activity related injuries.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): KIN 70, KIN 188 (concurrent enrollment acceptable).

name: Advanced Assessment of Lower Extremity Injuries
description: An advanced course designed to develop knowledge and skills in recognition, assessment, and medical referral of athletic injuries to the lower extremity, thoracolumbar spine, posture and gait. Activity sessions are designed to assist in the development of clinical assessment skills.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): KIN 70, KIN 188, KIN 189. Open only to declared KIN majors/minors or instructor consent.

name: Advanced Assessment of Upper Extremity Injuries
description: An advanced course designed to develop knowledge and skills in recognition, assessment, and medical referral of athletic injuries to the upper extremity, abdomen, thorax, cervical spine, head, and general medical conditions. Activity sessions are designed to develop clinical assessment skills.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): KIN 70; KIN 191A.

name: International Program Studies
description: Study Abroad and Away transfer credit course. Study Abroad and Away provides students the opportunity to study abroad on long term programs (Exchange Programs, CSU International Programs, and International Student Exchange Programs) and short-term programs (Faculty-Led Programs and Summer School Abroad Programs) for academic credit, offering Alternative Break Programs for cultural immersion, and designing other globally focused opportunities. This course is designated as a placeholder course for Study Abroad and Away programs.

name: Organization & Administration in Athletic Training
description: Theoretical and practical information concerning organization and administration of a modern athletic training program, including managerial styles, personnel, facilities/equipment management, budget, medical records, insurance issues, legal aspects, public relations, and other current topics in athletic training.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): KIN 70 for majors/minors only or instructor consent; KIN 188.

name: Therapeutic Exercise
description: Theoretical and clinical bases for the use of therapeutic exercise in rehabilitation settings; basic biomechanics, indications, contraindications, and proper application procedures of therapeutic exercise in athletic injury rehabilitation.
prereqs: Pre/Corequisite(s): KIN 191A and KIN 191B.

name: Therapeutic Modalities
description: Theoretical and clinical aspects of therapeutic modalities in athletic rehabilitation. Includes the physics and physiological effects, indications and contra-indications, as well as application procedures of various therapeutic modalities.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): KIN 70 for majors/minors only or instructor consent. KIN 188 and upper division standing.

name: Practicum in Athletic Training I
description: Introductory level supervised practical experiences at selected athletic training clinical settings.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): BIOL 65 and BIOL 66 with a grade of ‘C’ in each, KIN 188, KIN 189 and 50 hours of observation. Open only to KIN majors.

name: Practicum in Athletic Training II
description: Observations and experiences within the profession of athletic training to assist in developing required National Athletic Trainers’ Association competencies. Interns supervised on a daily basis by a NATA-certified athletic trainer.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): KIN 197A. Open only to KIN majors.

name: Practicum in Athletic Training III
description: Clinical internship in allied health-related situations, e.g., physician’s offices, physical therapy sports medicine clinics, etc. Typically off-campus assignment.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): KIN 191A and KIN 191B (concurrent enrollment in KIN 191B is allowed), KIN 197B and professional insurance recommended.

name: Practicum in Athletic Training IV
description: Course is designed to provide the student with advanced, diverse, supervised, and practical experiences in the athletic training profession. Selected on-an-off campus clinical settings will be used to assist the student in the development of professional competencies and proficiencies.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): KIN 195, KIN 197C.

name: Internship in Kinesiology
description: Practical professional experiences related to the field of Kinesiology. Experiences are varied and can include exercise testing, prescription and evaluation; program leadership, design, and/or administration; coaching; and sport medicine internships. May be repeated for a total of 6 units.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Upper division status;GPA overall of 2.0; KIN 70 or instructor consent
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 6 units.

name: Fundamentals of Quantitative Research
description: Design, analysis and interpretation of quantitative research. Course focuses on the research process from the formulation of a research problem through the analysis of data. Topics include: ethics in research, research design and analysis issues and techniques, psychometrics, descriptive statistics, parametric and non-parametric inferential statistics, critiquing research.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): KIN 175 (or equivalent).
satisfies: Satisfies GWAR: Graduation Writing Assessment Requirement.
notes: Note(s): This course satisfies graduate-level GWAR in this master’s program.

name: Fundamentals of Qualitative Research
description: Design, analysis and interpretation of qualitative research. Course focuses on the research process from the formulation of a research problem through the analysis of data. Topics include: ethics in research, research design and analysis issues and techniques, data representation, critiquing research.
satisfies: Satisfies GWAR: Graduation Writing Assessment Requirement.
notes: Note(s): This course satisfies graduate-level GWAR in this master’s program.

name: Advanced Exercise Physiology
description: Survey and critical evaluation of current concepts and literature regarding physiological regulatory mechanisms of the oxygen transport system and muscle metabolism. Acute and chronic effects of exercise with emphasis placed on physiological limitations.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): KIN 155 (or equivalent).

name: Environmental Exercise Physiology
description: Survey and critical evaluation of current concepts and literature regarding various environmental (heat, cold, altitude, etc.) conditions as they affect the typical responses to exercise. Acute effects and chronic adaptations examined.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): KIN 155 (or equivalent).

name: Biomechanics
description: Principles and laws of physics and mechanics as applied to analysis of human movement activities. Critical evaluation of current research findings in sport biomechanics.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): KIN 158 (or equivalent).

name: Advanced Internship in Adapted Physical Activity
description: Advanced, supervised practicum for the development of direct service, administration/supervision, in-service training and advocacy/leadership competencies in adapted physical activity.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): BS degree with emphasis in adapted physical education and/or satisfactory completion of specified didactic curriculum.

name: Philosophy of Sport and Embodiment
description: Development of a consistent set of basic professional values compatible with individual differences which may serve as a frame of reference for professional behavior.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): KIN 161 (or equivalent).

name: International Sport and Physical Education
description: An analysis of the current structure, organization, and methods of physical education and sport in selected countries.  Social, cultural, political, economic, and religious influences in western and non-western cultures will be explored by both national and topicals methods of study.

name: Sport Sociology
description: An in-depth study of the relationship between sport and society. Focus will be on social and cultural factors that affect how Americans play and view sport.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): KIN 164 (or equivalent).

name: Advanced Motor Development
description: Examination of specific theory and research related to the movement changes that occur across the lifespan. Interpretation of recent related research and individually guided investigation of a specific area of concern in motor development.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): KIN 165 (or equivalent).

name: Principles and Concepts of Perceptual Motor Learning
description: Motor behavior and the learning patterns developed in acquiring skill in a motor activity.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): KIN 166 (or equivalent).

name: Advanced Sport Psychology
description: Sport psychology research and its use in field settings. Major theoretical areas (anxiety, motivation, cohesion, etc.) and their application in sport.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): KIN 167 and KIN 168 (or equivalent).

name: Evidence Based Research and Practice in Management and Assessment of Injuries to Lower Extremities
description: Multidisciplinary approach for recognition, initial care, treatment, and rehabilitation used to return athletes to lower extremity pre-injury fitness levels. (First course in two-course series.)
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): BIOL 65, BIOL 66, KIN 155, KIN 158 and KIN 188.

name: Evidence Based Research and Practice in the Mgmt and Assessment of Injuries to the Upper Extremity
description: Multidisciplinary approach for recognition, initial care, treatment and rehabilitation used to return an athlete to upper extremity pre-injury fitness levels (second course in two-course series).
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): KIN 268.

name: Advanced Topics in Athletic Training
description: This course is designed to improve the basic knowledge of athletic training students. Topics include outcome research and practical applications for mild traumatic brain injury, alteration evaluation skills for athletic injuries, and research design in the field of athletic training.

name: Evidence Based Research in the Practice of Therapeutic Exercise
description: Investigation of the scientific and philosophical bases of therapeutic exercise and therapeutic modalities with reference to the rehabilitation process, and to acquire skills necessary for prudent application of current modalities and techniques.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): KIN 155, KIN 158 and KIN 188 (or equivalent).

name: Evidence Based Research in the Practice of Therapeutic Modalities
description: An advanced course designed to critically evaluate the scientific and philosophical bases of therapeutic modality use. The course is intended to provide the student with the information necessary to perform prudent clinical applications of therapeutic modalities on orthopedic injuries.

name: Advanced Fieldwork in Sport Management
description: Advanced practical experience in a professional work setting under the direct supervision of qualified sport management professionals. Interns assigned a variety of duties and experiences.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing or instructor consent.

name: Legal and Ethical Aspects of Sport
description: Topics include sport and its relationship to the common law of contracts and torts, the statutory law of labor and antitrust, constitutional and civil rights law, communications law and ethics.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing

name: Marketing and Social Aspects of Sport
description: Sport and its relationship to market research designs, strategies, plans, fundraising, consumer behavior, political, sociological and historical parameters.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing or instructor consent.

name: Management, Leadership and Communication in Sport
description: Management, administration, organizational behavior and communication theories, problems and issues in leadership in sport.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing.

name: Financial Aspects of Sport
description: Examines traditional and innovative methods of revenue acquisition available to sport organizations. Current financial challenges, innovative concepts and strategies used in financing sport operation.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing or approval of the instructor.

name: Internship in Kinesiology
description: Advanced practical experience in a professional work setting under direct supervision of qualified professionals. Interns assigned various duties and experiences related to areas of specialization.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing and instructor consent.

name: Independent Study
description: Independent study through research projects, creative intellectual productions or directed reading/literature review related to the field of Kinesiology. May be repeated for a total of 6 units.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Graduate Standing
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 6 units.

name: Advanced Clinical Exercise Physiology
description: Pathophysiology and recent advances in the diagnosis and treatment of cardiovascular, metabolic, neurologic, and musculoskeletal diseases and disorders, including innovative biotechnological approaches.  Content will include physiological mechanisms of these clinical conditions that affect responses to acute exercise and chronic adaptations to exercise training.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): KIN 187

name: Master of Arts Seminar in Kinesiology
description: The purpose of this seminar course is to offer an intensive, comprehensive focus of a specific topic, and/or theme as it relates to the study of kinesiology.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing or instructor consent.

name: Leadership and Administration in Athletic Training
description: Current problems and issues related to the athletic training profession. Topics include professional ethics and competency, medicolegal issues, administration of athletic training programs, stress management and drug testing.

name: Seminar in Sports Medicine II
description: Current issues related to the athletic training profession. Topics include eating disorders, injury rehabilitation and management. Related topics of medical and scientific nature will be discussed with guest lecturers.

name: Fieldwork in Athletic Training I
description: Advanced practical experience in athletic training under the direct supervision of qualified sports medicine professionals.

name: Fieldwork in Athletic Training II
description: Advanced practical experience in athletic training under the direct supervision of qualified sports medicine professionals.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): KIN 293A.

name: Fieldwork in Athletic Training III
description: Advanced practical experience in athletic training under the direct supervision of qualified sports medicine professionals.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): KIN 293A, KIN 293B.

name: Fieldwork in Athletic Training IV
description: Advanced practical experience in athletic training under the direct supervision of qualified sports medicine professionals.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): KIN 293A, KIN 293B and KIN 293C.

name: Special Studies
description: Advanced individual research and projects.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): KIN 250.

name: Master’s Thesis
description: Repeatable for credit.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): KIN 250 and advancement to candidacy for the master’s degree.

name: Student Teaching II: Classroom Teaching
description: Minimum 80-120 class periods of classroom, teaching laboratory or field teaching in appropriate single subjects, grades K-12 and related teaching activities and seminar.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Joint approval of major and Education departments.

name: Student Teaching III - Classroom Teaching
description: Minimum 80-120 class periods of classroom, teaching laboratory or field teaching in appropriate single subjects, grades K-12 and related teaching activities and seminar.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Joint approval of major and Education departments.
notes: Note(s): May be in different subject/school and will be at a different grade level.

name: Student Teaching Seminar in Adapted PE
description: Minimum 80-120 class periods of classroom, teaching laboratory, or field teaching in supervised experiences in adapted physical education at selected public and private agencies, across grades K-12 as well as related teaching activities and seminar.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): KIN 107, KIN 108, KIN 156, KIN 159, and KIN 174. Adapted physical education added authorization (APEAA) candidates only. Candidates concurrently enrolled in teaching credential programs or who have already earned a base credential only.

name: Instructional Materials and Procedures in Physical Education
description: Application of theories of learning and principles of teaching to the selection of instructional procedures to be used in physical education. Practical experience provided.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): KIN 170B, KIN 172 and KIN 179 and department teacher education approval.
notes: Note(s): Physical education majors and minors only.

name: International Program Studies
description: Study Abroad and Away transfer credit course. Study Abroad and Away provides students the opportunity to study abroad on long term programs (Exchange Programs, CSU International Programs, and International Student Exchange Programs) and short-term programs (Faculty-Led Programs and Summer School Abroad Programs) for academic credit, offering Alternative Break Programs for cultural immersion, and designing other globally focused opportunities. This course is designated as a placeholder course for Study Abroad and Away programs.

name: Individual Studies in Latin
description: Individual work by arrangement.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Upper Division Standing in Latin and instructor consent.

name: Nature of Language
description: Introduction to the nature of language as a social institution and practice in observing language structure and use in local speech communities.
satisfies: Satisfies D: Social Sciences (formerly GE Area D1).

name: Language and Thinking
description: Exploring systems of language and logic in oral and written discourse, with a focus on the role of shared cultural assumptions, language style and the media of presentation in shaping the form and content of argumentation.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Completion of GE Area A2 with a grade of C- or better.
satisfies: Satisfies A3: Critical Thinking and Writing.

name: Language across the Lifespan
description: Introduction to what is known about how people successfully learn second languages, with a focus on physiological, psychological, social-cultural and linguistic factors that affect second language acquisition, and on skills and strategies that promote language learning across the lifespan.
satisfies: Satisfies E: Human Understanding & Development.

name: Language Variation in Space, Time, & Culture
description: Exploring the diverse structural patterns and social functions found in English; analyzing the social, cultural, political, historical, and technological factors underlying language change; developing critical thinking and effective argumentation in writing.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Completion of GE Area A2 with a grade of C- or better.
satisfies: Satisfies A3 or D (formerly GE Area D1): Critical Thinking and Writing or Social Sciences.

name: Languages of the World
description: Explore the diversity of the world’s languages through studying major language families, including basic language structure, language change and historical relationships, the sociocultural aspects of language, typological patterns and universals, writing systems and language vitality and endangerment.
satisfies: Satisfies D: Social Sciences (formerly GE Area D1).

name: Quantitative Reasoning in Linguistic Diversity
description: An introduction to descriptive and inferential statistics, including the visual interpretation and presentation of data about linguistic diversity and related social phenomena like education and immigration. Interpretation of numerical and graphical data to draw inferences about complex social issues.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Mathematics Enrollment Category M-I or M-II; for Categories III and IV, LING 26W is required as a corequisite, unless a GE Area B4 course was previously completed with a grade of C- or better.
satisfies: Satisfies B4: Mathematics/Quantitative Reasoning.
notes: Note(s): A grade of C- or better is required to satisfy GE Area B4.

name: Quantitative Reasoning Linguistic Diversity Workshop
description: Support course for LING 26. Provides extra practice and support for students with both concepts and operations related to quantitative reasoning and descriptive statistics.

name: International Program Studies
description: Study Abroad and Away transfer credit course. Study Abroad and Away provides students the opportunity to study abroad on long term programs (Exchange Programs, CSU International Programs, and International Student Exchange Programs) and short-term programs (Faculty-Led Programs and Summer School Abroad Programs) for academic credit, offering Alternative Break Programs for cultural immersion, and designing other globally focused opportunities. This course is designated as a placeholder course for Study Abroad and Away programs.

name: Introduction to Linguistics
description: Scientific study of language. Phonetics, phonology, morphology, syntax, semantics, pragmatics, sociolinguistics, psycholinguistics, historical linguistics, language universals and typology.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing.

name: Patterns of English
description: Description of the sound, word-formation, sentence, semantic and discourse patterns of English. Analysis of contemporary examples of spoken and written English.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Written Communication I (or equivalent).
