description: Structure and behavior of atmospheric circulation systems, practical weather analysis and forecasting techniques. Acquisition, manipulation and display of real-time data sets, verbal presentations of weather analyses and forecasts.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): METR 100W, METR 121B or instructor consent.
notes: Note(s): Year course.

name: Mesoscale Meteorology
description: Structure and behavior of mesocale atmospheric circulations, practical weather forecasting techniques.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): METR 171A.

name: Global Climate Modeling
description: Senior-level workshop-based course focused on climate modeling using general circulation model data.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): METR 51, METR 61, METR 100W, and METR 136.
sustainability: Sustainability Focused - SDG 13: Climate Action

name: Climate Change Capstone
description: Senior level capstone course in which students will define and conduct a project which is both climate change related and of a practical nature.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): METR 173 and METR 100W.
sustainability: Sustainability Focused - SDG 13: Climate Action

name: Topics in Senior Thesis
description: Supervised research and the preparation of a senior thesis.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): METR 100W. Not available to Open University Students.
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 3 units.

name: Individual Studies
description: Independent work on topics by special arrangement. A maximum of four units may be repeated.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Meteorology major or minor. Not available to Open University Students.
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 4 units.

name: Tutor Assistant in Meteorology
description: Supervised instructional experience as a tutor assistant. A maximum of four units may be repeated.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing and instructor consent. Not available to Open University Students.
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 4 units.

name: Special Topics
description: Selected topics in meteorology. Topics vary and are announced each semester.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): METR 121B.

name: International Program Studies
description: Study Abroad and Away transfer credit course. Study Abroad and Away provides students the opportunity to study abroad on long term programs (Exchange Programs, CSU International Programs, and International Student Exchange Programs) and short-term programs (Faculty-Led Programs and Summer School Abroad Programs) for academic credit, offering Alternative Break Programs for cultural immersion, and designing other globally focused opportunities. This course is designated as a placeholder course for Study Abroad and Away programs.

name: Research Methods in Meteorology
description: The nature of research in meteorology with particular reference to formulation of the problem, methods of attack and presentation of results. Proposal writing and selection of MS thesis topic.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Instructor consent.
satisfies: Satisfies GWAR: Graduation Writing Assessment Requirement.
notes: Note(s): Offered on an irregular basis only. This course satisfies graduate-level GWAR in this master’s program.

name: Advanced Atmospheric and Climate Dynamics
description: Dynamics of larger-scale atmospheric flows over short and climate timescales. Quasi-geostrophic theory and applications; atmospheric waves; baroclinic instability; energetics of atmospheric and climate systems; dynamics of the general circulation; dynamics of the climate system; dynamics of climate change.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): METR 121B or equivalent
sustainability: Sustainability Related - SDG 13: Climate Action

name: Adv Fire Behavior
description: Advanced topics in meteorology of extreme fire behavior. Includes fire-atmosphere interactions, microscale turbulence, flame properties, combustion physics, fuel dynamics, and extreme fire behavior such as fire whirls. Offered every fourth year.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): METR 121A or instructor consent.

name: Advanced Physical Meteorology
description: Thermodynamics of moist air; nucleation processes; particulates in air, microphysics and cloud dynamics, sampling techniques.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): METR 125 (or equivalent).

name: Numerical Modeling
description: Numerical analysis and prediction in meteorology. Numerical methods and their errors; finite-difference and spectral methods; atmospheric models.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): METR 50 (or equivalent); METR 205A or instructor consent.

name: Parameterization in NWP
description: Studies of parameterization schemes for sub-gridscale physics in numerical models. Included are schemes for surface fluxes, soil-vegetation models, convection, clouds, and radiative transfer. Why these are needed, and how they are developed and implemented.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): METR 240

name: Recent Developments in Meteorology
description: Intensive study of a particular topic in the atmospheric sciences with special emphasis on recent research results, such as instrumentation or modeling techniques. Topics vary and are announced each semester.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Instructor consent.

name: Colloquium
description: Advanced studies in special fields, including original work by faculty, guest speakers and graduate students. One presentation required of each enrolled student and attendance required for all graduate students.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Instructor consent.

name: Research
description: Supervised individual laboratory or field work.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Instructor consent. Not available to Open University Students.

name: Master’s Project
description: Repeatable for credit.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Advancement to candidacy for the MS degree and approval of topic by thesis advisor. Not available to Open University Students.

name: Master’s Thesis
description: Repeatable for credit.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Advancement to candidacy for the MS degree and approval of topic by thesis advisor. Not available to Open University Students.

name: General Bacteriology
description: Morphology, physiology, genetics and diversity of bacteria; their control by chemical and physical means; and their role in disease. For majors in allied health professions.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): CHEM 1B, or CHEM 30A with a C or better or instructor consent.
satisfies: Satisfies B2 + B3: Life Science & Lab.
notes: Note(s): Not an elective in the department majors.

name: International Program Studies
description: Study Abroad and Away transfer credit course. Study Abroad and Away provides students the opportunity to study abroad on long term programs (Exchange Programs, CSU International Programs, and International Student Exchange Programs) and short-term programs (Faculty-Led Programs and Summer School Abroad Programs) for academic credit, offering Alternative Break Programs for cultural immersion, and designing other globally focused opportunities. This course is designated as a placeholder course for Study Abroad and Away programs.

name: General Microbiology
description: Fundamentals of basic microbiology emphasizing cell structure, cell metabolism, molecular genetics, microbial diversity and ecological relationships.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): BIOL 30 and BIOL 31 (with a grade of “C-” or better in each); CHEM 8 or CHEM 112A (with a grade of “C” or better), or instructor consent. Must be a declared Biology Major (all).

name: Bacterial Diversity
description: Study of the characteristics and microecology of unusual prokaryotes. Molecular and traditional approaches will be discussed.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): MICR 101 (with a grade of “C” or better), or instructor consent. Must be a declared Biology Major (all).
crosslist: Cross-listed with BIOL 122. Biological Sciences is responsible for scheduling.
sustainability: Sustainability Related

name: Bacterial Diversity Laboratory
description: Laboratory techniques in bacterial diversity.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): MICR 101 (with grade of “C” or better) or Instructor Consent. Must be a declared Biology Major (all).
crosslist: Cross-listed with BIOL 122L. Biological Sciences is responsible for scheduling.

name: Food Microbiology
description: Detection and enumeration of both normal microbiological flora and spoilage organisms of specific foods. Control of sanitation problems in food production and processing.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): MICR 101 (with a grade of “C” or better), or instructor consent. Must be a declared Biology Major (all).

name: Food Microbiology Laboratory
description: Practical microbiological techniques for the detection and enumeration of both normal microbiological flora and spoilage organisms of specific foods; and for the control of sanitation problems in food production and processing. Field trips to local food industries and/or a water treatment plant may be required within lab hours.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): MICR 101 (with a grade of “C” or better), or instructor consent. Must be a declared Biology Major (all).

name: Microbial Physiology
description: Studies of the physiology of microbes specifically focusing on bacteria (growth, metabolism and regulation of gene expression); growth experiments and mutagenesis techniques. SJSU Studies Area: R for Biology Majors only.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): CHEM 135, MICR 166, both with a C or better, or instructor consent. Completion of Core General Education and upper division standing are prerequisites to all SJSU studies courses.
satisfies: Satisfies SJSU Studies R: Earth, Environment, and Sustainability.
notes: Note(s): Biological Sciences Majors only.

name: Microbial Physiology Laboratory
description: Laboratory experiments involve small and large-scale growth experiments (fermentation, continuous culture and batch culture), techniques used in mutagenesis and mutant characterization as well as construction and studies of reporter fusions.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): MICR 101 (with grade of “C” or better), or instructor consent. Must be a declared Biology Major (all).

name: Hematology
description: Blood and blood forming organs. Theoretical and clinical aspects of normal and pathologic conditions of the erythrocytic, leukocytic, coagulation and blood group systems.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): MICR 101 (with grade of “C” or better), or instructor consent. Must be a declared Biology Major (all).

name: Hematology Laboratory
description: Laboratory methodologies used to diagnose hematologic pathology. Prerequisite(s): MICR 101 (with grade of “C” or better), or instructor consent.
prereqs: Pre/Corequisite(s): MICR 140. Must be a declared Biology Major (all).

name: Pathogenic Microbiology I
description: Concepts and principles of medical microbiology, emphasizing the biology of host-parasite interactions and mechanisms of infectious disease pathogenesis.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): MICR 101, BIOL 107 (with a grade of “C” or better in each); CHEM 112A or CHEM 8, (with a grade of “C” or better in each); or instructor consent. Must be a declared Biology Major (all).

name: Pathogenic Microbiology I Laboratory
description: Application of principles of medical microbiology to pathogen isolation, characterization and identification.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): MICR 101, BIOL 107, BIOL 107L (with a grade of “C” or better in each); CHEM 8 or CHEM 112A (with a grade of “C” or better in each), or instructor consent.

name: Pathogenic Microbiology II
description: Concepts and principles of medical microbiology, emphasizing the biology of host-parasite interactions and mechanisms of infectious disease pathogenesis. Continuation of MICR 141.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): MICR 141 (with grade of “C” or better), or instructor consent. Must be a declared Biology Major (all).

name: Pathogenic Microbiology II Laboratory
description: Application of principles of medical microbiology to pathogen isolation, characterization and identification.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): MICR 141 and MICR 141L and BIOL 107L (with grades of “C” or better in each), or instructor consent.

name: Bacterial Genetics
description: Fundamental prokaryotic genetic concepts and their incorporation into problem solving and experimental design. Emphasis on how and why someone might use genetic approaches to their benefit when addressing biological questions in bacteria.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): MICR 101 (with a grade of “C” or better), or instructor consent. Must be a declared Biology Major (all).

name: General Virology
description: Molecular and biological aspects of animal, plant and microbial viruses and their relationships with their hosts, with primary emphasis on viruses that infect humans.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): MICR 101 with a grade of “C” or better, or instructor consent.

name: Individual Studies
description: Advanced lab work in special fields.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Instructor consent. Must be a declared Biology Major (all).

name: Directed Reading
description: Assigned readings of selected books, journals and papers to fill gaps in training or for contact with new fields. Evaluation through weekly reports and conferences.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Instructor consent. Must be a declared Biology Major (all).

name: International Program Studies
description: Study Abroad and Away transfer credit course. Study Abroad and Away provides students the opportunity to study abroad on long term programs (Exchange Programs, CSU International Programs, and International Student Exchange Programs) and short-term programs (Faculty-Led Programs and Summer School Abroad Programs) for academic credit, offering Alternative Break Programs for cultural immersion, and designing other globally focused opportunities. This course is designated as a placeholder course for Study Abroad and Away programs.

name: Advanced Hematology
description: Students will engage in advanced study of normal and abnormal hematologic conditions, including molecular diagnosis of disorders.

name: Advanced Pathophysiology
description: Students will engage in advanced study of normal and abnormal physiologic conditions, including but not limited to diseases of glucose metabolism, organ dysfunction, endocrine disorders and electrolyte balance.
notes: Note(s): Not an elective for Biology majors and not available to Open University students.

name: Advanced Human Immunology
description: Students will engage in advanced study of normal and abnormal immunologic conditions in humans, including molecular diagnosis of those disorders.
notes: Note(s): Not an elective for Biology majors and not available to Open University students.

name: Advanced Medical Microbiology
description: Students will engage in advanced study of bacteria, fungi, viruses and other organisms of significance in medical microbiology. Emphasis will be on experience through clinical practice.
notes: Note(s): Not an elective for Biology majors and not available to Open University students.

name: Advanced Immunohematology
description: Students will engage in advanced study of immunohematology and the use of transfused products in medical treatment. Emphasis will be on experience through clinical practice.
notes: Note(s): Not an elective for Biology majors and not available to Open University students.

name: Molecular Based Diagnostic Techniques
description: Students will engage in advanced study of application of molecular techniques for diagnostic purposes. Emphasis will be on advanced practical training.
notes: Note(s): Not an elective for Biology majors and not available to Open University students.

name: Clinical Laboratory Management
description: Students will engage in advanced study of laboratory management skills, including finance, time management, team building, quality control, basic human resources management and other topics. Emphasis will be on practical training.
notes: Note(s): Not an elective for Biology majors and not available to Open University students.

name: Topics and Demonstrations in Clinical Laboratory Science
description: Presentations and demonstrations of topics and selected clinical lab procedures.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Baccalaureate degree in a biological science, valid license as a CLS Trainee, admission into the CLS Traineeship, and instructor consent. Concurrent enrollment in MICR 291.
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 36 units.

name: CGMBS Lab Management
description: Complements CGMBS Program students’ experiences at their assigned clinical molecular laboratory training sites. Emphasis is on laboratory management, quality control and assurance, and safety.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Acceptance into the SJSU CGMBS Training Program.

name: Leadership & Personal Development
description: Introduction to the personal challenges and competencies that are critical for effective leadership. The focus is on developing basic knowledge and comprehension of Army leadership dimensions while gaining a big picture understanding of the ROTC program.

name: Introduction to Tactical Leadership
description: Overviews leadership fundamentals such as setting direction, problem-solving, listening, presenting briefs, providing feedback, and using effective writing skills. Students explore leadership attributes and core leader competencies in the context of practical, hands-on, and interactive exercises.

name: Innovative Team Leadership
description: Explores creative and innovative tactical leadership strategies and styles by examining team dynamics and trait and behavior theories. Students practice aspects of personal motivation and team building during planning, executing, and assessment of team exercises and participation in leadership labs.

name: Foundations of Tactical Leadership
description: Examines the challenges of leading tactical teams in today’s complex world. The course highlights dimensions of terrain analysis, patrolling, and orders. Students develop greater awareness as they assess their own leadership styles and practice communication and team building skills.

name: Adaptive Team Leadership
description: Challenges students to study, practice, and evaluate adaptive leadership skills as they overcome challenging squad tactical operations scenarios. Cadets hone their leadership and critical thinking while they prepare for success at ROTC’s summer Leadership Development and Assessment Course (LDAC).

name: Applied Team Leadership
description: Uses situational team leadership challenges to build awareness and skills in leading small units. Students review aspects of full spectrum operations, and conduct military briefings to develop proficiency giving operation orders. This is the final course before students attend LDAC.

name: Adaptive Leadership
description: Students learn how to train, mentor and evaluate underclassmen. They will learn the duties and responsibilities of an Army staff officer and apply those lessons during weekly training meetings to plan, execute and assess battalion training events.

name: Leadership in a Complex World
description: Explores the realities of leading in the Contemporary Operating Environment (COE). Students learn to adapt to operations in unfamiliar lands and international terrorism. The course places significant emphasis on preparing cadets for their first assignment in the US Army.

name: Individual Studies
description: Individual work on special topics by arrangement.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Instructor consent and Military Science Chair approval.

name: American Military History
description: A survey of diplomatic, international, military and economic aspects of American involvement in conflicts from the Anglo-Indian Wars to present time. Study of leadership, weapons technology, politics, humanitarian operations and critical thinking.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing.

name: Marine Ecology
description: Field-oriented introduction to interrelationship between marine and estuarine organisms and their environment emphasis on quantitative data collection and analysis.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Ecology, statistics (or concurrent registration in MS 104), or instructor consent.
satisfies: Satisfies GWAR: Graduation Writing Assessment Requirement.
notes: Note(s): Offered fall semester. This course satisfies graduate-level GWAR in this master’s program.

name: Marine Science Diving
description: Skin and SCUBA diving course; pool-training culminates in ten ocean dives. Topics covered include diving physics physiology, diving environments night diving and research diving. Successful completion gives NAUI and MLML certification.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Certified SCUBA diver (or equivalency as determined by instructor), upper division science major status, thorough physical examination, ability to pass swimming test
notes: Note(s): Course cannot be used to meet 30-unit degree requirement. Offered fall & summer.

name: Marine Birds and Mammals
description: Systematics, morphology, ecology and biology of marine turtles, birds, and mammals.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Upper division college vertebrate zoology, instructor’s consent; MS 103 recommended.
notes: Note(s): Course is generally offered alternate fall semesters during the odd years.

name: Marine Ichthyology
description: A description of the taxonomy, morphology and ecology of marine fishes. Both field and laboratory work concentrate on the structure, function and habits of marine fishes and the ecological interactions of these fishes with their biotic and abiotic surroundings.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): College zoology (or equivalent) or instructor’s consent. MS 103 recommended.
notes: Note(s): Offered spring semester.

name: Marine Invertebrate Zoology I
description: A field-oriented introduction to the structure, systematics, evolution and life histories of the major marine phyla.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): College zoology or instructor consent; MS 103 recommended.
notes: Note(s): Course is generally offered alternate fall semesters during the odd years.

name: Marine Botany
description: Introduction to the plants of the sea, marshes and dunes, with emphasis on the morphology, taxonomy and natural history of seaweeds and vascular plants.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): MS 103 recommended, or instructor consent.
notes: Note(s): Offered fall semester.

name: Physiological Ecology of Marine Algae
description: Understanding the adaptations of marine algae to their environment, including respiration, enzyme activity, and biochemical composition. Hands-on experience in basic electronic instrumentation, chemical separations, optical measurements, culturing methods and radioisotope techniques. Designed for students interested in the biology of seaweeds and phytoplankton.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): MS 103, MS 131, MS 144 or instructor consent.
notes: Note(s): Offered fall semester.

name: Geological Oceanography
description: A study of the structures, physiography and sediments of the sea bottom and shoreline.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Instructor consent.
satisfies: Satisfies GWAR: Graduation Writing Assessment Requirement.
notes: Note(s): Offered fall semester. This course satisfies graduate-level GWAR in this master’s program.

name: Physical Oceanography
description: An introduction to the nature and causes of various oceanic motions including currents, waves, tides and mixing, and the physical properties of seawater including transmission of sound and light. Limited use of calculus.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): College algebra, college physics recommended, or instructor consent.
satisfies: Satisfies GWAR: Graduation Writing Assessment Requirement.
notes: Note(s): Offered fall semester. This course satisfies graduate-level GWAR in this master’s program.

name: Chemical Oceanography
description: An introduction to the theoretical and practical aspects of the chemistry of the oceans, including major salts, dissolved gases, nutrient ions, carbonate system, transient tracers and shipboard sampling techniques.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): One year of college chemistry.
satisfies: Satisfies GWAR: Graduation Writing Assessment Requirement.
sustainability: Sustainability Related - SDG 14: Life Below Water
notes: Note(s): Offered spring semester. This course satisfies graduate-level GWAR in this master’s program.

name: Biological Oceanography
description: The ocean as an ecological system. Emphasis on the complexity of environmental influences on plankton, the transfer of organic matter between trophic levels and nutrient cycles. Laboratory sessions will include methods in sampling, shipboard techniques, identification of the plankton, and current analytical techniques.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): General biology, general chemistry, or instructor consent.
satisfies: Satisfies GWAR: Graduation Writing Assessment Requirement.
sustainability: Sustainability Related - SDG 14: Life Below Water
notes: Note(s): Offered spring semester. This course satisfies graduate-level GWAR in this master’s program.

name: Independent Studies
description: Faculty-directed study of selected problems; open to undergraduate students with adequate preparation. Offered every semester. May be repeated once for credit.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Instructor consent.

name: Library Research Methods in Marine Science
description: Students will gain an advanced understanding of the nature of scientific information. Lectures, discussions and assignments will provide the framework for using and evaluating a variety of information sources in marine and ocean sciences. Strong emphasis will be placed on developing critical skills to interweave knowledge of the history of science into the context of bibliographic tools including the digital realm.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing, instructor consent.
notes: Note(s): Offered spring semester.

name: Oceanographic Instrumentation
description: Principles of instruments used in oceanographic research, introduction to electronics, and applications of instrument measurements. Emphasis will vary from CTD profilers, current meters, radiometry and chemical measurement.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing; MS 141, MS 142 and instructor consent.
notes: Note(s): Offered alternate spring semesters.

name: Advanced Marine Ecology
description: Marine ecology is the study of factors determining the distribution and abundance of marine organisms. This course focuses on the major ecological processes determining the structure and diversity of species assemblages at several scales, primarily at that of the community.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Ecology, Statistics, Instructor consent, Graduate level.
satisfies: Satisfies GWAR: Graduation Writing Assessment Requirement.
notes: Note(s): This course satisfies graduate-level GWAR in this master’s program.

name: Sampling and Experimental Design
description: Basic design of experiments and field sampling. Biases and problems of sampling marine biota.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing; MS 103 and MS 104.
notes: Note(s): Offered spring semester.

name: Aquaculture
description: Theoretical and technical aspects of commercial and conservation aquaculture including water quality, pathobiology, nutrition, physiology, reproduction, environmental impacts, and regulations. Includes field trips to aquaculture facilities and hands-on practice.
sustainability: Sustainability Related - SDG 2: Zero Hunger

name: Molecular Biological Techniques
description: Laboratory-based overview of concepts and techniques for the isolation, characterization, and analysis of DNA and RNA. Covers standard methods (amplification, cloning, and sequencing), and selected specialized techniques (analysis of gene expression), emphasizing marine science applications.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing; college level genetics, molecular biology, or instructor consent.
notes: Note(s): Offered fall semester.

name: Scientific Methods
description: Course is designed to help students develop an understanding of strengths and limitations of various types of scientific reasoning, methodology, and analysis as they relate to scientific progress. Course centers on: round-table discussions of papers and techniques; interactive computer , laboratory, and field learning experiences; and development of critical thinking and writing skills.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing; instructor consent and approved thesis proposal.
notes: Note(s): Offered spring semester.

name: Advanced Marine Mammals, Birds & Turtles
description: This course examines the biology of marine mammals, birds and turtles. Topics include systematics and evolution, adaptations to the marine environment, diving physiology and behavior, communication and echolocation, ecology, and conservation. This class consists of lectures, discussions of recent literature, and laboratory exercises.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Introductory Biology, upper division vertebrate biology (physiology, ecology or similar)
sustainability: Sustainability Related - SDG 14: Life Below Water

name: Ecology of Marine turtles, Birds, and Mammals
description: Community approach to the ecology of marine birds and mammals using experimental and sampling methodology. The class will examine the distribution, abundance, trophic ecology, and behavior of birds and mammals in Elkhorn Slough and Monterey Bay.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing; MS 103, MS 104 and MS 112 and instructor consent.
sustainability: Sustainability Related - SDG 14: Life Below Water
notes: Note(s): Generally offered alternate fall semesters during even years.

name: Advanced Marine Ichthyology
description: This course covers taxonomy and systematics, functional morphology, physiology, biogeography, and ecology of marine fishes at an advanced level. Accompanying laboratory and field sessions focus on taxonomic identification, morphological structure and function, and habits of marine fishes, and the ecological interactions of these fishes with their biotic and abiotic surroundings.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): College zoology or equivalent or consent of instructor; MS 103 recommended.

name: Physiological Ecology of Marine Animals
description: Examines the adaptations animals have evolved to live in marine environments to deal with gradients in water, temperature, salinity, oxygen, exercise, nutrients as well as short-term physiological responses to environmental changes. Topics include metabolism, sensory systems, respiration, circulation, thermoregulation, osmoregulation.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): upper division vertebrate biology (physiology)
sustainability: Sustainability Related - SDG 14: Life Below Water

name: Advanced Topics in Marine Invertebrates
description: Advanced consideration of the ecology, physiology and phylogeny of the various invertebrate phyla emphasizing current literature and research. Topics and emphasis will vary from term to term. May be once repeated for credit when topic changes.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): MS 124 and instructor consent.
sustainability: Sustainability Related - SDG 14: Life Below Water

name: Biology of Seaweeds
description: Discussions on on marine macroalgal biology with extensive reading of original literature. Ecologically-oriented individual research projects involving laboratory culture and field experimentation.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing; MS 131 or instructor consent.
notes: Note(s): Offered fall semester.

name: Advanced Topics in Marine Ecology
description: Selected topics and current issues in marine ecology. Subjects vary depending on student demand and availability of instructors. May be repeated once for credit when topic changes.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing; MS 103 and instructor consent.
sustainability: Sustainability Related - SDG 14: Life Below Water

name: Advanced Geological Oceanography
description: Geological Oceanography (also known as Marine Geology) is the study of the past and present geological processes that occur on earth’s largest habitat: the oceans. Topics covered include: types and composition of marine rocks and sediments, the shape of the ocean basins, processes occurring in the earth’s lithosphere and how they are interpreted within the broad theory of Plate Tectonics and interactions between geological processes, oceanography and biology in different marine habitats. Includes California’s regional geology with visits on local outcrops.
satisfies: Satisfies GWAR: Graduation Writing Assessment Requirement.
sustainability: Sustainability Related - SDG: 14 - Life Below Water
notes: Note(s): This course satisfies graduate-level GWAR in this master’s program.

name: Advanced Physical Oceanography
description: A comprehensive review of the physical processes involved in ocean transport and mixing on a global scale and in coastal regions. Laboratory component involves the collection, processing, and interpretation of oceanographic data. Students discuss recent scientific literature on the physical dynamics of the climate system and the role of physical processes in interdisciplinary problems in oceanography.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Instructor’s consent (college algebra, college physics and calculus highly recommended).
satisfies: Satisfies GWAR: Graduation Writing Assessment Requirement.
sustainability: Sustainability Related - SDG: 14 - Life Below Water
notes: Note(s): This course satisfies graduate-level GWAR in this master’s program.

name: Advanced Chemical Oceanography
description: Comprehensive study of biogeochemical cycling in the oceans, including major salts, dissolved gases, nutrient ions, carbonate parameters, and transient chemical tracers. Students will participate in field expeditions and laboratory experiments to apply their knowledge to real-world oceanographic problems.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): One year of college inorganic chemistry, or instructor consent.
satisfies: Satisfies GWAR: Graduation Writing Assessment Requirement.
sustainability: Sustainability Related - SDG: 14 - Life Below Water.
notes: Note(s): This course satisfies graduate-level GWAR in this master’s program.

name: Advanced Biological Oceanography
description: Comprehensive study of the ocean as an ecological system. Emphasis on the complexity of environmental influences on plankton, the transfer of organic matter between trophic levels and nutrient cycles. Laboratory sessions include methods in sampling, shipboard techniques, identification of the plankton, and current analytical techniques.
sustainability: Sustainability Related - SDG: 14 - Life Below Water.

name: Marine Benthic Habitat Techniques
description: Collection and interpretation of geophysical data used to characterize marine benthic habitats. Basic geophysical principals will be reviewed. Application of techniques to identify and characterize marine benthic habitats, including echosounders, multibeam bathymetry and backscatter, sidescan sonar, seismic profiling, and GIS.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing; MS 141 or instructor consent.
notes: Note(s): Offered alternate spring semesters during odd years.

name: Laboratory Analysis for Marine Scientists
description: Theory and practice with standard and state-of-the-art laboratory techniques in marine sciences for dissolved and particulate constituents of seawater including spectroscopy, flow injection techniques, gas chromatography, ICP-MS, electrochemistry, chemical sensors and chemometrics.

name: Marine Geochemistry
description: Geochemical processes in the oceans; low temperature thermodynamics of aqueous reactions, weathering, oxidation-reduction and biologically mediated reactions, processes occurring at the sea floor and air-sea interface.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): MS 143 or instructor consent.

name: Marine Pollution
description: General aquatic chemistry principles and in-depth analysis of the sources, transport and fate of various contaminants in the marine environment. Topics include nutrients, trace metals, persistent organic pollutants, microplastics, hydrocarbons, radioactive substances and carbon dioxide with accompanying practical experience in the field and laboratory.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): MS 143 or instructor consent.

name: Data Analysis in Marine Science
description: Introduction to using observational oceanographic data, with hands on practice in scientific programming for data analysis. Lecture, discussion, and practical experience including the use of existing programs and subroutine libraries. Semester project required.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing; MS 104, college math and instructor consent.
notes: Note(s): Offer spring semester.

name: Subtidal Ecology
description: The ecology of nearshore rocky subtidal populations and communities with emphasis on kelp forests. Lectures and discussions of original literature. Field work with SCUBA including group projects on underwater research techniques and community analysis. Individual research on ecological questions chosen by the student. Knowledge of marine algae, invertebrates and statistics recommended.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing; MS 103; MLML diver certification and marine ecology.
sustainability: Sustainability Related - SDG 14: Life Below Water
notes: Note(s): Offered alternate spring semesters during odd years.

name: Marine Environmental Studies of the Gulf of California
description: An analysis of Gulf of California marine environments. Lectures, readings, intensive field work, and written scientific paper based on original research. Topics vary. Taught with Mexican faculty and students from La Paz, Mexico. Must be able to participate in 2 weeks of field work.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing; instructor consent.
sustainability: Sustainability Related - SDG 14: Life Below Water
notes: Note(s): Offered spring semester.

name: Advanced Topics in Oceanography
description: Study of selected area in oceanography. Subjects vary depending on student demand and availability of instructors. May be repeated once for credit when topic changes.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing and instructor consent.
sustainability: Sustainability Related - SDG 14: Life Below Water

name: Scientific Writing
description: Techniques and strategies of scientific writing used for proposals, journal submissions and abstracts of meetings. Emphasis to develop writing skills by preparing, editing, and rewriting manuscripts.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing and instructor consent.
notes: Note(s): Offered spring semester.

name: Graduate Seminar in Marine Science
description: Seminar will be held on topics changing each semester. Each student will be required to give at least one seminar.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing and instructor consent.
notes: Note(s): Offered fall and spring semesters.

name: Research in the Marine Science
description: Independent investigations of an advanced character for the graduate student with adequate preparation.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing and instructor consent.

name: Master’s Thesis
description: Offered spring and fall semesters. Available only to MLML Masters’ students in good standing with the approval of their major advisor.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Classified graduate standing, advancement to candidacy.

name: Culminating Experience Supervision
description: Continued work on thesis.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Outstanding RP grade in a preceding semester in MS 299
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 16 units.
notes: Note(s): No Degree Credit.

name: Research in Math Education
description: Theories of learning mathematics; recent trends in mathematics curriculum and pedagogy; types of research in mathematics education; methods of conducting research in mathematics education; developing research questions; conducting library research; and synthesis of research in various areas of mathematics education.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Graduate-level core class for the MA Math, MS Math, or MS Statistics, or instructor consent.

name: Math Education Phase II Seminar
description: This seminar will support the student teaching field experience. Students will be asked to extend their pedagogical content knowledge in light of their phase II experiences and will be supported in the preparation of their Performance Assessment for California Teachers.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): EDSC 184X and good standing in the Secondary Education Credential program

name: Student Teaching Phase I
description: Student teaching in Mathematics Education (Phase I) is designed to provide students with the experiences they need to be successful in Phase II. During the Phase I semester, student teachers work with their mentor teacher in a mathematics classroom one period each day, with additional times set aside each week to confer, debrief, and plan.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): MTED 394

name: Student Teaching II - Classroom Teaching
description: Minimum 80-120 class periods of classroom teaching, laboratory or field teaching in appropriate single subjects, grades K-12 and related teaching activities. Attendance at a weekly seminar is required.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): MTED 394 and joint approval of Mathematics and Education departments.

name: Student Teaching III - Classroom Teaching
description: Same as MTED 184Y, including the seminar, but in a different course. May be in a different school.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): MTED 394 and joint approval of the Mathematics and Teacher Education Departments.

name: Secondary Mathematics Methods
description: The place and function of mathematics in secondary education, improvement and evaluation of instruction. Teaching the subject matter of secondary mathematics.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Passing score on all 3 CSET math exams or be within 3 courses of completing the subject matter preparation program, or instructor consent.

name: Middle School Mathematics Methods
description: The place and function of mathematics in middle grades education, improvement and evaluation of instruction. Teaching the subject matter of middle grades mathematics.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): EDEL 108D, Passing scores on CSET I and II or Instructor consent.

name: Transportation Systems and Society
description: Core transportation knowledge and systems thinking. Characteristics of travel modes and infrastructural elements that produce transportation systems; public, private, and nonprofit actors involved in transportation; transportation systems as levers toward achieving economic vitality, social equity, environmental sustainability, and community goals; and key challenges transportation system managers will face in the coming decade.
satisfies: Satisfies GWAR: Graduation Writing Assessment Requirement.
notes: Note(s): This course satisfies graduate-level GWAR in this master’s program.

name: Introduction to Transportation Funding and Finance
description: Introduces financial and managerial uses of accounting information systems and concepts. Includes standard costs, cost-volume-profit relationships, contribution analysis, budgeting, performance measurement, variance analysis, working capital, valuing capital costs and financing investment decisions. Explores use of complex information decision systems.

name: Transportation Marketing and Communications Management
description: Emphasizes positioning services to meet the needs of particular groups/market segments and marketing the system to new users/user groups (including developing the public/private sector relationship). Examines strategies for developing the community relationship with marketing and public relations efforts (and using the media to advantage).

name: Transportation Policy and Regulation
description: Surveys political frameworks of governments as both customer and provider; development of transportation policy with public involvement; and performance measurement with public oversight. Reviews policy impact on intermodal development in seeking to manage public and private objectives and diverse agendas of federal, state and local agencies.

name: Transportation Planning and Project Development
description: Examines management of transportation planning and project development processes, including: regional and state system-wide planning; project-level planning; environmental review; obtaining governmental approvals and permits; contract management; and project management.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): MTM 201 or instructor approval.

name: Leadership and Management of Transportation Organizations
description: A study of the human resource aspects of managing transportation systems, including labor/management collaboration/negotiation and consultative employee relations programs. Builds skills in leadership and team building within the context of bringing about organizational change in a complex transportation system.

name: Transportation Emergency Management
description: Examines the role of emergency management within transportation agencies and the role of transportation and related resources in community-wide responses to emergencies disasters. Includes instruction in Standardized Emergency Management Systems (SEMS).

name: Transportation Security Management
description: Examines contemporary challenges to transportation security. Topics to be covered include: management of infrastructure challenges (such as tunnel, bridge, road and rail vulnerabilities) prevention of and response to theft, work place violence, disruptive terrorism, suicide and placement combing attacks, and their related protection strategies. Students will learn about federal and state grants for security, as well as regional transportation planning for disaster response planning.

name: Transportation Safety and Compliance Management
description: Examines contemporary challenges to transportation safety and regulatory compliance. Topics to be covered include the history and evolution of safety principles, developing and managing a safety culture, hazard identification and management, along with federal and state regulatory compliance and safety certification processes. Students will also be introduced to the federal rulemaking process and the role of the National Transportation Safety Board.

name: Managing Technology Innovations in Transportation
description: Management challenges posed by five technological trends: electrification, vehicle automation, connected vehicles and infrastructure, car sharing and ride sharing, and mobility as a service. Topics include: impacts on infrastructure, financing, and labor; managing technologies to support environmental, equity, and economic efficiency policy goals; and supporting collaboration between public agencies and private sector firms.

name: High-Speed and Intercity Rail: Planning & Design
description: Course introduces students to fundamental principles for managing the planning and design of high-speed and intercity rail projects. Students analyze the challenges and opportunities that high-speed and intercity rail services face in the U.S., given prevailing travel behavior patterns, land-use patterns, and funding sources. Topics include the interrelationship of high-speed rail with conventional intercity rail and urban public transportation, the roles of different levels of government in planning and design, and the delivery and governance of rail corridors and stations. The course takes an international perspective, drawing lessons from around the globe and applying these principles to the U.S. context.

name: High-Speed and Intercity Rail Operations/Engineering
description: Course introduces students to best practices for managing the engineering and operations of high-speed and intercity rail. Topics covered include day-to-day operational concerns such as customer experience, service scheduling, and security management. In addition, the class covers strategic issues such as operating blended service that accommodates both passenger and freight service, managing public communications, and contracting approaches for both construction and operations.

name: Sustainable & Resilient Transportation Management
description: Analysis of the multidimensional relationship between transportation systems and major environmental problems such as climate change, air pollution, noise, diminished water and soil quality, and decreased biodiversity. Exploration of innovative strategies to achieve sustainable and resilient transportation systems, such as zero-emission and other new vehicle technologies, climate resilience and adaptation plans, habitat conservation plans, principles of climate justice, and environmental impact assessment and monitoring. Case studies from across the globe that examine the interplay between sustainable management practices and technological, political, and societal factors.

name: Project Management in Transportation
description: Reviews project management, program, and portfolio practices defined by the Project Management Institute (PMI) and the International Organization for Standardization (ISO). Examines how those practices apply to transportation and compares project management practices in the US transportation industry to other industry sectors and to general practices in other countries.

name: MSTM Capstone - Project Design
description: Provides the first part of a culminating experience in which students design and carry out an individual, comprehensive policy or program evaluation. Students conduct background research and develop a Policy or Program Evaluation Proposal that demonstrates their capacity to do independent research, analysis, and writing about a complex transportation management problem.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Completion of 21 units towards the Master of Science in Transportation Management degree

name: MSTM Capstone - Evaluation Report
description: Provides the second part of a culminating experience in which students design and carry out an individual, comprehensive policy or program evaluation. Students complete a Policy or Program Evaluation following the proposal design they developed in MTM 283. The final report demonstrates their capacity to do independent research, analysis, and writing about a complex transportation management problem.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): MTM 283

name: Special Topics in Transportation Management
description: Special topics to supplement regularly programmed elective course. Topics can include, but are not limited to, special skills development, labor relations, information systems, legal environment, public policy, and urban planning.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing and prerequisite courses as may be specified.

name: Foundations of Music Education
description: Survey of music education’s historical, philosophical, psychological and sociological foundations.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing or instructor consent.

name: Introduction to Music Education: Early Field Experience
description: Introduction to teaching music in the public schools. Includes in-school paraprofessional work in approved music program under supervision of university faculty and master teachers.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Sophomore standing.

name: Teaching Instrumental Music
description: Materials, literature, methods and pedagogy for teachers of instrumental music.

name: Teaching Choral Music
description: Materials, literature, methods and pedagogy for teachers of choral music.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing.

name: Practicum in Music Education
description: Practical experience in music education including pedagogy, classroom management and practice teaching.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): MUED 140, MUED 170, MUED 147A, MUED147B or instructor consent.

name: Student Teaching for Music Individualized Interns
description: Supervised student teaching in music class(es) in the public school where the student is employed as an Individualized Intern.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Admission to Single Subject Credential Program; music advisor and Single Subject Coordinator consent.
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 12 units.

name: Student Teaching II - Classroom Teaching
description: Minimum 80-120 class periods of classroom, teaching lab or field teaching in music subjects, grades K-12. Includes seminar.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing and joint approval of major and education departments.

name: Student Teaching III-Classroom Teaching
description: To be taken concurrently or in different semester than 184Y. May be in a different subject or in different school and will be at a different grade level.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing and joint approval of major and education departments.

name: Music Ed Trends
description: Investigation of current trends in music education. Topics vary with course offering.

name: International Program Studies
description: Study Abroad and Away transfer credit course. Study Abroad and Away provides students the opportunity to study abroad on long term programs (Exchange Programs, CSU International Programs, and International Student Exchange Programs) and short-term programs (Faculty-Led Programs and Summer School Abroad Programs) for academic credit, offering Alternative Break Programs for cultural immersion, and designing other globally focused opportunities. This course is designated as a placeholder course for Study Abroad and Away programs.
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 6 units.

name: Foundations of Music Education
description: This course provides an introduction to graduate studies in music education. Topics include; historical contexts; philosophy; sociology, aesthetics; psychology; and learning theory in music education.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Graduate student standing and instructor consent

name: Research in Music Education
description: This course examines research in music education, concentrating on qualitative, quantitative, and historical methodologies. Attention will focus on applications of research within music education, and the course will culminate in a capstone project using one of these research methodologies.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Graduate student standing, instructor consent

name: Directions and Issues in Music Education
description: This course examines current issues and directions in music education. Topics include historical, sociological, and philosophical contexts for music education; learning and development issues; curriculum and pedagogy; assessment; applied research in music education; and leadership development.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Graduate student standing and instructor consent
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 4 units.

name: Methodology for Music Educators: Elementary K-8
description: Study of Kodaly, Orff and Dalcroze elementary methods including a multicultural emphasis. A review of materials for the comprehensive elementary music curriculum. Peer teaching/field observations of classrooms, choral and instrumental classes required.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing or instructor consent.
notes: Note(s): Required for certification.

name: Methodology for Music Educators: Secondary
description: Prepares secondary music instructors to teach non-performance courses, including music appreciation, theory, technology, history and multicultural survey. Peer teaching and field observations required. Organization of comprehensive secondary music departments included.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): MUED 370A.

name: Culminating Experience Supervision
description: Continued work on thesis or project
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Outstanding RP grade in a preceding semesters in a thesis, composition, or project class.
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 16 units.
notes: Note(s): No Degree Credit.

name: Music Systems IA
description: First course in a four-semester core sequence of study of analytical systems of music. Topics include rhythm, melody, harmony, timbre, structure, style and contexts for performance and composition.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Placement examination or completion of MUSC 9 with a grade of ‘C’ or better.

name: Music Systems IB
description: First course in a four-semester core sequence of aural skills acquisition, including dictation, sight-singing and analysis.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Placement examination.

name: Music Systems IIA
description: Second course in a four-semester core sequence of study of analytical systems of music. Topics from MUSC 1A are continued in greater detail with increased complexity.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): MUSC 1A or placement examination.

name: Music Systems IIB
description: Second course in a four-semester core sequence of aural skills acquisition, including diction, sight-singing and analysis.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): MUSC 1B or placement examination.

name: Music Systems IIIA
description: Third course in a four-semester core sequence of study of analytical systems of music. Topics from MUSC 2A are continued in greater detail with increased complexity.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): MUSC 2A or placement examination.

name: Music Systems IIIB
description: Third course in a four-semester core sequence of aural skills acquisition, including dictation, sight-singing and analysis.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): MUSC 2B or placement examination.

name: Music Systems IVA
description: Fourth course in a four-semester core sequence of study of analytical systems of music. Topics from MUSC 3A are continued in greater detail and with increased complexity.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): MUSC 3A or placement examination.
satisfies: Satisfies C1: Arts when taken as part of the Music Intensive Package.
notes: Note(s): Music Intensive Package also requires MUSC 4B and MUSC 12

name: Music Systems IVB
description: Fourth course in a four-semester core sequence of aural skills acquisition, including dictation, sight-singing and analysis.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): MUSC 3B or placement examination.
satisfies: Satisfies C1: Arts when taken as part of the Music Intensive Package.
notes: Note(s): Music Intensive Package also requires MUSC 12 and MUSC 4A

name: Jazz Theory
description: Understanding of traditional jazz nomenclature including chord symbols, chord/scale relationships, and jazz harmony. Various scales, their modes and their applications will be addressed as well as their applications to harmonic progressions common to the jazz idiom.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): MUSC 1A, MUSC 1B, MUSC 25A.

name: The Artist’s Way
description: Assists performing artists in becoming successful scholar/artists at SJSU and beyond through strategies for successful completion of studies at SJSU; experiencing and understanding the elements of the performing arts; and understanding and implementing lifelong practices for forging healthy performing arts careers.
satisfies: Satisfies E: Human Understanding & Development.

name: Music Fundamentals
description: Understanding music terminology, fundamental concepts in music theory and techniques in music reading. Acceptable as elective credit for music major (as review of fundamentals or for individual instruction in conjunction with applied music study) only with prior advisor approval.

name: Music Appreciation
description: General survey of Western music focusing on recorded and live performances.
satisfies: Satisfies C1: Arts.

name: Introduction to Music
description: Beginning piano playing as a means to understanding music. Listening skills developed through exposure to a variety of music: Popular/classical, old/new, Western/non-Western.
satisfies: Satisfies C1: Arts.

name: Pop and Rock in the U.S.
description: Examines the musical attributes, structures, and stylistic choices in American popular music, as well as the historical and cultural underpinnings of the originating forces and influences and how they affect or are affected by social/cultural norms and political and economic developments.
satisfies: Satisfies C1: Arts.

name: Introduction to Hip Hop
description: Examines the origins, development, and importance of the music and culture of Hip Hop with emphasis on its societal implications in the U.S. and worldwide.
satisfies: Satisfies C1: Arts.

name: Medieval and Renaissance Music
description: A brief introduction to the six major periods of music history (Ancient and Medieval, Renaissance, Baroque, Classical, Romantic and Modern) followed by a survey of the Ancient, Medieval, and Renaissance periods with a study of notation, theory, composers, works, and cultural history.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): MUSC 2A or instructor consent.
satisfies: Satisfies C2: Humanities when taken as part of the Music Intensive Package.
notes: Note(s): Music Intensive Package also requires MUSC 4A and MUSC 4B

name: Music Technology
description: Hands-on skills development in music hardware and software, including music integration in word processing and graphics, music notation and Internet/WWW-based research tools for music majors or non-music majors with some music background.

name: Music in World Cultures
description: Introduction to music in various cultural contexts outside European classical tradition. Live performances, film, video tapes and slides. Projects involving related arts encouraged.
satisfies: Satisfies C1: Arts.
crosslist: Cross-listed with ASIA 19.  Music is responsible for scheduling.

name: Piano Proficiency I
description: Skills development in performing four-part harmony; harmonizing melodies in pianistic style, modulation, simple score reading and sight-reading. First in three-course sequence to prepare applied music students for piano proficiency exam at the end of MUSC 25C.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): MUSC 9 (or equivalent) or instructor consent.

name: Piano Proficiency II
description: 25B continuation of 25A.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): MUSC 25A or equivalent, instructor consent

name: Piano Proficiency III
description: Preparation for Piano Proficiency Exam
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): MUSC 9, MUSC 25B or equivalent, instructor consent
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 5 units.

name: Voice Fundamentals
description: Principles of voice production and performance.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): MUSC 9 or MUSC 10B (or equivalent).

name: Fundamentals of Jazz Keyboard I
description: For any instrumental/voice student. Basic skills in jazz keyboard: Chord voicings, symbols, progressions and rhythmic patterns, jazz styles, simple melodic techniques and accompaniment.

name: Fundamentals of Jazz Keyboard II
description: Advanced applications of materials presented in MUSC 27A, including keyboard performance of selected lead-sheet literature; chord symbol recognition, keyboard techniques, chord substitutions introduced, polychords.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): MUSC 27A (or equivalent).

name: Guitar Fundamentals
description: The purpose of this course is to develop basic skills and techniques in guitar playing, applicable to various types of music and teaching.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Ability to read music.

name: Electro-Acoustics
description: Incorporating current music technology and instrumentation in creating works and projects. Required each semester of lower division electro-acoustic majors.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Audition or Instructor Consent

name: Electro-Acoustics 1
description: APPLIED LESSONS: Electro-acoustics level 1, incorporating current music technology and instrumentation into projects. For music technology majors.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Audition and instructor consent

name: Applied Electro-Acoustic 1
description: The course is an intensive study of electro-acoustic music and audio production methods. Works and projects are created incorporating current music technology and instrumentation.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Successful audition into the applied area

name: Electro-Acoustics 2
description: APPLIED LESSONS: Electro-acoustics level 2, incorporating current music technology and instrumentation into projects. For music technology majors.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Audition and instructor consent, MUSC 29A or equivalent

name: Applied Electro-Acoustic 2
description: The course is an intensive study of electro-acoustic music and audio production methods. Works and projects are created incorporating current music technology and instrumentation.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Successful audition into the applied area

name: Electro-Acoustics 3
description: APPLIED LESSONS: Electro-acoustics level 3, incorporating current music technology and instrumentation into projects. For music technology majors.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Audition and instructor consent, MUSC 29B or equivalent

name: Applied Electro-Acoustic 3
description: The course is an intensive study of electro-acoustic music and audio production methods. Works and projects are created incorporating current music technology and instrumentation.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Successful audition into the applied area

name: Electro-Acoustics 4
description: APPLIED LESSONS: Electro-acoustics level 4, incorporating current music technology and instrumentation into projects. For music technology majors.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Audition and instructor consent, MUSC 29C or equivalent

name: Applied Electro-Acoustic 4
description: The course is an intensive study of electro-acoustic music and audio production methods. Works and projects are created incorporating current music technology and instrumentation.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Successful audition into the applied area

name: Piano
description: Required each semester of lower division piano majors.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Audition or instructor consent.

name: Piano 1
description: APPLIED LESSONS: Piano level 1. Required of BM piano majors every semester.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Audition and instructor consent

name: Applied Piano 1
description: The objective of applied lessons is for the instructor to work intensively with the individual piano major in acquiring skills both technical and interpretive in the mastery of standard repertory.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Successful audition into applied area

name: Piano 2
description: APPLIED LESSONS: Piano level 2. Lessons required of BM piano majors every semester.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Audition and instructor consent

name: Applied Piano 2
description: The objective of applied lessons is for the instructor to work intensively with the individual piano major in acquiring skills both technical and interpretive in the mastery of standard repertory.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Successful audition into applied area

name: Piano 3
description: APPLIED LESSONS: Piano level 3. Lessons required of BM piano majors every semester.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Audition and instructor consent, MUSC 30B or equivalent.

name: Applied Piano 3
description: The objective of applied lessons is for the instructor to work intensively with the individual piano major in acquiring skills both technical and interpretive in the mastery of standard repertory.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Successful audition into applied area

name: Piano 4
description: APPLIED LESSONS: Piano level 4. Lessons required of BM piano majors every semester.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Audition and instructor consent, MUSC 30C or equivalent.

name: Applied Piano 3
description: The objective of applied lessons is for the instructor to work intensively with the individual piano major in acquiring skills both technical and interpretive in the mastery of standard repertory.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Successful audition into applied area

name: Voice
description: Required each semester of lower division voice majors. Study and development of vocal techniques and performance of representative repertoire from principal periods in music. Includes compositions embracing the English, Italian, French and German languages.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Audition or instructor consent.

name: Voice 1
description: APPLIED LESSONS: Voice level 1. Required of BM vocal majors every semester.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Audition and instructor consent

name: Applied Voice 1
description: Applied Lessons 1-8, required each semester for lower and upper division Voice majors.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Audition and/or the prior course in the sequence

name: Voice 2
description: APPLIED LESSONS: Voice level 2. Required of BM vocal majors every semester.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Audition and instructor consent, MUSC 33A or equivalent.

name: Applied Voice 2
description: Applied Lessons 1-8, required each semester for lower and upper division Voice majors.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Audition and/or the prior course in the sequence

name: Voice 3
description: APPLIED LESSONS: Voice level 3. Required of BM vocal majors every semester.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Audition and instructor consent, MUSC 33B or equivalent.

name: Voice 4
description: APPLIED LESSONS: Voice level 4. Required of BM vocal majors every semester.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Audition and instructor consent, MUSC 33C or equivalent.

description: Applied Lessons 1-8, required each semester for lower and upper division Voice majors.

name: Applied Voice
description: Applied Lessons 1-8, required each semester for lower and upper division Voice majors.
