description: APPLIED LESSONS: Jazz. Vocal or instrumental improvisation, composition or arranging, level 1. Required of BM Jazz Studies majors every semester.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Audition and instructor consent

name: Jazz: Improvisation, Composition or Arranging 1
description: APPLIED LESSONS: Jazz. Vocal or instrumental improvisation, composition or arranging, level 1. Required of BA, BM-Composition, or BM Jazz Studies majors every semester.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Audition and instructor approval

name: Jazz: Improvisation, Composition or Arranging 2
description: APPLIED LESSONS: Jazz. Vocal or instrumental improvisation, composition or arranging, level 2. Required of BM Jazz Studies majors every semester.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Audition and instructor consent, MUSC 39A or equivalent

name: Jazz: Improvisation, Composition or Arranging 2
description: APPLIED LESSONS: Jazz. Vocal or instrumental improvisation, composition or arranging, level 2. Required of BA, BM-Composition, or BM Jazz Studies majors every semester.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): MUSC 39AX or equivalent

name: Jazz: Improvisation, Composition or Arranging 3
description: APPLIED LESSONS: Jazz. Vocal or instrumental improvisation, composition or arranging, level 3. Required of BM Jazz Studies majors every semester.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Audition and instructor consent, MUSC 39B or equivalent

name: Jazz: Improvisation, Composition or Arranging 3
description: APPLIED LESSONS: Jazz. Vocal or instrumental improvisation, composition or arranging, level 3. Required of BA, BM-Composition, or BM Jazz Studies majors every semester.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): MUSC 39BX or equivalent

name: Jazz: Improvisation, Composition and Arranging 4
description: APPLIED LESSONS: Jazz. Vocal or instrumental improvisation, composition or arranging, level 5. Required of BM Jazz Studies majors every semester.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Audition and instructor consent, MUSC 39C or equivalent

name: Jazz: Improvisation, Composition or Arranging 4
description: APPLIED LESSONS: Jazz. Vocal or instrumental improvisation, composition or arranging, level 4. Required of BA, BM-Composition, or BM Jazz Studies majors every semester.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): MUSC 39CX or equivalent

name: Applied Jazz Saxophone
description: The goal of Applied Jazz Saxophone at any level is to present each student with the appropriate materials to increase his/her ability as an improvising musician. Emphasis will be placed on learning standard jazz repertoire; the transcription of jazz solos; the assimilation of technical patterns associated with improvisation; and internalizing an idiomatic stylistic approach.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): MUSC 39AxBxCxDx: Successful audition into the BA Music Degree MUSC 39ABCD: Successful audition into the BM Jazz Studies Degree MUSC 139ABCD: Successful completion of Junior Qualifying Examination MUSC 224: Successful audition into the MM Jazz Studies Degree MUSC 239: With graduate advisors and applied instructors consent

name: Jazz Improvisation - I
description: Development of performance skills for lead-sheet interpretation: response and interplay, ear-training for improvisers, basic chord-scales and jazz vocabulary. Vocal, instrumental, and transcription exercises. In-class performance. Emphasis will be placed on blues, modal compositions, and simple song forms.
prereqs: Pre/Corequisite(s): MUSC 1A, MUSC 1B and MUSC 25A; or equivalent.

name: Applied Lyric Diction
description: Pronunciation and applied execution of correct diction in English and Italian for singers in a master class setting. Performance of specific literature of these languages with emphasis on correct usage of the International Phonetic alphabet for lyric diction.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Instructor consent.

name: Applied Lyric Diction
description: Pronunciation and applied execution of correct diction in French and German for singers in a master class setting. Performance of specific literature of these languages with emphasis on correct usage of the International Phonetic Alphabet for lyric diction.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Instructor consent.

name: ENS: Concert Choir
description: Ensemble. Large select choral ensemble, specializing in advanced a cappella and symphonic major works from all periods.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Audition and instructor consent
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 5 units.

name: ENS: University Chorales
description: ENS: Rehearsal and performance of choral masterpieces and music with wide popular appeal. Students involved in the University Chorales will participate in either the SJSU Women’s Chorus, Men’s Glee Club, or other specialized choral ensemble and will have the opportunity to study and perform high quality choral literature.
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 5 units.
notes: Note(s): Elective course open to music majors and non-music majors.

name: ENS: University Chorales - Treble Choir
description: Vocal ensemble for treble voices.  Bi-weekly rehearsals lead to one or more performances per semester.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Audition or Instructor Consent
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 5 units.

name: ENS: University Chorales - Spartan Glee
description: Vocal ensemble for low voices.  Bi-weekly rehearsals lead to one or more performances per semester.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Audition or Instructor Consent
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 5 units.

name: ENS: Opera Theater
description: Ens: Training and performance experience in the field of opera. Fully-staged productions of one-act and conventional length works of varying styles.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Audition and instructor consent.
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 5 units.

name: ENS: University Symphony Orchestra
description: Ens: Rehearsal and performance of standard orchestral and operatic repertory.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Audition and Instructor Consent
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 5 units.

name: ENS: Symphonic Band
description: ENS: Rehearsal and performance of large symphonic band repertory.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Audition and Instructor Consent
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 5 units.

name: ENS: Wind Ensemble
description: ENS: Major performing group open to all wind instrumentalists by audition. Select group that performs the most advanced and high quality contemporary and traditional literature for wind ensemble from all periods. Programming changes every semester. Performances can include but not be limited to state and national conferences.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Audition and instructor consent
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 5 units.

name: ENS: Spartan Marching Band
description: ENS: Open by permission to all students who play saxophone, brass or percussion instruments. Performs at all home and selected away Spartan football games.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Audition and Instructor Consent
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 5 units.

name: ENS: Jazz Orchestra
description: ENS: Big band jazz performance for instrumentalists and singers. Classic and new repertoire. Concert performances.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Audition and Instructor Consent
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 5 units.

name: ENS: Afro-Latin Jazz Ensemble
description: ENS:Performance of Afro-Latin jazz and popular music repertoires of the US, the Caribbean, and Latin America. Ensemble techniques and solo improvisation. Concert performances.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Audition and Instructor Consent
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 5 units.

name: ENS: Choraliers
description: ENS: Small select chamber vocal group specializing in music from all periods, Renaissance to Contemporary.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Audition and Instructor Consent
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 5 units.

name: ENS: Chamber Music
description: ENS: In-depth chamber music study and performance of standard repertoire with two or more instruments plus piano.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Audition and instructor consent
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 5 units.

name: ENS: Collegium Musicum
description: ENS: Reinforces music history studies through performance. Authenticating performance of pre-Classical music on period instruments and accurate vocal/instrumental practices. Vocal and instrumental, sacred and secular music performed.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Audition and Instructor Consent
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 5 units.

name: ENS: Jazz Singers
description: ENS: Performance of advanced literature for chamber jazz chorus in concerts, festivals, and special events. Performance techniques, improvisation, musicianship and studio-recording techniques.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Audition and Instructor Consent
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 5 units.

name: ENS: Small Jazz Ensembles
description: ENS: Small-group jazz performance: standard literature, informal (“head”) arrangements. In-class and/or public performances.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): MUSC 1A, MUSC 1B, MUSC 40A and MUSC 140B or equivalent. Instructor consent.
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 5 units.

name: ENS: Pep Band
description: ENS: Limited to twenty-five woodwind, brass and percussion players; performs at home Spartan basketball games and certain campus functions.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Audition and Instructor Consent
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 5 units.

name: ENS: Percussion Ensemble
description: ENS: Performing class consisting of percussion majors. Master classes during fall semester.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Non-majors by audition and instructor consent
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 5 units.

name: ENS: Jazz Ensemble
description: ENS: Large jazz ensemble focused on learning standard repertoire, style, pedagogy and improvisation.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Audition and instructor consent
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 5 units.

name: ENS: String Ensemble
description: ENS: Chamber works for various string combinations studied and performed. Rehearsal and performance techniques for small chamber groups.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Audition and Instructor Consent
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 5 units.

name: ENS: Brass Ensemble
description: ENS: Performance of duet, trio, quartet and quintet literature for mixed and homogeneous brass instruments. Literature used represents all style periods with either original or transcription materials.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Audition and Instructor Consent
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 5 units.

name: ENS: Woodwind Ensemble
description: ENS: Chamber works for various woodwind combinations. Rehearsal and performance techniques for small chamber groups.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Audition or Instructor Consent
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 5 units.

name: ENS: Saxophone Ensemble
description: ENS: Overview of music for saxophone ensemble for two to twenty players. All styles studied from Renaissance to Jazz.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Audition and Instructor Consent
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 5 units.

name: ENS: Trombone Ensemble
description: ENS: Rehearsal and performance of literature for trombone ensemble. Weekly meetings will also include discussion of brass related topics.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Audition and instructor consent
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 5 units.

name: REP: Styles and Interpretation of Opera I
description: REP: Introduction to styles of opera composition and presentation focusing on opera scenes being presented by the Opera Theater.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Audition and Instructor Consent
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 5 units.

name: REP:Styles and Interpretation of Opera II
description: REP: Advanced styles of opera composition and presentation focusing on opera scenes being presented by the Opera Theater
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Audition and Instructor Consent
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 5 units.

name: New Music Ensemble
description: The New Music Ensemble performs solo, chamber, and large ensemble works drawn from the broad spectrum of contemporary music, including works by living composers.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Audition and instructor consent.
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 5 units.

name: Concert Band
description: Concert Band is an ensemble open to all wind and percussion instrumentalists regardless of major. It is designed for instrumentalists that are still developing rehearsal and performance skills in an ensemble setting that culminates in a concert on campus each semester.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Open to freshmen and sophomores only.
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 4 units.

name: Concert Listening I
description: Active involvement in the professional musical life of the campus and community through attending programs from the master list published each semester and writing five critical reviews.
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 4 units.
notes: Note(s): Open to all university students.

name: International Program Studies
description: Study Abroad and Away transfer credit course. Study Abroad and Away provides students the opportunity to study abroad on long term programs (Exchange Programs, CSU International Programs, and International Student Exchange Programs) and short-term programs (Faculty-Led Programs and Summer School Abroad Programs) for academic credit, offering Alternative Break Programs for cultural immersion, and designing other globally focused opportunities. This course is designated as a placeholder course for Study Abroad and Away programs.

name: Written Communication II
description: Examines the process of critique, creative description, research, and professional communications central to the performing arts. Students develop writing skills through the study of varied formats focused on the arts.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): A3 or equivalent second semester composition course (with a grade of C- or better); completion of core GE; and upper division standing. Or Graduate or Postbaccalaureate level.
satisfies: Satisfies Writing in the Disciplines (WID).
notes: Note(s): Must be passed with C or better to satisfy the CSU Graduation Writing Assessment Requirement (GWAR).

name: Orchestration
description: Ranges, sonorities, transposition and technical considerations of orchestral instruments. Performance of project for full orchestra as culminating activity.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): MUSC 13, MUSC 4A and MUSC 4B or equivalents
notes: Note(s): May be taken singly or in any sequence.

name: Form and Analysis
description: Formal design and pitch structure of Western art music.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): MUSC 4A and MUSC 4B.

name: Counterpoint
description: The study of the art of counterpoint from the sixteenth century to the present. Includes analysis, imitative and original composition.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): MUSC 4A and MUSC 4B (both with C or better); placement examination.
notes: Note(s): May be taken singly or in any sequence. Emphasis may vary.

name: Jazz Arranging I
description: First in a two -semester sequence of jazz arranging and composition required of all jazz majors. Deals primarily with techniques involved in writing and arranging music for the small jazz ensemble and addresses skills used jazz composition.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): MUSC 2A, MUSC 2B, MUSC 6, MUSC 40A.

name: Jazz Arranging II
description: Second in a two-semester sequence of jazz arranging and composition required of all jazz majors. Deals primarily with techniques involved in writing and arranging music for the large jazz ensemble. Computer notation is required on all finished projects.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): MUSC 2A, MUSC 2B, MUSC 6, MUSC 106A.

name: Film Scoring Techniques
description: Production-oriented introduction to techniques of applied composition and sound for film, television, video and related visual media. Concepts of style and orchestration.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Lower division music theory (MUSC 4A and MUSC 4B) or consent of instructor.
notes: Note(s): Emphasis may vary.

name: Baroque and Classical Music History
description: Exploration and survey of the Baroque and Classical periods with study of styles, composers, works, music theory, performance practices, and cultural and intellectual history. Application of research and library skills through research assignments.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): MUSC 12, MUSC 3A (or equivalent), or instructor consent.

name: Romantic and Modern Music History
description: Exploration and survey of Romantic and Modern classical music with study of styles, composers, works, music theory, performance practices, and cultural and intellectual history. Demonstration of research and library skills through a term paper.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): MUSC 110, or equivalent.

name: Music and Culture in Latin America
description: Traces development of musical traditions in Latin America. Analyzes formation of musical styles resulting from socio-political, cultural and economic processes.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Completion of Core General Education and upper division standing are prerequisites to all SJSU studies courses. Completion of, or co-registration in, 100W is strongly recommended.
satisfies: Satisfies SJSU Studies V: Cultures and Global Understanding.

name: Worlds of Jazz
description: Course approaches jazz as part of American and global cultural history, exploring the changing social contexts in which jazz musicians in the US and abroad have worked and lived throughout the 20th century and today.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Completion of Core General Education and upper division standing are prerequisites to all SJSU studies courses. Completion of, or co-registration in, 100W is strongly recommended.
satisfies: Satisfies SJSU Studies S: Self, Society & Equality in U.S.

name: Fundamental Techniques of Woodwinds: Flute, Clarinet, and Saxophone
description: Woodwinds: Flute, Clarinet, and Saxophone. Required for credential. Instrumental emphasis in music education must take two units including clarinet, saxophone, flute, oboe, and bassoon. Choral/general emphasis must take a minimum of one unit to include flute, clarinet and saxophone.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing.

name: Fundamental Techniques and Literature: Instrumental
description: Woodwinds: double reeds and saxophone. Required for credential. Instrumental emphasis in music education must take two units including flute, clarinet, saxophone and double reeds. Choral/general emphasis must take a minimum of one unit including flute, clarinet, and saxophone.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing and instructor consent.

name: Brass Fundamentals: Upper Brass
description: Upper Brass. Required for credential. Instrumental emphasis in music education must take two units including upper and lower brass. Choral/general emphasis must take a minimum of one unit of brass.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing.

name: Bass Fundamentals: Low Brass
description: Lower Brass. Required for credential. Instrumental emphasis in music education must take two units including upper and lower brass. Choral/general emphasis must take a minimum of one unit of upper brass.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Upper Division Standing and Instructor Consent

name: Special Topics in Music History/Literature
description: Content varies to allow presentation of one-time courses by specialists from artist-faculty and guests.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing or instructor consent.
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 6 units.

name: Percussion Techniques
description: Percussion. Required for credential.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing.

name: Marching Band Techniques
description: Methods and materials of marching band instruction. Techniques of show development, arranging, drill design, charting, and drill instruction. Principles of band administration, such as budget management, purchasing, and program development. Required for credential.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing and instructor consent.
notes: Note(s): Offer through Extended Studies.

name: Fundamental Techniques and Literature: Instrumental Upper Strings - Violin and Viola
description: Upper Strings. Required for credential. Instrumental emphasis in music education must take two units including upper and lower strings. Choral/general emphasis must take a minimum of one unit of strings.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing.

name: Fundamental Techniques and Literature: Instrumental Lower Strings - Cello and Bass
description: Lower Strings. Required for credential. Instrumental emphasis in music education must take two units including upper and lower strings. Choral/general emphasis must take a minimum of one unit of upper strings.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing and instructor consent.

name: Electro-Acoustics 5
description: APPLIED LESSONS: Electro-acoustics level 5, incorporating current music technology and instrumentation into projects. For music technology majors.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Audition and instructor consent, MUSC 29D or equivalent

name: Piano 5
description: APPLIED LESSONS: Piano level 5. Lessons required of BM piano majors every semester.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Audition and instructor consent, MUSC 30D or equivalent.

name: Piano 6
description: APPLIED LESSONS: Piano level 6. Lessons required of BM piano majors every semester.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Audition and instructor consent, MUSC 130A or equivalent.

name: Piano 7
description: APPLIED LESSONS: Piano level 7. Lessons required of BM piano majors every semester.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Audition and instructor consent, MUSC 130B or equivalent.

name: Piano 8
description: APPLIED LESSONS: Piano level 8. Lessons required of BM piano majors every semester.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Audition and instructor consent, MUSC 130C or equivalent.

name: Voice
description: Required each semester of upper division voice majors. Continuation of MUSC 33. Study of more advanced repertoire and techniques.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Audition or instructor consent.

name: Voice 5
description: APPLIED LESSONS: Voice level 5. Required of BM vocal majors every semester. Upper division.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Audition and instructor consent, MUSC 33D or equivalent
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 4 units.

name: Voice 6
description: APPLIED LESSONS: Voice level 6. Required of BM vocal majors every semester. Upper division.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Audition and instructor consent, MUSC 133A or equivalent, MUSC 25C or equivalent

name: Voice 7
description: APPLIED LESSONS: Voice level 7. Required of BM vocal majors every semester. Upper division.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Audition and instructor consent, MUSC 133B or equivalent.

name: Voice 8
description: APPLIED LESSONS: Voice level 8. Required of BM vocal majors every semester. Upper division.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Audition and instructor consent, MUSC 133C or equivalent

name: Strings
description: Required each semester of upper division string majors. Violin: All major and minor scales and arpeggios in three octaves; double stops; Kreutzer, Fiorillo, Rode etudes; Bach unaccompanied sonatas and standard concert repertoire, including concerti and sonatas by Vivaldi, Bach, Mozart, Mendelssohn, Beethoven and Brahms. Viola: All major and minor scales in three octaves; double stops; standard etudes including Kreutzer, Mazas, Bruni; Bach suites; all standard repertoire including Block suites, Brahms, Hindemith and Schubert. Cello: All major and minor scales and arpeggios in three octaves; double stops; standard etudes including Duport, Popper, Piatti. Solo literature will include selections by Bach, Beethoven, Boccherini, Brahms, Dvorak, Faure, Haydn, Saint-Saens, Shostakovich and Vivaldi. String Bass: All major and minor scales and arpeggios; Simandl Reinshagen, Bille, Storch, Hrabe etudes. Includes solo literature of Bottesini, Dittersdorf, Dragonetti, Koussevitzky, Hindemith, Marcello, Vivaldi and standard orchestral literature. Harp: Literature and techniques, with solo and ensemble performances. Etudes by Salzedo, Lariviere and standard concert works comparable to Ravel Introduction and Allegro, Salzedo Preludes, Prescetti Sonata and Pierne Impromptu CapriGuitar: Literature and technique of the guitar including studies by Shearer, Casassi, Guiliani, Torrega and Segovia, and solos by J. S. Bach, Carulli, De Visee, Fernando Sor and Paganini.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Audition or instructor consent.

name: Strings 5
description: APPLIED LESSONS: Strings level 5. Required of BM string majors every semester. Upper division.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Audition and instructor consent, MUSC 34D or equivalent

name: Strings 6
description: APPLIED LESSONS: Strings level 6. Required of BM string majors every semester. Upper division.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Audition and instructor consent, MUSC 134A or equivalent, MUSC 25C or equivalent

name: Strings 7
description: APPLIED LESSONS: Strings level 7. Required of BM string majors every semester. Upper division.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Audition and instructor consent, MUSC 135B or equivalent

name: Strings 8
description: APPLIED LESSONS: Strings level 8. Required of BM string majors every semester. Upper division.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Audition and instructor consent, MUSC 134C or equivalent

name: Woodwinds
description: Required each semester of upper division woodwind majors. Clarinet: Selections comparable to Mozart Clarinet Concerto, Brahms Sonatas and Weber Concertino. Saxophone: Comprehensive pedagogical approach to study of modern Saxophone technique from classical to jazz to avant-garde. Repertory comparable to Dahl Concerto, Woods Sonata, Wirth Indonesian Landscapes, Snyder Variations. Oboe: Selections comparable to Handel Concerto in G Minor. Haydn Oboe Concerto, Hindemith Oboe Sonata, Barret Oboe Studies. Double-reed construction is required. Flute: Selections comparable to Bach Sonata IV, Debussy Syrinx, Mozart concerti and Varese Density. Bassoon: Sonatas comparable to those of Etler, Saint-Saens and Mozart Sonata for Cello and Bassoon; concerti comparable to those of Weber, J. C. Bach, Mozart and Jacob, and representative excerpts from orchestral and chamber repertoire. Double-reed construction is required.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Audition or instructor consent.

name: Woodwinds 5
description: APPLIED LESSONS: Woodwinds level 5. Required of BM woodwind majors every semester. Flute, oboe, saxophone, clarinet or bassoon. Upper division.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Audition and instructor consent, MUSC 35D or equivalent

name: Woodwinds 6
description: APPLIED LESSONS: Woodwinds level 6. Required of BM woodwind majors every semester. Flute, oboe, saxophone, clarinet or bassoon. Upper division.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Audition and instructor consent, MUSC 25C or equivalent, MUSC 135A or equivalent

name: Woodwinds 7
description: APPLIED LESSONS: Woodwinds level 7. Required of BM woodwind majors every semester. Flute, oboe, saxophone, clarinet or bassoon. Upper division.

name: Woodwinds 8
description: APPLIED LESSONS: Woodwinds level 8. Required of BM woodwind majors every semester. Flute, oboe, saxophone, clarinet or bassoon. Upper division.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Audition and instructor consent, MUSC 135C or equivalent

name: Brass
description: Required each semester of upper division brass majors. Trumpet: Selections comparable to Haydn Concerto, Hummel Concerto, Arutunian Concerto, Neruda Concerto and Hindemith Sonata. Trombone: Selections comparable to Concerto in B flat by Albrechtsberger or 15 Rhythmical Etudes by Bitsch. French Horn: Selections comparable to Concerto in E flat by Strauss, Concerti Nos. 2 and 4 by Mozart and Hindemith Sonata. Baritone Horn: Selections comparable to literature listed for trombone. Tuba: Selections comparable to Sonata Capriccioso by Takzcs, Concerto by Vaughn Williams and Suite No. 2 by Wilder.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Audition or instructor consent.

name: Vocal-Instrumental Improvisation
description: Advanced vocal and instrumental private lessons. Development of performing skills in various styles, with emphasis on soloing, reading lead sheets and advanced levels of musicianship and musicality.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Instructor consent.

name: Brass 5
description: APPLIED LESSONS: Brass level 5. Required of BM brass majors every semester. Trumpet, trombone, french horn, euphonium, tuba. Upper division.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Audition and instructor consent, MUSC 36D or equivalent

name: Brass 6
description: APPLIED LESSONS: Brass level 6. Required of BM brass majors every semester. Trumpet, trombone, french horn, euphonium, tuba. Upper division.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Audition and instructor consent, MUSC 25C or equivalent, MUSC 136B or equivalent

description: APPLIED LESSONS: Brass level 7. Required of BM brass majors every semester. Trumpet, trombone, french horn, euphonium, tuba. Upper division.

description: APPLIED LESSONS: Brass level 8. Required of BM brass majors every semester. Trumpet, trombone, french horn, euphonium, tuba. Upper division.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Audition and instructor consent, MUSC 136D or equivalent.

name: Percussion
description: Required each semester of upper division percussion majors. Performance on timpani, keyboard percussion and snare drum as well as the accessory percussion instruments. Timpani etudes: Goodman, Firth, Cirone and the classical timpani repertoire. Keyboard repertoire includes Orchestral Mallet Player by Cirone. Goldenberg etudes, standard orchestral literature plus 4-mallet literature. Snare drum methods of Podemski, Whaley and Cirone and the standard orchestral literature.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Audition or instructor consent.

name: Percussion 5
description: APPLIED LESSONS: Percussion level 5. Required of BM percussion majors every semester. Upper division.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Audition and instructor consent, MUSC 37D or equivalent.

description: APPLIED LESSONS: Percussion level 7. Required of BM percussion majors every semester. Upper division.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Audition and instructor consent, MUSC 137B or equivalent.

name: Percussion 8
description: APPLIED LESSONS: Percussion level 8. Required of BM percussion majors every semester. Upper division.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Audition and instructor consent, MUSC 137C or equivalent

name: Composition
description: Private studio lessons. Advanced applications of the process needed to bring personal musical ideas and concepts to realities, such as compositions or arrangements in concert performance and video productions.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Instructor consent.

name: Composition 5
description: APPLIED LESSONS: Composition level 5. Required of BM composition majors every semester. Upper division.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Audition and instructor consent, MUSC 4A and MUSC 4B, MUSC 38E

name: Radiation Safety
description: Health hazards involved in working with radioactive substances. Physical nature of hazards, biological effects, standards of permissible exposures, safety precautions and protection techniques. Two units meet State of California recommendations.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Lower division calculus, chemistry and physics.
crosslist: Cross-listed with CHEM 121S / PHYS 121S. Chemistry is responsible for scheduling.

name: Introduction to Nuclear Science
description: Properties of the atomic nucleus. Applications of nuclear science in biology, chemistry, engineering, geology and physics.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Lower division calculus, chemistry and physics.
crosslist: Cross-listed with CHEM 126 / PHYS 126. Chemistry is responsible for scheduling.

name: Nuclear Science Lab
description: Basic techniques and procedures used in nuclear science. Nuclear decay, nuclear reactions, radiation detection and measurements, nuclear analytical methods and tracer techniques.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): NUCS 121S, CHEM 100W and CHEM 126 (with grades of “C” or better; “C-” not accepted); or instructor consent.
crosslist: Cross-listed with CHEM 127 / PHYS 127. Chemistry is responsible for scheduling.

name: Research
description: Directed individual laboratory work or field studies in radiological health physics and nuclear science for students with adequate preparation. A maximum of 8 units may be repeated.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Instructor consent.
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 8 units.

name: Master’s Thesis
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): NUCS 298, instructor consent and advancement to candidacy for the master’s degree.

name: Physical Science of Food
description: Introductory course to the physical, chemical and sensory properties of food for students not majoring in the sciences. Basic structure, function and organization of foods, laws of thermodynamics, systems of classification, as well as the interactions of energy and matter.
satisfies: Satisfies B1: Physical Science.

name: Nutrition for the Health Professions
description: Nutrients and their functions; recommended nutrient intakes and evaluation of dietary adequacy; relationship of nutrition to optimum health and dietary changes in disease. For nutritional science, nursing and other health profession majors.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): CHEM 1A or CHEM 30A (with a grade of ‘C’ or better), or instructor consent.

name: Introduction to Human Nutrition
description: Principles and methodology of nutritional science; standards of nutrient intake; physiological functions and chemical classification of nutrients; nutrient needs throughout the lifespan; relationship between diet and disease; scientific, social, and psychological issues.
satisfies: Satisfies E: Human Understanding & Development.
notes: Note(s): Not open to majors.

name: Basic Life Skills
description: Introduction to basic nutrition and culinary concepts for selecting and preparing healthy, budget-friendly foods to establish healthy eating habits for independent living. Emphasis on self-care, wellness, and development of personal resource management skills to foster academic, professional, and personal growth.
satisfies: Satisfies E: Human Understanding & Development.

name: Cost Control in Hospitality
description: Food, beverage and payroll systems, including standards determination; variable, semi-variable and fixed costs; the operating budget; income and cost control and menu pricing. Cost control simulation exercises implemented through software programs.
crosslist: Cross-listed with HSPM 12. Hospitality Management is responsible for scheduling.

name: Science, Physiology, and Nutrition
description: Introduction to life sciences, from chemistry to cellular and physiologic functions, with nutrition as an underlying theme. Interactions with environment, including effect of culture, genetics, and nutrition on susceptibility to disease. Applications of biotechnology in the life sciences.
satisfies: Satisfies B2: Life Science.
sustainability: Sustainability Related - SDG 3: Good Health and Well-Being

name: Sanitation and Environmental Issues in the Hospitality Industry
description: Sanitation in food service, hotel and travel/tourism industries; study of pathogenic organisms and food handling procedures. Occupational health, safety and environmental control in the hospitality industry.
crosslist: Cross-listed with HSPM 20. Nutrition, Food Science and Packaging is responsible for scheduling.
sustainability: Sustainability Related - SDG 8: Decent Work and Economic Growth

name: Culinary Principles and Practice
description: Introduction to principles of food and beverage production and techniques. Emphasis on quality and culinary standards.

name: Catering and Beverage Management
description: Planning and executing catering and buffet functions. Evaluation of alcoholic and non-alcoholic beverages regarding purchasing, storage, preparation, merchandising and regulations.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): NUFS 20 or instructor consent.
crosslist: Cross-listed with HSPM 22. Nutrition, Food Science and Packaging is responsible for scheduling.

name: Internship in Foodservice Management
description: Approved professional broad-based work experience in foodservice management industry for total of 200 hours. Written report due at completion. A maximum of 2 units may be repeated.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): NUFS 20 and instructor consent.
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 2 units.

name: Professionalism in Nutrition, Food Science and Packaging
description: Professional roles, skills and opportunities in the fields of dietetics, foodservice, food science, and packaging.

name: International Program Studies
description: Study Abroad and Away transfer credit course. Study Abroad and Away provides students the opportunity to study abroad on long term programs (Exchange Programs, CSU International Programs, and International Student Exchange Programs) and short-term programs (Faculty-Led Programs and Summer School Abroad Programs) for academic credit, offering Alternative Break Programs for cultural immersion, and designing other globally focused opportunities. This course is designated as a placeholder course for Study Abroad and Away programs.

name: Writing Workshop
description: Development of skills in scientific and technical writing. How to write a critical review of published writing, a business letter, a scholarly paper, and give an oral presentation.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): A3 or equivalent second semester composition course (with a grade of C- or better); completion of core GE; and upper division standing. Allowed Declared Majors: Nursing and pre-Nursing, Occupational Therapy, Public Health, Recreation, Communicative Disorders and Sciences, Nutritional Science, Special Majors, and Individual Studies. Or Graduate or Postbaccalaureate level.
satisfies: Satisfies Writing in the Disciplines (WID).
notes: Note(s): Must be passed with C or better to satisfy the CSU Graduation Writing Assessment Requirement (GWAR).

name: Food Science
description: Experimental study of food and introduction to scientific methods used in food evaluation; functions of ingredients in prepared foods.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): CHEM 30B or CHEM 8. College basic food preparation course or instructor consent.

name: Food Processing and Packaging I
description: Principles and methods of food preservation/processing and packaging operations. Raw materials handling, effect of processing on nutritional value of foods, packaging and food additives. Recommended: College basic food preparation course.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): CHEM 30B or CHEM 8 or instructor consent.
sustainability: Sustainability Related - SDG 12: Responsible Consumption and Production

name: Food Processing Laboratory
description: Laboratory activities associated with the principles and methods of food preservation/processing and packaging operations; raw materials handling, effect of processing on nutritional value of foods, packaging and food additives.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): CHEM 30B or CHEM 8; instructor consent

name: Cultural Aspects of Food
description: Regional, ethnic and religious influences on food culture. Activity with foods of several cultures.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing.

name: Current Issues in Nutrition
description: Controversial topics, including the relation of nutrition to cancer, coronary heart disease, hypertension, diabetes, eating disorders, osteoporosis and athletic performance; recommended nutrient intakes; and other current issues.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): NUFS 8, NUFS 9, NUFS 163 or equivalent introductory course in human nutrition.
sustainability: Sustainability Focused - SDG 3: Good Health and Well-Being

name: Human Nutrition in the Life Span
description: Integrates chemical, biological and social sciences into a comprehensive concept of human nutrition. Emphasis on assessing nutrient status; planning and intervention throughout the life cycle.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): NUFS 8 (with a grade of ‘C’ or better) or passing grade on a challenge exam.
sustainability: Sustainability Related - SDG 3: Good Health and Well-Being

name: Research Methodology in Nutrition and Food Science
description: Introduction to research methodology, interpretation and data analysis with a focus on developing strong information literacy skills, as well as critical thinking, reading, and writing skills in refining scholarly writing in the style of the discipline.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): STAT 95 or PH 67.

name: Nutrition and Metabolism
description: Chemical and physiological studies of carbohydrate, protein, lipid, vitamin and mineral metabolism. Application to the normal nutrition of human beings.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): NUFS 106A, BIOL 66, CHEM 132 (both with a grade of ‘C’ or better); and NUFS 100W / PH 100W.

name: Nutrition Laboratory
description: Chemical and biochemical analysis of nutrients and metabolites in body fluids for the assessment of nutritional status of humans.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): CHEM 132L; STAT 95 or BUS2 90 or PH 167.

name: Advanced Nutrition
description: Advanced studies of vitamins and minerals. Evaluation and interpretation of nutritional research methodology and findings.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): NUFS 106A; CHEM 132 (with grades of ‘C’ or better in each); NUFS 100W / PH 100W; and BIOL 66; BUS2 90, STAT 95 or PH 167.

name: Medical Nutrition Therapy
description: Application of nutritional principles and dietary intake to meet the needs of various pathological conditions.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): NUFS 108A (with grade of ‘C’ or better).

name: Medical Nutrition Therapy
description: Application of nutritional principles and dietary intake to meet the needs of various pathological conditions.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): NUFS 110A and NUFS 109 (with a grade of C or better in each).

name: Foodservice Production Management
description: Principles and procedures for menu planning, production scheduling, volume food production, operation of foodservice equipment, sanitation control and formula costing.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): NUFS 101A or HSPM 11; NUFS 8 or NUFS 9; or instructor consent.
sustainability: Sustainability Related - SDG 12: Responsible Consumption and Production

name: Foodservice Systems: Mgmt & Proc
description: Selection and purchasing in foodservice operations: food and equipment and writing food/equipment specifications. Allocation and management of resources in foodservice systems: materials (food and supplies), facilities (equipment and space), human (management and employee labor), operational (time and money).
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): NUFS 111 or instructor consent.

name: Community Nutrition for Majors
description: Nutrition problems; public policy, advocacy and legislation; government programs; needs assessments; management of community services.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): NUFS 106A, senior standing, and instructor consent.
sustainability: Sustainability Related - SDG 2: Zero Hunger

name: Community Nutrition (non-majors)
description: Key nutrition concepts and terms; age appropriate nutritional interventions; nutrition and public policy, advocacy and legislation; government programs and provision of community nutrition services.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Completion of Core General Education and upper division standing are prerequisites to all SJSU studies courses. Completion of, or co-registration in, 100W is strongly recommended.
satisfies: Satisfies SJSU Studies Area S. Self, Society & Equality in the U.S.
sustainability: Sustainability Related - SDG 2: Zero Hunger

name: Issues in Food Toxicology
description: Introduction to toxicology of foods, and food-borne chemicals and organisms. Scientific basis for determining biological and environmental safety of the food supply from food development, growth and production through harvesting, processing, storage and eventual consumption.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Completion of Core General Education and upper division standing are prerequisites to all SJSU studies courses. Completion of, or co-registration in, 100W is strongly recommended.
satisfies: Satisfies SJSU Studies R: Earth, Environment, and Sustainability.

name: Aging and Nutrition
description: The aging process, physiological changes, dietary requirements, diseases, environmental factors, housing, economic status, handicaps, personal relations and current programs for the aged.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): One college nutrition course or instructor consent.
crosslist: Cross-listed with GERO 116. Nutrition, Food Science and Packaging is responsible for scheduling.
sustainability: Sustainability Focused - SDG 10: Reduced Inequalities

name: Food Evaluation Techniques
description: Food evaluation techniques used to evaluate the appearance, aroma, flavor, texture and acceptability of foods. Relationships between sensory and instrumental measurements of color and texture. Work independently and cooperatively to identify sensory evaluation objectives, write hypotheses, design and conduct experiments, and analyze and interpret data. Intended for majors.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): NUFS 8 and NUFS 101A; CHEM 30A, CHEM 30B, CHEM 1A; or instructor consent.

name: Food Chemistry
description: Important classes of food constituents, their nature, occurrence, chemical and biochemical significance, and the changes they undergo during food preservation and processing.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): NUFS 101A and/or NUFS 103; CHEM 30B or CHEM 8; or Instructor Consent

name: Chemical Analysis of Food
description: Techniques in chemical analysis of nutrients and other components of food. Planning, conducting and evaluating a scientific experiment and presenting the data in technical written form.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): NUFS 103 or NUFS 101A, NUFS 100W / PH 100W, STAT 95 or PH 67.

name: Nutrition for Sport
description: Planning optimum diets for performance and health; metabolism and energy systems; roles of nutrients in physical performance; efficacy of ergogenic nutrition aids.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): NUFS 8 or NUFS 9.

name: Disordered Eating and Nutrition Therapy
description: Metabolic, physiological, and psychological determinants and effects of disordered dietary behaviors. Disorders in regulation of food intake, case studies, and different intervention approaches explored. Screening and treatment of disordered eating in athletes emphasized. Opportunities provided to develop counseling strategies.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): NUFS 8.

name: Child Nutrition Program Administration
description: Study of the components of model child nutrition programs through application of current child health and nutrition principles, education practices, marketing procedures, communication strategies, computer-based nutrient and business analysis and operations management skills.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing.
notes: Note(s): Offered Summer only.

name: Complementary and Alternative Health Practices
description: Philosophical, historical, clinical, and scholarly aspects of complementary and alternative medicine and associated health practices used in the US, with emphasis on scientific clinical investigation and evidence based efficacy.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing.

name: Health Issues in a Multicultural Society
description: A multidisciplinary interpretation and evaluation of consumer health issues. Impact of cultural variables (including communication methods, socioeconomic status, and traditional beliefs) on health and illness. Interaction of individuals in families and other groups.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Completion of Core General Education and upper division standing are prerequisites to all SJSU studies courses. Completion of, or co-registration in, 100W is strongly recommended.
satisfies: Satisfies SJSU Studies Area S: Self, Society & Equality in U.S.
crosslist: Cross-listed with PH 135. Public Health is responsible for scheduling.
sustainability: Sustainability Focused - SDG 3: Good Health and Well-Being

name: Hunger and Environmental Nutrition
description: Physiology of hunger/malnutrition on human development and health; political, social, cultural and gender factors that contribute to world hunger; scientific/technological foundation to population research and food production and their effect on the environment.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Completion of Core General Education and upper division standing are prerequisites to all SJSU studies courses. Completion of, or co-registration in, 100W is strongly recommended.
satisfies: Satisfies SJSU Studies R: Earth, Environment, and Sustainability.

name: Hunger and Environmental Nutrition
description: The physiology of hunger/malnutrition on human development and health; political, social, cultural, and gender factors that contribute to world hunger; scientific/technological foundations of population research and food production and their effect on the environment.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Passage of the Writing Skills Test (WST) or ENGL 100A/LLD 100A with a C or better (C- not accepted), completion of Core General Education and upper division standing are prerequisites to all SJSU studies courses. Completion of, or co-registration in, 100W is strongly recommended.
satisfies: Satisfies SJSU Studies R: Earth & Environment
sustainability: Sustainability Focused - SDG 3: Good Health and Well-Being
notes: Note(s): All of SJSU Studies courses require completion of the WST and upper division standing.

name: Food Culture: Consuming Passions
description: Cultural aspects of food as related to regional, ethnic and religious influences. Issue based examination of effects of food behavior on culture, society, health, and economics.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Completion of Core General Education and upper division standing are prerequisites to all SJSU studies courses. Completion of, or co-registration in, 100W is strongly recommended.
satisfies: Satisfies SJSU Studies V: Cultures and Global Understanding.

name: Food Culture: Consuming Passions: International Experience
description: Cultural aspects of food as related to regional, ethnic, and religious influences abroad. Issue-based examination of the effects of food behavior on culture, society, health, and economics abroad. Involves an international, study abroad experience.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Completion of Core General Education and upper division standing are prerequisites to all SJSU studies courses. Completion of, or co-registration in, 100W is strongly recommended.
satisfies: Satisfies SJSU Studies V: Culture, Civil & Global Understanding
sustainability: Sustainability Related - SDG 2: Zero Hunger

name: Food and Nutritional Toxicology
description: Major classes of food toxicants, their importance, properties, detection, metabolism, control and regulation; and basic issues in food/diet safety and toxicology.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): NUFS 103, CHEM 30B or CHEM 8; introductory courses in nutrition and biology and instructor consent.
sustainability: Sustainability Related - SDG 3: Good Health and Well-Being

name: Food Microbiology
description: Role of microorganisms in foodborne illness, food quality, spoilage, and preservation. Control of microorganisms in foods. Methods to enumerate, identify, and characterize microorganisms in foods.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): MICR 101

name: Physical Fitness and Nutrition
description: Use of scientific principles, scientific investigation, and current technological advances to assess the relationship between diet, physical fitness, and disease. Examine scientific literature to evaluate the effects of nutritional intervention on exercise performance.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Completion of Core General Education and upper division standing are prerequisites to all SJSU studies courses. Completion of, or co-registration in, 100W is strongly recommended.
satisfies: Satisfies SJSU Studies R: Earth, Environment, and Sustainability.
crosslist: Cross-listed with KIN 163. Nutrition, Food Science and Packaging is responsible for scheduling.

name: Individual Studies
description: Individual work for majors or minors on special topics by arrangement.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): NUFS 8; instructor and department chair consent during semester prior to enrollment.

name: Nutrition Education and Counseling
description: Education principles and behavior change theories; counseling and communication techniques for nutritionists and dietitians working with individuals and groups.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): NUFS 106A or Instructor Consent
sustainability: Sustainability Related - SDG 3: Good Health and Well-Being

name: Field Experience in Nutrition and Food Science and Packaging Technology
description: Practical application of academic principles in nutrition, food science, packaging, dietetics food management, nutrition education, and/or sports nutrition. Repeatable for a maximum of 6 units.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Senior standing in NUFS; instructor consent by end of prior semester.
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 6 units.

name: International Program Studies
description: Study Abroad and Away transfer credit course. Study Abroad and Away provides students the opportunity to study abroad on long term programs (Exchange Programs, CSU International Programs, and International Student Exchange Programs) and short-term programs (Faculty-Led Programs and Summer School Abroad Programs) for academic credit, offering Alternative Break Programs for cultural immersion, and designing other globally focused opportunities. This course is designated as a placeholder course for Study Abroad and Away programs.

name: Entrepreneurial Nutrition
description: Introduction to entrepreneurial nutrition including professional roles, skills and opportunities.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): ENGL 1A or instructor consent.

name: Colloquium in Nutrition, Food Science and Packaging
description: Presentation and discussion of original research or specialized studies in Nutrition, Food Science and Packaging by graduate students, faculty & guest speakers.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Instructor consent.

name: Issues in Nutrition, Food and Packaging
description: Discussion and critical evaluation of advanced topics in nutritional science, food science and technology, foodservice management, and packaging.
satisfies: Satisfies GWAR: Graduation Writing Assessment Requirement.
notes: Note(s): This course satisfies graduate-level GWAR in this master’s program.

name: Advanced Nutrition and Metabolism
description: Advanced seminar course in human nutrition and metabolism that covers sources and interactions among dietary constituents, digestion and absorption, transport, processing storage, and catabolism and excretion as well as the regulation of metabolic homeostasis in normal healthy individuals.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): NUFS 108A & NUFS 109 or equivalent advance courses in Human nutrition and Metabolism, CHEM 132 or equivalent, BIOL 66 or equivalent, advanced course in statistics or biostatistics, or Consent of Instructor.
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 6 units.

name: Seminar in Advanced Topics in Human Nutrition & Dietetics
description: Advanced seminar on selected topics in human nutrition and dietetics such as: sources and interactions among dietary constituents, nutrition and disease, community nutrition, nutrition education, hunger and environmental nutrition, sustainability, nutrition and culture, and issues of social justice.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Instructor Consent
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 9 units.

name: Advanced Medical Nutrition Therapy
description: Assessment and evaluation of nutritional status; diet planning in health and disease; counseling techniques; and medical documentation.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): NUFS 110A and NUFS 110B (each with a grade of “C” or better).

name: Advanced Foodservice/Restaurant Management
description: Quantitative and qualitative analyses of foodservice/restaurant operations as bases for managerial decision-making.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): NUFS 113.

name: Nutrition and Dietetics Leadership
description: Leadership as dietitian and nutrition-related manager in a variety of settings. Quantitative and qualitative analyses of leadership strategies including communication, emotional intelligence and quality improvement.

name: Biostatistics in Research
description: Concepts in biostatistics including best practices and skills for managing, analyzing, and interpreting research data within the health profession fields.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): An undergraduate statistics course.

name: Multidisciplinary Health Promotion in Later Life
description: Multidisciplinary assessment and planning. Principles of promoting health and preventing disability in later life. Physical, psychological, social, cultural, spiritual, and environmental factors that affect length and quality of life.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): BIOL 66 or GERO 108 or instructor consent.
crosslist: Cross-listed with GERO 260 / HPRF 260. Nutrition, Food Science and Packaging is responsible for scheduling.
sustainability: Sustainability Related - SDG 3: Good Health and Well-Being

name: Dietetic Internship
description: Supervised professional field experience to fulfill ADA eligibility requirements for registered dietitian examination.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): DPD or instructor consent.
notes: Note(s): Course can be taken for 1, 3, 6, 9 or 12 units.

name: Research Methodology
description: Introduction to scientific methodology, and research design; including refining scholarly search strategies to build a strong scientific base for research, development of research design, data collection, analysis, interpretation and application of research in nutrition, food science and packaging.

name: Special Studies in Nutrition, Food Science and Packaging
description: Advanced individual research and projects.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Consent of graduate advisor.

name: Master’s Thesis
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Advancement to candidacy for the master’s degree.

name: Culminating Experience Supervision
description: This course satisfies the requirement that all graduate students must remain enrolled during semesters in which they are working solely on their theses or projects, for which they have previously received but not cleared an RP grade.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Existing RP grade in a graduate-level thesis or project course
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 16 units.
notes: Note(s): No Degree Credit.

name: Leadership I
description: An overview of professional nursing role and scope of practice. Includes: nursing core values, professional role, nursing process, systems theory, code of ethics, Nurse Practice Act, conflict resolution, communication, the transformative process from novice to expert, and self-care strategies.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Admission to Nursing program.
notes: Note(s): Nursing BS Semester 1.

name: Introduction to Pharmacology
description: An introduction to major medication classifications. Emphasizes the nurse’s role in medication administration including assessments, interventions, and expected outcomes of commonly used medications.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Admission to Nursing program.
notes: Note(s): Nursing BS Semester 1.

name: Health Assessment & Skills I
description: Foundational nursing skills including health assessment, nursing process, communication, psychomotor skills and critical thinking in the context of diverse client populations. Person-centered care and safety are emphasized through the use of simulation.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Admission to Nursing program.
notes: Note(s): Nursing BS Semester 1.

name: Gerontological Nursing Theory
description: Introduction to gerontological nursing, including developmental stages and transitions of aging, expected age-related physiological and psychological changes and assessment findings, promotion of health for the older adult client, resources available to seniors, and end of life issues.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Admission to Nursing program.
notes: Note(s): Nursing BS Semester 1.

name: Geriatric Nursing Practicum
description: Provide supervised nursing care to geriatric clients in a variety of healthcare settings. Focus on applying professional fundamental nursing skills including therapeutic communications, nursing assessment and health promotion.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Admission to Nursing program.
notes: Note(s): Nursing BS Semester 2.

name: Adult Care Management I
description: Concepts related to care of the adult with selected medical-surgical conditions. Emphasis is on the nursing process and developing competence in providing and coordinating nursing care.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): NURS 10, NURS 11, NURS 12, NURS 13A, NURS 13B, and NURS 100WE.
notes: Note(s): Nursing BS Semester 2.

name: Adult Care Clinical Practicum I
description: Provides supervised nursing care to hospitalized adults and their families. Emphasizes systematic assessment, nursing process, and clinical reasoning. Builds competency in selected nursing therapies, and in developing the role of the professional nurse.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): NURS 10, NURS 11, NURS 12, NURS 13A, NURS 13B, and NURS 100WE.
notes: Note(s): Nursing BS Semester 2.

name: Health Assessment & Skills in Nursing II
description: Integration of clinical reasoning and client context in performing complex nursing therapies and complex psychomotor skills. Person-centered care and patient safety are emphasized through the use of simulation.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): NURS 10, NURS 11, NURS 12, NURS 13A, NURS 13B, and NURS 100WE.
notes: Note(s): Nursing BS Semester 2.

name: Health Assessment & Skills III
description: Focuses on the childrearing and childbearing population with integration of clinical reasoning (nursing process) during health assessments and psychomotor skills to provide safe client care in a variety of settings.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): NURS 20A, NURS 20B, NURS 22, NURS 123A, and NURS 123B.
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 2 units.
notes: Note(s): Nursing BS Semester 3.

name: Evidence Based Practice Writing Workshop
description: Examines the systematic inquiry of basic research concepts and processes. Evidence-based practice (EBP) results from the appraisal of the best scientific evidence available to guide clinical decision-making and thus to achieve quality patient outcomes.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Admission to Nursing program. GE A3 or equivalent second semester composition course (with a grade of C- or better); completion of core GE; and upper division standing.
satisfies: Satisfies Writing in the Disciplines (WID).
notes: Note(s): Nursing BS Semester 1. Must be passed with C or better to satisfy the CSU Graduation Writing Assessment Requirement (GWAR).

name: Global Influences on Health
description: Examination of major issues influencing health and human services and their delivery on a global scale. The health care needs of a diverse and multicultural population, health care disparities, and strategies to address global health needs are explored. Includes special populations service provision, advocacy, patient/client centered care, psycho-social aspects of disease and wellness, health promotion and education, quality, cost controls, and multidisciplinary team approaches to service delivery.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Passage of the Writing Skills Test (WST) or ENGL 100A / LLD 100A with a C or better (C- not accepted), completion of Core General Education and upper division standing are prerequisites to all SJSU studies courses. Completion of, or co-registration in, 100W is strongly recommended.
satisfies: Satisfies SJSU Studies V: Cultures and Global Understanding.
notes: Note(s): All of SJSU Studies courses require completion of the WST and upper division standing.

name: Professional Practice Success I
description: First course in a two course sequence focusing on the application of nursing concepts that are essential to successful professional nursing practice: improving clinical reasoning, linking theory to practice, and implementing a plan of self-care for maintaining longevity in the profession.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the RN to BSN Nursing Program.
notes: Note(s): RN to BSN Nursing Semester 1.

name: Professional Practice Success II
description: Second course in a two course sequence focusing on the application of nursing concepts essential to successful professional nursing practice: improving clinical reasoning, developing a systems viewpoint, and implementing change in the current healthcare setting.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): NURS 100WE, NURS 112, and NURS 171.
notes: Note(s): Nursing Semester 2.

name: Mental Health Theory
description: Psychiatric-mental health theoretical nursing concepts for culturally diverse clients. Emphasis on therapeutic communication, health promotion and prevention, advocacy and ethical issues for individuals and families with complex health problems.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): NURS 10, NURS 11, NURS 12, NURS 13A, NURS 13B, and NURS 100WE.
notes: Note(s): Nursing BS Semester 2.

name: Mental Health Practicum
description: Provides supervised nursing care to diverse individuals with mental health conditions in a variety of settings. Emphasis on therapeutic communications and symptom management, screening interventions, health promotion, and interdisciplinary care coordination.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): NURS 10, NURS 11, NURS 12, NURS 13A, NURS 13B, and NURS 100WE.
notes: Note(s): RN to BSN Nursing Semester 2.

name: Professional Role Development III
description: Expansion of the professional role in the childbearing-childrearing setting to include further application of: evidence-based practice, therapeutic communication, developmentally appropriate teaching/learning strategies, informatics, health literacy, developmental and cultural assessment, leadership and ethical principles, grief and loss.

name: Senior Practicum - International Experience
description: Use a systems approach to research, leadership management, theory and beginning clinical proficiency, in collaboration with other health care members in an international setting.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Final semester of Nursing, BS or Nursing, RN to BSN Concentration, BSN.

name: Leadership II
description: Safe practice of professional nursing, including interdisciplinary communication, bioethical and legal concerns, cost of care, end-of-life care, and health literacy and disparities for culturally diverse clients.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): NURS 20A, NURS 20B, NURS 22, NURS 123A, and NURS 123B.
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 4 units.
notes: Note(s): Nursing BS Semester 3.

name: Community Health Theory for Nursing BS Program
description: Community health concepts and the care of the population, families, and individuals with complex health problems using health promotion and wellness strategies across the life span. Emphasis on core public health competencies and the influence of health policy on the populations’ health.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): NURS 20A, NURS 20B, NURS 22, NURS 123A and NURS 123B.
satisfies: Satisfies SJSU Studies R: Earth, Environment, and Sustainability.
notes: Note(s): Nursing BS Semester 3.

name: Community Health Practicum
description: Provides supervised nursing care to culturally diverse child-rearing families and children using concepts of systems theory in acute care, home and community settings.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): NURS 20A, NURS 20B, NURS 22, NURS 123A, and NURS 123B.
notes: Note(s): Nursing BS Semester 3.

name: Child Health Theory
description: Direct health care of children and the childrearing family in various health care settings. Exploration of bio-psychosocial processes involved in health, life transitions, and illness with identification of related preventive and therapeutic nursing behaviors.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): NURS 20A, NURS 20B, NURS 22, NURS 123A, and NURS 123B.
notes: Note(s): Nursing BS Semester 3.

name: Child Health Practicum
description: Provides supervised nursing care to culturally diverse child-rearing families and children using concepts of systems theory in acute care, home and community settings.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): NURS 20A, NURS 20B, NURS 22, NURS 123A, and NURS 123B.
notes: Note(s): Nursing BS Semester 4.

name: Simulation I
description: Provides objective-driven learning activities using a variety of simulation modalities. Faculty-guided simulations provide opportunities for developing problem identification and clinical reasoning skills across the lifespan. Reflective thinking is incorporated into all simulated experiences.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): NURS 32, NURS 161, NURS 164B, NURS 165A, and NURS 165B.
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 2 units.
notes: Note(s): Nursing BS Semester 4.

name: Adult Care Management II
description: Concepts and care related to adult medical-surgical clients in the acute care setting. Systems approach integrates human responses to alterations in physiological functioning related to disorders of the musculoskeletal, neurological, gastrointestinal, integumentary, endocrine systems and oncologic disorders.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): NURS 32, NURS 161, NURS 164B, NURS 165A, and NURS 165B.
notes: Note(s): Nursing BS Semester 4.

name: Adult Care Clinical Practicum II
description: Provides an advanced level of supervised nursing care to hospitalized adults and their families. Emphasizes systematic assessment, nursing process, and clinical reasoning. Promotes development of competency in professional registered nurse role and application of clinical judgment.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): NURS 32, NURS 161, NURS 164A, NURS 164B, NURS 165A, and NURS 165B.
notes: Note(s): Nursing BS Semester 4.

name: Maternal Newborn Theory
description: Direct health care of newborns and the childbearing family in various health care settings. Exploration of bio-psychosocial processes involved in health, life transitions, and illness with identification of related preventive and therapeutic nursing behaviors.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): NURS 32, NURS 161, NURS 164B, NURS 165A, and NURS 165B.
notes: Note(s): Nursing BS Semester 4.

name: Maternal Newborn Practicum
description: Practicum provides family-centered care to culturally diverse childbearing families using concepts of systems theory in acute care, home and community settings.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): NURS 32, NURS 161, NURS 164B, NURS 165A, and NURS 165B.
notes: Note(s): RN to BSN Nursing Semester 1.

name: Theoretical Foundations
description: Theoretical bases for health and illness management of culturally diverse individuals, families, and groups. Concepts include nursing and change theories, quality measurement, patient safety, clinical reasoning and judgment, health promotion, and health literacy.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the RN to BSN Nursing Program.
notes: Note(s): RN to BSN Nursing Semester 2.

name: Community Health Theory for RN to BSN Program
description: Community health concepts and the care of the population, families, and individuals with complex health problems using health promotion and wellness strategies across the life span. Emphasis on core public health competencies and the influence of health policy on the populations’ health.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): NURS 100WE, NURS 112, and NURS 171.
satisfies: Satisfies SJSU Studies R: Earth, Environment, and Sustainability.
notes: Note(s): RN to BSN Nursing Semester 2.

name: Community Health Practicum
description: Utilizes a systems approach to promoting health and wellness for individuals and groups across the lifespan. Applies nursing process to care of clients from diverse populations in the community in a variety of settings.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): NURS 100WE, NURS 112, and NURS 171.
notes: Note(s): Nursing Semester 5.

name: Senior Preceptorship
description: Independent, precepted experience in a clinical setting. Uses a systems approach integrating knowledge of research, leadership, pathophysiology, and nursing into practice.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): NURS 166, NURS 167A, NURS 167B, NURS 168A, and NURS 168B.
notes: Note(s): Nursing BS Semester 5.

name: Senior Preceptorship
description: Independent, precepted experience in a clinical setting. Uses a systems approach integrating knowledge of research, leadership, pathophysiology, and nursing into practice.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): NURS 113, and NURS 173.
notes: Note(s): RN to BSN Nursing Semester 5.

name: Leadership III
description: Demonstration of the professional nurse role. Includes integration of theoretical concepts in the practice setting. Encompasses models and theories of nursing management and leadership, teamwork, communication, cultural competence, economics, health disparities, quality improvement, ethics, patient safety, career development.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): NURS 166, NURS 167A, NURS 167B, NURS 168A, and NURS 168B.
satisfies: Satisfies SJSU Studies S: Self, Society & Equality in U.S.
notes: Note(s): Nursing BS Semester 5.

name: Leadership
description: Demonstration of the professional nurse role. Includes integration of theoretical concepts in the practice setting. Encompasses models and theories of nursing management and leadership, teamwork, communication, cultural competence, economics, health disparities, quality improvement, ethics, patient safety, career development.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): NURS 113, and NURS 173.
satisfies: Satisfies SJSU Studies S: Self, Society & Equality in U.S.
notes: Note(s): BSN Nursing.

name: Individual Studies
description: Individual study or project work on a selected problem or professional issue in nursing.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Arrangement must be made with a nursing faculty member and approved by the school director during the semester prior to taking the course.
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 12 units.

name: International Program Studies
description: Study Abroad and Away transfer credit course. Study Abroad and Away provides students the opportunity to study abroad on long term programs (Exchange Programs, CSU International Programs, and International Student Exchange Programs) and short-term programs (Faculty-Led Programs and Summer School Abroad Programs) for academic credit, offering Alternative Break Programs for cultural immersion, and designing other globally focused opportunities. This course is designated as a placeholder course for Study Abroad and Away programs.

name: Population Based Health Care Systems
description: Planning, policy, organization, and financing of health care systems. Prepares nurses to participate in design, implementation, and evaluation of ethical, cost-effective, quality health care in health care systems to improve health care delivery and client outcomes.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Admission to nursing masters program
sustainability: Sustainability Related - SDG 3: Good Health and Well-Being

name: Clinical Leadership Role Development
description: The purpose of this course is to prepare students for leadership roles in healthcare through the study, analysis, and application of nursing leadership and management theories and principles.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Acceptance into nursing masters program

name: Theoretical Foundations
description: Addresses the theoretical underpinnings of nursing practice and research, including a wide range of theories from nursing and other disciplines. Students develop and apply relevant criteria in evaluating theories for practice and research with individuals, families and communities.

name: Foot and Nail Care
description: A theory-based didactic course incorporating both simulation and skills for the learning of selected disorders of the foot and nail and practice of advanced specialized psychomotor and cognitive skills used to assess and manage the conditions of lower extremity, foot, and nail.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): RN with a minimum of a Baccalaureate degree and at least one year of clinical nursing experience post RN licensure.
notes: Note(s): The course consists of 60 hours of didactic learning and 40 hours of practicum. Duration of the didactic portion is five weeks but practicum can be completed within six months upon completion of the didactic portion.  Students are required to achieve a final score of at least 80% on the didactic portion and a passing credit in practicum.  Upon completion of all the requirements, students will be eligible to take the ostomy specialty exam offered by the Wound, Ostomy and Continence Nursing Certification Board (WOCNCB).

name: Ostomy Care
description: A theory-based course incorporating both simulation and skills for the learning of selected disorders of the gastrointestinal and genitourinary systems and practice of specialized psychomotor and cognitive skills used to assess and manage fecal and urinary diversions, continent diversions, fistulas, and percutaneous tubes.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): RN with a minimum of a Baccalaureate degree and at least one year of clinical nursing experience post RN licensure.
notes: Note(s): The course consists of 60 hours of didactic learning and 40 hours of practicum. Duration of the didactic portion is five weeks but practicum can be completed within six months upon completion of the didactic portion.  Students are required to achieve a final score of at least 80% on the didactic portion and a passing credit in practicum.  Upon completion of all the requirements, students will be eligible to take the ostomy specialty exam offered by the Wound, Ostomy and Continence Nursing Certification Board (WOCNCB).

name: Wound Care
description: A theory-based continuing education course incorporating simulation, psychomotor skills, and clinical practice. Students develop the knowledge and skills to assess selected disorders of the integumentary and arterial-venous systems and manage wounds, fistulas, percutaneous tubes, and pressure ulcers.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): RN with a minimum of a Baccalaureate degree and at least one year of clinical nursing experience post RN licensure.
notes: Note(s): The course consists of 60 hours of didactic learning and 40 hours of practicum. Duration of the didactic portion is five weeks but practicum can be completed within six months upon completion of the didactic portion.  Students are required to achieve a final score of at least 80% on the didactic portion and a passing credit in practicum.  Upon completion of all the requirements, students will be eligible to take the wound specialty exam offered by the Wound, Ostomy and Continence Nursing Certification Board (WOCNCB).

name: Curriculum Development in Nursing
description: Curriculum development with application to programs in nursing and health education. Focuses on formulation of conceptual framework for curriculum development and utilization in making decisions regarding the objectives, learning experiences, and evaluation strategies.

name: Nurse Educator Theory and Direct Care Practicum I
