description: Issues surrounding innovation: what exactly innovation is; whether it is created or discovered; why the law should protect it; whether innovators have special natural claims over their innovations; and whether the law ought to aim at a set of rules regarding innovation that maximizes societal well-being.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing or instructor consent.

name: Metaphysics & Epistemology
description: Such topics as nature of knowledge, skepticism, nature of reality, space, time, substance and causality. Course is repeatable once for credit in different area.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): 3 units of philosophy or upper division standing.
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 6 units.

name: Philosophy of Law
description: Theories of the nature of law, legal reasoning, and morality. Philosophical issues in criminal, civil, and constitutional law.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): 3 units of philosophy or upper division standing.

name: Intermediate Logic & Language Analysis
description: Predicate logic, methods of proof and some meta theory. Additional systems of logic may be considered.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): PHIL 9 or instructor consent.

name: Philosophy of Language
description: Philosophical investigations into language in view of its relation to reality, thought, and logic.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): 3 units of philosophy or upper division standing.

name: Philosophy of Mind
description: Problems in connection with emotion, intention, human action and personal identity.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): 3 units of philosophy or upper division standing.

name: Philosophy of Science
description: Scientific methodology, explanation and verification; science and society. Varying topics from physical, biological and social sciences.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Completion of Core General Education and upper division standing are prerequisites to all SJSU studies courses. Completion of, or co-registration in, 100W is strongly recommended.
satisfies: Satisfies SJSU Studies R: Earth, Environment, and Sustainability.

name: Individual Studies
description: By arrangement. Course is repeatable for a total of 4 units.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Department chair consent.
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 3 units.

name: Directed Reading
description: Course is repeatable for a total of 4 units.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Qualified upper division student.
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 3 units.

name: Professional and Business Ethics
description: Interdisciplinary study of types of ethical problems which arise within the contexts of business occupations and professions. Major ethical theories, critique of economic and criminal justice. Focus is on issues of justice and equality in the U.S. Case studies.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Completion of Core General Education and upper division standing are prerequisites to all SJSU studies courses. Completion of, or co-registration in, 100W is strongly recommended.
satisfies: Satisfies SJSU Studies S: Self, Society & Equality in U.S.
crosslist: Cross-listed with BUS3 186. Philosophy is responsible for scheduling.
sustainability: Sustainability Focused - SDG 16: Peace, Justice and Strong Institutions

name: Seminar in Philosophical Classics
description: Works of a major philosopher or philosophical tradition. Course is repeatable for up to 12 units of credit when a seminar topic is different.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): PHIL 70A and PHIL 70B and 6 units of upper division philosophy or instructor consent.
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 12 units.

name: International Program Studies
description: Study Abroad and Away transfer credit course. Study Abroad and Away provides students the opportunity to study abroad on long term programs (Exchange Programs, CSU International Programs, and International Student Exchange Programs) and short-term programs (Faculty-Led Programs and Summer School Abroad Programs) for academic credit, offering Alternative Break Programs for cultural immersion, and designing other globally focused opportunities. This course is designated as a placeholder course for Study Abroad and Away programs.

name: Seminar in Philosophy of Law
description: Critical examination of topics in legal philosophy.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): 3 units of Philosophy and upper division standing.

name: Graduate Proseminar
description: Prepares graduate students for graduate work, teaching, professionalism, and future steps’ particularly applying to PhD programs or teaching jobs. Topics include: reading philosophy, the writing process, teaching pedagogy, course design, presenting in professional settings, and writing a successful application. Open to advanced undergraduate students who are considering pursuing graduate work in philosophy.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Graduate student or upper division Philosophy major standing.

name: Advanced Seminar in a Selected Philosopher or Tradition
description: An exhaustive and detailed study of the entire, or most significant, writings of some outstanding philosopher or philosophical tradition.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Nine units of philosophy including PHIL 70A and PHIL 70B or instructor consent.
satisfies: Satisfies GWAR: Graduation Writing Assessment Requirement.
notes: Note(s): This course satisfies graduate-level GWAR in this master’s program.

name: Advanced Seminar in Epistemology and Metaphysics
description: Classical or contemporary problems in knowledge and reality.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): At least one upper division course in epistemology or metaphysics, or instructor consent.
satisfies: Satisfies GWAR: Graduation Writing Assessment Requirement.
notes: Note(s): This course satisfies graduate-level GWAR in this master’s program.

name: Advanced Seminar in Ethics or Aesthetics
description: Classic or contemporary problems in some value area such as that of moral or aesthetic value. Course is repeatable for up to 12 units of credit when seminar topic is different.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): At least one upper division course in ethics or value theory, or instructor consent.
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 12 units.

name: Advanced Seminar in Logical Theory
description: Concepts of logic, such as truth and inference, considered on an advanced level. Course is repeatable for credit when seminar topic is different.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): PHIL 9, PHIL 157 or instructor consent.

name: Special Studies
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Advisor consent.

name: Master’s Thesis
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Advisor consent.

name: Beginning Photography
description: A Beginning photography course which introduces basic aesthetic issues in (primarily black and white) image making. Introduces photographic technique utilizing digital cameras, electronic image processing and digital printing. Requires a DSLR (digital single lens reflex) type camera. Requires Adobe Lightroom.

name: International Program Studies
description: Study Abroad and Away transfer credit course. Study Abroad and Away provides students the opportunity to study abroad on long term programs (Exchange Programs, CSU International Programs, and International Student Exchange Programs) and short-term programs (Faculty-Led Programs and Summer School Abroad Programs) for academic credit, offering Alternative Break Programs for cultural immersion, and designing other globally focused opportunities. This course is designated as a placeholder course for Study Abroad and Away programs.

name: Black and White Photography
description: A traditional darkroom photography class which introduces black and white film developing, fiber based printing, and image manipulation and presentation techniques. Taught with traditional film and photo paper; requires a film camera, limited number of which department can loan students.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): PHOT 40.

name: Color Photography
description: An intermediate course introducing principles of color photography, color theory, a refined use of the camera and digital printing techniques. Requires a DSLR (digital single lens reflex) type camera. Requires Adobe Lightroom and Adobe Photoshop.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): PHOT 40.

name: Alternative Photo Media
description: Explores historical, handmade photographic printing processes which open avenues of expression unavailable through contemporary photographic processes. Cyanotype, Van Dyke, and gum bichromate techniques are covered, as well as creating traditional and digital negatives for contact printing.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): PHOT 40

name: Advanced Black and White Photography
description: An advanced exploration of traditional silver based film and darkroom printing, the use of view cameras, and the Zone System. Provides students with the opportunity to explore qualities of expression unique to the gelatin silver process.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): PHOT 40 and PHOT 110 or instructor consent.

name: Intermediate Digital Imaging
description: An intermediate level course investigating the unique possibilities afforded by contemporary digital imaging. Includes preparation of images for presentation via print, video and/or web. Emphasis upon incorporating digital tools with ongoing development of student work.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): PHOT 40.

name: Contemporary Issues in Photography
description: Examination and discussion of aesthetic trends and philosophies in photography and related media, their impact on the medium and society.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): PHOT 40

name: Image and Idea
description: An intermediate course in which students pursue individual projects. Emphasis on diverse strategies of approach and presentation which culminate in a group exhibition.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): PHOT 40 and PHOT 110 or PHOT 112 or PHOT 115.

name: Introduction to Studio Lighting
description: Concepts and principles of lighting using both daylight and incandescent light sources and the use of standard studio lighting equipment.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): PHOT 40.

name: Advanced Lighting: Working with Strobes
description: An advanced lighting course incorporating strobes and professional photographic tools and techniques in the studio and on location that can be applied to commercial advertising photography or fine art imagery. Training on professional-level equipment and software is emphasized.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): PHOT 121

name: Photography as Illustration
description: Technical and conceptual aspects of producing effective photographic illustrations for fine art and commercial purposes (fine art exhibitions, advertisements, posters, magazines, story illustrations, etc.). Can include studio work, location photography, darkroom work and digital manipulation.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): PHOT 40.
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 6 units.

name: Special Topics in Photography
description: Photography is a rapidly evolving field of study. In order to keep our curriculum current and add diversity to our staple of course offerings, our Photo 125, “Special Topics in Photography” offers a rotating variety of contemporary topics. Can be repeated for up to 15 units of credit when course topic changes.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): PHOT 112, PHOT 113, PHOT 115, or instructor consent.
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 15 units.

name: History of Photography
description: Technical developments and aesthetic trends in photography traced from its invention in the nineteenth century to the present day. Slide presentations, discussions, field trips.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): ARTH 70B or instructor consent.
crosslist: Cross-listed with ARTH 126. Art and Art History is responsible for scheduling.

name: Professional Practices in Photography
description: Designed to prepare graduating photo majors for practicing their profession. Emphasis will be placed on building a comprehensive portfolio and business identity. Course is repeatable once for credit.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): PHOT 120, PHOT 121, plus two additional upper division photography courses.
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 6 units.

name: Individual Studies
description: Individual work under guidance in field of special interest.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): PHOT 110.

name: International Program Studies
description: Study Abroad and Away transfer credit course. Study Abroad and Away provides students the opportunity to study abroad on long term programs (Exchange Programs, CSU International Programs, and International Student Exchange Programs) and short-term programs (Faculty-Led Programs and Summer School Abroad Programs) for academic credit, offering Alternative Break Programs for cultural immersion, and designing other globally focused opportunities. This course is designated as a placeholder course for Study Abroad and Away programs.

name: Senior Project Photography
description: Advanced course focused on creation or further development of photo-based project to be determined by the student and consisting of new work. Course emphasizes developing professional exit skills, a final body of finished work, and a professional portfolio.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): 15 units of upper division courses in PHOT.

name: Elementary Physics
description: Mechanics, energy, electricity, magnetism, optics, atomic and nuclear physics, properties of matter; emphasizes practical applications of physics principles to contemporary problems.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): The following Declared Majors are not allowed to enroll in this course:Engineering, Chemistry, Geology, Meteorology, Physics, Earth Science.
satisfies: Satisfies B1: Physical Science.

name: Fundamentals of Physics
description: First semester of a two-semester sequence that is non-calculus based and covers the topics of mechanics, heat, and sound.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Algebra. Department permission needed if this course is not required for student’s major.
satisfies: Satisfies B1: Physical Science + B3: Laboratory.
notes: Note(s): Year course. Declared Physics majors not allowed.

name: Fundamentals of Physics
description: Electricity and magnetism, optics and atomic structure.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): PHYS 2A (with grade of “C-” or better).
satisfies: Satisfies B1 + B3: Physical + Lab Science.
notes: Note(s): Declared Physics majors not allowed.

name: Invitation to Physics and Astronomy
description: Introduction to the physics department, its faculty, and basic skills necessary for success as a physics major. Topics include relativity and quantum theory for beginners, careers in physics and astronomy, career pathways of BA/BS physics recipients, the role of research in undergraduate STEM education, a historical perspective on the field of physics, and physics/astronomy in the news.

name: Animation Physics
description: This course presents principles and concepts of physics relevant to animation and special effects. Students will demonstrate mastery of this scientific knowledge in the critical analysis of films, shows, video games, etc., and in creating their own animated shorts.
satisfies: Satisfies B1: Physical Science.

name: Introduction to Computational Physics
description: An introduction to programming for physics majors who have no previous programming experience. Problem solving, data visualization and analysis using computational methods.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): PHYS 50.

name: Introduction to Physics
description: A preparatory course in physics for science and engineering majors, emphasizing significant figures, unit conversions, vectors, quantitative reasoning. Introduction to Newton’s Laws and conservation laws. The relevance of physics to science and engineering careers.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): MATH 19 or pre-calc placement test

name: General Physics I: Mechanics
description: A calculus-based treatment of particle kinematics and dynamics, work, energy, momentum, rotational motion, equilibrium, and simple harmonic motion.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Writing Enrollment Category I / II / III or GE Area A2 completed (grade of C- or better) or ENGL 1AF (grade of CR); AND, 3 or better on AP Calculus Test, or C- or better in MATH 30/30X. Allowed declared majors: College of Science or Engineering.
satisfies: Satisfies B1: Physical Science + B3: Laboratory.

name: General Physics/Mechanics Workshop
description: A discussion course for students concurrently registered in PHYS 50 General Physics/Mechanics covering problem solving methods as related to topics normally covered in PHYS 50.
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 3 units.

name: General Physics II: Electricity and Magnetism
description: A calculus-based introduction to electricity and magnetism, covering electric charges, electric and magnetic fields, dc and ac circuits, and electromagnetic waves.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): PHYS 50, MATH 31 or MATH 31X, both with grades of “C-” or better. Allowed declared majors: College of Science or Engineering majors only.
satisfies: Satisfies B1: Physical Science + B3: Laboratory.

name: General Physics III: Waves, Light, Heat
description: Mechanical waves, light, spectra, quantization of electromagnetic radiation; geometric and physical optics; temperature, heat, and thermodynamics.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): PHYS 51 with grade of “C-” or better. Allowed declared majors: College of Science or Engineering majors only.
satisfies: Satisfies B1: Physical Science + B3: Laboratory.

name: International Program Studies
description: Study Abroad and Away transfer credit course. Study Abroad and Away provides students the opportunity to study abroad on long term programs (Exchange Programs, CSU International Programs, and International Student Exchange Programs) and short-term programs (Faculty-Led Programs and Summer School Abroad Programs) for academic credit, offering Alternative Break Programs for cultural immersion, and designing other globally focused opportunities. This course is designated as a placeholder course for Study Abroad and Away programs.

name: Methods of Research and Communication in Physics
description: Develop communication skills for physics, including proposals, posters, research reports and oral presentations. Research strategies and methodologies for effective communication to general and specialized audiences.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): A3 or equivalent second semester composition course (with a grade of C- or better); completion of core GE; and upper division standing. Or Graduate or Postbaccalaureate level.
satisfies: Satisfies Writing in the Disciplines (WID).
notes: Note(s): Must be passed with C or better to satisfy the CSU Graduation Writing Assessment Requirement (GWAR).

name: Advanced Mechanics I
description: Dynamics of particles, Newtons laws, Lagranges and Hamiltons equations, conservation laws, symmetry and the laws of physics, oscillations, central-force motion, and non-inertial reference frames.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): PHYS 52, MATH 33A, each with grade of “C-” or better.
notes: Note(s): Year course.

name: Advanced Mechanics II
description: Dynamics of systems of particles: collisions, rigid body rotations, non-inertial frames, coupled oscillations, waves. This course is strongly recommended for students who are considering graduate study in physics.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): PHYS 105A with grade “C-” or better.

name: Waves and Oscillations
description: Oscillatory phenomena and their connection to waves. Review of simple harmonic motion and extension to damped, driven, and coupled oscillators. Applications to waves on strings, and basic concepts of electromagnetic and sound waves. Connections to the beginnings of quantum theory are developed.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): PHYS 52 (or equivalent coverage of waves and oscillations) and PHYS 105A, both with C- or better.

name: Electricity and Magnetism I
description: Theories of electrostatics, magnetostatics, electrodynamics and electromagnetic waves.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): PHYS 130, MATH 33A, each with “C-” or better.
notes: Note(s): Year course.

name: Electricity and Magnetism II
description: Theories of electrostatics, magnetostatics, electrodynamics and electromagnetic waves.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): PHYS 110A

name: Electronics, Data Acquisition & Analysis
description: The characteristics of basic analog and digital electronic circuits used in a scientific laboratory. Topics include transistors, operational amplifiers, digital electronic circuits, and computer data acquisition.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): PHYS 51 with “C” or better. Physics Majors Only

name: Advanced Scientific Measurements Lab
description: Modern experimental techniques in the context of modern and solid state physics. Examples include phase sensitive detection, spectrum analysis, four-point-probe resistivity measurements, and related techniques.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): PHYS 122 and PHYS 120A both with C or better. Physics Majors only.

name: Advanced Physics Lab: Optics and Lasers
description: Design of optical systems involving lasers and other common optical components. Use of optical systems to explore interference, holography, and other optical phenomena.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): PHYS 120A and PHYS 158 all with grade of “C-” or better.

name: Radiation Safety
description: Health hazards involved in working with radioactive substances. Physical nature of hazards, biological effects, standards of permissible exposures, safety precautions and protection techniques. Two units meet State of California recommendations.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Lower division calculus, chemistry and physics.
crosslist: Cross-listed with CHEM 121S / NUCS 121S. Chemistry is responsible for scheduling.

name: Modern Physics
description: Survey of modern physics for science majors, covering special relativity, pre-quantum theory, basic quantum mechanics, atomic and molecular physics, solid state physics, nuclear and particle physics, and cosmology. Historical foundations of these topics will also be are presented.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): CHEM 1A, MATH 32, and PHYS 52 all with a C- or better.

name: Introduction to Nuclear Science
description: Properties of the atomic nucleus. Applications of nuclear science in biology, chemistry, engineering, geology and physics.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Lower division calculus, chemistry and physics.
crosslist: Cross-listed with CHEM 126 / NUCS 126. Chemistry is responsible for scheduling.

name: Nuclear Science Lab
description: Basic techniques and procedures used in nuclear science. Nuclear decay, nuclear reactions, radiation detection and measurements, nuclear analytical methods and tracer techniques.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): NUCS 121S, CHEM 100W and CHEM 126 (with grades of “C” or better; “C-” not accepted); or instructor consent.
crosslist: Cross-listed with CHEM 127 / NUCS 127. Chemistry is responsible for scheduling.

name: Mathematical Methods in Physics
description: Mathematical methodologies commonly used in physics, including linear algebra, vector calculus, partial differential equations and complex variables, and their applications to classical mechanics, electricity and magnetism, and quantum mechanics.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): MATH 32 or MATH 32X, and PHYS 52.

name: Computational Methods in Physics
description: An introduction to the programming of algorithms and numerical techniques pertinent to physical systems.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): PHYS 40 or previous programming experience; PHYS 52 with a C- or better. Physics Majors Only.

name: Topics in Physics and Astronomy
description: Trending topics of physics and astronomy research and areas of special interest. Content varies by semester.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): PHYS 52, and MATH 32 or MATH 32X, both with a C- or better. Or Instructor Consent.

name: Modern Optics
description: Thin and thick lens systems. Double and multiple beam interference, holography, Fraunhofer and Fresnel diffraction, Fourier optics, spatial filtering, polarization and birefringence.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): PHYS 52 with a C- or better; MATH 32 or MATH 32X.

name: Thermodynamics and Statistical Physics
description: The laws of thermodynamics and kinetic theory with introduction to statistical mechanics.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): CHEM 1A and PHYS 52 both with a C- or better; MATH 32 or MATH 32X.

name: Fundamentals of Quantum Information
description: Introduction to fundamental topics in quantum information science (QIS). Course covers select concepts in quantum theory used in quantum technology including discrete quantum systems, measurements, quantum states, and gate operations. Modern applications of QIS including quantum communication, quantum computing, and physical realizations of quantum bits are discussed.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): PHYS 51 and one of the following: PHYS 130 or MATH 33LA or MATH 39. All with C- or better. Or instructor consent.

name: Quantum Mechanics
description: General principles of quantum theories. Wave functions, operator algebra and approximation methods. Applications to atomic structure and solid state physics.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): PHYS 122, MATH 33A, PHYS 130, all with a grade of “C-” or better.

name: Lasers
description: Properties of lasers and Gaussian light beams. Principles of laser operation and design. Application of lasers.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): PHYS 122 and PHYS 158 with a C- or better.

name: Solid State Physics
description: A detailed treatment of the physics of solids using quantum mechanics, crystallography, electromagnetism, and metallurgy.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): PHYS 122 with grade of “C-” or better.

name: Individual Studies
description: Advanced work in special fields.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Physics major or minor. Not available to Open University Students.
notes: Note(s): Maximum 4 units of 180/184 may be applied toward graduation.

name: Directed Reading
description: Assigned readings of selected books, journals and special papers to fill gaps in training or for contact with new fields. Weekly reports and conferences.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Not available to Open University Students.
notes: Note(s): Maximum 4 units of 180/184 may be applied toward graduation.

name: International Program Studies
description: Study Abroad and Away transfer credit course. Study Abroad and Away provides students the opportunity to study abroad on long term programs (Exchange Programs, CSU International Programs, and International Student Exchange Programs) and short-term programs (Faculty-Led Programs and Summer School Abroad Programs) for academic credit, offering Alternative Break Programs for cultural immersion, and designing other globally focused opportunities. This course is designated as a placeholder course for Study Abroad and Away programs.

name: Physics Education: Theory and Practice
description: Instructional Student Assistants and Teaching Associates integrate educational theory, pedagogy, content, and practice by focusing on practical concerns and associated theoretical models. Weekly readings, in-class discussions, out-of-class data collection, reflections, projects, and presentations based on classroom teaching experience.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): PHYS 50, PHYS 2A, or equivalent

name: Research and Communication in Physics
description: Learn and develop modern research and communication skills for physics and astronomy, including literature review, proposal writing, posters, research reports, theses, publications, resume/CV, and oral presentations. Research strategies and methodologies for effective communication to general and specialized audiences.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing.
satisfies: Satisfies GWAR: Graduation Writing Assessment Requirement.
notes: Note(s): This course satisfies graduate-level GWAR in this master’s program.

name: Advanced Dynamics
description: Generalized methods and selected topics in classical mechanics.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): PHYS 105A, PHYS 130, and MATH 33A, or equivalents; or instructor consent.

name: Introduction to Electro-Optics
description: This course introduces the physical principles of electro-optics including modulators (electro- and acousto-optic), non-linear optics, semiconductor lasers, optical detection and integrated optics with applications.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): PHYS 158

name: Electromagnetic Theory
description: Advanced topics in electromagnetic theory; Maxwell’s equations; solutions of Laplace’s and Poisson’s equations; Green functions; electromagnetic properties of materials; electromagnetic waves and wave propagation.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): PHYS 230.

name: Graduate Optics Lab
description: Covers the application of Lasers and Optics with emphasis on topics such as Gaussian beams, Fabry-Perot cavities, Laser oscillators including CW and pulsed operation, non-linear optics, frequency stabilization and Fourier Optics. Communication of scientific content through written communication.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): PHYS 120C or PHYS 208 or PHYS 258 or PHYS 268.
satisfies: Satisfies GWAR: Graduation Writing Assessment Requirement.
notes: Note(s): This course satisfies graduate-level GWAR in this master’s program.

name: Methods in Mathematical Physics
description: Partial differential equations and special functions: Bessel functions, Legendre polynomials, spherical harmonics; Green’s functions; complex variables and contour integrations; matrices and eigenvalue problems; Fourier and Laplace transforms.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): MATH 33A and PHYS 130, or equivalents; or instructor consent.

name: Computational Physics
description: Numerical techniques and computational methods applied to solving problems from various branches of physics.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): PHYS 40, PHYS 105A, and PHYS 163, or equivalents; or instructor consent.

name: Quantum Programming
description: Introduction to quantum algorithms and programming a quantum computer. Includes a review of relevant quantum mechanical concepts, topics from linear algebra and complex numbers, spins and qubits, quantum gates and circuits, entanglement, quantum algorithms, such as Deutsch-Jozsa, Grover, quantum Fourier transforms.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing, or PHYS 163 and instructor approval.

name: Quantum Many-Body Physics
description: From the perspective of quantum information science, the course builds functional understanding of phase transitions and quantum simulations via systems of interacting spins. Systems of non-interacting Bosons and Fermions will be examined, followed by an examination of interacting particles via the Hubbard model and some coverage of numerical solutions for small systems.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing and PHYS 161, or equivalent with approval of program advisor.

name: Advanced Topics in Physics
description: Selected topics in physics. Topics vary each semester. Course is repeatable when content changes.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Suitable upper division background in physics and mathematics.

name: Celestial Mechanics
description: Basic concepts in celestial mechanics emphasizing orbital mechanics and the calculation of orbital perturbation. Topics covered include dynamical principles, potential theory, planetary equations, the disturbing function, Lagrange’s perturbation equations and geopotential perturbations.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Senior or graduate standing.

name: General Relativity
description: General Relativity is the foundation for modern understanding of space and time. Coverage includes review of Special Relativity followed by the development of the mathematical tools of tensor calculus and Riemannian geometry and derivation of Einstein’s field equations from the postulates of General Relativity. Topics covered include the energy-momentum tensor, geodesics, and curvature tensors, as well as applications of the theory to Black Holes, gravitational waves, and cosmology.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): PHYS 130 and PHYS 110B, or equivalent. Upper division standing or graduate standing.

name: Optics
description: Fourier optics, diffraction theory, imaging and image enhancement, holography and information processing.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): PHYS 158 and MATH 33A.

name: Statistical Mechanics
description: Classical and quantum statistics with applications to properties of matter. Principles of thermodynamics.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): PHYS 160 and PHYS 163.

name: Quantum Theory
description: Postulates of quantum theory. The Schroedinger equation and its solution for simple physical systems. Heisenberg’s matrix formulation of quantum mechanics. Approximation methods: Time dependent and time independent perturbation theory. Variational method.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): PHYS 163, PHYS 230.

name: Laser Spectroscopy
description: Importance of spectroscopy. Interaction of radiation with matter. Instrumentation for laser spectroscopy. Examples of various techniques, cw and pulsed.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): PHYS 110B, PHYS 158 or instructor consent.
crosslist: Cross-listed with CHEM 268. Physics and Astronomy is responsible for scheduling.

name: Solid State Physics
description: Properties of crystals; electric, magnetic and thermal properties of solids.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): PHYS 263A or instructor consent.

name: Magnetism and Superconductivity
description: Fundamental properties of magnetic and superconducting materials and devices and their applications. Topics include magnetic anisotropy, magnetic domains, magnetization dynamics, conventional and unconventional superconductivity, magnetic properties of superconductors, Josephson effects, and SQUID.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): PHYS 210, PHYS 263A, or instructor consent.

name: Seminar
description: Meetings for the presentation and discussion of advanced studies in special fields including work by the faculty, guest investigators and graduate students. Topics will vary each semester.

name: Directed Research
description: Advanced work in special fields. Only open to currently enrolled graduate students.
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 5 units.
notes: Note(s): Not available to Open University students.

name: Graduate Research Report
description: Graduate Research Report.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): PHYS 297 and Instructor consent. Not available to Open University Students.

name: Master’s Thesis
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Advancement to candidacy for the master’s degree. Not available to Open University Students.

name: Culminating Experience Supervision
description: Continued work on thesis or project.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Outstanding RP grade in a preceding semester in Chem 299, Master’s Thesis
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 16 units.
notes: Note(s): No Degree Credit.

name: Principles of Packaging
description: Basic knowledge of packaging functions, materials and industry. A variety of packaging topics including distribution systems, packaging development, package design, legislation, regulations, societal and environmental issues, ergonomics and packaging careers.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): ENGL 1A or equivalent.
sustainability: Sustainability Related - SDG 12: Responsible Consumption and Production

name: Artios CAD For Packaging
description: Prepares students for ArtiosCAD (a packaging design tool common to the folding carton and corrugated industries). Introduces basic commands of ArtiosCAD to draw and design the representations for different products. Students use the structure database, change from 2D to 3D models, and make simple animations.

name: Solidworks For Packaging
description: Prepare students for SolidWorks (a computer drawing tool) so they can generate 3-D drawings suitable for specifications and transference to computer-driven cutting tables and 3-D printers to make prototype packages.

name: Packaging Materials I, Paper, Metal, and Wood Based
description: In-depth study of selected materials to provide a working knowledge of structures, physical and chemical properties, development, evaluation and design. Experiments in applications, design limitations and cost.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): PKG 107 or instructor consent.

name: Packaging Materials II, Plastics, Composites, and Glass
description: In-depth study of plastic and glass materials in packaging; chemical and physical properties, design, manufacturing, compatibility, and evaluation. Experiments in applications, design limitations and cost.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): NUFS 31, PKG 107, PKG 141A or instructor consent.

name: Packaging for Medical Devices and Pharmaceuticals
description: Chemical and physical properties of medical device and pharmaceuticals packages, fabrications techniques, package testing and evaluation methods, regulatory requirements, ergonomics and child resistant packages, tamper evidence, shelf life and aging, coding.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): PKG 107, PKG 141A, PKG 141B or instructor consent.

name: Globalization and the Environment
description: Scientific approach to goods distribution worldwide, and environmental consequences of shipping materials and packaging, which when discarded become waste. Mutual interests of commerce and environment.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Completion of Core General Education and upper division standing are prerequisites to all SJSU studies courses. Completion of, or co-registration in, 100W is strongly recommended.
satisfies: Satisfies SJSU Studies R: Earth, Environment, and Sustainability.
crosslist: Cross-listed with ENVS 152. Environmental Studies is responsible for scheduling.

name: Packaging Machinery Systems
description: Evaluation of packaging machinery as a subset of a packaging production system. Component selection, design, and implementation of package filling lines in a production facility. Package design requirements for filling lines.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): PKG 107, PKG 141A, PKG 141B, MATH 70, MATH 71 or MATH 71X, STAT 95.

name: Protective Package Design and Testing
description: In-depth study of protective packaging dynamics; theory and practice of shock, vibration, compression, humidity, temperature extremes. Measurement and analysis of the dist environment, product fragility, package design principles, package testing and evaluation.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): PKG 107, PKG 141A, PKG 141B, MATH 70, MATH 71 or MATH 71X, STAT 95.

name: Packaging Material Handling and Distribution
description: Transportation, handling, and storage of packaged goods. Transportation modes, environment hazards, measurement techniques. Military and Hazmat packaging regulations and testing, classification of goods, legal requirements, export packaging.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): PKG 158 or instructor consent.

name: Hazardous Materials Packaging
description: Identification and classification of hazardous materials, standards and requirements, proper documentation practices, identifying and sourcing the proper packaging materials to comply with hazardous materials packaging requires, and testing a package to provide United Nations Performance Orientated Packaging (UN POP) certification for shipping.

name: Advanced Laboratory Testing
description: Laboratory testing course that elaborates on concepts learned in previous classes. The focus is on good laboratory practices along with test methods covered in medical device package testing (PKG 146), packaging materials testing (PKG 141A/PKG 141B), and packaging dynamics testing (PKG 158).
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): PKG 141A, PKG 146 and PKG 158.

name: Food Packaging and Preservation
description: This course investigates the interaction of food processing and packaging technology. Content includes food chemistry, microbiology in foods, food processing, and finally how packaging augments these areas in food protection and preservation.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): PKG 107 or instructor consent.

name: Packaging Development and Management
description: Capstone course emphasizing development and evaluation of packaging systems. Specifications and design, marketing criteria, package production, distribution performance, legal and environmental evaluations.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): PKG 107, PKG 141A, PKG 141B, PKG 156, PKG 158 or instructor consent.
sustainability: Sustainability Related - SDG 12: Responsible Consumption and Production

name: Individual Studies
description: Individual work for majors or minors on special topics by arrangement.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): PKG 107; instructor and department chair consent during semester prior to enrollment.
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 6 units.

name: Advanced Laboratory Testing and Analysis
description: Focuses on good laboratory practices along with test methods covered in previous classes, such as medical device package testing (PKG 146), packaging materials testing (PKG 141A / PKG 141B), and packaging dynamics testing (PKG 158). At the completion of the class, students should be able to clearly organize, analyze, and present their data in a clear and concise manner.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): PKG 146 and PKG 158.

name: Package Design for End Use
description: Current Package Design and Influences on Designs.

name: American Government
description: Institutions and processes of American government and democracy; the U.S. Constitution and California state and local government.
satisfies: Satisfies American Institutions US2: US Constitution + US3: California Government.
notes: Note(s): Satisfies American Institutions requirements in American and California government.

name: Introduction to Comparative Politics
description: Comparative analysis of different kinds of political systems; their political institutions, processes and policies; the environments in which they occur and their consequences.
satisfies: Satisfies D: Social Sciences (formerly GE Area D2).

name: Introduction to Political Thought
description: Thinking critically about the classic problems of politics; learning how to interpret, discuss and write about historical and contemporary political thought.
satisfies: Satisfies C2: Humanities.

name: Introduction to International Relations
description: Introductory survey of major topics in international relations, including global, national and individual causes of war and peace, international cooperation, north-south relations and political economy.
satisfies: Satisfies D: Social Sciences (formerly GE Area D3).
sustainability: Sustainability Related - SDG 17: Partnerships for the Goals

name: Essentials of U.S. & California Government
description: Treatment of essentials of U.S. and California government. Satisfies the American Institutions (US23) and the GE Area D: Social Sciences requirements.
satisfies: Satisfies D (formerly GE Area D3) + US23: Social Sciences and US Constitution and California Government.

name: Power and Ideas in American Politics
description: Study of power, institutions, and creative ideas in American political thought. Engages work of intellect and imagination in political documents, essays, speeches, letters, short works of fiction, poems, and manifestos.
satisfies: Satisfies C2: Humanities + US2: US Constitution + US3: California Government.

name: Controversial Legal Issues
description: Basic concepts in critical thinking as demonstrated in legal reasoning and analysis of contemporary legal issues possibly including abortion, drug testing, offensive speech, affirmative action, gender and sexual preference discrimination, school prayer and pornography.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Completion of GE Area A2 with a grade of C- or better.
satisfies: Satisfies A3: Critical Thinking and Writing.
sustainability: Sustainability Related - SDG 16: Peace, Justice and Strong Institutions

name: International Program Studies
description: Study Abroad and Away transfer credit course. Study Abroad and Away provides students the opportunity to study abroad on long term programs (Exchange Programs, CSU International Programs, and International Student Exchange Programs) and short-term programs (Faculty-Led Programs and Summer School Abroad Programs) for academic credit, offering Alternative Break Programs for cultural immersion, and designing other globally focused opportunities. This course is designated as a placeholder course for Study Abroad and Away programs.

name: Political Inquiry
description: Introduction to the scope and methods of political science. Beginning with research design, measurement, and ethical considerations, and including a variety of research methods including surveys, experiments, interviews, fieldwork, content analysis, and an introduction to quantitative and qualitative analysis.
notes: Note(s): Should be taken junior year.

name: Writing Workshop
description: Writing skills for majors in political science. Basic materials; research; memos and research reports, press releases, analyses of political/electoral behavior, political speeches.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): A3 or equivalent second semester composition course (with a grade of C- or better); completion of core GE; and upper division standing. Or Graduate or Postbaccalaureate level.
satisfies: Satisfies Writing in the Disciplines (WID).
notes: Note(s): Must be passed with C or better to satisfy the CSU Graduation Writing Assessment Requirement (GWAR).

name: American Government for Teachers
description: Introduction to the institutions and processes of American and California governments with emphasis on meeting CCTC Teacher Preparation Standards. Topics include U.S. Constitution, federalism, political participation, civil rights and liberties, Congress, the presidency.

name: State Government and Politics
description: This course examines the politics and institutions of U.S. state governments. The structure and powers of state legislatures, governors, and court systems are analyzed. The effect of states’ racial, ideological, and economic characteristics on public policy is also explored.
satisfies: Satisfies American Institutions US3: California Government.
notes: Note(s): Satisfies American Institutions requirement in California government.

name: Local Government and Politics
description: Offers a theoretical and practical study of local politics and government. The structure, role, and functions of city and county governments are examined. Students gain knowledge of the resources and skills required for effective citizenship in their communities.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing.
crosslist: Cross-listed with URBP 103. Political Science is responsible for scheduling.

name: Congress
description: Examines politics and policymaking in the U.S. Congress. Topics include party leadership, interest groups in Congress, congressional committees, political representation, redistricting and congressional elections, party polarization, and the process of how a bill becomes law.

name: The United States Presidency
description: Examination of the American presidency. Topics include the historical emergence of the presidency as an institution, the formal and informal powers of the modern presidency, and the tension between the presidency and other federal institutions, most notably Congress.

name: Politics and Public Opinion
description: Examines the measurement and impact of public opinion on the democratic political process. The effects of socialization, media, and ideology on public opinion are explored, as well as the state of American public opinion on current political issues.

name: Political Participation
description: Explores various forms of political participation including voting, community engagement, and social change. Includes consideration of the roles that socialization, media, campaign and elections, and other social and technological factors play in shaping citizen participation.
sustainability: Sustainability Focused - SDG 16: Peace, Justice and Strong Institutions

name: Women and Politics
description: Examines social movement strategies and theories of gender and power employed by differently situated women. Includes critical examination of the relationship between sex and gender, and intersections of race, class, gender, law and nation.
sustainability: Sustainability Focused - SDG 5: Gender Equality

name: Race and Politics
description: Examines race and politics in America by focusing on political participation and social movement strategies among minoritized groups. Explores theories of equality, diversity, and justice, and the changing legal relationship between states and citizens.
sustainability: Sustainability Focused - SDG 16: Peace, Justice and Strong Institutions

name: Political Movements
description: Strategies and tactics of past and current US political movements. Local, state, and national government policy making processes and how they are influenced and shaped by organizing campaigns. Students plan, organize, and implement their own campaigns.

name: Introduction to Public Administration
description: A broad overview of the theory and practice of public policy analysis and management in the modern context. Topics include aspects of organizational theory, leadership, budgeting, finance, personnel management, problem formulation, analysis and decision making in a political environment.

name: Law and Society
description: Social and philosophical foundations of law and legal systems and development of legal institutions in various cultures. Anglo-American law and administration of justice in the U.S. emphasized.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Completion of Core General Education and upper division standing are prerequisites to all SJSU studies courses. Completion of, or co-registration in, 100W is strongly recommended.
satisfies: Satisfies SJSU Studies S: Self, Society & Equality in U.S.

name: Constitutional Law: Institutional Powers
description: Examines the U.S. Supreme Court, its processes, and the role it plays in the American governing system. Examination of judicial policy making through cases on judicial review, separations of powers, federalism, commerce, and tax and treaty powers.

name: Constitutional Law: Civil Liberties
description: Explores the constitutional basis for civil liberties in America. Application of methods of constitutional analysis to cases involving freedom of speech, religion, and the press. Examination of personal privacy rights including abortion, gun rights, and criminal procedures.

name: Constitutional Law: Civil Rights
description: Explores the constitutional basis for civil rights in America. Application of methods of constitutional analysis to cases involving discrimination, equal protection, and due process.  Examination of leading cases related to voting rights, affirmative action, criminal justice, and other issues
sustainability: Sustainability Focused - SDG 16: Peace, Justice and Strong Institutions

name: Judicial Politics
description: Examines the effects of political forces on judicial behavior. Includes consideration of the roles of interest groups, public opinion, methods of selecting judges, and the importance of judges’ personal political beliefs, on judicial decisions.

name: Introduction to Environmental Law
description: Development, interpretation, application and enforcement of environmental laws, regulations and legal policies by legislatures, courts, administrative agencies and citizens. Examination of air and water quality, hazardous materials, workplace, land use and wetlands regulation, international, ethical and efficacy issues.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): ENVS 1 or Instructor Consent.
crosslist: Cross-listed with ENVS 124. Environmental Studies is responsible for scheduling.

name: American Public Policy
description: Introduces students to the public policy making process in the American governing system. The politics of agenda setting, policy formulation, and policy implementation are examined. Students learn to analyze and evaluate public policy outcomes.

name: U.S. Environmental Policy
description: Inquiry focuses on environmental pollution, public attitudes toward environmental problems, interest groups involved in formulation of policy, and the role of government policy makers in shaping the environmental agenda.
crosslist: Cross-listed with ENVS 135. Political Science is responsible for scheduling.

name: Politics of Post-Communist Countries
description: Political development and change in countries that have transitioned from communist or socialist systems such as Russia, Eastern Europe, Central Asia, and the Caucasus; internal politics of these countries and relations with other countries.

name: African Politics
description: Basic concepts, theoretical perspectives, and information to understand the evolution of contemporary African states. Begins with a study of colonialism, and proceeds to nationalism, personalistic and military rule, development, democratization, and inter-state and civil war.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing.
crosslist: Cross-listed with AFRS 142. Political Science is responsible for scheduling.

name: Middle Eastern Politics
description: Study of unfolding events in the Middle East. Themes include: the failure of democratic movements, nuclear proliferation and terrorism, US foreign policy towards the region, the Israel-Palestine conflict, urbanization, gender and human rights.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing.
crosslist: Cross-listed with JWSS 144 / MDES 144. Political Science is responsible for scheduling.

name: Asian Politics
description: Study of unfolding events in Asia. Themes include: the Asian economic ‘miracle,’ the implications of China’s rise for international security, nuclear proliferation and terrorism, and sustainability; specifically, energy, environment and human rights.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing.
crosslist: Cross-listed with ASIA 145. Political Science is responsible for scheduling.
sustainability: Sustainability Related - SDG 17: Partnerships for the Goals

name: Latin American Politics
description: Survey of the political systems of Latin American countries. Places Latin American countries in a global perspective. Major themes include: civil-military relations, democratization, economic development, social movements, and foreign relations both within and outside Latin America.

name: Globalization
description: Considers the impact of economic and political globalization, focusing primarily on nations in Latin America, Asia and Africa. Issues include the effects of multinational production, migration, aid, international institutions and humanitarian intervention.
sustainability: Sustainability Focused - SDG 17: Partnerships for the Goals

name: Nationalism and Comparative Political Cultures
description: Comparative analysis of the origin, nature, and impact of nationalism on the politics of Western and non-Western states. Students examine cases where nationalism resulted in conflict, and those in which it supports a stable nation-state. Completion of POLS 2, POLS 3 and POLS 4 highly recommended before enrolling.

name: War and Peace
description: Fundamental human questions about causes of war, definitions of peace and approaches toward achieving peace from perspectives of historical and contemporary thinkers, including philosophers, political leaders, military strategists and diplomats.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Completion of Core General Education and upper division standing are prerequisites to all SJSU studies courses. Completion of, or co-registration in, 100W is strongly recommended.
satisfies: Satisfies SJSU Studies V: Cultures and Global Understanding.
notes: Note(s): Not counted as a core course in the international relations subfield.

name: International Organizations and NGOs
description: Examines the structures and functions of different types of international organizations (such as the UN, NATO, regional organizations, and non-governmental organizations), and their role in maintaining international peace and security, promoting human rights and economic development, and protecting the environment.
sustainability: Sustainability Related - SDG 17: Partnerships for the Goals

name: Model United Nations
description: Structure and operations of the United Nations explored and analyzed through participation in annual U.N. simulation.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): POLS 152A
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 16 units.

name: European Union
description: Surveys and analyzes the historical evolution, the institutions, as well as the process of policy making in the European Union. Examines key policy areas: agricultural, social, economic, environmental, and foreign policy.
sustainability: Sustainability Related - SDG 17: Partnerships for the Goals

name: U.S. Foreign Policy: Formulation and Administration
description: Consideration of the factors that shape American foreign policy making, including ideology, organization, as well as partisanship, interest groups, and public opinion. Issues considered include relations with the Middle East and Russia, and economic diplomacy.

name: The Wealth of Nations
description: This course examines how states, international and multinational bodies, and global social movements shape trade, financial, and labor relations. Topics include: international trade and protectionism, the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank, regional integration, and transnational corporations.

name: Islam, Politics and the West
description: An in-depth look at the roots of Islamic tradition, law, politics, culture, and society. Emphasis on Islam’s growing global prominence; relations with the West; stereotypes and misconception, as well as the nature of the Islamic state.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Upper-division standing or instructor consent.
crosslist: Cross-listed with MDES 156 / RELS 156. Humanities is responsible for scheduling.

name: International Security
description: Examines theories of international security, debates over sources, conduct and termination of conflict, including but not limited to inter-state war; security decision-making; military and economic strategy; crisis management; regional security; intelligence; new and complex security issues along the war-peace continuum.

name: Classical Political Thought
description: Critical examination of the foundations of Western political thought and the continuing influence of these foundations; sources chosen from among a variety of pre-Renaissance traditions and include writers such as Plato, Aristotle, Augustine and Aquinas.

name: Modern Political Thought
description: The basis of the modern state and society as interpreted by political thought between (and including) the Renaissance and the French Revolution; this key period includes writers such as Machiavelli, Hobbes, Locke and Rousseau.

name: Recent Political Thought
description: The roots of today’s politics in the ideas and writers of the nineteenth and twentieth centuries; sources drawn from a variety of recent traditions such as democratic theory, Marxism, political psychology and political sociology.

name: American Political Thought
description: Critical examination of the origins and development of American politics as seen through theorists, concepts and forces which have shaped American political consciousness.

name: American Politics in Global Perspective
description: A survey of U.S. and California political institutions and culture in comparison with political institutions and cultures outside the U.S., as well as American Institutions Requirement: US2 and US3.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Completion of Core General Education and upper division standing are prerequisites to all SJSU studies courses. Completion of, or co-registration in, 100W is strongly recommended.
satisfies: Satisfies SJSU Studies V + US23: Cultures and Global Understanding. + US Constitution and California Government.

name: Political Psychology
description: Introduction to the interdisciplinary field of political psychology, with a focus on topics including personality and leadership, political cognition, social identity, emotions and attitudes, voting and political behavior, racism and ethnocentrism, ethnic conflict and genocide, nationalism, terrorism, and conflict resolution.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): POLS 1 (or other US2-3), PSYC 1, or instructor consent
crosslist: Cross-listed with PSYC 177. Political Science is responsible for scheduling.
sustainability: Sustainability Related - SDG 10: Reduced Inequalities

name: Individual Studies
description: Individual study for advanced work in areas where no courses are offered.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Appropriate courses, instructor consent and department chair consent.

name: Internships
description: Offers students the opportunity to connect knowledge of politics, government, and policy making learned in the classroom to real life application through internships with elected officials, non-profit organizations, government agencies, or political campaigns.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): POLS 100W and instructor consent.

name: Internship Capstone
description: Application of knowledge of politics, government, and policy making through internships with elected officials, non-profit organizations, government agencies, or political campaigns. Students complete a major capstone paper.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): POLS 100W and POLS 100M, and instructor consent. A minimum grade of C- is required to fulfill the BA Political Science capstone requirement.

name: Directed Reading
description: Program of reading and writing created through student/faculty consultation in areas not covered by other courses. Course is not repeatable for credit.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Appropriate courses, instructor consent and department chair consent.

name: Senior Seminar
description: Culminating experience for the political science major. Seminar class with significant participation required. Specific course topics vary each semester.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): POLS 100W and POLS 100M, or instructor consent. A minimum grade of C- is required to fulfill the BA Political Science capstone requirement.

name: Honors Thesis
description: Preparation and writing of an original project.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Senior standing. 3.2 overall GPA and 3.5 GPA in the major and instructor consent.

name: International Program Studies
description: Study Abroad and Away transfer credit course. Study Abroad and Away provides students the opportunity to study abroad on long term programs (Exchange Programs, CSU International Programs, and International Student Exchange Programs) and short-term programs (Faculty-Led Programs and Summer School Abroad Programs) for academic credit, offering Alternative Break Programs for cultural immersion, and designing other globally focused opportunities. This course is designated as a placeholder course for Study Abroad and Away programs.

name: Current Political Issues
description: Major political issues of the day. Topics vary each semester. Course is repeatable for credit with instructor consent.

name: International Program Studies
description: Study Abroad and Away transfer credit course. Study Abroad and Away provides students the opportunity to study abroad on long term programs (Exchange Programs, CSU International Programs, and International Student Exchange Programs) and short-term programs (Faculty-Led Programs and Summer School Abroad Programs) for academic credit, offering Alternative Break Programs for cultural immersion, and designing other globally focused opportunities. This course is designated as a placeholder course for Study Abroad and Away programs.

name: Elementary Portuguese I
description: Basic skills and structure of the language in the context of culture.
satisfies: Satisfies C2: Humanities.

name: Elementary Portuguese II
description: Basic skills and structure of the language in the context of culture.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): PORT 1A (or equivalent).
satisfies: Satisfies C2: Humanities.

name: Intermediate Portuguese
description: Reading, sentence structure and idiomatic usage in conversation and simple essays.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): 2 semesters of college Portuguese (or equivalent or SJSU placement exam).

name: Intermediate Portuguese
description: A continuation of PORT 20A.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): 3 semesters of college Portuguese (or equivalent).

name: International Program Studies
description: Study Abroad and Away transfer credit course. Study Abroad and Away provides students the opportunity to study abroad on long term programs (Exchange Programs, CSU International Programs, and International Student Exchange Programs) and short-term programs (Faculty-Led Programs and Summer School Abroad Programs) for academic credit, offering Alternative Break Programs for cultural immersion, and designing other globally focused opportunities. This course is designated as a placeholder course for Study Abroad and Away programs.

name: Advanced Portuguese
description: Reading, discussion, morphology, syntax and composition.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Four semesters of college Portuguese (or equivalent).

name: Advanced Portuguese
description: Reading, discussion, morphology, syntax and composition.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Four semesters of college Portuguese (or equivalent).

name: Intro to Portuguese-Speaking Cultures
description: Introduction to the culture and civilization of the Portuguese-speaking world, including geography, history, customs, and literature of the different countries. Taught in English.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Four semesters of college Portuguese (or equivalent).

name: Brazilian Culture
description: History, geography, fine art and daily life in Brazil.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing

name: Individual Studies in Portuguese
description: By arrangement.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing in Portuguese (or equivalent) and instructor consent.

name: International Program Studies
description: Study Abroad and Away transfer credit course. Study Abroad and Away provides students the opportunity to study abroad on long term programs (Exchange Programs, CSU International Programs, and International Student Exchange Programs) and short-term programs (Faculty-Led Programs and Summer School Abroad Programs) for academic credit, offering Alternative Break Programs for cultural immersion, and designing other globally focused opportunities. This course is designated as a placeholder course for Study Abroad and Away programs.

name: International Program Studies
description: Study Abroad and Away transfer credit course. Study Abroad and Away provides students the opportunity to study abroad on long term programs (Exchange Programs, CSU International Programs, and International Student Exchange Programs) and short-term programs (Faculty-Led Programs and Summer School Abroad Programs) for academic credit, offering Alternative Break Programs for cultural immersion, and designing other globally focused opportunities. This course is designated as a placeholder course for Study Abroad and Away programs.
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 6 units.

name: Introduction to Public Relations
description: Principles, evolution, and professional practice of modern public relations. Concepts of planning and executing effective communication strategies, including message design and distribution, for any organization.

name: Media and Influencer Relations
description: How to promote an organizations brand by developing relationships with traditional and digital news organizations and social media influencers to earn credible third-party content that is ultimately discovered, shared, and drives a desired action.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): JOUR 61

name: Strategic Content Creation
description: Basics of creating and implementing a strategic content marketing plan, introducing students to tools and techniques for delivering valuable, relevant, and measurably effective content on behalf of organizations, guiding students through production of various marketing communication assets.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): JOUR 61

name: Case Studies in Strategic Communication
description: Case studies focusing on the problems and challenges faced by a variety of organizations. Practical application of creative problem-solving, theory, and research about “real world” situations.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): PR 99.

name: International Program Studies
description: Study Abroad and Away transfer credit course. Study Abroad and Away provides students the opportunity to study abroad on long term programs (Exchange Programs, CSU International Programs, and International Student Exchange Programs) and short-term programs (Faculty-Led Programs and Summer School Abroad Programs) for academic credit, offering Alternative Break Programs for cultural immersion, and designing other globally focused opportunities. This course is designated as a placeholder course for Study Abroad and Away programs.

name: Special Event Management
description: The planning and managing of events for the purpose of accomplishing organizational objectives. Emphasis on creative thinking, logistics and practical application of strategies and tactics. A major project is the execution of an actual event.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): PR 99 or instructor consent.

name: Strategic Sport Communication and Media
description: Overview of the field of sport communication and media; specific topics include models of sport communication, print and electronic media, sport advertising, public relations, media relations, and employment opportunities. Students critically assess the communication efforts of a sports organization as well as construct their own communications in the field of sport.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): PR 99.

name: Introduction to Corporate Internal Communication
description: Internal and employee communications from strategy to tactical delivery. Best practices in building internal communication strategies that support organization business goals, as well as raise employee morale, productivity and collaboration. Topics include building internal communication strategy, planning, platform design, tools and strategic messaging campaigns.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): PR 99.

name: Campaign Planning and Management
description: Creative problem-solving in strategic planning and program management. Conceive, develop and present an integrated communications plan to a “real-world” client.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): PR 99, PR 190 or PR 191, PR 192, and MCOM 111.

name: Introduction to Psychology
description: Psychology is the scientific study of behavior and mental processes. The content focuses on the exploration of major psychological theories and concepts, methods, and research findings in psychology. Topics include the biological bases of behavior, perception, cognition and consciousness, learning, memory, emotion, motivation, development, personality, social psychology, psychological disorders and therapeutic approaches to treatment, and applied psychology.
satisfies: Satisfies D: Social Sciences (formerly GE Area D1).

name: Identity Development and Prejudice
description: This seminar is designed to facilitate the transition to the university smoothly with a view to an increased understanding of one’s cultural identity; and exploring mechanisms and consequences of prejudice and discrimination in American cultural groups.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): First term freshmen only.
satisfies: Satisfies E: Human Understanding & Development.
sustainability: Sustainability Related - SDG 16: Peace, Justice and Strong Institutions
notes: Note(s): All courses with a ‘Q’ suffix are designated as First Year Experience courses.

name: Introduction to Research Methods
description: Psychological research methods and design (experimental, quasi-experimental [correlational], and descriptive investigations) covering observation, instrumentation, and the collection, analysis, interpretation, and reporting of research data as illustrated through a review of original research in a variety of the subdisciplines of psychology.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): PSYC 1, and STAT 95.

name: Introductory Psychobiology
description: Biological approaches to understanding behavior: evolutionary, genetic, neural and hormonal influences on normal and abnormal behavior.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): BIOL 21 or BIOL 65.

name: International Program Studies
description: Study Abroad and Away transfer credit course. Study Abroad and Away provides students the opportunity to study abroad on long term programs (Exchange Programs, CSU International Programs, and International Student Exchange Programs) and short-term programs (Faculty-Led Programs and Summer School Abroad Programs) for academic credit, offering Alternative Break Programs for cultural immersion, and designing other globally focused opportunities. This course is designated as a placeholder course for Study Abroad and Away programs.

name: Writing Workshop
description: Practice in improvement of writing skills appropriate to the broad field of psychology, including essays, reports and scholarly communication.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): PSYC 1; STAT 95 or senior standing; A3 or equivalent second semester composition course (with a grade of C- or better); completion of core GE; and upper division standing. Allowed Declared Majors: Psychology Majors/Minors and Behavioral Science Majors only. Or Graduate or Postbaccalaureate level.
satisfies: Satisfies Writing in the Disciplines (WID).
notes: Note(s): Must be passed with C or better to satisfy the CSU Graduation Writing Assessment Requirement (GWAR).

name: Psychology of Childhood
description: Psychological development of children from conception to middle childhood emphasizing normative (typical) development in the context of cognitive, socioemotional, biological, and cultural processes.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): PSYC 1.

name: Special Topics in Developmental Psychology
description: Intensive examination of current research and theory in a specialized area of developmental psychology. Course is repeatable for credit when course content changes.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): PSYC 102 or PSYC 112 or PSYC 114 or equivalent
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 6 units.

name: Psychology of Women
description: Sex-role development of women in terms of bio-social factors involved in intellectual and personal-emotional functions. Psychological theory and research.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): PSYC 1.
crosslist: Cross-listed with WGSS 107. Psychology is responsible for scheduling.

name: Adult Psychopathology
description: Nature, causes, assessment, and treatment of behavioral, emotional, and personality problems of adults. Emphasis on psychological, social, and biological determinants of human behavioral and psychological disturbance.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): PSYC 1.

name: Psychology of Adolescence
description: Psychological development of adolescents’ and young (emerging) adults emphasizing normative (typical) development in the context of cognitive, socioemotional, biological, and cultural processes.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): PSYC 1.

name: Psychology of Aging
description: Psychological development of middle-aged and older adults emphasizing normative (typical) development in the context of cognitive, socioemotional, biological, and cultural processes. Course content also includes age-related health problems and their prevention.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): PSYC 1.
crosslist: Cross-listed with GERO 114. Psychology is responsible for scheduling.

name: Psychological Tests and Measures
description: Test and questionnaire construction, evaluation and interpretation applied to intelligence and ability tests, personality and adjustment questionnaires, ratings and behavioral observation techniques.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): STAT 95.

name: Advanced Research Methods in Psychology
description: Descriptive, correlational, quasi-experimental, and experimental approaches: design, methodology, and analysis. Experience designing, conducting, analyzing, and presenting (verbal and written) research findings. Topics include: hypothesis testing, validity, reliability, scales of measurement, questionnaire development, power, statistical significance, and effect size.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Lower division GE complete; STAT 95, PSYC 18, PSYC 100W with a “C” or better (or departmental approval), Upper division standing, Psychology or Behavioral Science majors only.

name: Advanced Research Methods and Design
description: Descriptive, correlational, quasi-experimental, and experimental approaches: design, methodology, and analysis. Experience designing, conducting, analyzing, and presenting (verbal and written) research findings. Topics will include: hypothesis testing, validity, reliability, scales of measurement, questionnaire development, power, statistical significance, and effect size.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): lower division GE complete; STAT 95; PSYC 100W with ‘C’ or better (or department approval); Upper Division; Psychology or Behavioral Science Major

name: Advanced Research Methods Social/Personality Laboratory
description: Advanced treatment of research approaches used in social and personality psychology. The course focus is shared between traditional laboratory and fieldwork experimental designs and methods. Data collection and statistical data analysis facilitate experiential learning.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): PSYC 100W, and PSYC 118 or PSYC 120, and PSYC 139 or PSYC 154. Upper division standing. Psychology majors only.
notes: Note(s):  Instructor consent may allow PSYC 121A and PSYC 120 concurrently on a space-available basis.

name: Advanced Research Methods: Cognition/Perception
description: Advanced treatment of research approaches used in cognition and/or perception through traditional laboratory experimental designs and methods. Laboratory-based data collection and analysis facilitate experiential learning.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): PSYC 100W; and either PSYC 135, PSYC 155, or PSYC 158; and either PSYC 118 or PSYC 120.
notes: Note(s): Instructor consent may allow PSYC 121B and PSYC 120 concurrently on a space-available basis.

name: Advanced Research Methods: Clinical Laboratory
description: Advanced research methods used in clinical research. The primary focus is on traditional field and laboratory research methodologies. Data collection and statistical data analysis facilitate experiential learning.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): PSYC 100W, and PSYC 118 or PSYC 120, and PSYC 110 or PSYC 142.
notes: Note(s): Note(s): Instructor consent may allow PSYC 121C and PSYC 120 concurrently on a space-available basis.

name: Advanced Research Methods: Psychophysiology Lab
description: Intensive experiential introduction to applied laboratory work in human psychophysiology and hormonal influences on human behavior. Focus on experimental methodology.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): PSYC 100W and PSYC 118 or PSYC 120 and PSYC 129

name: Drugs, Brain and Behavior
description: Survey of psychoactive drugs, including prescription and street drugs; social, behavioral and physiological effects of drugs; neural mechanisms of drug action; history of drug use.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): PSYC 30 or 3 units of biology.
crosslist: Cross-listed with PH 126. Psychology is responsible for scheduling.

name: Neuroscience
description: Principles of brain organization and function underlying behavior. Topics include neuroanatomy and physiology of language, vision, sexual behavior, memory and abnormal behavior.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Either PSYC 30 and 3 units of biology, or 9 units of biology.
crosslist: Cross-listed with BIOL 129. Psychology is responsible for scheduling.
notes: Note(s): Not acceptable as an elective in the Biology major.

name: Cognition
