description: The activity of knowing: acquisition, organization and use of knowledge. Processes involved in that activity, including perception, memory, thinking and language.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): PSYC 1.

name: Cognitive Science
description: Focuses on the study of the mind and the nature of intelligence from interdisciplinary perspectives including psychology, computer science, philosophy, linguistics, mathematics, and neuroscience. Topics typically include the history of computer-based approaches to artificial intelligence and expertise, human cognition, neuroscience, language acquisition, and computational approaches to modeling cognitive processes.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): PSYC 1 and PSYC 135.

name: Psychology of Personality
description: Current approaches to the study of personality and personality processes.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): PSYC 1.

name: Child Psychopathology
description: Nature, causes, assessment, and treatment of behavioral, cognitive, and emotional problems of children and adolescents. Emphasis on psychological, social, and biological determinants of human behavioral and psychological disturbance.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): PSYC 1.

name: Community Mental Health
description: Comprehensive analysis of community mental health using a socio-ecological framework. Intersection of race, socioeconomic status, gender, sexual orientation, and mental health is examined. Emphasis is on prevention and recovery.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Any 100W or instructor consent.
crosslist: Cross-listed with PH 145 / SOCI 145. Public Health and Recreation is responsible for scheduling.

name: Educational Psychology
description: Development of individuals and how they learn. Intelligence, emotions, interests, social relations as related to development and learning.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): PSYC 1.
notes: Note(s): No credit for those who have taken EDSC 173.

name: Psychology in the Courtroom
description: Role of psychology in the legal system: legal procedure and adversary system, jury selection, jury decision-making, eyewitness testimony, mental health law, criminal responsibility and legal insanity, expert psychological testimony, role of forensic psychologists.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): PSYC 1.

name: Social Psychology
description: Theories, problems and issues in the study of human social behavior.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): PSYC 1.

name: Human Learning
description: Memory, forgetting, concept formation, language learning, reinforcement and related topics. Traditional learning concepts, theories and findings with reference to contemporary classroom management, behavior modification and other applications.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): PSYC 1.

name: Applied Behavior Analysis
description: Survey of applications of behavioral principles to problems of clinical and social importance. Topics include data-based decision making, approaches to promoting skill acquisition, and strategies for assessing and reducing problem behavior.
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 6 units.

name: Perception
description: Empirical and theoretical approaches to the psychology of perception with an emphasis on vision. Topics include the perception of form, color, depth and motion as well as the effects of attention and experience.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): PSYC 1.

name: Clinical Psychology
description: Survey of clinical psychology as a profession. Emphasis placed on training models, specializations within the field, the scientific study of psychological interventions, and the graduate school admissions process for masters and doctoral level psychotherapists.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): PSYC 1.

name: Theory and Methods of Counseling
description: A survey of theories focused on helping and behavior change. Course covers both historical and contemporary psychotherapeutic interventions found in clinical and counseling psychology and evidence based practice approaches in psychotherapy.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): PSYC 1.

name: Sports Psychology
description: Psychological aspects of sports, including the value of sports, psychological factors involved in competitive as well as non-competitive athletic activities and the role of sports psychologists.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): PSYC 1.
crosslist: Cross-listed with KIN 167. Kinesiology is responsible for scheduling.

name: Industrial and Organizational Psychology
description: Application of psychological theory, research and methodology to the work environment. Topics covered include leadership, power, group processes, motivation, satisfaction and issues in personnel psychology.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): PSYC 1.

name: Human Factors
description: Human psychology and physiological characteristics and methods for taking these into account in designs and development of human-machine systems. Current human factor engineering efforts in lab, design process and operational environment.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): PSYC 1.

name: Management Psychology
description: Theory and practice of psychology in organizations and management. Topics include learning, motivation, perception, attitudes, personality, stress, groups, culture, careers, communication, leadership, politics, conflict, cooperation, decision-making and organizational change.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): PSYC 1.

name: Political Psychology
description: Introduction to the interdisciplinary field of political psychology, with a focus on topics including personality and leadership, political cognition, social identity, emotions and attitudes, voting and political behavior, racism and ethnocentrism, ethnic conflict and genocide, nationalism, terrorism, and conflict resolution.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): POLS 1 (or other US2-3), PSYC 1, or instructor consent.
crosslist: Cross-listed with POLS 177. Political Science is responsible for scheduling.
sustainability: Sustainability Related - SDG 10: Reduced Inequalities

name: Individual Studies
description: Research project in psychology.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): 12 units of psychology and instructor and department chair consent.

name: Directed Reading
description: Directed reading on a specific psychological topic.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): 12 units of psychology and instructor and department chair consent.

name: Psychology Field Work
description: Supervised field work in a selected area of psychology. Course is repeatable for 4 unit maximum.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Instructor and department chair consent.
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 4 units.

name: Current Issues Capstone
description: Integrative survey of current issues in psychology, how they developed and likely future directions. Completion of the research methods requirement prior to enrollment in this course is recommended.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): PSYC 100W and senior standing.

name: The Psychology of Prejudice
description: Provides an examination of psychological theory and research related to prejudice and discrimination from the perspectives of both the holders and targets of prejudice. Includes individual and small group exercises to provide experiential learning.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Completion of Core General Education and upper division standing are prerequisites to all SJSU studies courses. Completion of, or co-registration in, 100W is strongly recommended.
satisfies: Satisfies SJSU Studies S: Self, Society & Equality in U.S.
sustainability: Sustainability Related - SDG 16: Peace, Justice and Strong Institutions

name: International Program Studies
description: Study Abroad and Away transfer credit course. Study Abroad and Away provides students the opportunity to study abroad on long term programs (Exchange Programs, CSU International Programs, and International Student Exchange Programs) and short-term programs (Faculty-Led Programs and Summer School Abroad Programs) for academic credit, offering Alternative Break Programs for cultural immersion, and designing other globally focused opportunities. This course is designated as a placeholder course for Study Abroad and Away programs.

name: Behavioral Science in Practice
description: Capstone workshop for behavioral science majors. Students assess methods and knowledge of anthropology, psychology and sociology, and synthesize them by reflecting upon case studies of individual, organizational, community, and global issues. Emphasis is on cooperative learning, reflection and synthesis of skills and knowledge.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Senior standing. Allowed Declared Major: Behavioral Science or Behavioral Science double major.
crosslist: Cross-listed with ANTH 193 / SOCI 193. Anthropology is responsible for scheduling.
sustainability: Sustainability Related - SDG 16: Peace, Justice and Strong Institutions

name: Cultural Psychology
description: Designed for students who have some background and interest in multicultural and cross-cultural issues. Introduction to how social group membership influences cognition, emotion, identity/the self, intergroup processes, attitudes, and related processes.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): PSYC 1.

name: Honors Seminar in Psychology
description: Intensive examination of background and current status of student-selected problems.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s):  at least 18 units of PSYC/STAT, PSYC 100W, PSYC 118 or PSYC 120, overall PSYC/STAT GPA of 3.5, Senior Standing

name: Senior Honors Thesis
description: Supervised thesis open only to exceptional senior psychology majors.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Senior or graduate standing and instructor consent.

name: Seminar in Personality Theory
description: A survey of contemporary approaches to personality study.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): PSYC 139 (or equivalent) plus a total of nine semester hours of upper division psychology courses.

name: Clinical Assessment I
description: An in-depth introduction to objective, projective and behavioral assessment techniques used in the clinical evaluation of the behavior and functioning of adults, children and families.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): PSYC 117 (or equivalent).
satisfies: Satisfies GWAR: Graduation Writing Assessment Requirement.
notes: Note(s): MS program priority. This course satisfies graduate-level GWAR in this master’s program.

name: Seminar in Developmental Psychology
description: An examination of significant theories, perspectives, and research in developmental psychology.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): PSYC 102 (or equivalent).

name: Family Assessment and Intervention
description: An interdisciplinary exploration of how therapists can analyze and change interpersonal dynamics in couples and families.

name: Psychology of Contemporary Families
description: An overview of current family issues faced by psychotherapists in clinical settings. Emphasis will be placed on identification and conceptualization of these issues from a psychological perspective, stressing integration of issues into clinical practice. MS Clinical program priority.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): PSYC 208.

name: Advanced Psychopathology
description: Advanced course to provide knowledge and experience in the classification and treatment of disorders of childhood, adolescence and adulthood as they are identified in schools, family interactions and worksite settings. Critical review of research related to the evaluation of treatment strategies.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): PSYC 110.
notes: Note(s): MS program priority.

name: Child Psychopathology
description: An overview on the nature, assessment and treatment of Child Psychopathology. Emphasis will be placed on understanding DSM-IV diagnoses from a developmental perspective. Objective methods of assessment and empirically supported treatments will be covered.

name: Lifespan Development
description: Psychological, biological and social development throughout the life cycle. Interdisciplinary lecture course includes infancy, childhood, adolescence, young adulthood, middle age and old age. Topics include theories, research, influences, changes, problems and patterns of human development.
notes: Note(s): MS program priority.

name: HCI for Cyber Security
description: The course covers HCI in cyber security that include: authentication and access control, trust, user privacy and data protections, cyber security in social networking, data protection and security in healthcare , cyber security in eCommerce, mobile, computing & cloud computing, compliance and regulation, visualization tools and techniques in cyber security and privacy.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Graduate Standing.
crosslist: Cross-listed with CMPE 219 / ISE 219. Industrial and Systems Engineering is responsible for scheduling.

name: Seminar in Experimental Psychology
description: Applications of experimental method to current problems in psychology. Individual design and experimental work required.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): PSYC 120A.

name: Gender and Ethnic Issues in Counseling and Therapy
description: Theoretical and practical understanding of gender and ethnic issues in clinical practice, including issues arising from differing socialization, psychological structures, values and cultural assumptions that may affect therapeutic intervention within individuals, couples and families.
notes: Note(s): MS program priority.

name: Clinical Psychology Practicum I
description: Supervised experience in the treatment of behavioral and emotional problems of individuals and families.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Same as PSYC 223A.
notes: Note(s): MS program priority.

name: Clinical Psychology Practicum II
description: Advanced supervision in the treatment of behavioral and emotional problems of individuals and families.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Same as PSYC 224A.
notes: Note(s): MS program priority.

name: Advanced Group Dynamics
description: Advanced study of the dynamics of small group interaction. Limited supervised training in group facilitation techniques.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): PSYC 125 (or equivalent).
notes: Note(s): MS program priority.

name: Addictions and Treatment
description: Advanced course in assessment, diagnosis, and treatment, and prevention of substance abuse and dependence and co-occurring disorders in multiple settings. Critical review of research related to the evaluation of treatment strategies are provided from recovery models, family, and individual perspectives.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): PSYC 203A and graduate standing in MS psychology program

name: Professional Ethics for Psychologists
description: Consideration of ethical and legal issues related to the professional application of psychology. Designed particularly for students involved in field work.
notes: Note(s): MS program priority.

name: Seminar in Physiological Psychology
description: An advanced consideration of the neurophysiological correlates of behavior.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): PSYC 129 (or equivalent).

name: Clinical Psychopharmacology
description: Prepares counseling professionals to understand aspects of drug use, mechanisms of change and clinical outcomes.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): PSYC 126 or equivalent.

name: Seminar in Cognitive Psychology
description: Theories and current research in cognitive psychology with emphasis on components of cognitive processing from pattern recognition to problem solving. Substantial emphasis on cognitive development and mechanisms of cognitive change.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing.

name: Psychology of Language
description: Selected topics in the cognitive mechanisms underlying spoken language processing. Topics include the perception, production, acquisition, and evolution of language.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): PSYC 135, PSYC 155, LING 101, or LING 161 (or equivalent).

name: Research Design and Applied Psychometrics
description: Advanced introduction to issues in psychological research (experimental, quasi-experimental and survey research), measurement, and survey construction (scale development, item analysis, reliability, validity).
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Instructor consent.

name: Field Work in Psychology
description: Supervised field work experience in outside agency settings. Open through consultation only to students in MS programs.
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 36 units.

name: Field Work in Industrial/Organizational Psychology
description: Supervised experience applying psychological and organizational theory and practice in business, industrial and other organizational settings.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Instructor consent.

name: Social Psychology Seminar
description: Theoretical and practical approaches to the understanding of human behavior within a social context.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): PSYC 154 (or equivalent).

name: Seminar in Learning
description: Current problems in learning with primary emphasis on learning theory.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): PSYC 155 (or equivalent).

name: Seminar in Perception
description: Selected issues in visual sensation and perception. Topics include the perception of color, form, depth and motion. Emphasis on the relationship of perception to sensory physiology.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): PSYC 158 (or equivalent).

name: Methods of Psychotherapy
description: Survey of the theoretical background and practical application of various approaches to psychotherapy.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): PSYC 139.
notes: Note(s): MS program priority.

name: Crisis and Trauma Counseling
description: Advanced course on trauma including strategies for assessing, managing, short and long term- treatment for acute and chronic stress reactions. Empirically supported risk and protective factors, and evidence-based treatments are covered. Resilience, personal, multidisciplinary, and community perspectives are emphasized.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): PSYC 203A and Graduate Standing in MS Psychology program

name: Seminar in Industrial and Organizational Psychology
description: Psychological theory, research and practice in organizations. Topics emphasized include motivation, job satisfaction, communication, leadership, group processes, decision-making, conflict, cooperation, power and organization development and change.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Instructor consent.
satisfies: Satisfies GWAR: Graduation Writing Assessment Requirement.
notes: Note(s): MS I/O program priority. This course satisfies graduate-level GWAR in this master’s program.

name: Seminar in Personnel Psychology
description: In-depth introduction to relevant methodology, research, applications and issues. Topics include legal issues in personnel, test validation, selection, job analysis, performance appraisal and training and development.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Instructor consent.
notes: Note(s): MS I/O program priority.

name: Training and Development in Organizations
description: Course will address classic, current, and future issues in training and development. Topics covered include theories of learning, needs assessment, training methodology, program evaluation, management development, and trends that may influence future training and development programs.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Instructor consent.

name: Seminar in Human Factors
description: Data and theory of sensory and cognitive psychology and their application to the design of systems used by humans.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): PSYC 135 and PSYC 158 (or equivalent).

name: Professional Issues in I/O Psychology
description: Address topics and issues faced by I/O psychologists working within organizational settings. Review and analysis of research regarding the application of psychological theory, concepts, and research methodologies. Evaluation and discussion of early career-related ethical issues and professional challenges and strategies.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): PSYC 270 and graduate standing in MS I/O Psychology program
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 6 units.

name: Groups at Work
description: Group process and performance, types of work groups and tasks, group development (norms, roles and strategies), group leadership approaches and skills, decision-making, team building, high performing and self managing teams.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Instructor consent.

name: General Seminar
description: Current psychological literature in selected fields and the development of a specific topic by the student.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Undergraduate major in psychology (or equivalent).
satisfies: Satisfies GWAR: Graduation Writing Assessment Requirement.
notes: Note(s): This course satisfies graduate-level GWAR in this master’s program.

name: Method and Design for Applied Research
description: Development and management of applied research programs based on contributions of psychological research and methodology. Criticizing existing and proposed research. Reporting and communicating research results.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): PSYC 18 or PSYC 120A; STAT 95 and STAT 115.
notes: Note(s): MS program priority.

name: Organizational Development
description: Theory and practice of organization development, including systems thinking; action research; organization assessment and diagnosis; survey development and feedback; individual, group, inter-group and organization-wide interventions; consultant roles; and ethics of practice in organizations.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Instructor consent.

name: Special Problems
description: Advanced work in areas not covered in any regular course offering. Course is repeatable for a maximum of four units.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Instructor consent.
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 6 units.

name: Master’s Thesis
description: Five units required for the M.A.; six units for the M.S.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Advancement to candidacy for the MA or MS degree and thesis chair permission.

name: Culminating Experience Supervision
description: Continued work on thesis or project unless concurrently enrolled in another SJSU course
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Outstanding RP grade in a preceding semester in a project or thesis class
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 16 units.
notes: Note(s): No Degree Credit.

name: Creating a Meaningful Life
description: Study how a meaningful life relates to the freedom to pursue happiness. Examines personal, social, and cultural bases for a creative and successful lifestyle. Learn to recognize and foster creative potential for lifelong personal growth, meaningful rewards, and leisure enjoyment.
satisfies: Satisfies E: Human Understanding & Development.

name: Human Life Span
description: Emphasizes growth and development of the individual from conception to death - perspective on biological, cultural, sociological and psychological changes and continuities during the human life span. Special attention will be given to socioeconomic status, gender and ethic variations.
satisfies: Satisfies D: Social Sciences (formerly GE Area D3).
crosslist: Cross-listed with PH 15. Public Health and Recreation is responsible for scheduling.
sustainability: Sustainability Related - SDG 3: Good Health and Well-Being

name: Foundations of Recreation Parks & Tourism
description: Field of parks and recreation; history of development of the recreation profession; survey of recreation and leisure services.

name: The Outdoor Recreation Experience
description: Students will explore, understand, and experience firsthand the value,meaning, and benefits of a variety of outdoor recreation activities. Socio-cultural and ecological systems will be examined as they relate to the delivery of outdoor recreation experiences in both the public and private sector.
sustainability: Sustainability Related - SDG 11: Sustainable Cities and Communities

name: Event Planning
description: Principles of event planning with emphasis on development and integration of operational strategies in recreation and hospitality management. Application of programming techniques and exploration of career opportunities in event management.

name: Writing Workshop
description: Developing and enhancing written communication skills in the recreation and leisure profession in the following areas: scientific/technical writing, administrative writing, public-relations-related writing and funding proposals.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): A3 or equivalent second semester composition course (with a grade of C- or better); completion of core GE; and upper division standing. Allowed Declared Majors: Recreation and Hospitality Management. Or Graduate or Postbaccalaureate level.
satisfies: Satisfies Writing in the Disciplines (WID).
notes: Note(s): Must be passed with C or better to satisfy the CSU Graduation Writing Assessment Requirement (GWAR).

name: Leisure, Life and Contemporary Society
description: Explore conceptual foundations of play, recreation and leisure and their importance in physical, social, psychological and spiritual development across the lifespan. Assess the roles of existing services in enhancing quality of life across social, cultural, economic and environmental realms.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing.
sustainability: Sustainability Related - SDG 11: Sustainable Cities and Communities

name: Leisure, Culture, and Identity
description: Perspectives of leisure as a source of self-expression and social control related to cultural beliefs, values, and practices and institutionalized social systems. Observation, analysis and critique of history and social structures, leisure and culture, and personal opportunities for change.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Completion of Core General Education and upper division standing are prerequisites to all SJSU studies courses. Completion of, or co-registration in, 100W is strongly recommended.
satisfies: Satisfies SJSU Studies S: Self, Society & Equality in U.S.
sustainability: Sustainability Related - SDG 11: Sustainable Cities and Communities

name: Foundations of Recreation Therapy
description: Fundamentals of the profession; history, delivery models, theory and practice of Recreation Therapy as a treatment modality for persons whose functional abilities are impaired. Exposure to ADA facility assessment, inclusion, and impact of social attitudes through didactic and experiential learning.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing.
sustainability: Sustainability Related - SDG 11: Sustainable Cities and Communities

name: Recreation Program Planning
description: Learn to plan and implement programs and events for diverse individual, group and community recreation experiences using contemporary needs assessment, outcomes oriented goal setting, program/event selection, leadership techniques and evaluation tools.

name: Planning and Managing Rec Areas & Facil
description: Content includes legal principles and risk management, as well as fundamentals of facility design and preventive maintenance in recreation, park, and tourism settings. This is a problem-based learning course, including case study, problem solving, project applications, and working with stakeholders.
sustainability: Sustainability Related - SDG 8: Decent Work and Economic Growth

name: Principles of Recreation and Park Admin
description: In the context of leadership roles and responsibilities in the field of recreation and park administration, course examines issues related to the organization and administration of human resources, finances, areas and facilities, programs, risk management, and liability.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Upper Division Standing
sustainability: Sustainability Related - SDG 8: Decent Work and Economic Growth

name: Spec Interventions in RT:Aquatic Therapy
description: Develop in-depth knowledge and skills related to the facilitation and supervision of a complex Recreation Therapy intervention. Includes equipment use, clinical application of each aspect of the activity or equipment, contraindications, safety, facilitation techniques, costs, industry standards, and evidence-based practices.
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 3 units.

name: Spec Inter in RT: Behavior Interventions
description: Theory and practice of interventions that positively affect healthy behaviors. Implementing prevention strategies including activity modification, assessment of harmful or disruptive behaviors, and identifying cause and effect relationships. Learn and practice teaching appropriate behaviors, increasing appropriate behaviors, decreasing inappropriate behaviors.
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 2 units.

name: Spec Inter in RT: Adventure Tx
description: Theoretical, hard, and soft skills related to adventure therapy interventions. Demonstrate skill development through facilitation. Learn diverse interventions and clinical application, modification, contraindications, and safety precautions for each based on psychiatric diagnosis served.
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 2 units.

name: Festivals and Community Special Events
description: Principles and applications for effective management of festivals, fairs and community special events; including planning, marketing, financing, evaluating, logistics, consumer behavior, corporate sponsorship, licensing agreements, risk management, and sustainable practices.
sustainability: Sustainability Related - SDG 8: Decent Work and Economic Growth

name: Natural and Cultural Resource Interpretation in Recreation and Parks
description: Explore the interpretive approach to communicating value and vision of nature, outdoor recreation and tourism sites. Gain skills to develop and conduct activities such as guided walks, interpretive programs and fireside chats. Learn fundamentals of creating interpretive media such as brochures, displays, and exhibits as well as e-media.
sustainability: Sustainability Related - SDG 11: Sustainable Cities and Communities

name: Biofeedback Principles and Practices
description: Conceptual and historical review of Biofeedback theory and practice. Experiential engagement with software, instrumentation, data interpretation and personal reflection. Assessment, treatment, evaluation, and case studies applied to medical and non-medical practices.

name: For-Profit Enterprises in Recreation
description: Development of knowledge and skills relating to the variety and types of for-profit recreation enterprises, including planning for and management of commercial ventures, development of corporate identity and market niche, and forecasting of trends and shifts in consumer culture.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing.

name: Non-Profit Leadership & Management
description: Introduction to the historical and philosophical foundations of the Non-Profit sector. Provides a basic understanding of key issues in managing contemporary nonprofit organizations including: organizational behavior; board development; fund-raising; boundary-spanning skills; and developing leadership skills for social innovation and entrepreneurship.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Upper Division Standing.

name: Youth Development and Services
description: Surveys the field of youth development, its historical roots, sociocultural and psychological development, and contemporary innovations. Develop knowledge of the institutional and programmatic factors that lead to positive developmental outcomes for youth in leisure and human service organizations.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Upper Division Standing

name: Outdoor Recreation Systems
description: Overview of outdoor recreation in the United States. Study of the historic, social, economic and political factors influencing natural resource protection. Includes a survey of organizations that manage visitors and protected areas to provide quality outdoor recreation experiences.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Upper Division Standing.
sustainability: Sustainability Related - SDG 15: Life on Land

name: Principles of Sustainable Travel and Tourism
description: Examination of travel and tourism as it relates to tourist motivations, hospitality and destination management. The impact of tourism on the physical, cultural and economic environment.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing.

name: Sustainable Recreation & Ecotourism
description: Course examines cultural, ethical, environmental and social science issues, and uses applied research methods to achieve competence in making programmatic and resource management decisions for recreational and tourism purposes.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing
sustainability: Sustainability Focused - SDG 8: Decent Work and Economic Growth

name: Sustainable Recreation & Ecotourism: International Experience
description: Course examines cultural, ethical, environmental and social science issues, and uses applied research methods to achieve competence in making programmatic and resource management decisions for recreational and tourism purposes.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing.

name: Evaluation and Research in Recreation
description: Students will learn about the systematic process for evaluation or research. The course focuses on three main areas: Criteria and research questions, evidence and data (data collection and data analysis), and judgment and interpretation. The course is for students interested in basic information about systematic inquiry using evaluation and research design, data collection and analysis, and data reporting.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): RECL 90, RECL 100W, RECL 110

name: Practicum in Recreation Therapy
description: Supervised 100 hour competency-based field learning in approved health agency (e.g., hospital, community health, municipal). Learning exposes the learner to different populations, interventions, terminology, resources. Learner will observe job task skills, apply knowledge, and gain abilities of Recreation Therapy practice.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): RECL 90

name: Pre-Intern Workshop
description: Introduces and prepares upper division majors for senior internship. Includes career goal clarification, resume development and interviewing through both workshops and online delivery.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): RECL 90, RECL 100W, RECL 110.

name: Internship in Recreation
description: Supervised 40-hour per week internship (minimum of 12 weeks) in one of a variety of approved agencies (leisure services, park and recreation, or tourism/commercial recreation).
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing; RECL 136, RECL 160, RECL 170A.

name: Internship in Recreation Therapy
description: Supervised 40-hour per week internship (minimum 15 weeks, 600 hours) occurring in approved health agencies. Supervisor must have a valid CTRS credential. Student develop competencies as identified in the NCTRC Job Task Analysis and ATRA Standards of Practice.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): RECL 112, RECL 170A, RECL 187, RECL 193, RECL 197, RECL 198, and RECL 199.

name: Individual Studies
description: Individual work investigating special topics/problems through research, applied projects, and/or field experiences. Assessment by project(s) and/or paper(s).
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing, supervising instructor approval, and department chair consent.
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 4 units.

name: Directed Reading
description: Directed reading in journals and books by authorities in Hospitality, Recreation, Tourism and related fields. Assessment by project(s) and/or paper(s).
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing, supervising instructor approval, and department chair consent.

name: Leisure, Recreation and Aging
description: Theory and practice related to the role of leisure services in maximizing the quality of life for older adults. Interrelationship of leisure and other supportive services for older adults in community and institutional settings.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing.
crosslist: Cross-listed with GERO 185. Public Health and Recreation is responsible for scheduling.

name: Leisure Education in Recreation Therapy
description: Overview of leisure education as it is used both in medical and non-medical settings to improve functioning and wellbeing among diverse clientele. Students will learn historical, philosophical, and contemporary conceptual foundations, evidence-based and practical applications to service delivery.

name: International Program Studies
description: Study Abroad and Away transfer credit course. Study Abroad and Away provides students the opportunity to study abroad on long term programs (Exchange Programs, CSU International Programs, and International Student Exchange Programs) and short-term programs (Faculty-Led Programs and Summer School Abroad Programs) for academic credit, offering Alternative Break Programs for cultural immersion, and designing other globally focused opportunities. This course is designated as a placeholder course for Study Abroad and Away programs.

name: RT Interventions for People with Physical Conditions
description: Theoretical foundations, research, and evidenced based Recreation Therapy interventions for persons with physical, intellectual, and developmental disabilities and other chronic conditions. Focuses on rehabilitation, community reintegration, day programs, and inclusion.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing
sustainability: Sustainability Focused - SDG 11: Sustainable Cities and Communities

name: Recreation Therapy in Mental Health
description: Application of theory, models, concepts and facilitation processes used in Recreation Therapy and related professions for people with mental health conditions. Experiential learning and facilitation of leisure education, clinical interventions, and behavioral change processes used in medical and non-medical settings.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing and RECL 112.
sustainability: Sustainability Focused - SDG 3: Good Health and Well-Being

name: Rec Therapy Assessment and Documentation
description: Clinical procedures utilized in Recreation Therapy whereby habilitation/rehabilitation is the primary goal; client assessment, development of behavioral objectives and treatment plans, evaluation, documentation, medical terminology, and charting procedures are covered. Extensive skill development regarding critique and development of assessment tools.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing.

name: Advanced Practices in Recreation Therapy
description: The application and examination of concepts, techniques, research, and legal issues utilized by advanced practitioners and managers. Includes trends and issues related to clinical supervision, reimbursement, quality improvement, legislation, comprehensive program design, and applied research that produces evidenced based practice.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): RECL 112.

name: Elementary Hebrew
description: Basic structure of the language in the context of culture.
crosslist: Cross-listed with HEBR 10A / JWSS 10A. World Languages and Literatures is responsible for scheduling.

name: Elementary Hebrew
description: Basic structure of the language in the context of culture.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): HEBR 10A (or equivalent).
crosslist: Cross-listed with HEBR 10B / JWSS 10B. World Languages and Literatures is responsible for scheduling.

name: Intermediate Hebrew
description: Developing speaking skills.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): HEBR 10A and HEBR 10B (or equivalent).
crosslist: Cross-listed with HEBR 15A / JWSS 15A. World Languages and Literatures is responsible for scheduling.

name: Intermediate Hebrew
description: Developing speaking skills.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): HEBR 10A and HEBR 10B (or equivalent).
crosslist: Cross-listed with HEBR 15B / JWSS 15B. World Languages and Literatures is responsible for scheduling.

name: Gods, Guns, Gurus, Grails-World Religion
description: Survey of major world religions, east and west, past and present. Structure and patterns of faith manifest in sacred texts, institutions, rituals, central figures and movements.
satisfies: Satisfies C2: Humanities.

name: Bible History and Literature
description: The Bible in context of its history, literary sources and as a reflection of Jewish and Christian traditions. Motifs and themes in light of their original audience, historic usage and contemporary development.
satisfies: Satisfies C2: Humanities.
crosslist: Cross-listed with HUM 90 / JWSS 90 / MDES 90. Humanities is responsible for scheduling.

name: International Program Studies
description: Study Abroad and Away transfer credit course. Study Abroad and Away provides students the opportunity to study abroad on long term programs (Exchange Programs, CSU International Programs, and International Student Exchange Programs) and short-term programs (Faculty-Led Programs and Summer School Abroad Programs) for academic credit, offering Alternative Break Programs for cultural immersion, and designing other globally focused opportunities. This course is designated as a placeholder course for Study Abroad and Away programs.

name: Death, Dying and Religions
description: Is death the end or the beginning? Learn how people integrate the physical, emotional, psychological, and spiritual dimensions of living and dying. Examine religious teachings and practices for making death personally meaningful, socially significant, or even politically powerful.
satisfies: Satisfies E: Human Understanding & Development.
crosslist: Cross-listed with GERO 99 / HUM 99. Humanities is responsible for scheduling.

name: Writing in the Humanities & Interdisciplinary Arts
description: Advanced workshop in composition and reading for the critical and comparative study of the humanities and interdisciplinary arts. Students explore and practice the thinking and writing skills that help us communicate insight, critique, interpretation, description, and analysis of arts, literature, history, and culture, including expository writing and library research. Readings and objects of study include a range of topics and at least two different art forms.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): A3 or equivalent second-semester composition course (with a grade of C- or better); completion of core GE; and upper-division standing. Or Graduate or Postbaccalaureate level.
satisfies: Satisfies Writing in the Disciplines (WID).
crosslist: Cross-listed with AMS 100W / HUM 100W. Humanities is responsible for scheduling.
notes: Note(s): Must be passed with C or better to satisfy the CSU Graduation Writing Assessment Requirement (GWAR).

name: Advanced Hebrew
description: Readings, grammar, discussion and composition.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Four semesters of college Hebrew (or equivalent).
crosslist: Cross-listed with HEBR 102A / JWSS 102A. World Languages and Literatures is responsible for scheduling.

name: Advanced Hebrew
description: Readings, grammar, discussion and composition.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): 12 units of college Hebrew (or equivalent).
crosslist: Cross-listed with HEBR 102B / JWSS 102B. World Languages and Literatures is responsible for scheduling.

name: Asian Philosophy
description: Philosophical examination of Confucianism, Daoism, Buddhism and some other significant movements of thought originated in Asia. Comparison with Western philosophy.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Completion of Core General Education and upper division standing are prerequisites to all SJSU studies courses. Completion of, or co-registration in, 100W is strongly recommended.
satisfies: Satisfies SJSU Studies V: Cultures and Global Understanding.
crosslist: Cross-listed with ASIA 104 / PHIL 104. Philosophy is responsible for scheduling.

name: Philosophy of Religion
description: Philosophical issues regarding the existence of a supreme being, evil, mysticism, miracles, reincarnation, faith, the possibility of enlightenment, and the connection between religion and morality.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): 3 units of philosophy or upper division standing.
crosslist: Cross-listed with PHIL 109. Philosophy is responsible for scheduling.

name: Special Topics in Jewish Studies
description: Special Topics in Jewish Studies. Topics vary and will be announced each semester. Repeatable for credit under different subtitles. Repeatable for credit when topic changes.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing.
crosslist: Cross-listed with HIST 111 / HUM 111 / JWSS 111. History is responsible for scheduling.

name: Legacy of Asia
description: Interdisciplinary focus on continuity and change in China and India as these ancient civilizations responded to challenges throughout their history.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Completion of Core General Education, and upper-division standing are prerequisites to all SJSU studies courses. Completion of, or co-registration in, 100W is strongly recommended.
satisfies: Satisfies SJSU Studies V: Cultures and Global Understanding.
crosslist: Cross-listed with ANTH 114 / ASIA 114 / HUM 114. Humanities is responsible for scheduling.

name: Censors and Icons: Arts and Religion
description: Study of interactions between arts and world religions, using paradigmatic examples (e.g. Eastern Orthodox icons, Muslim architecture, Zen Buddhist calligraphy, Hindu Vedic chant, Biblical poetry) and contemporary developments (e.g. Evangelical Christian films, New Age music, religious themes in literature).

name: Magic, Science and Religion
description: Exploring the ways in which people have attempted to gain mastery over the natural and supernatural worlds beginning with prehistoric times and concluding with modern day society and the contemporary world.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Completion of Core General Education, and upper-division standing are prerequisites to all SJSU studies courses. Completion of, or co-registration in, 100W is strongly recommended.
satisfies: Satisfies SJSU Studies V: Cultures and Global Understanding.
crosslist: Cross-listed with ANTH 122. Humanities is responsible for scheduling.
sustainability: Sustainability Related - SDG 16: Peace, Justice and Strong Institutions

name: Gender, Sexuality, and Religion
description: Women’s roles and gendered categories within diverse religions. Feminist critiques, reforms, and creations of religious institutions. The political and feminist dimensions of women’s religious experience. Understanding the roles of sexuality in religion.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Upper-division standing or instructor consent.
crosslist: Cross-listed with WGSS 131. Humanities is responsible for scheduling.
sustainability: Sustainability Related - SDG 5: Gender Equality

name: Religion Film & Media
description: Depictions of religion, religions, religious behavior, and religious propaganda in film and media. Exploring these from several perspectives, (e.g. emic and etic, cross-national, aesthetic) and examining the murky problem of “the truth” in the depiction of religious and spiritual experience.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Upper-division standing or instructor consent.
crosslist: Cross-listed with CA 134 / HUM 134. Humanities is responsible for scheduling.

name: Introduction to Black Religion
description: Analysis of formation and development of African American religious ideas and institutions (i.e., Christianity, Islam, Judaism) in the Black community and their effect on the African American personality.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing.
crosslist: Cross-listed with AFAM 137. African American Studies is responsible for scheduling.

name: Contemporary Buddhism and its Roots
description: Teachings of Gautama, the Buddha and ways in which those teachings were modified in forms of Buddhism that followed: Therevada in southeast Asia and Mahayana in East Asia.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Upper-division standing or instructor consent.
crosslist: Cross-listed with ASIA 142 / HUM 142. Humanities is responsible for scheduling.

name: Chinese Traditions
description: Religious thought and practice of China’s three Great Traditions (Buddhism, Taoism and Confucianism) as well as China’s Little Tradition (Chinese folk religion). The role of these traditions within traditional Chinese culture and their relevance to the modern world, including China.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Upper-division standing or instructor consent.
crosslist: Cross-listed with ASIA 144 / HUM 144. Humanities is responsible for scheduling.

name: Middle Eastern Traditions
description: Introduction to the peoples and cultures of the Middle East through exploration of the cooperation, competition, conflict and dialogues between the ethnic, national, and religious communities of contemporary Middle Eastern countries.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Completion of Core General Education, and upper-division standing are prerequisites to all SJSU studies courses. Completion of, or co-registration in, 100W is strongly recommended.
satisfies: Satisfies SJSU Studies V: Cultures and Global Understanding.
crosslist: Cross-listed with ANTH 145 / MDES 145. Humanities is responsible for scheduling.

name: Religion and Anthropology
description: Comparative anthropological study of religious systems and world views; Anthropological theories concerning origin and evolution of religion; structure and function of ritual and myth; types of religious specialists.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): ANTH 11, ANTH 25 or instructor consent.
crosslist: Cross-listed with ANTH 148. Anthropology is responsible for scheduling.

name: Islam, Politics and the West
description: An in-depth look at the roots of Islamic tradition, law, politics, culture, and society. Emphasis on Islam’s growing global prominence; relations with the West; stereotypes and misconception, as well as the nature of the Islamic state.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Upper-division standing or instructor consent.
crosslist: Cross-listed with MDES 156 / POLS 156. Humanities is responsible for scheduling.

name: Religion and Political Controversy in the US
description: Contemporary problems (e.g., ecology, abortion, war, gender, sexuality and race) as interpreted by a diverse range of American ethno-religious groups.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Completion of Core General Education and upper division standing are prerequisites to all SJSU studies courses. Completion of, or co-registration in, 100W is strongly recommended.
satisfies: Satisfies SJSU Studies S: Self, Society & Equality in U.S.
sustainability: Sustainability Related - SDG 16: Peace, Justice and Strong Institutions

name: Individual Studies
description: A project.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Religious studies upper-division major or minor and coordinator consent.
crosslist: Cross-listed with MDES 180. Humanities is responsible for scheduling.

name: Directed Reading
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Religious studies upper-division major or minor and coordinator consent.
crosslist: Cross-listed with MDES 184. Humanities is responsible for scheduling.

name: Senior Seminar in Humanities
description: Readings, discussions and individual research projects relating to an interdisciplinary theme selected by the instructor.
prereqs: Pre/Corequisite(s): Upper-division Standing, Passage of WST. Any 100W class.
crosslist: Cross-listed with AMS 190 / HUM 190. Humanities is responsible for scheduling.

name: Religion in America
description: History of social and intellectual influence of religious groups, stressing their African-, Asian-, European-, Latin- and Native-American roots. Highlights contact between groups, immigration, religious diversity and syncretism.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Completion of Core General Education, and upper-division standing are prerequisites to all SJSU studies courses. Completion of, or co-registration in, 100W is strongly recommended.
satisfies: Satisfies SJSU Studies S: Self, Society & Equality in U.S.
crosslist: Cross-listed with HUM 191. Humanities is responsible for scheduling.

name: International Program Studies
description: Study Abroad and Away transfer credit course. Study Abroad and Away provides students the opportunity to study abroad on long term programs (Exchange Programs, CSU International Programs, and International Student Exchange Programs) and short-term programs (Faculty-Led Programs and Summer School Abroad Programs) for academic credit, offering Alternative Break Programs for cultural immersion, and designing other globally focused opportunities. This course is designated as a placeholder course for Study Abroad and Away programs.

name: The Art of Film
description: Study of the formal, aesthetic, historical, and cultural contexts of film as an art form. GE Area C1.
satisfies: Satisfies C1: Arts.

name: Introduction to Audio for Film & Television
description: Fundamentals of audio production in film and television settings.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Instructor Consent.

name: KSJS On-Air Operations
description: On-Air operation of campus radio station KSJS-FM, FCC, equipment, D.J. interview, sports; all activities and processes required for live broadcasting, music, public service and community service programming.

name: Introduction to Film & Television Production
description: Fundamentals of film and television production.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Instructor Consent

name: Film and Television Aesthetics
description: Theory of applied aesthetics in video, film, and new media based on an examination of fundamental image and sound production.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Instructor Consent

name: Introduction to Media
description: Analysis of the history and evolution of radio (audio) and television (video) in the U.S. Examination of programming, government regulation, advertising, networking, development of electronic media technologies and world media systems.

name: Introduction to Film History
description: The history and evolution of the motion picture from 1895 to 1945. Viewing of representative films, study and discussion of major world film movements, important directors, and key genres.

name: International Program Studies
description: Study Abroad and Away transfer credit course. Study Abroad and Away provides students the opportunity to study abroad on long term programs (Exchange Programs, CSU International Programs, and International Student Exchange Programs) and short-term programs (Faculty-Led Programs and Summer School Abroad Programs) for academic credit, offering Alternative Break Programs for cultural immersion, and designing other globally focused opportunities. This course is designated as a placeholder course for Study Abroad and Away programs.

name: Media and Culture
description: Critical survey of roles played by electronic media in shaping culture. Media institutions are examined regarding information they distribute, entertainment they provide and influence they bring. Analysis of media sources, messages and audiences.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Completion of Core General Education and upper division standing are prerequisites to all SJSU studies courses. Completion of, or co-registration in, 100W is strongly recommended.
satisfies: Satisfies SJSU Studies S: Self, Society & Equality in U.S.
sustainability: Sustainability Related - SDG 4: Quality Education

name: Alternative Cinema
description: Uses films from previously marginalized national cinemas from around the world as primary sources to teach students to appreciate, understand and compare diverse cultures. Introduces students to alternative modes of filmmaking and analysis.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Completion of Core General Education and upper division standing are prerequisites to all SJSU studies courses. Completion of, or co-registration in, 100W is strongly recommended.
satisfies: Satisfies SJSU Studies V: Cultures and Global Understanding.

name: Intermediate Audio for Film & Television
description: Techniques of audio production and post production for film and television settings.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): RTVF 20, RTVF 30, RTVF 31, upper division standing or instructor consent. No concurrent enrollment with prerequisites.

name: KSJS-FM Radio Activity
description: Student participation in radio with KSJS-FM. Activities supervised by area faculty. Open to all students whether lower division or upper-division standing. Repeatable, but only 6 units may be used for graduation.
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 6 units.

name: KSJS Station Operation & Mgmt
description: Structure and operation of non-commercial radio station KSJS-FM. Theory and practice of radio management, programming, production, public service, sales and engineering. Repeatable, but only 6 units may be used for graduation.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Appointment to KSJS management staff or instructor consent.

name: Advanced Audio Mixing
description: Postproduction sound, editing, sweetening, and mixing for the film and television industry. Through exploration and hands-on exercises - software and hardware are utilized for audio mixing and sweetening. Covers both the technology and the art of audio mixing to improve the final film and/or media product aesthetically and technically.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): RTVF 20 and RTVF 120

name: Intermediate Film & Television Production
description: Techniques of film and television production.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): RTVF 20, RTVF 30, and RTVF 31, upper division standing or instructor consent. No concurrent enrollment with prerequisites.

name: Post Production: Color Correction
description: Post production course with emphasis on color grading and correction of film and television production projects.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): RTVF 130 or instructor consent.

name: Post Production Editing & Delivery
description: Editing, post production and delivery techniques for film and television projects.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): RTVF 130 or instructor consent.

name: Introduction to Cinematography
description: First in-depth course in cinematography. Principles of motion picture photography explored through lecture, discussions, projects and screenings. Skills of the cinematographer developed by shooting exercises during and outside of class. Appreciation of the art of and technology of cinematography.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): RTVF 30 or Instructor consent.

name: Advanced Cinematography
description: Advanced, in-depth course in cinematography consisting of mostly hands-on practicum, with lectures as needed. Dramatic scenes are filmed in realistic production shooting situations, both in the studio and on location. Scripts to be photographed are selected by the professor and the students based on the challenges they present.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): RTVF 131A or Instructor consent. No concurrent enrollment with prerequisites.

name: Film and Television Production Management
description: Analysis of film and television organization and programming concepts, including production management, decision-making processes, technical script breakdown, and its relation to budgeting and finance.

name: RTVF Production: Special Projects
description: Principles, procedures and techniques used to produce an advanced-level radio, audio, television or film project. See department office for specific project information.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): RTVF 20, RTVF 30, upper division standing or instructor consent.
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 6 units.

name: Advanced Film & Television Production
description: Creation, production and direction of senior-level project utilizing cinematic language, advanced technical skills, directing talent, and narrative storytelling.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): RTVF 120, RTVF 130; Upper division standing or instructor consent.

name: Introduction to Screenwriting
description: Basic principles and practices in writing scripts for film and/or television.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): RTVF 020, RTVF 030 and TA 100W, upper division standing or instructor consent.

name: Advanced Screenwriting
description: Each student develops an original screenplay through several drafts in this workshop. Drawing on constructive feedback from classmates and instructor. The course focuses on dramatic structure, character and plot development as well as visual language of the screen.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): RTVF 160.

name: Creating and Writing the Television Series
description: Builds on a student’s previous narrative writing experience to provide an intensive study of creating and writing an original television series.  Modeling a television writer’s room, students study the narrative and dramatic requirements of developing a storyline and characters in the episodic form.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): RTVF 160 or consent of instructor.

name: Individual Studies
description: Directed study (special production or research projects) in specified fields not covered by offered courses.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Instructor Consent
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 6 units.

name: Modern Film History
description: The history and evolution of the motion picture after 1945. Viewing of representative films, study and discussion of major world film movements, important directors, and key genres.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): RTVF 82, upper division standing or instructor consent.

name: Critical Studies & Research in RTVF
description: Critical and scholarly inquiry into established and emerging areas of criticism, theory and research in RTVF studies. Production of scholarly criticism and research.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): RTVF 10, RTVF 80, Upper Division standing or instructor consent.

name: Special Topics in RTVF
description: Special topics in radio, television and film. Contact department office for specific topic information. Repeatable for up to 6 units when topic changes.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing. Open to all students lower division students with instructor consent.
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 6 units.

name: International Program Studies
description: Study Abroad and Away transfer credit course. Study Abroad and Away provides students the opportunity to study abroad on long term programs (Exchange Programs, CSU International Programs, and International Student Exchange Programs) and short-term programs (Faculty-Led Programs and Summer School Abroad Programs) for academic credit, offering Alternative Break Programs for cultural immersion, and designing other globally focused opportunities. This course is designated as a placeholder course for Study Abroad and Away programs.

name: RTVF Internships, Portfolio, Career Prep
description: Supervised internships with approved radio, television, film or media organizations. Written evaluation submitted by sponsor and student after field work. Repeatable for credit up to 6 units.
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 6 units.

name: Honors Program
description: Demanding project demonstrating student’s ability to do independent action and research. Written thesis or, in the case of the creative project, analysis and evaluation of the aesthetic problem; thesis to be defended orally by the student before a theatre arts staff committee. May be repeated once for credit.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Senior standing/3.0 GPA; by invitation only.
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 6 units.
crosslist: Cross-listed with TA 199H. Film and Theatre is responsible for scheduling.

name: Elementary Russian I
description: Elementary Level course that teaches the basics of Russian script and cursive, pronunciation patterns, grammar and sentence structure. Students are able to conduct everyday conversations, read simple texts and write short paragraphs on topics studied.
satisfies: Satisfies C2: Humanities.

name: Elementary Russian II
description: Second semester Elementary Level course. Basics of Russian pronunciation patterns, grammar and sentence structure in the context of culture. Students will be able to conduct everyday conversations, read simple texts and write short paragraphs on topics studied.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): RUSS 1A (or equivalent).
satisfies: Satisfies C2: Humanities.

name: Sustainability, Human Development, and the Earth
description: Introductory course examining the role and interaction of the natural world on the physiological, social, and psychological development of human beings within the context of the environmental, social, and academic community system.
satisfies: Satisfies E: Human Understanding & Development.
crosslist: Cross-listed with GEOL 5. Geology is responsible for scheduling.
sustainability: Sustainability Related - SDG 11: Sustainable Cities and Communities

name: Science Pedagogy for Learning Assistants
description: Learning Assistants (LAs) investigate how people learn and how to support learning as they are immersed in teaching roles in the San José community. Integrates educational theory, pedagogy, content, and practice by focusing on practical concerns and theoretical models of learning.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Instructor consent.

name: Classroom Experiences in Science Teaching
description: The goal of this hybrid online/face-to-face course is to provide students with the opportunity to complete their 45 hours of science teaching observation in California public schools while also reflecting on teaching and learning practices. The course will emphasize the multi-faceted aspects of the teaching profession and most importantly will provide a forum for sharing experiences with other students who are similarly placed. The course will fulfill pre-professional teaching observation experience required of most Single Subject Teacher Credential Programs.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Sophomore or upper division standing. Not available to Open University Students.

name: Student Teaching II - Classroom Teaching
description: Minimum 80-120 class hours of classroom, lab or field teaching in appropriate single subject, grades K-12 and related teaching activities/seminar.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): SCED 273 (Science Credential Candidates must complete SCED 273 with a grade of “B” or better, “B-” not accepted) and joint approval of the Science Education Program and the Secondary Education Department. Not available to Open University Students.

name: Student Teaching III - Classroom Teaching
description: Minimum 80-120 class hours of classroom, lab or field teaching in appropriate single subject, grades K-12 and related teaching activities/seminar.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): SCED 273 (Science Credential Candidates must complete SCED 273 with a grade of “B” or better, “B-” not accepted) and joint approval of the Science Education Program and the Secondary Education Department. Not available to Open University Students.
notes: Note(s): May be in different subject/school and will be at a different grade level.

name: Methods of Research
description: Introduction to techniques and procedures of scientific research. Each student is required to prepare and defend a working outline of a master’s thesis or project in his or her area of concentration.
notes: Note(s): Introductory course in statistics or equivalent recommended.

name: Theories and Practices in Science Education
description: Introduction to classic and cutting-edge learning theories in science education. Explore research-based understandings of science learning with implications for inquiry and practice. Emphasis on developing expertise in a science education area of interest and contextualizing questions and problems of teaching and learning in educational literature.
satisfies: Satisfies GWAR: Graduation Writing Assessment Requirement.
notes: Note(s): Teaching experience preferred. Must be taken during first year in program. This course satisfies graduate-level GWAR in this master’s program.

name: Science Education Data Analysis
description: Introduction to science education data analysis methods and techniques. Students will engage in both quantitative and qualitative data analysis.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Instructor consent required.

name: Advanced Natural Science
description: Selected topics in natural science or science education.

name: Secondary School Science
description: Designed to engage teacher candidates (TC) in the methods, learning theories, practices, and instructional and pedagogical approaches for teaching justice-centered science in secondary schools. TCs develop strategies, master techniques, and gain practice-based experience in the promotion of inclusive, inquiry-based classrooms. In addition, TCs learn to design equitable unit and lesson plans that build from young people’s experiences and sense making practices, engage in the Next Generation Science Standards (NGSS) and use technology to enhance the learning environment. Theory and practice, instructional techniques, and materials for science in the secondary schools.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): CSET Subtest I (test code 215) covers general science content and CSET Subtest II (test codes 217-220) select the subtest II that fits candidate’s area of concentration. Life Sciences (test code 217), Chemistry (test code 218), Earth and Space Sciences (test code 219), Physics (test code 220).

name: Seminar
description: Provides a format for the presentation and discussion of original work by faculty, guest investigators and graduate students.
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 6 units.

name: Science Education Research
description: Research in science education under the supervision of a faculty member associated with the science education program.
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 6 units.

name: Research
description: Project development for MS Science Education students, to be carried out under direct supervision of a faculty member and committee. Seminar presentation required upon final completion of project.
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 6 units.

name: Colloquium in Science Education
description: Resources and innovations for science curriculum development and instruction. An interface with people and facilities which can enhance Bay Area science instruction. California Teaching Performance Assessment (Cal TPA)  preparation and guidance.
notes: Note(s): Also open to experienced teachers.

name: Culminating Experience Supervision
description: Continued Work on Thesis
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Outstanding RP grade in a preceding semester in a project or thesis class.
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 16 units.
notes: Note(s): No Degree Credit.

name: Success in Science
description: Emphasis on development of study skills, time management, and personal growth needed to transition from high school to university. Orientation to SJSU policies and procedures; and degree and career options in science. Guest lecturers, peer advisors, and community building.
satisfies: Satisfies E: Human Understanding & Development.

name: Fundamentals of Leadership and Career Accelerator
description: This course is a foundational course designed to begin preparing students in their sophomore year or first year of transfer to SJSU to practice the leadership habits of mind and workplace skills needed to thrive in 21st century workplaces. Given the increasingly competitive, and globalized job marketplace, this course enables participants to cycle through rounds of interactive experiences and practice to acquire “hard” and “soft” skills needed to succeed. Students will apply these skills in real-life leadership situations and build meaningful networks of peers and adults, all while activating their personal assets and deepening their sense of self and community.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): ENGL 1A
crosslist: Cross-listed with UNVS 75. Science is responsible for scheduling.

name: Success as Transfer Students
description: Emphasis on development of study skills, time management, and personal growth needed to transition from community college to university. Orientation to SJSU policies and procedures; and degree and career options. Guest lecturers, peer advisors, and community building.

name: Leadership and Career Accelerator
description: Prepares students for the increasingly competitive, globalized job marketplace. Through online, peer learning, interactive experiences, and reflection, students build meaningful networks, discover their innate leadership, and cultivate the hard” and “soft” skills and habits of mind needed to thrive in twenty-first century workplaces and make positive impact through their careers upon graduation. Aimed at students in their sophomore or junior year or first year of transfer, though all students of all majors can participate.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): ENGL 1A or ENGL 1AS with a grade of “C-” or better or complete GE Area A2 with a grade of “C-” or better.
crosslist: Cross-listed with UNVS 101. Science is responsible for scheduling.
notes: Note(s): Why take UNVS 101?

name: Community Action/Community Service
description: A campus-wide service learning program with opportunities for direct involvement with local community services, both off campus and on campus. Weekly seminars held on campus or at the field site, plus four to six hours of community service work per week at the field site.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Completion of Core General Education and upper division standing are prerequisites to all SJSU studies courses. Completion of, or co-registration in, 100W is strongly recommended.
satisfies: Satisfies SJSU Studies S: Self, Society & Equality in U.S.
crosslist: Cross-listed with COMM 157SL / EDUC 157SL / ENGR 157SL / HA 157SL. Communication Studies is responsible for scheduling.
sustainability: Sustainability Related - SDG 11: Sustainable Cities and Communities

name: Individual Studies
description: Work, under guidance, in special fields. Repeatable: Repeatable for credit.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Instructor consent.

name: Directed Reading
description: Assigned readings of selected books, journals and special papers chosen to fill gaps in training or to introduce new fields. Evaluation through weekly reports and conferences.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Instructor consent.

name: Master’s Thesis
description: Thesis development for Plan A MA Natural Science students, to be carried out under direct supervision of a faculty member and committee. Seminar presentation required upon final completion of thesis. Repeatable: Repeatable for credit.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Advancement to candidacy for the master’s degree and selection of a thesis committee.
repeatable: Course may be repeated for credit for up to 6 units.

name: Introduction to Social Welfare and Social Work
description: Social welfare institutions and the social work profession: its development, knowledge base, value system and specific areas of direct practice.

name: Writing Workshop
description: Focuses on developing and enhancing writing and presentation skills vital to the social work profession in the following areas: research, grant writing, clinical documentation, and administration.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): A3 or equivalent second semester composition course (with a grade of C- or better); completion of core GE; and upper division standing. Or Graduate or Postbaccalaureate level.
satisfies: Satisfies Writing in the Disciplines (WID).
notes: Note(s): Must be passed with C or better to satisfy the CSU Graduation Writing Assessment Requirement (GWAR).

name: Social Work and Environmental Justice
description: Explores evidence-based social work practice and policies to respond to natural and human-influenced domestic and international environmental issues. Provides a social work perspective to environmental issues and its impact on diverse vulnerable populations.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Completion of Core General Education and upper division standing are prerequisites to all SJSU studies courses. Completion of, or co-registration in, 100W is strongly recommended.
satisfies: Satisfies SJSU Studies Area R: Earth, Environment, and Sustainability

name: Understanding Diversity Through a Transcultural Lens
description: Enhances understanding of diversity by examining multiple aspects of human expression in cultures and societies outside the US. Using the Transcultural Perspective, students will deepen their knowledge and appreciation of various cultures.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Completion of Core General Education and upper division standing are prerequisites to all SJSU studies courses. Completion of, or co-registration in, 100W is strongly recommended.
satisfies: Satisfies SJSU Studies Area V: Cultures and Global Understanding

name: Aging and Society
description: Social, psychological and physiological aging processes. Implications of aging for individuals and societies, with emphasis on issues related to diversity, equality and gender in the U.S.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Completion of Core General Education and upper division standing are prerequisites to all SJSU studies courses. Completion of, or co-registration in, 100W is strongly recommended.
satisfies: Satisfies SJSU Studies S: Self, Society & Equality in U.S.
crosslist: Cross-listed with GERO 107 / PH 107. Social Work is responsible for scheduling.
sustainability: Sustainability Focused - SDG 10: Reduced Inequalities

name: Foundations of Social Work Practice
description: Introduction to the history, mission, values, skills and knowledge base of generalist social work practice within a transcultural perspective. Focus on social work practice with emphasis on those populations-at-risk who are disenfranchised and marginalized.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Junior standing, Social Work majors only.
sustainability: Sustainability Focused - SDG 1: No Poverty

name: Generalist Social Work Practice I
description: Knowledge, values and skills for generalist social work practice utilizing problem-solving methods with systems of all sizes. Focus on developing professional relationships, defining issues, communication skills, collecting data and assessing individuals from diverse backgrounds interacting with their environments.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): SCWK 110, SCWK 120, SCWK 130, SCWK 140. Allowed Declared Majors: Social Work.

name: Generalist Practice II
description: Knowledge, values and skills for generalist social work practice with emphasis on families, groups, organizations and communities. Focus on transactions to optimize social well-being and empowerment of individuals, families and communities utilizing strengths and transcultural perspectives.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): SCWK 111 (with a grade of “C” or better).

name: Social Welfare Institutions and Policies I
description: Development of social work as a profession, including mission, values, ethics. Development and changes in the philosophy, legislative base and structures for social services as these affect social and economic justice and impact health and well-being.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Junior standing and Social Work majors only.
sustainability: Sustainability Focused - SDG 1: No Poverty

name: Social Welfare Institutions and Policies II
description: Methodology and framework for analyzing social policy and understanding institutional discrimination, particularly related to populations-at-risk and other disenfranchised groups. Political and organizational processes to influence policy development.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): SCWK 120, junior standing, Social Work majors only.
sustainability: Sustainability Focused - SDG 1: No Poverty

name: Human Behavior in the Social Environment I
description: Theories and knowledge of bio-psycho-social development from birth to old age. The dynamics of interacting social systems and culture on human development. Theories and research on risk and resilience. Human diversity and populations-at-risk emphasized.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Junior standing, Social Work majors only.
sustainability: Sustainability Focused - SDG 1: No Poverty

name: Human Behavior in the Social Environment II
