Study Abroad and Away provides students the opportunity to study abroad on long term programs (Exchange Programs, CSU International Programs, and International Student Exchange Programs) and short-term programs (Faculty-Led Programs and Summer School Abroad Programs) for academic credit, offering Alternative Break Programs for cultural immersion, and designing other globally focused opportunities. This course is designated as a placeholder course for Study Abroad and Away programs.

name: Capstone Studio: Community Planning
description: Through fieldwork and laboratory assignments, the student applies theories and techniques of analysis to identify the assets, problems, and opportunities of an urban community.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Instructor consent.

name: Planning Report Preliminary Proposal
description: Advanced research and proposal writing. Students conduct background research and develop a preliminary research proposal that demonstrates their capacity to do independent research, analysis, and writing about a complex planning problem.

name: Special Study: Planning Report
description: Advanced research and report writing. Students develop a plan and complete the initial research to write a planning report that demonstrates their capacity to do independent research, analysis, and writing about a complex planning problem.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Graduate Adviser approval. Passage of URBP 297P with a grade of B or better.

name: Special Study: Planning Report Completion
description: Advanced individual research and report writing. Students work with a faculty advisor to complete a professional planning report that demonstrates their capacity to do independent research, analysis, and writing about a complex planning problem.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Passage of URBP 298A and Graduate Student Advisor approval.

name: Elementary Vietnamese
description: Basic skills and structure of the language in the context of culture.
satisfies: Satisfies C2: Humanities.

name: Elementary Vietnamese
description: Continuation of VIET 1A. Basic skills and structure of the language in the context of culture.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): VIET 1A or equivalent.
satisfies: Satisfies C2: Humanities.

name: Women, Gender, and Sexuality Studies
description: Interdisciplinary introduction to core concepts and analytical tools addressing the diversity of human experience cross cut by gender, sexuality, embodiment, and class location. Students will become familiar with key contemporary and historical debates in both global and local contexts.
satisfies: Satisfies D: Social Sciences (formerly GE Area D1).

name: Women of Color in the U.S.
description: Constructs knowledge of the historical and contemporary experience of women of color. Focuses on Native American, African American, Latina, and Asian American women and considers contributions they have made to the shaping of the nation.
satisfies: Satisfies D: Social Sciences (formerly GE Area D2).
crosslist: Cross-listed with AAS 20. Sociology and Interdisciplinary Social Sciences is responsible for scheduling.
sustainability: Sustainability Focused - SDG 5: Gender Equality

name: International Program Studies
description: Study Abroad and Away transfer credit course. Study Abroad and Away provides students the opportunity to study abroad on long term programs (Exchange Programs, CSU International Programs, and International Student Exchange Programs) and short-term programs (Faculty-Led Programs and Summer School Abroad Programs) for academic credit, offering Alternative Break Programs for cultural immersion, and designing other globally focused opportunities. This course is designated as a placeholder course for Study Abroad and Away programs.

name: Sex, Power, and Politics
description: Multidisciplinary introduction to traditional and new images, roles, experiences, ethnic similarities and differences, and contemporary problems of American women.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Completion of Core General Education and upper division standing are prerequisites to all SJSU studies courses. Completion of, or co-registration in, 100W is strongly recommended.
satisfies: Satisfies SJSU Studies S: Self, Society & Equality in U.S.
sustainability: Sustainability Focused - SDG 5: Gender Equality

name: The Global Study of Women
description: Survey of literature on the interaction of gender and forces of globalism.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Completion of Core General Education and upper division standing are prerequisites to all SJSU studies courses. Completion of, or co-registration in, 100W is strongly recommended.
satisfies: Satisfies SJSU Studies V: Cultures and Global Understanding.
sustainability: Sustainability Focused - SDG 5: Gender Equality

name: Psychology of Women
description: Sex-role development of women in terms of bio-social factors involved in intellectual and personal-emotional functions. Psychological theory and research.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): PSYC 1.
crosslist: Cross-listed with PSYC 107. Psychology is responsible for scheduling.

name: Women in the Global Economy
description: Women’s participation in the economy, US and internationally: paid employment, consumption, subsistence labor, reproduction, volunteerism. It connects daily life activities with international economic trends, with particular attention to race, class, implications for families and strategies for equity.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): WGSS 10, WGSS 20, WGSS 101 or instructor consent.
sustainability: Sustainability Focused - SDG 5: Gender Equality

name: Politics of Mothering and Reproduction
description: Explore contemporary definitions and values inscribed in issues pertaining to mothers and reproduction. It will be built upon three literatures: discourses of law and legality, discourses of nature and science, and discourses based in feminist thinking.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Upper Division standing or instructor consent.
sustainability: Sustainability Focused - SDG 5: Gender Equality

name: Special Topics in Women’s Studies
description: Focus announced in the schedule of classes. Repeatable for credit with program coordinator approval.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): WGSS 10, WGSS 20, WGSS 101 or instructor consent.

name: Philosophy and Feminism
description: A philosophical examination of writings that deal with issues of special concern to women, with emphasis on feminist writings.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): 3 units of philosophy or upper division standing.
crosslist: Cross-listed with PHIL 121. Philosophy is responsible for scheduling.
sustainability: Sustainability Focused - SDG 5: Gender Equality

name: Gender, Sexuality, and Religion
description: Women’s roles and gendered categories within diverse religions. Feminist critiques, reforms, and creations of religious institutions. The political and feminist dimensions of women’s religious experience. Understanding the roles of sexuality in religion.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Upper-division standing or instructor consent.
crosslist: Cross-listed with RELS 131. Humanities is responsible for scheduling.
sustainability: Sustainability Related - SDG 5: Gender Equality

name: Trans Studies: Identities, Embodiment, & Politics
description: Introduction to the field of transgender studies. A look at the present moment of transgender experience and embodiment through the lenses of history, science, institutions, cultural production, and activism. Explores the past and future of trans, transgender, intersex, nonbinary, genderqueer, and transsexual people. Working with the assertion that “the personal is political” that emerged from Feminist of Color scholarship, course is also attentive to questions of race, ethnicity, class, sexuality, legal status, and ability, while introducing transgender identity and politics.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Upper Division standing or instructor consent.

name: Black Women’s Writing
description: Comparative analysis of the meaning and developmental stages of womanhood for women of African ancestry as depicted in the fiction of women of African ancestry. Emphasis on the role of race and culture in shaping contemporary conceptions of womanhood among Black women.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing or instructor consent.
crosslist: Cross-listed with AFAM 156 / ENGL 156. African American Studies is responsible for scheduling.

name: Queering Gender, Race, and Class
description: Queer analysis of race and class diversity; social, political, and economic hierarchies of race, class, and gender in the U.S. Topics may include sexuality, racism, LGBT experience, the welfare system.

name: Sexualities and the Body
description: This course explores the social construction of sexuality and the body from a feminist perspective. It investigates various aspects of sexuality and gendered bodies including identity, community, and social movements based on intersections of race, gender, sexuality, culture, and nation.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Upper Division Standing or instructor consent.
sustainability: Sustainability Focused - SDG 5: Gender Equality

name: Sociology of Masculinities and Femininities
description: Examination and analysis of social construction of gender through interaction and social institutions. Explores gender-based identities and how intersections of gender, race, class, and sexuality shape men’s and women’s experiences. Examines theories of gender and gender-based social movements.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): SOCI 1.
crosslist: Cross-listed with SOCI 175. Sociology and Interdisciplinary Social Sciences is responsible for scheduling.
sustainability: Sustainability Focused - SDG 5: Gender Equality

name: Individual Studies
description: Individual work on special topics by arrangement.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Minor or emphasis in women’s studies.

name: Women, Gender, and Sexuality in Literature
description: Representations of women, gender, and sexuality in literature, with special attention to the intersecting structures of race, ethnicity, and class.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing.
crosslist: Cross-listed with ENGL 182. English and Comparative Literature is responsible for scheduling.

name: Queer Literary Studies
description: Examination of queerness in literature, history, and culture. Explores queerness as it exists across historical contexts, tracing its manifestations in various literary genres and in other cultural artifacts such as film and television, including the ways gender and sexuality intersect with race, class, and ability, as they relate to identity formation and structures of power.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing.
crosslist: Cross-listed with ENGL 184.  English and Comparative Literature is responsible for scheduling.

name: Feminist Perspectives on Gender and Religion
description: Contemporary feminist theories analyze premises of gender roles in religious cultures and variety of sexual expressions. Course will allow students understand the diversity of religious cultures and communities, in addition to how geographical, political, and social locations, like ethnicity and class affect the gender debate in religious perspectives.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing or instructor consent.
crosslist: Cross-listed with MDES 189. Sociology and Interdisciplinary Social Sciences is responsible for scheduling.
sustainability: Sustainability Focused - SDG 5: Gender Equality

name: Internship
description: On-site experience with community or campus organization or other agency involved with women’s issues. Individual and group advising augments the experiential learning. Repeatable for credit with program coordinator approval.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): WGSS 101 or instructor consent.

name: International Program Studies
description: Study Abroad and Away transfer credit course. Study Abroad and Away provides students the opportunity to study abroad on long term programs (Exchange Programs, CSU International Programs, and International Student Exchange Programs) and short-term programs (Faculty-Led Programs and Summer School Abroad Programs) for academic credit, offering Alternative Break Programs for cultural immersion, and designing other globally focused opportunities. This course is designated as a placeholder course for Study Abroad and Away programs.

name: Principles of Systematics
description: Students gain the understanding and skills needed to taxonomically study biodiversity, including the use of morphological and DNA sequence characters to examine phylogeny, and use of a range of biodiversity research techniques and tools.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): BIOL 115 or BIOL 118 (with a grade of “C” or better), or instructor consent. Must be a declared Biology Major (all).
crosslist: Cross-listed with BIOL 113 / BOT 113 / ENT 113. Biological Sciences is responsible for scheduling.

name: Functional Morphology
description: Develops understanding and skills needed to taxonomically study biodiversity, including the use of morphological and DNA sequence characters to examine phylogeny, and use of a range of biodiversity research techniques and tools.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): BIOL 115 or BIOL 118 (with a grade of “C” or better), or instructor consent. Must be a declared Biology Major (all).
crosslist: Cross-listed with BIOL 114 / BOT 114 / ENT 114. Biological Sciences is responsible for scheduling.

name: Invertebrate Zoology and Natural History
description: The evolution, distribution, structure, natural history and systematics of invertebrates other than insects.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): BIOL 113 (with a grade of “C” or better), or instructor consent. Must be a declared major in Biological Sciences.

name: Vertebrate Evolution and Natural History
description: Origin, evolution, distribution and natural history of the vertebrates. Development, reproductive patterns, anatomy, morphology, behavior, ecology and systematics.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): BIOL 113 (with a grade of “C” or better), or instructor consent. Must be a declared major in Biological Sciences.

name: Biogeography
description: Examination of the patterns of biodiversity over space and through time. Using data and models from a variety of sources including botany, zoology, ecology, evolutionary biology, paleontology, and geology, effects of isolation, elevation, and latitude are examined to understand spatial patterns of biodiversity.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): BIOL 31 or equivalent (with a grade of “C-” or better), or instructor consent. Must be a declared Biology Major (all).
crosslist: Cross-listed with BIOL 143 / BOT 143 / ENT 143. Biological Sciences is responsible for scheduling.
sustainability: Sustainability Related - SDG 15: Life on Land

name: Individual Studies
description: Advanced lab work in special fields. Course is repeatable for credit.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Instructor consent. Must be a declared Biology Major (all).

name: Senior Thesis
description: Advanced laboratory or field research under supervision of faculty member, culminating in a senior thesis.
prereqs: Prerequisite(s): Instructor consent. Must be a declared Biology Major (all).
